column2: J.L. Douglass presided yesterday afternoon at the meeting of the Insurance Men's Cleveland and Hendricks Campaign Club, held at No. 155 Broadway. The large room was packed with officers of companies and clerks, and cheer after cheer went up for the candidates.

In spite of the cold weather yesterday, the Metropolitan and New-York Clubs played the third of their series of games for the local championship. It was a poor contest as regards fielding, and the New-York men won, after five uninteresting innings, by figures of 9 to 7.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 18.--A Portland special says: "Gen. Sam Tappen, ex-State Treasurer of Kansas, was arrested yesterday at Albany, Oregon. He was traveling under the name of Richardson, as a book agent. He will be taken to Kansas as soon as the proper papers arrive. He is charged with forging $19,000 worth of school bonds in December, 1874. He was arrested at Topeka, but escaped the following July and went to South America."

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 18.--The Rev. Dr. William Taylor, Pastor of the Universalist Church here, was stricken with paralysis while attending the play of "Hazel Kirke" at the Griswold Opera House this afternoon. His condition is critical.

It is pleasant to learn that the large salaries once paid to cornet players are tending steadily downward. It is said that men who a year ago refused to play the cornet for less than a prima donna receives for singing are now glad to play for half that sum.

There was considerable excitement in the tea trade yesterday over the announcement that serious charges have been lodged with the Treasury Department against Mr. James R. Davies, Examiner of Teas in the Appraiser's division of the Custom House.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18.--Adjt.-Gen. Drum, in his annual report to the Secretary of War states that the reports of officers detailed to inspect the various militia encampments are generally favorable as to the condition of the militia of the several States, and evidence great zeal on the part of the officers.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Oct. 18.--A shooting affray occurred at Bois d'Arc, 10 miles from here, last night, during which Bart Wilds, a saloon keeper, was shot and instantly killed, Green Deboard seriously shot through the neck, and Elisha Deboard shot through the arm. Two of the parties connected with the shooting have been arrested. The cause of the affray was whisky and an old feud.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 18.--James Wormley, the celebrated hotel proprietor, of Washington, D.C., died at the Massachusetts General Hospital this afternoon of calculus. He had been ill for some time, and yesterday an operation was performed, since which he sank rapidly.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 18.--In a yacht race to-day between the yachts Linda and Maggie May, when off Peter's Beach, about a mile above Atlantic City, the main sheet of the Linda parted and swept the deck of the Maggie May, killing Harvey Carr, proprietor of the Falstaid Hotel in this city, and seriously injuring William Pember and Elliott Repp.

BATAVIA, Ohio, Oct. 18.--At 6 o'clock last evening the middle span of the bridge across the East Fork River, on the Cincinnati Eastern Narrow Gauge Railroad, gave way as the Manchester express train was passing over it. The bridge is 50 feet above the water.

The county officials declare that they do not think any State tax will have to be paid by the county this year. The usual time for receiving notification of the amount of State tax apportioned to this county has expired, and no word has yet been received from Madison concerning the matter.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 18.--A boy of 7 Summers, son of Z.P. Town, of Midway, while playing upon a wagon yesterday threw off the brake and the vehicle ran against a post, pitching the boy out and killing him instantly.

After all delays the new Mackay-Bennett ocean cable found a safe resting place for its American end at 12:30 o'clock yesterday, in the pretty little cottage prepared for its reception on Manhattan Beach, just east of the Oriental Hotel.

PARIS, Oct. 18.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day the Marquis de Roys interpellated the Government in regard to the economic crisis, and demanded the same protection for agriculture as for the manufacturing industry.

Gen. W.H. Parsons is stopping at the Sturtevant House, in this city. Butler's treachery to the labor interests has been exposed by him in a letter, portions of which were published in THE TIMES of yesterday. Gen. Parsons is a gray-mustached man of 60 or thereabout, erect, and vigorous alike in manner and talk.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 19.--A.W. Norton, a railway contractor, wanted in Clearfield County, Penn., was arrested here late last night.

Christian Frederick Borgquist, who plays the double bass in the orchestra of the UnionSquare Theatre, lives at Gravesend, Long Island. Saturdays he sleeps at a friend's in East Tenthstreet, because he cannot get to his home con veniently.
While walking along Elizabeth-street on Saturday Officer Docherty, of the Fourteenth Precinct, came upon a coal-black negro who was butting his woolly head viciously against a tree.

A block of two-story frame buildings on Vernon-avenue, extending from Eighth to Ninth street, Hunter's Point, including five dwellings, two stores, and the house of Hose Company No. 6, of the Long Island City Fire Department, were destroyed by fire last night.

Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday morning the liquor store of ex-Alderman Bernard Goodwin, near the West Twenty-third-street Ferryhouse, was broken into and $30 and some cigars and liquor were stolen. Soon after 6 o'clock Robert Lovett, a hack driver, of West Thirty-third-street, entered the place and treated a friend to drinks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19.--A partial eclipse of the sun was visible here at 4:20 o' clock yesterday afternoon. No extraordinary phenomena in connection with the obscuration are reported.

In August last Emilie Von Derven, of Now-York, was staying at the Summer boarding house kept by Mr. and Mrs. Gustav Wolff at Great Neck. Mrs. Von Derven, who is an attractive-looking young woman, was a great favorite among the boarders.

The championship season of the different baseball associations closed last week, and the Metropolitan Club. of this city, and the Providence nine were declared the victors in their associations. In winning the championship of the American Association the Mets, with one exception, came out ahead in their series with the other 11 clubs.

Park A. Wood, a well-to-do manufacturer of Townville, Penn., came to New-York and put up at the Kenwood House, at Bayard-street and the Bowery. Saturday night he went out to see the sights and drank beer too copiously.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 19.--The Liberals were victorious in the election here and at Antwerp, Ostend, Liege, and 15 other towns. The Clericals succeeded in electing their candidates at Bruges, Nivelles, and 9 other places.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19.--Capt. Alexander Wilson, of the Philadelphia bark Fluorine, arrived in town last evening, from his vessel, which has begun to unload at Greenwich Point, with further information about the finding of Jeannette relics off the coast of Greenland.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 19.--The Rev. Edward Judson, D.d., of New-York, preached before the Faculty and students of Cornell University to-day. The morning sermon was on the "The Shipwreck of Faith," the text being from First Timothy, i., 19. The attendance was not as large as usual owing to the cold, threatening weather.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19.--A saloon at Richmond and Westmoreland streets was slightly damaged by fire early this morning. Thomas Kennedy, a Scotchman, who was sleeping in the place, was burned to death.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 19.--N.C. Wiley, the Postmaster who so mysteriously disappeared from this place two or three weeks ago, returned last night. He had, in a semi-conscious state, wandered off. When his mind became clear again he found himself in Omaha, Neb.

Late on Saturday night a man, apparently about 70 years of age, fell dead in front of No. 60 East Broadway. He was found by John Hall, of No. 30 Cherry-street, who removed the body to a drug store close by.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19.--Herman Kolb, a middle-aged German, was discharged to-day from the convalescent ward of the Homeopathic Hospital. During the night weeks he has been under medical and surgical treatment no less than five ordinary round-headed steel pins have been removed from his body by surgical operations.

An important addition to the hotels of New-York is the Murray Hill Hotel, at Parkavenue and Forty-first-street. It is now open for the reception of guests. It has a frontage of 200 feet on Park-avenue, 230 feet on Fortieth, and 130 on Forty-first street.

Joseph McFlynn, of No. 59 East Nineteenth-street, was held in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday for trial for snatching Eliza A. Snyder's sachel from her as she was passing through Second-avenue, near Twenty-ninthstreet, on Saturday.

The single feature of interest in last evening's programme at the Casino was the playing of M.Ovide Musin. M.Musin, whose violin performances last season have doubtless not been forgotten, made his reappearance yesterday, and was the recipient of a very cordial greeting.

VALPARAISO, Oct. 19, via Galveston.-- The steamer Cordillera, which was stranded in the straits, will probably be got off. Three feet of water has already been pumped out, and the openings in the keel have been stopped. Three hundred tons of undamaged cargo have been saved.
LONDON, Oct. 19.--Dongola advices report that a native contractor is supplying the forces there with daily rations for 3,000 men, thus greatly relieving the pressure upon the commissary department.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19.--The war between the Pennsylvania and Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Companies is a more serious matter than would be generally supposed. So far there has not been such a violent row as was always kicked up before when these railroads fell out.

A beautiful chapel, 60 by 60 feet, for the New-York Foundling Asylum, at Sixty-eighthstreet and Lexington-avenue, has just been completed. The general entrance to the chapel is at the south end, and the altar, of pure white marble, stands on a semicircle at the north end. Over the entrance is the choir gallery, and over this is a large circular window.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 19.--A woodchuck had its burrow in an elevated piece of ground at the edge of a field of buckwheat stubble along the public road between Monticello and Thompsonville, in Sullivan County. It had been seen occasionally playing in the stubble.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 19.--Mrs. Mary Blackburn Morris, wife of the late Judge Buckner Morris, of Chicago, and the sister of ex-Gov. Luke P. Blackburn and Senator J.C.S. Blackburn, died at the Blackburn Sanitarium yesterday after a long and painful illness.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19.--Frederick P. Nash, of Mystic Bridge, Coun., who was shot by Daniel E. Stanton, of the same town, last Thursday night, died at the Germantown Hospital this afternoon. The cause of the shooting remains a mystery.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 19.--A special to the Post, from Sistersville, West Va., says: "Intelligence has been received here from Middlebourne, Tyler County, to the effect that the boiler of Isaac Wehrmaur's saw mill, on Ten-mile Creek, exploded yesterday morning.

WASHINTON, Penn., Oct. 19.--A freight and a passenger train on the Pittsburg Division of the Baltimore and Ohio Road ran into each other at Crouche's last night, delaying the trains several hours. Both engines were wrecked and the passengers considerably shaken up, but fortunately no one was seriously injured.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 19.--Rumors that H. Fraser Grant, one of the largest naval stores and rice factors in the State, has fled from the city, leaving liabilities estimated anywhere between $25,000 and $100,000, caused an unusual flutter in business circles to-day.

The Guion steamship Alaska, arrived yesterday from Liverpool, after another very quick passage. She left Queenstown at 9:30 A. M. on Oct. 12, and anchored off the bar at 3:40 yesterday morning. Her corrected time was 6 days 22 hours and 32 minutes.

Here is a little pamphlet presenting a very plausible account of the chance beginning of an organization which afterward achieved great renown and greater infamy in most of the Southern States. Its writers are inhabitants of Pulaski, Tenn., where the secret society had its birth.

PARIS, Oct. 19.--M.Sardou read yesterday his new drama, "Theodore," to the artists of the Porte St. Martin Theatre. According to a critical forecast it is his finest work. The drama opens to Mme. Bernhardt a chance for her greatest creation. Bernhardt was ill and unable to be present at the reading.
ORILLIA, Ontario, Oct. 19.--Albert Davey has been arrested here on suspicion of having murdered his wife, who suddenly disappeared on Thursday.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 19.--Col. Plympton, Butler's political manager, arrived here today. He says that Butler has canceled all his Ohio dates "on account of legal engagements in Boston." He will speak in this State after Tuesday of this week until Monday, when he will begin his final trip through New-York State.

The friends of William B. Fitch, the candidate for Presidential Elector on the Democratic ticket who was shot on Broadway in broad daylight Friday, are exceedingly anxious to have the circumstances kept from the police and from the public.

Dullness in trade was the general complaint made by the delegates at the meeting of the Central Labor Union yesterday. The bricklayers, cigarmakers, printers, machinists, trunkmakers, and knifecutters all reported that trade was dull.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Oct. 19.--A riot occurred late last night among a number of colored men at a festival at the African Methodist Episconal Zion Church. Several shots were fired and several of the men wounded. One of them will probably die. No arrests have yet been made.

A preliminary injunction preventing the extension of the bridge to the west side of Centre-street was served upon the Bridge Trustees Saturday afternoon, upon papers issued by Judge Allen, in the Court of Common Pleas.

The fruit supply for this market seems to be almost unlimited this season. Every steamboat, almost every transatlantic steamship, all the West India and Southern steamers, and nearly every freight train that now reaches New-York bring a supply of fruit to our market.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Oct. 19.--Gen. Samuel Lappin, ex-State Treasurer of Kansas, was arrested at Albany, this State, yesterday. He was traveling as a book agent under the name of Richardson. In 1874 he was charged with forging $19,000 of school bonds, was arrested and confined in jail at Topeka, but escaped and fled to South America, and had not been heard of since until his arrest.

The new building of the Progress Club, at Nos. 110 and 112 East Fifty-ninth-street, was opened on Saturday amid festivity and rejoicing. It is a handsome four-story basement building, in the Moorish style of architecture.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--The Democratic Congressional Committee of the First District of Illinois have nominated William L. Tilden for Congress, the Congressional Convention having placed the matter in their hands.
William Roche, of No. 408 Water-street, has been on the Island five times for beating his mother, who is 70 years old. He went home Saturday night and demanded some money of her.

GALVESTON, Oct. 19.--The iron steamship Atachia, of the Atachia Steamship Line, of Sunderland, England, plying between Galveston and Liverpool, was discovered to be on fire this afternoon while lying in the harbor.

The annual meeting of the Society of St. Luke's Hospital was held on Saturday in the hospital. The business was confined to receiving the report of the Board of Managers and the election of managers for the ensuing year. NEWARK, Oct. 19.--Anna Theresa mayer, 10 years old, died at her home, No.13 Ashland street, to-night, from the effects of burns received by her clothing taking fire at a bonfire last night. She was endeavoring to induce her younger brother to go home when she received the injuries from which she died.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--The Fall meeting of the National Jockey Club will begin on Tuesday at the Ivy City track and continue four days. The track is being thoroughly worked and sprinkled, and will be in fine condition when the sport begins. There will be five races each day. On Tuesday the first event will be a dash of six furlongs, followed by a mile selling race.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 19.--Owing to the reduction of wages at South Tredegar Nail Works all nailers and laborers in that department refuse to go to work, throwing out of employment about 350 men. Employes in the rolling mill department of the works accepted the reduction and continue. The mills will shut down for the present.

Anthony O'Donnell, who described himself as an Irish orator, artist, and scholar, stood at the bar of the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning, charged with being drunk and collecting a crowd around the steps of St.Gabriel's Church, where he was trying to preach an impromptu sermon.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19.--Several warehouses and the German Theatre, situated in the centre of the town, are on fire. It is likely that the flames will spread to the surrounding buildings.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 19.--The Enterprise factory, which has been shut down for six weeks, will begin running on full time to-morrow. The Augusta, and the King mills are running on full time.

The friends of Counselor George N. Barron, who is accused of abusing his trust, while serving as executor of the estate of John Faulkner, say that he is away from Jersey City on a hunting expedition, and that when he returns he will make a satisfactory explanation of all the heirs allege against him.

The opening services of the semicentennial celebration of the Sixteenth Baptist Church were begun yesterday in the church edifice in West Sixteenth-street, near Eighth-avenue. Every seat on the main floor was occupied, the entire congregation numbering over 700 persons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--About three years ago a well-known young Chicagoan went to Boston and returned in a few weeks, bringing with him a fair-haired, pretty wife, who belonged to one of the Hub's best families.

When Mrs.Belva A.Lockwood, the candidate for the Presidency of the National Equa1 Rights Party, trotted onto the stage at the Academy of Music last night there were 34 men and women in the orchestra choirs, a score in the proscenium boxes, and 900 or 1,000 in the top gallery.

The work of the Church Temperance Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this country during the past year was the subject of an address by Mr.Robert Graham, in Christ Church, Brooklyn, yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 19.--Fire broke out in the Winter quarters of Barnum's "Greatest Show on Earth" late this evening. By prompt exertions the flames were soon got under control, without having done any very great damage.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--James D. Paddock, alias "Dave Parker," one of the most expert cracksmen in the country, was released from Joliet yesterday. A sentence of eight years for a burglary committed at Rock Island has just expired.
At a meeting of Typographical Union, No. 6, in Clarendon Hall, yesterday afternoon, an address was adopted and signed by more than 500 members of the union.

The funeral of the late David C. Anderson, the veteran actor, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Chrysostom's Chapel, at Thirtyninth-street and Seventh-avenue. The body lay in a plain coffin, covered with black cloth and bearing the name and age of the dead man on the plate.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19.--Satisfactory arrangements have been made by John T. Davies, of the firm of Davies Atkinson, by which the attachments against the firm's property have been released, and the packing house will be opened tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--The leave of absence of Lieut. F.S. Calhoun, of the Fourteenth Infantry, has been extended two months. Leave of absence has been granted Second Lieut. J.N. Glass, Sixth Cavalry, for three months. The leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate of disability of First Lieut. G.K. Spencer, Nineteenth Infantry, has been extended six months.

It is very sad to learn that the entire North Atlantic fleet is in such a condition that it must seek safety and rapairs in the Brooklyn Navy Yard before the end of the first week in November. This is extremely discouraging to Mr.CHANDLER.

Extensive arrangements for Tammany's ratification meeting and parade to-morrow night are being made. The big meeting will be in the wigwam, and stands for two overflow meetings will be erected in front of the building in Fourteenthsreet.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 19.--In his sermon to-night on political parties and political duties, the Rev. George Hepworth, Pastor of the Belleville-Avenue Congregational Church, denounced the Republican Party and its nominees in strong terms, claiming that they were not entitled to the support of the moral portion of the community. Mr. Hepworth has heretofore been a strong Republican.
The members of the Grand Army of the Republic and of other veteran organizations of this city gave a clam chowder yesterday afternoon to several officers who fought in the Confederate Army.

CARTHAGE, N.Y., Oct. 20.--Fire was discovered at 10:30 this morning in the Eaton sash and door factory, in West Carthage. The wind, which was southeast, was blowing a gale at the time, and the flames quickly communicated to the furniture factory of Myers Ross.

MERIDEN, Conn., Oct. 20.--Albert G. Pratt, aged 45 years, a carriage painter, has just recovered from an attack of hiccough that lasted 12 days and 9 hours without intermission, during which time he hiccoughed at every respiration. Medical men say nine days continuous hiccough have heretofore proved fatal.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Oct. 20.--An explosion occurred this morning at the Chemung Canal Bank, creating for a time great excitement. The gas had evidently been left turned on in the vault since Saturday night and had smothered itself out.

William Ryan, an athletic looking young man, 23 years old, was lying in bed yesterday at his mother's house, No. 2 Jersey-street, NewBrighton, Staten Island. The young man's head was covered with cloths and bandages.

CONNELLSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 20.--This morning when Rice Orbin came down to breakfast at his parents' home in Bradford he exclaimed in frightened tones: "I had a terrible dream last night. I dreamed that I shot a man while out hunting last Thursday."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--Commissary-General MacFeely has submitted to the Secretary of War his report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1884. The report shows that the aggregate resources for the year were $4,258,481 and the total expenditures $3,217,224, leaving a balance of $1,041,257. The New-York Tribune makes merry over the Hocking Valley. It intimates that the Hocking region failed to give Mr. Blaine "a piece of its mind." Wait a while. The vote on President will not be cast till November. In the meantime it is well to remember that Hocking County gave a Democratic gain of 214 last Tuesday. There was also a Democratic gain in Perry County.

The failure of the Chinese loan is announced to be "complete," but the facts do not seem to bear out the characterization. The loan was for $3,000,000. One million six hundred thousand dollars of this amount was bid for at par and $500,000 at 4 per cent. less than par.
"Nita's First" is drawing large audiences at Wallack's. Miss Helen Russell still plays the part of Mrs. Fred Fizzleton, Miss Robe not having sufficiently recovered to return to the stage.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 20.--Eugene Kelly Co., bankers, of New-York, have, through their attorneys in this city, attached real estate owned here by Benjamin Richardson, of New-York, which was given by the latter as security on two promissory notes for $175,000.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 20.--A dispatch to the Courier-Journal, from Shelbyville, this State, reports the killing of Elijah Kirk by Robert Clark near there. Kirk accused Clark if circulating evil reports about his daughter, and threatened to kill him.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20.--While putting a head gate in the canal back of the Colburn factories at Ansonia the cofferdam was undermined at 8 o'clock to-night, and the whole body of water stored to furnish power for Ansonia's many manufactories swept over the town.

BUFFALO, Oct. 20.--Something of a stir was made in political circles to-day by the exposure of an alleged attempt to bribe an Irish Democratic orator to come out for Blaine. The Courier this morning gave editorial prominence to a statement of the case.

BERNE, Oct. 20.--The Grand Hotel at Latuerbrunnen was burned to-day. The damage is placed at $1,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 20.--The failure of A.W. Bowman, capitalist and real estate broker, which was announced last Thursday, will prove much more serious than at first supposed.

PARIS, Oct. 20.--Mr. Fearn, agent of the New-Orleans Cotton Exposition and World's Fair, has had an interview with President Grevy and Prime Minister Ferry. He solicited that France should take a larger part in the exhibition.

A number of jewelers who were watching the contingent of the tradesmen who had joined in the Blaine demonstration and parade yesterday afternoon decided at once to organize a Cleveland and Hendricks Club made up of jewelers.

BRUSSELS, Oct. 20.--The election at Malines yesterday was attended with great disorder. The civic guard was called out and placed under arms to quell the disturbance. The mob smashed the windows of one convent. Seventeen of the rioters were arrested. The Liberals, in view of their success, demand that the Chamber shall be dissolved and the Government resign. The Clericals, however, claim that little change has been made in the relative positions of the parties.

ALBANY, Oct. 20.--The Democrats to-day nominated Frank Frickleton for Assembly in the Second District and Patrick Murray in the Third District of Albany County.

Mr. Oliver Doud Byron appeared at the Grand Opera House last evening in "Across the Continent. This play was constructed in the early days of the Pacific Railroad, when the vast Western country had just been brought within a few days' ride from the Atlantic coast, and it was one of many built upon the same lines, introducing about the same sort of characters and betraying about the same measure of literary skill.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 20.--Two dozen workingmen and THE TIMES'S correspondent held a large and enthusiastic Butler meeting here tonight. Twenty-four of those present wore spoons. Before the meeting was called to order the members sat and talked, and chewed tobacco.
Moscow, Oct. 20.--The German Theatre and 76 shops were destroyed by the fire here last night. The damage is estimated at 3,000,000 rubles.

Wall-street was again crowded with people yesterday afternoon, the occasion being the business men's meeting to ratify the nominations of Blaine and Logan. A large stand, heavily draped with the American colors, was erected on the southwest corner of the steps of the Sub-Treasury building.

Three or four policemen were called to quell a row that occurred at Sixty-ninth-street and the Eastern Boulevard on the night of April 19 last. In the course of the trouble three or four pistol shots were fired.

BERLIN, Oct. 20.--Baron Seydewitz has taken possession, in behalf of the Emperor of all the feudal and allodial property of the late Duke of Brunswick. It is stated that the Duke left a will disposing of his private property, which is estimated to have amounted to 50,000,000 marks.

The Republicans of the Fourteenth Congressional District, comprising three Assembly districts of Westchester County, and the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards of this city, held a convention at White Plains, yesterday, for the purpose of nominating a candidate for Congress.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 20.--In the United States court to-day the attorneys for the defense in the libel suit of Blaine against the Indianapolis Sentinel Company had a writ of subpoena in chancery issued for personal service on Mr. Blaine to-morrow, ordering him to appear in court on the 23d of next December, and answer interrogatories filed with the Sentinel's last bill of discovery in the case.

ALBANY, Oct. 20.--Intense excitement was caused this morning by the report that Gov. Cleveland had been assaulted on the street while on his way to the Capitol. About 9 o'clock, as his usual custom, he was walking through Eagle-street from the Executive Mansion to his office.

LONDON, Oct. 20.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the English grain trade says: "The weather during the past week has been fine and warmer. English wheat is in little demand, except for fine parcels. The sales during the week were 78,412 quarters at 32s. 4d., against 65,388 quarters at 42s. 5d. for the corresponding week last year.

J., Oct. 20.--In the Mercer County Court to-day Prosecutor of the Peace Beasley announced that he had three indictments against the Trenton and Allentown, the Hopewell and Ewing, and the Crosswicks and Trenton Turnpike Companies, which would be cited by summons to appear and answer on Friday next, being corporations.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 20.--Hugh O'Neil, of Mechanicsville, N. Y., has been brought to this place by Sheriff Van Hoesen on an indictment for arson. Mr. O'Neil lived here for a number of years previous to his departure under suspicious circumstances last February.

LOCKPORT, N. Y., Oct. 20.--The Lockport Banking Association, a private banking firm of this city of many years' standing, suspended payment this morning, causing considerable excitement among business men here, as this is the first bank failure here in over 15 years.

PARIS, Oct. 20.--It is reported that the Chinese have made an attack on Thai Nguyen, in upper Tonquin, and been repulsed with heavy loss.

When the engagement of Mile. Janisch at the New Park Theatre was brought to an abrupt conclusion recently, owing to her illness, Miss Mary Shaw, one of the ladies of the company, removed her wardrobe from the theatre to the boarding house No. 24 East Twentiethstreet.

DUBLIN, Oct. 20.--At the meeting of Nationalists and others yesterday expressions of condolence with Mr. A.M. Sullivan's family were made. Masses were celebrated and prayers were offered for the ropose of his soul in most of the Catholic churches.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 20.--E.J. Ohl, the Postmaster at Mineral Ridge, Stark County, was arrested and brought to Cleveland this morning by Post Office Inspector S.E. Fink. He was charged with embezzling $600 from the United States. Ohl runs a drug store at Mineral Ridge in connection with his Post Office business, and for some time the authorities have suspected a leakage at the Post Office.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20.--Among those who know anything about the work done by the Blaineites in the recent Ohio campaign, Commissioner Dudley's denial that the Pension Bureau was prostituted to party use is ranked as a good imitation of some of the denials his political master has felt called upon to issue so often since he opened his "aggressive" campaign.

CAIRO, Oct. 20.--Advices from Dongola state that contrary winds are interfering with the passage of boats up the Nile.

ALBANY, Oct. 20.--A. number of prominent Republicans not identified with either the Burlingame or Fitts committees have proposed a scheme of arbitration of the differences existing among the Republicans in the county which they consider entirely fair, and they call upon the committees to adopt it.

Republican Congressional Conventions were to have been held in all the districts last night, but in only three were nominations made. In the Sixth District, Assemblyman Frederick B. House was chosen without opposition. Mr. House is a lawyer, 27 years old, and has served two terms in the Legislature.

The names of over 50 Republican and independent voters of Plainfield, N.J., were signed at a meeting held in that place on Saturday evening to an address urging upon voters the necessity of using every influence to defeat James G. Blaine for the Presidency. None of the signers are members of the Democratic Party.

Lower Broadway from Wall-street to the Battery was in a blaze of glory last night. What resident Republicans jubilantly termed the "first successful Republican mass meeting ever held in the First Ward" was in full blast, and its participants seemed to be enjoying themselves to the top of their bent.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 20.--The stock. holders of the Pittsburg and Western Railroad Company met here to-day and ratified the lease of the Pittsburg, Cleveland and Toledo Railroad. About two-thirds of the stock was represented.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 20.--Ben Hop Lee, formerly of Canton, China, applied to Clerk Bill, of the United States court, this morning, for first papers of citizenship. Ben Hop Lee is a smart, looking, well-dressed Mongolian.

LONDON, Oct. 20.--The Queen's speech, to be read at the opening of Parliament, has received the sanction of the Council at Balmoral. It is brief and refers to no home measure except the Franchise bill. Vague allusions are made to the settlement of the Egyptian question, the Nile expedition, and South African affairs.

NORTHFIELD, Mass., Oct. 20.--A brilliant rally for Cleveland and Hendricks was held at this place, which is the home of Evangelist Moody, to-night. An address was delivered by A.P. Child's, of Springfield, Mass. A large delegation, headed by the First Vermont Regiment Band, was present from Windham, Cheshire, and Franklin Counties, Vt., Brattleborough sending a special train. There was much enthusiasm. A rally will be held at Keene on Weddesday evening.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 20.--A special to the Ithaca Journal from Groton, in this county, says that Artemas Backus died suddenly of heart disease this morning, while on his way to visit his brother George, who was dying with lockjaw. The brother died a few minutes after Artemas breathed his last.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20.--A special agent of the United States Government arrived in the city this evening for the purpose of still further investigating an alleged fraud in connection with the erection of the new Post Office at Ninth and Chestnut streets.

The Tenement House Commission met yesterday afternoon at Sanitary Headquarters. There were present Chairman Wingate, Building Inspector W.P. Esterbrook, Prof. Felix Adler, Anton Reichardt, and Secretary Moreau Morris, Chief of the First Sanitary Division.

ITHACA N.Y., Oct. 20.--As the political campaign nears its close both parties in this part of the State are holding two or three meetings a week. Gantz, Jones Co.'s drug warehouse, at No. 176 Duane-street, was destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. The building was five stories high, and belonged to the Lorillard estate. WASHINGTON, Oct. 21.--Paymaster--General Rochester, in his annual report to the Secretary of War, says that the total amount available for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1884, was $15,180,161, and that the total amount disbursed was $18,250,750, leaving a balance of $1,929,411.

PARIS, Oct. 21.--Chinese advices state that a French corvette has been exchanging shots with the Tai-Wan forts, on the west coast of Formosa. The corvette subjects all approaching steamers to search.

The Brooklyn Democratic City Convention, which met in the Assembly Rooms in that city at 8 o'clock last evening, was in strong contrast to the county convention which had been held in the same place a few hours before. It was not by any means an "open" convention.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21.--The marriage of Miss Lilian Billings, daughter of Mr. John N. Billings, of Chicago, and Mr. Frederick Mann, of Kenwood, both members of the Hanlons' company, took place at 2 o'clock this afternoon at St. Paul's Episcopal Church. Some of the grievances under which Minnie Cummings, the actress, has labored for nearly--three years were recited by her yesterday before Judge Barrett and a jury in the Supreme Court.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 21, via Galveston.-- The Secretary of the Treasury has issued a peremptory order to Customs Collectors at Paso del Norte, Laredo, and Chihuahua to pass without delay all goods shipped in bond for this city or other interior cities. The greatest obstacle to international commerce and through traffic on the Mexican Central Road is thereby removed.

Mrs. Ettie Henderson, the distinguished actress, author of "Almost a Life" and "Claire and the Forge Master," has just finished a new drama entitled "Bound for Ever."

VIROQUA, Wis., Oct. 21--The news that a crazy German farmer named John Huschka, living near here, bad murdered his aged wife and fled to the woods was telegraphed yesterday. Yesterday forenoon he was captured by a farmer and returned to the village.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 21--A petition was submitted to the Board of County Commissioners to-day asking for an increase in the license fee charged retail liquor dealers. It is signed by 61 prominent citizens, the list being headed by the name of President Porter, of Yale College.

Barclay's 4-year-old br. c. Bendigo came in second, and Mr. Mainley's 3-year-old b.c. Pizarro third. There were 18 starters. The trial of Henry Lehr was continued at Paterson yesterday for the murder of Joseph Henry Wilson. Witnesses testified that Lehr struck the boy Wilson several times with his whip, and then shot him, holding the pistol in one hand while he held his mule with the other.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 22.--Edward O. Fitzgerald, Jr., a popular young man of this city, accidentally shot himself in the head today, and may die from the effects of the wound. He was to have been married this evening to Miss Lillie Carrington, daughter of Col. W.C. Carrington, Mayor of this city.

The National steamship America has made her last ocean trip for the present season. During the Winter she will be laid up and her machinery will be overhauled. It is thought in shipping circles that the America is better fitted for Summer use than for Winter. During the past season she made a record second only to that of the Oregon.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22.--News from Southern New-Jersey is to the effect that the forest fires, after having burned many miles of fine timber, a church, and several dwelling houses, are now on the wane and apparently under control. The damage is estimated at $150,000.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 18.--Very few persons ever stop to think about it, but the fact is that Allegheny County and Philadelphia County, which include the cities of Pittsburg and Philadelphia, furnish the Republican Party and candidates with the Republican majorities for which the Keystone State has been "good" for many consecutives Presidential contests.
ALBANY., Oct. 23.--The Executive Chamber was thronged with visitors to-day. The Governor was very busy with routine work, but shook hands with several hundred persons.

A workingmen's mass meeting, under the auspices of the Central Labor Union, was held last evening at Irving Hall, John Swinton was the first speaker. He expressed astonishment at the wonderful growth of the idea upon which the Central Labor Union had been founded--a union of ideas and unions.

On the steps of the Parker House, last evening, stood a farmer-like man of about 55 years, wearing a white beard, cropped quite close. He said: "I hev bet a berril of apples that Cleveland 'll be 'lected, and the loser hez got to wheel that berril of apples from Keene to Walpole, N.H., 16 miles. But I shell not bev to du the wheelin'. you bet."

PETERSBURG, Va., Oct. 23.--The first rain that has fallen in this section for more than eight weeks fell last night. It extended along the Norfolk and Western Railroad as far as Lynchburg, and along the Atlantic coast line as far south as Weldon. Rain is still badly needed thoughout the south side of Virginia. The creeks and smaller streams have dried up, and on their beds are to be found many skeletons of fish.

A Lewiston man, Mr. F.A. Herring, is looking daily for an earthquake. He expects it within a few days, but would not be disappointed if it did not occur for a year or two. The earth quake is to occur in New-Madrid, in Missouri.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 23.--The Democratic Congressional Convention of the Twentyfourth District to-day nominated John L. Pindar, of Schoharie, on the one hundred and fourth ballot.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 23.--The National Wrought Iron Pipe Pool, which was formed here last December, was dissolved to-day because of a disagreement over the division of the profits. "Is this what they call a non-sporting dog show? why, bless my heart, do you know I thought non-sporting dogs were all little household pets. And most of the dogs here are big ones! VALPARAISO, Oct. 23, via Galveston.--The remains of Rear-Admiral Luis A. Lynch, not those of his brother, Vice-Admiral Patricio Lynch, arrived here from England recently in the war ship Esmeralda. A dispatch from Rio de Janeiro, dated yesterday, states that ViceAdmiral Lynch has left that city for Europe on the steamer Britannia to assume his duties as Chilian Minister to Spain.

Peter M. Sherwood, a machinist and inventor, committed suicide last evening at his home, No. 660 Monroe-street, Brooklyn, by shooting himself through the head. Mr. Sherwood lost his wife some time ago, and since her death he had been in a very despondent frame of mind.

PORT AU PRINCE, Oct. 10.--The Government has proposed to the representatives of the foreign powers here a scheme for paying in six years the claims against Hayti for losses sustained by foreign residents during the uprising under Gen. Boyer-Bazelais in September, 1883, in the event of a refusal of this proposition it is rumored that another loan of $2,000,000, paper money, will be negotiated for the purpose of settling these claims at once.
The new Hebrew Orphan Asylum at Tenth-avenue and One Hundred and Thirtysixth-street was yesterday formally presented to the city and religiously dedicated to the purposes for which it was built.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 23.--East Pennsylvania Eldership of the Church of God is now holding its annual session in this city.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 23.--The North Reformed Church, of West Troy, has extended a call to the Rev. Dr. John W. Beardslee, of Constantine, Mich. It is thought that he will accept.

MONTREAL, Oct. 23.--A collision occurred at Pointe Claire, a station on the Grand Trunk Railway, about 20 miles from here, early this morning, resulting in the instant death of an engineer and the badly wounding of a fireman.

The Grand Opera House at Newark was packed to the trussed rafters of its arched roof last night when the State and County Committees of Republicans opposed to Mr. Blaine held a mass meeting. Every seat in the house was occupied and all the available standing room was packed.

Counties where there has been no local option on the liquor question are now giving notice that such bills will be applied for at the next session of the General Assembly. We will publish a notice to that effect for Habersham County next week. We hope, however, that a general option law may be passed, but if not let us have the local option.
DUBLIN, Oct. 23.--The Mail regards the removal of Mr. Trevelyan as an evidence of the conclusion of another "Kilmainham treaty" between Mr. Gladstone and Mr. Parnell.

MONTREAL, Oct. 23.--A private detective has made certain discoveries regarding the recent explosions in the new Parliamentary buildings which tend to show that the occurrence was the result of local work, and disproves entirely the theory that the explosion was caused by O'Donnovan Rossa or other Fenian agency. The detective's statement on oath is to be laid before the Provincial Government.

The funeral of the late Police Commissioner Sydney P. Nichols took place at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning at St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, Fourth-avenue and Twenty-second-street. Long before the hour appointed for the services people began to gather in the streets in the neighborhood.

The regulations of the city of Elmira, were approved by the New-York Civil Service Commission yesterday. In general the principles are the same as those presented by Mayor Edson, of New-York, and Mayor Low, of Brooklyn. The commission subsequently visited the Academy of Medicine, where an examination for physicians in the various asylums was in progress. There were 15 candidates and the examination was a rigid one. The commission will meet again on Nov. 10.

LONDON, Oct. 23.--Mr. Abbey has signed a contract with Mary Anderson to become her manager during her American tour. He has also engaged Mme. Modjeska to play for several weeks at the Lyceum Theatre, commencing in March next.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 23.--Frank Patterson, the theatrical manager of Asbury Park, was arraigned to-day before Judges Scudder, Walling, and Bennett upon indictments charging him with having forged indorsements to notes aggregating $36,000. There were 34 indictments against him. He entered a plea of not guilty in each case and was released on giving bonds for $10,200. His first trial will begin on Nov. 17.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 23.--When the Faculty and students at the institute met in the chapel for prayers this morning it was discovered that a horse, the property of Prof. M.P. Higgins, occupied one of the pews.

A large portrait of James G. Blaine, draped in the American colors, hung from the centre of the stage of the Academy of Music in Brooklyn last evening, which was crowded by an enthusiastic mass meeting under the auspices of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club.

Some sixty Republicans in Utica, representing those who have been known as the Conkling stalwarts, have put their names to an address to their fellow-Republicans setting forth what they characterize as the "unanswerable objections to Mr. BLAINE as a candidate for the Presidency."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23.--The session of the Masonic Grand Lodge of Ohio closed here today. Among the resolutions adopted was one declaring it to be the opinion of the body that the selling of intoxicating drinks is a Masonic offense, and should disqualify any one from initiation into or affiliation with any Masonic lodge.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 23.--The Prohibitionists of Rockland County had a lively convention in Nyack this afternoon. Various portions of the county were represented. The convection was called to order by George F. Morse, of Nyack, and the Rev. George H. Hicks, of Monsey was elected Chairman.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 23.--The tusks, ribs, and part of the vertebral column of a mastodon were found to-day on the Andrews farm, near Monroe.
ATOKA, Indian Territory, Oct. 23.--The boilers at B. Seattches Co's saw mill exploded this morning, killing three men--J.B. Oliver and Frank Choate, of this place and John Radcliffe, of Clayton, Ill.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23.--At a late hour last night William N. Hirst, Democratic candidate for City Controller, withdrew from the ticket in a letter to the Democratic Executive Committee. Mr. Hirst is at present the Controller, and was nominated to succeed himself.

The janitor of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church evidently had forgotten that the Board of Trustees were to meet in the church last night, for when seven members of the board arrived they found that the doors were locked and the whole church was in an alarming state of darkness.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 23.--The trial of Dr. Ira Butler, alias Richmond, for the murder of Lizzie Coon by criminal malpractice, was commenced in the court here to-day and creates considerable interest. SHAMOKIN, Penn., Oct. 23.--The Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company's Bear Valley shatt was found to be on fire this morning. The vein is perpendicular, and it is impossible to reach the fire. The mine will probably have to be flooded.

HORNELLSVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 21.--Dr. James Faulkner, one of the most remarkable men in New-York State, if not in this country, died in Dansville, Livingston County, on Sunday last. Dr. Faulkner would have been 95 years old on Jan. 21, 1885.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23.--It is stated that the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company, whose lines now enter California, intends resisting the authority of the State Railroad Commission and attacking its constitutionality in the courts.

It will be a nice problem for the statisticians presently to determine what the latest visitasion of the cholera in Europe has cost. A week or two ago it was calculated that the quarantine had already resulted in a loss of 1,600,000 to the Italian revenue, and now the Spaniards have begun counting their bill of costs.

READING, Penn., Oct. 23.--A breeze of more than ordinary dimensions has been created by a suit and counter suit between Aaron Smith, proprietor of: "Our Healthful Home," on the outskirts of this city, and Dr. Robert Walter, owner of "Walter's Mountain Park." near Wernersville.
Among the attractions of the dog show is a genuine St. Bernard dog who is credited with having saved twenty-six lives in the Alpine snow.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 3.--Heavy wind and snow storms are reported this morning from Lake Huron and Lake Michigan ports. There is a jam at St. Clair Flats, and 46 vessels are detained. All passage between Lake Erie and Lake Huron is thus blockaded.

Among the passengers of the White Star steamship Celtic, which sailed yesterday for Liverpool, were the Hon. Horace C. Plunkitt and the Hon. A.C. Roche. Among those who left for Glasgow on the State of Nebraska, of the State Line, were Fourth Officer J. Long, of the lost steamship State of Florida, and Capt. Theodore H. Tebbs.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 23, via Galveston.-- The Senate has approved the preliminaries for a renewal of diplomatic relations with England. The question of the English debt has been referred to a committee of the House.

ROME, Oct. 23.--During the past 24 hours there were 16 fresh cases of cholera at Naples and 1 death. At Genoa no new cases or deaths were reported.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 23.--A slight snow squall prevailed here to-day and the weather was extremely cold.
The recent election in which Gen. Robinson was chosen Secretary of State of Ohio was held on his fifty-seventh birthday.

WATERBURY, Conn., Oct. 24.--For two days the people of Waterbury have stopped stirring in the political caldron, and have devoted themselves with much spirit, unbounded hospitality, and universal interest to unveiling a monument to the memory of the brave men who laid down their lives in order that the Union might live.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 24.--The widow of Ezra C. Reed, of Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, late master of the bark Brazil, has been presented with a gold watch which was to have been given to her late husband by the Marine Department. The watch was received through the GovernorGeneral from the President of the United States. Capt. Reed rendered valuable service to the American schooner Nellie Bell.

The Bureau of Statistics at Washington has put out an elaborate statement--a part of the annual report--which, whatever the intention may have been, will be used extensively in the few remaining days of the canvass as a campaign document. It contains a general comparison of the volume of internal and foreign ...

The other day a young man who was on the eve of marriage and was packing his trunk with a view to his wedding trip was accidentally killed by the explosion of his pistol as he was putting it in his trunk. This incident has been generally called a melancholy occurrence, and the young man has been severely criticised for turning his attention to pistols just before the time fixed for his marriage.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 24.--Advices from the Northwest report that a half breed horse dealer has been murdered by a party of Blood Indians, who also stole 11 horses. A party of mounted police, on hearing the report, started from Fort McLeod for the Blood reserve, where the ringleader of the murdering party was captured and taken to the fort. The horses were recovered.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24.--The Western Export Association met here to-day, and a liberal percentage of the distilleries west of the Ohio River were represented. The most important work of the meeting was a further reduction of capacity. The distilleries are and have been running only ...

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 24.--When the St. Louis Express, which arrived in Syracuse this morning, was about 30 miles below Poughkeepsie, last night, running at a high rate of speed, the passengers felt a shock, accompanied by a dull sound.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 24.--Until within 20 minutes of the close the oil market was as dull and uneventful as it very well could be. The events of the last 20 minutes, however, will render the day long memorable.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 24.--Charles W. Baker, of Bradford, Penn., charged with defrauding numerous pensioners in various parts of the State by representing himself as a United States Pension Agent, was to-day convicted and sentenced to five years' imprisonment in the Western Penitentiary.

The trial of Policeman Richard Walsh, for the killing of Marino, the Spanish sailor, near the ferry at Hunter's Point, on Sept. 4, was continued yesterday in the Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer.

UTICA, Oct. 24.--The signatures to the Utica stalwarts' address published in THE TIMES this morning have increased to 150, and more are looked for. The open movement of the stalwarts has been the talk of the town to-day, and has led to several bitter word encounters.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--Early this evening, while James L. Clayton, aged 18, was visiting his friend, John S. Baker, aged 17, at the latter's home, near 17th and Brown streets, Baker's parents left them alone in the dining room, his father going out to a store, ...

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 24.--Miss Ella Reed, living at Shenandoah, committed suicide by hanging herself in the attic of her mother's house last night. The reason for her rash act is assigned to be melancholy, brought on by un unfortunate love affair.

The Corporation Counsel has been asked to give an opinion, so that the Police Commissioners may act in the matter of the appointment of a Police Captain in the place of Edward Tynan.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 24.--The steamboat Henry Frank, hence last evening for Memphis, was burned to the water's edge last night near the Davis crevasse. The boat and cargo are a total loss. No lives were lost. The Frank was owned by Capt. Frank Hicks and Alfred Grierson. It was valued at $40,000, and was insured in Cincinnati and Louisville for $35,000.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, Oct. 24.--The State Supreme Court to-day rendered an opinion on one of the sections of the State prohibitory law, the effect of which is that Justices of the Peace have jurisdiction to try certain cases under it where the fine is $100 or less.
Three years ago Prof. A.J. Birmingham, of New-York City, while on a professional visit to Princeton, N.J., became acquainted with Miss Katie A. Fennin, daughter of a prominent gentleman of that city.

Italian economists are beginning to feel anxious about the rapid increase in the number of illegitimate births registered in that country. It has indeed risen by some 20,000 in the last 10 years, but the returns show that the births are very unevenly distributed.

The mass meeting of the independent Republicans at Patterson last night was a great success, the attendance far exceeding the capacity of the Hall. Mr. William Talcott, of Passaic, President of the club, made the opening address. He was followed by the Hon. Carl Schurz, who, in the course of his remarks, compared the tariff issue now put forward to a fig leaf used to cover the crookedness of the Republican Party.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 24.--The State Executive Committee of the Prohibition Party met here to-day and decided upon a plan for the thorough canvass of the State. The Rev. J.H. Gambrell, of Brookhaven, was appointed Corresponding and Financial Secretary.

BOSTON, Oct. 24.--The case of Georgina Heustis, charged with appropriating $20,000 worth of diamonds belonging to Teresa Lynch, of New-York, is still under consideration by the Governor, and as District Attorney Olney, of New-York, who wished for time for further investigation, has not been heard from, his decision will not be announced at present.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 286--Board of County Commissioners of Labette County, Kansas, et al, plaintiffs in error, vs. The United States ex rel. C.F. Moulton. Submitted.
PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 24.--The house of William Pancoast was destroyed by fire to-night, and his two children, Clifford and Mamie, aged 5 and 3 years, were burned to death.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 24.--The trial of Gilbert W. Hazeltine for the murder of Mamie Thorpe was continued in the Criminal Court to-day. In opening the case for the defense ex-Gov. Whyte stated that the ground of defense would be insanity.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24.--John T. Davies has begun another suit against John A. Atkinson, his late partner in the packing firm of Davies, Atkinson Co., mention of which has been suppressed till to-day so as to enable a writ of capias issued by Judgs Williamson to be served by the Deputy Sheriff on the defendant.
John Karler, a vagrant beggar, was led yesterday into the Tombs Police Court by Officer Ciardi. In his pocket he had two badges, one for Blaine and the other for Cleveland.

In response to a call for a meeting of Brooklyn business men opposed to the election of Blaine and Logan about 200 merchants gathered last evening in the Assembly Rooms on Washington-street in that city.

The new Temple Al Zoorah, in Broadstreet, just above Vine, Philadelphia, will be dedicated to the use of Lu Lu Temple, Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine, on Friday evening next, the new Arabic year, A.H. 1302.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 24.--East Pennsylvania Eldership Church of God this morning changed the name of Stonetown Circuit to Saxton Circuit, and gave Philadelphia Station permission to sell their church property and purchase a new site.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24.--John P. St. John, the Prohibition candidate for President, arrived in this city about 1 o'clock to-day. He was welcomed by a Reception Committee, and went to a hotel. An hour and a half later a procession of Prohibitionists from this city and the towns of this vicinity was formed to escort the candidate to Music Hall.

Gentlemen of horsey proclivities, who frequent "the road" in the vicinity of the Fleetwood track, often point out a stout and elderly gentleman who is generally attired in a drab topcoat and holding the reins over a fast horse, and say with reverential awe: "There goes the man who owns Maxey Cobb."

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 24.--Great excitement prevails here over the attempted desecration of the vault of the Phelps family last night. This family are all laid at rest in a monster marble tomb in Spring Forest Cemetery. This structure cost about $8,000.

The Cambiaggio-Sieni troupe did not appear to as decided advantage in "Rigoletto" as in "Aida" and "Il Trovatore," but their performance at the Star Theatre last evening was good as a whole and quite impressive in the most striking portions of the opera. Signor Giannini was the Duke, and his representation of that picturesque and melodious sovereign was only inferior to his Manrico and Rhadames ...

The Insurance Men's Blaine and Logan Club had a meeting at No. 27 Pine-street yesterday. Two flags from Fort Sumter, belonging to a member, hung on the wall. E.R. Kennedy presided. Sherman S. Rogers, of Buffalo; the Rev. John Rhey Thompson, of Brooklyn, and Stewart L. Woodford spoke.

The letter written to the President by J. J. Barker, who recently resigned his position as clerk in the office of the First Controller of the Treasury, charges United States Marshal Joel B. Erhardt, of this city, with paying Special Deputy Marshals for more work than was required of them by law, and United States Commissioner Shields with collecting an illegal bill of $1,400 for swearing in Marshals in 1880.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 24.--Several changes have recently taken place in the Yale corporation. The Rev. Dr. Joseph Anderson, of Waterbury, has been elected to fill the vacancy by the resignation of the Rev. Mr. Amos S. Chesebrough, and ex-President Woolsey has resigned on account of growing age and physical infirmities.

Two Congressional and a number of Aldermanic and Assembly conventions were held in the city last night. The Tammany Hall Twelfth Congressional District Convention was held in Progress Hall, No. 845 Third-avenue. Justice Ambrose Monell announced that the Hon. Orlando B. Potter had declined a renomination, and he asked the convention to present candidates.

The non-sporting dog show closed at 10 o'clock last night with a great chorus of joyful yelps and pitiful whines. Some dogs liked the show; some did not, and they wriggled their tails in joy to have it over. Others put their tails between their legs and raised their voices to heaven in heartrending howls at sight of their traveling boxes. There is a difference in dogs.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--Dominick McCaffrey, who recently defeated Charles Mitchell in a glove fight in New-York, declines to accept the challenge issued by Mitchell yesterday to fight with hard gloves or barn knuckles. He gives as his reason a desire to meet John L. Sullivan before making any other matches. He states his willingness to meet the latter with gloves or knuckles.

Capt. Woodward, of the bark Arcadia, which arrived yesterday from Antigua, reports that when five miles east of Long Beach he passed a sunken two-masted schooner with all sails set. The fact that the sails were set indicated that the vessel had gone down suddenly. As no shipwrecked schooner's crew have recently been reported in this neighborhood, it is feared that all on the vessel were lost.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 24.--In the Clawson polygamy case to-day the jury was completed. Lydia Spencer, the presumed second wife, was called, but refused to be sworn or to testify.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--Acting Judge-Advocate-General G.N. Lieber in his annual report to the Secretary of War says that 19 commissioned officers, 7 West Point cadets, 2,242 enlisted men, and 10 military convicts wero tried by general courts-martial during the year, making a total of 2,278. For the last five years the number of general courts-martial has been constantly increasing. In 1880 there were 1,543; in 1881, 1,792; in 1882, 1,850, and in 1883, 1,985.

Little circulars announced at Koster Bial's last evening that Miss Josie Marshall, "the magnetic wonder," and Paul Mutzenbacker, proprietor of the Silver Grill, at No. 468 Sixthavenue, would test the comparative merits of muscle and magnetism for the sum of $500.

The registration yesterday was very heavy, the fine weather bringing out a great many voters, especially in the up-town and eastern districts of the city. The totals thus far are largely in excess of any previous year, the increase being over 20,000 from the phenomenal registration of 1880.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Oct. 24.--The Greenback Congressional Conference of the Sixteenth District met here to-day and nominated W.C. Kennedy, of Bradford City, for Congress. It is expected that the Democrats will make no nomination.

The public rehearsal prefatory to the first of the series of four "Novelty Concerts" to be given by Mr. F. Van der Stucken at Steinway Hall was held yesterday afternoon. The performance was, on the whole, satisfactory, and offered promise of an interesting entertainment this evening, when the concert proper occurs.

SING, SING, N.Y., Oct. 24.--The Democrats of the Third Assembly District of Westchester County held a convention at Pine's Bridge to-day and nominated George D. Sandford, of Peekskill, for member of Assembly and William D. Lyon, of Bedford, for School Commissioner.

MYSTIC, Conn., Oct. 24.--As regards the murder by young Stanton of his schoolmate, Frederick Nash, Mr. Henry MacDonald, of Florida, one of the students at the institute, who boarded with young Nash on Zion's Hill, told the following story to a reporter this afternoon. "The night Fred went away he and I were preparing to go to a political meeting.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 24.--Miss Emma Stout, a resident of this place, but formerly a school teacher at Rockaway, N.J., has brought suit for breach of promise against Jacob Biltz, of Ashland, and asks $5,000 damages.
PARIS, Oct. 24.--The Telegraphe says that France has declined England's overtures to mediate in the Franco-Chinese difficulty.

Among the admirers of Sophia Frieder, a pretty brown-haired German girl, of No. 163 Eldridge-street, are William Meyer and Charles Friedel, who live in the neighborhood. The rivals met in the fair Sophia's house on Thursday evening.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--The fourth and last day of the Fall meeting of the National Jockey Club closed one of the most successful events in the history of the club. The weather was rather cool for comfort, but that did not prevent an attendance of fully 4,000 persons, including many ladies.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--United States Commissioner Bell to-day committed George Frymiar, alias Peabody, in default of $15,000 bail. Frymiar was brought to this city last night from Williamsport for counterfeiting Government coin. The United States Attorney will apply for an order of removal, and in a few days Frymiar will be taken to Trenton for trial.

"The People, As It Laughs and Weeps," is the title of the piece acted at the Thalia Theatre last evening. The play is divided into three acts and 10 scenes, and its incidents are supposed to be illustrative of popular life in Berlin.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 24.--The immigration returns for the nine months ending Sept. 30 show that the number of immigrants settling in Canada during that time fell off 18 per cent., as compared with the corresponding period of last year.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--Little Johnny Price, barely 10 years old, filched a withered Seckel pear from a fruit stand on Filbertstreet, near the Broad-street station, on the 8th of this month.

When Miss Mary Irene Hoyt, the daughter of the late Jesse Hoyt, was arrested and fined $10 for disorderly conduct at the Grand Central Station, her friends claimed that the judgment against her was rendered without hearing evidence in her behalf.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 24.--The Phelps family vault, one of the costliest structures of the kind in the State, was entered by grave robbers last night and the tomb of Robert, a son of the late Judge Phelps, was forced open.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 24.--At the meeting of the Women's Christian Temperance Union today Miss Frances E. Willard was re-elected President.

An engineer named Fisher is reported to have made an important discovery in aeronautics, by which he is enabled to condense or expand the gas in a balloon. The agent he employs is compressed carbonic acid, with the help of which he can ascend or descend at pleasure.

A torchlight procession, with fireworks and music, wound through the streets of Tremont last evening and then marched into Ittner Hall. Here about 500 independent Republicans were gathered, crowding the hall so that it was soon impossible for any more to gain admission. A.B. Tappen called the meeting to order and introduced Gustav Schwab as Chairman.

To farm 400 acres well, and keep plenty of beasts, and be admittedly prosperous, a man must have 4,000, and make of least a rent for himself besides his interest--that is, must have from 400 to 500 a year clear.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--The Commissioner of Railroads, William H. Armstrong, has submitted to the Secretary of the Interior his annual report for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1884.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 24.--State Senator J.L. Powell, of Spottsylvania County, formerly one of Mahone's stanchest followers, has just addressed an open letter to his constituents repudiating Blaine and coming out in favor of Cleveland and Hendricks. Mr. Powell is the ablest lawyer Mahone ever attracted to his party.
The city and county ticket of the Republican machine seems to be going to pieces. Mr. LEWIS J. PHILLIPS has concluded that he cannot accept the nomination for Mayor.

A sensation was created in Kelloggsville, Cayuga County, last week on the discovery of a rebel flag flying in a corn field of the Rev. Mr. Cross, an Episcopal minister, who came North after the war. Hot-headed people of the town declared him an "unrepentant rebel," and ordered him to take it down. Mr. Cross said he put it up to frighten the crows away.
SALEM, N.J., Oct. 24.--Howard Sullivan, the young colored man, who on Tuesday last pleaded guilty to the murder of Ella Watson, was to-day placed on trial to determine the degree of his guilt.

George A. Leavitt , Co. completed last evening the sale of the Benjamin Fitch collection of oil paintings by foroign artists. The bidding was not brisk, and a number of good works were knocked down at figures far below what they originally cost.

NAPANEE, Ontario, Oct. 24.--James Clark, a druggist, was drowned in Bay Quine to-day. He was duck shooting with Frederick Dewsbury, a bookkeeper, of Benville, when the boat was overturned. Dewsbury was saved by other hunters.

DELPHOS, Kan., Oct. 24.--William Hall, aged 58 years, of this place, was shot and instantly killed yesterday by his son Lincoln, aged 18. The shooting was the result of a family quarrel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24.--Emmons Blaine, Horace A. Taylor, Chairman of the Wisconsin Republican Committee, and "Long" Jones arranged with the Northwestern Road to-day to run a special train to Milwaukee to-morrow with James G. Blaine and his party.

PARIS, Oct. 24.--Yport, in the Department of the Seine Inferieure, where the last outbreak of cholera in France has occurred, is in a bad sanitary condition, and there is a scarcity of drinking water.

WARSAW, N.Y., Oct. 24.--John Dundon, aged 43, a mild-mannered Irishman who for 18 years has been employed by the Erie Railroad Company here, was discovered yesterday to be in a very excited condition mentally.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--About 10 o'clock this morning some of the residents in the large tenement house No. 1,208 Callowhillstreet broke into a small back room occupied by Mrs. Annie Logan, a young married woman, and found Mrs. Logan and her little son, about 2 years old, lying dead on the bed.

EASTON, Penn., Oct. 24.--The Fall games of the Lafayette College Athletic Association attracted a fair audience to the campus this afternoon. Some of the events were exciting and well contested, though a number of events were omitted.

SAN JOSE, Cal., Oct. 24.--Jan Wasielewsky was hanged here this morning at 11:03 o'clock. Wasielewsky was a native of Poland, aged 30, and a butcher by trade. In 1879 he was sentenced to three years' imprisonment in the State prison for cattle stealing.
Funeral services were held yesterday afternoon over the remains of Mrs. Bridgman, wife of the Rev. Dr. C. D'W. Bridgman, in the Madison-Avenue Baptist Church, of which he is the Pastor.

ROME, Oct. 24.--Lieut.-Gen. Ferrero, Minister of War, has resigned, and Gen. Ricotti has been appointed to fill the place.
DRY HOLLOW, Penn., Oct. 24.--An accident occurred at this place about 3 o'clock this afternoon which resulted in the killing of one man and the fatally injuring of another.

SCHNECTADY, N.Y., Oct. 24.--Two ladies met Officer Gould to-night in Union-street and told him there was a burglar in their house. When the officer reached the house he saw two men going down the street.

The first race at Brighton Beach yesterday was for a purse of $250, of which $50 to the second, for 3-year-olds and upward; five furlongs. Auction pools--King Fan, $100; Audacity, Montauk, Marsh Redon, and Glideway, $30 each; the field--Flyaway, Jeremiah, Romola, Hazard, Electrifier, Eva S., Eldorado, Medusa, and Frolic -$50. Romola won by a neck, Marsh Redon second, and Frolic third. Time--1:06 . French pools raid $56.55.

Mrs. Anna Elizabeth Garrish, wife of Dr. John P. Garrish, of this city, died on Wednesday at her home, No. 417 West Twenty-third-street. Mrs. Garrish was a daughter of Mr. Brady, a Philadelphia cloth merchant, and was especially ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24.--Mr. Blaine's friends are worried about Colorado. They have learned from the most authentic sources that the election of the Republican ticket in that State, both local and national, is in grave doubt.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 24.--The Government will place the sum of $140,000 in the estimate during the coming session of Parliament to defray the expense of laying a cable between Nova Scotia and Sable Island. Owing to the rocky nature of the bottom over which the cable will run it will be necessary to lay a shore cable the whole distance, which will cost three times as much as an ordinary ocean cable.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 24.--About 5 o'clock this morning the guards on duty at the river side of the penitentiary discovered flames issuing from that portion occupied by Warden Wright as a residence.

At Novomoskofsk, in the Province of Ekaterinoslav, a trial of heresy is about to take place, in which 92 men and 11 women sectarians will figure as accused. They belong to a new seet of seceders from the Orthodox Church, which recognizes neither spiritual nor temporal authorities, and disbelieves in the sacrament and the virtue of holy pictures. Its members lead sober, industrious lives.

LONDON, Oct. 24.--The Cabinet has not yet sanctioned the advance of the Nile expedition to Khartoum. The question will not be decided before the return of Lord Northbrook, the British High Commissioner, who is now in Egypt.

MANCHESTER, Oct. 21.--The Guardian, in its commercial article says: "The market is steady and quiet. Buyers, in view of the drooping tendency of cotton, are cautious. There is a fair demand for yarns and goods, owing to the lowness of prices."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 24.--At the NewEngland Yearly Meeting of Friends, held in their boarding school, in this city, this morning, the Whittier anniversary was celebrated by the presentation of a portrait of the poet by Charles F. Coffin, of Lynn, Mass. Mr. Coffin was a pupil at the school 50 years ago, and later was a teacher and then a committeeman, which office he still holds.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 24.--At 9 A.M. the Univeralist National Convention was called to order. The Committee on Nominations reported as follows: President-J.D.W. Joy, of Boston; Vice-President-J.H. Swan, of Illinois: Secretary-- ...

Miss Sarah Elizabeth Seelye, daughter of Mrs. Lindsley P. Seelye, of Ballston, Saratoga County, N.Y., and Mr. William Minavar Ver Planck, of New-York, were married Wednesday afternoon at the residence of the bride's mother.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24.--Three hundred and fifty delegates have already arrived at Princeton to attend the fifth annual Convention of the American Interseminary Missionary Alliance.
A dark-haired mysterious little woman, living at No. 99 Stanton-street, gave her name to Justice Duffy in the Tombs Police Court yesterday as Louisa Heitman, and said that she was a fortune teller.

The business of the brisk little manufacturing town of Jamestown, Chautauqua County, will not be seriously interrupted by the exhibition of the Blaine combination, as the troupe will arrive there to-morrow morning and leave the place at noon Monday.

The parade of the business men who favor the election of Cleveland and Hendricks will start from the Battery at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon. No resident of this city whose name is not inscribed on the registry book of his election district by 9 o'clock to-night will be entitled to vote for either national, State, or county officers at the election of Nov. 4.

Senator EDMUNDS, an honest and learned statesman who regards public office as a public trust, is trying to perfect a bill, to be submitted to the Senate at its next session, that will compel the Union Pacific Railroad Company to keep its engagements with the people of the United States.

When the Republican Convention of the First Congressional District, comprising the Counties of Suffolk, Queens, and Richmond, assembled in Jamaica yesterday it was found that Richmond County was not represented.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24.--The Democratic Conventions to nominate candidates for City Controller and Recorder of Deeds, to fill the vacancies on the ticket caused by the declination of Messrs. Hirst and McCully, ...

The following ward nominations were made in Brooklyn last evening: W.J. Denham, (Dem.,) for Supervisor of the Twentieth Ward; Thomas Maurer, (Dem.,) for Supervisor of the Sixteenth Ward, and Neil F. Dougherty, (Dem.,) for Supervisor of the Second Ward. The Fourteenth Ward primary broke up in a row.

Mr. Theodore Houston, one of the Receivers of the West Shore, said yesterday that no Receivers' certificates had been issued for any purposes except to pay wages and the rentals of terminal property and equipment. None had been issued for operating expenses since the Receivers took control.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Oct. 24.--The National Convention of Soldiers and Sailors assembled here this afternoon in response to a call issued by Gen. F.W. Haskell and Gen. Merrill. The delegates present represented about 1,100 organizations.
