Some of our speakers and orators talk about Georgia being the banner Democratic State at the November election. This is all very well to palaver about or to make a newspaper item of, but no such thing will be accomplished without work and plenty of it.
To-night the last performance of "Called Back" will be given at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre. On Monday evening Mr. Eric Barley's comedy company will produce "The Colonel" at that house.

QUEBEC, Oct. 24.--The special constables recently guarding the departmental buildings have been discharged and others taken in their places. A permanent guard is in course of formation, with the defective bureau in command.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 24.--The failure of S. Kopelowich, Brother Co., wholesale jewelers and diamond merchants, of this city, is for the sum of $70,000, of which $40,000 are due to Eastern manufacturers.
BERLIN, Oct. 24.--Great honors have been shown the body of the late Duke of Brunswick. Sir Edward Malet, the British Ambassador, will attend the funeral as the representative of Queen Victoria.

"I was trying to arrest this man for disorderly conduct," said Officer Tierney, of the Fourth Precinct, in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, "when he assaulted me and struck me in the face several times with his clenched fist."

The O'Brien Democracy sees something hopeful in the local political outlook, and proposes to hold a county convention of its own tonight. Threats are made that a straight county ticket will be nominated.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Oct. 24.--The fire in Chapman's dry goods store on Thursday night caused a loss of $200,000 on buildings and $350,000 on stock. The insurance is estimated at $450,000. Stark Brothers, carpet dealers, who occupied the basement, lose $100,000 in stock, which is fully insured.

LONDON, Oct. 24.--Contrary to his usual custom Mr. Gladstone, in his speech in the House of Commons last evening, read from manuscript the passage in which he referred to the possible reform of the House of Lords.

LONDON, Oct. 24.--Mr. G.E. Rogers, the American who was arrested last Saturday at the instance of Mr. Parkinson, editor of St. Stephen's Review, on the charge of assault and battery, was before the Bow-Street Police Court to-day. He was bound over in the sum of 10 to keep the peace, and was forbidden to approach the office of the St. Stephen's Review. Mr. Train, the barrister, appeared for the prosecution against Mr. Rogers.

VALPARAISO, Oct. 25.--The Pacific Steam Navigation Company's steamer Chiloe brings Capt. Evans and 16 sailors of the British bark Helen Burns, which took fire off Staten Island, Terra del Fuego, on the 27th ult. The fire was caused by a generation of gas in the cargo of coal. The men had been previously landed at Lota by the British bark Rejion, which was on her way to San Francisco.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 25.--A dispatch from Franklin to the Times-Democrat says: "Richard Holley, colored, shot and instantly killed Henry Wiley, a colored preacher, this afternoon. Honey fled after the killing and fired three shots at his pursuers, but was finally captured and lodged in jail. Family affairs were the cause of the trouble."

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Oct. 25. --Two inches of snow fell in this part of the Mohawk Valley to-day. Trains on the Cherry Valley track were delayed several hours this morning.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Oct. 25.--The residence of Joseph Hutchings was wrecked this morning by an explosion of gas. There being a break near the meter, Mrs. Hutchings used a light to investigate its source, when the explosion took place. The lady and two servants were badly burned.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 25.--A number of Italian navvies who were shipped here by Henry Zandler Co., of New-York, at the request of Hanson Co., employment agents of this city, who stated that they were instructed to engage 200 laborers for a North Shore contractor, have been victimized. Only 20 men have obtained employment, and the rest are stranded here without a cent. The men state that they each paid Zandler Co. $2.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 25.--The steamer Faraday, which arrived from New-York to-day, will take 2,000 tons of coal on board. She will remain until the first of the week, and then proceed to sea to find and repair the broken portion of the first Mackay-Bennett cable.

GREENFIELD, Oct. 25.--Mallory Davenport, of Colerain, yesterday filled a sack with stones, tied it around him, shot himself through the neck, and jumped into the Deerfield River. His body was found to-day, and also a note saying he committed suicide to escape the insane asylum. He was the son of Levi Davenport, a wealthy farmer. He had been a teacher in Bernardston Academy, and was 23 years old.
EASTON, Penn., Oct. 25.--The Lafayette College and Lehigh University eleven played football this afternoon, and Lafayette won a signal victory, defeating Lehigh 50 to 0.
LONDON, Oct. 25.--Great crowds waited in and about the House of Parliament for the opening of the Autumn session, though only some scores of persons could hope to witness the ceremony.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25.--Mr. Blaine arrived here last night at midnight. This morning he was driven to the Northwestern Station at 9:30 o'clock, accompanied by his sons Walker and Emmons, and Mr. Joseph Medill, at whose residence he had passed the night.

William McGrath had his leg badly scattered, William Nash his collar bone broken, and John Arneld the fleshy part of his arm torn off by one explosion, and Herbert Bidner was injured by the other explosion so that he died this morning.

BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Oct. 25.--The propeller City of St. Joseph took fire at her dock at 8 o'clock to-night. Her upper works have burned away and fire is still in her hold. The loss cannot be estimated at present, but is believed to be covered by insurance.

DUBLIN, Oct. 25.--An attempt was made to-day to destroy with dynamite a loch gate near Coleraine, in County Londonderry. The attempt failed. The police are making an active inquiry into the case.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 25.--A dispatch from Ruston to the Times-Democrat reports that the King and Boatner committees called together for the purpose of adjusting Democratic Party differences in the Fifth Congressional District adjourned without having accomplished the desired result. Boatner and King will, therefore, continue in the field as Democratic candidates for Congress. This gives Morey, Republican, a good prospect of election to Congress from the Fifth District.

A farmer who was in town from Wells, Wednesday morning, related a remarkable circumstance which happened in his town one day last week. For some time past the herring have remained way from shore, and the fishermen were unable to obtain them very large numbers. All at once they began to come in shore.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 25.--O.M. Bond, Prohibition candidate for Congress, fell from a lumber pile hero to-day and sustained probably fatal injuries.

OTTAWA, Ontario Oct. 25.--The search which was made for the lighthouse keepers of Sandhead, British Columbia, who have been missing since the 7th inst., has proved fruitless, and the three men have undoubtedly been drowned. The names of the missing men are H.H. Fraser, keeper; W.S. Fraser, his brother, and a man named Williams. The Frasers were natives of Pictou, Nova Scotia. Williams belonged to British Columbia. The lights have again been put in operation.

This can be none other than the famous " WHALLEY, M.P.," who was for many years member for Peterborough.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 25.--In the Clawson polygamy case, this morning, Lydia, the second wife, concluded to testify. She was asked but three questions, and answered admitting her marriage, when it occurred, and where, The prosecution has rested.

LONDON, Oct. 25.--Sir Moses Montefiore received hundreds of telegrams congratulating him on attaining his hundredth birthday. They came from all parts of the world, and there were many from America.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 25.--The tanners and hide and leather dealers of this city have decided to issue a call for a convention of the tanners of the country, to be held here at the time the cattle men's convention will meet next month.

PARIS, Oct. 25.--The Cri du Peuple states that on Tuesday, at Laeken, an attempt was made to shoot King Leopold. One shot from a revolver was fired at him by a Radical student. The would-be regicide was then arrested. The news of the incident was suppressed.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25.--Policeman Patten, of Hornedisville, brought Michael Devine from that place to serve a sentence in Monroe County Penitentiary. Near Red Creek the prisoner jumped from the car window, with handcuffs on, the train going at the rate of 25 miles an hour. The train was stopped, but no traces of the man could be found. Rochester police are looking for him.

BOSTON, Oct. 25.--Official returns of the Board of Registrars of voters show that the number of voters registered is 65,969, against 64,22l in 1883. This year the original lists showed that 48,160 registered, and the additional registration has amounted to 17,800.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25.--J.V. Brown, husband of the Postmistress at Rocky Mount, Va., was arrested this morning by Post Office Inspector Henderson for rifling registered letters. He made a confession showing that the rifling has been extensive.

PARIS, Oct. 2.--Yesterday was the second centennial anniversary of the death of Pierre Corneille. In the morning at St. Roch the venerable Cure celebrated the day by a long and touching tribute of admiration for the genius, who was not only a learned man, but who was also a devout Christian. When Register Reilly found that his gas bills for illuminating his office amounted to $60 a month in midsummer, he put on his spectacles and went through the hall of records from cellar to garret. In one room, which the city uses as a bindery, the Register found a glue-pot with 40 gas burners blazing under it.

ALBANY, Oct. 25.--The prospects of securing Republican harmony in this county are not considered as bright as they were yesterday. The arbiters agreed to recommend a new commitiee of seven, three from each side, and the Chairman to be selected by the arbiters. After endeavoring all day to select the seventh man the arbiters gave up in disgust this afternoon, but will make a final attempt on Monday to solve the difficulties.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 25.--The suit brought against the Freehold and New-York Railway Company by Miss Sarah M. Ashmore, a school teacher of Keyport, to recover $10,000 damages for injuries alleged to have been received in a fall while stepping from a train, closed last night. The jury gave her a verdict for $2,500.

The Lotus Club began its monthly "Saturday Nights" for the season last evening, and there was a large attendance of members and guests. The feature of the evening was the presentation of a portrait of Col. Thomas W. Knox, the Secretary of the club, to the club.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 25.--The Southern Exposition closed to-night, and was a grand success in every respect. The immense building was crowded all day with people, and at night fully 40,000 persons took part in the closing scenes. President Young spoke a few appropriate words, Gilmore played a national air, and Louisville's great show was at an end.

WADY HALFA, Oct. 25.--Gen. Lord Wolveley will start up the Nile on Tuesday. SUAKIN, Oct. 25.--Abyssinian advices state that King John has ordered Ras Aloula, the Abyssisian General, to march on Kassala, in the Southeastern Soudan. Major Chermside is trying to prevent this.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 26.--The single-scull race between Teemer and Gandaur for $500 a side, three miles, with turn, Teemer to give Gandaur five seconds start, was rowed at Creve Coeur Lake, near this city, this afternoon. Rain fell steadily during the day and until half an hour prior to the race.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26.--The celebration of the centenary of Sir Moses Montefiore was continued this afternoon at the Hanover-Street Synagogue. The large auditorium was completely packed. Col. B.F. Ulman presided. He spoke of the large charities of Sir Moses, and said that in the dispensation of his benevolence he knew only mankind.

RUTHERFORD, N.Y., Oct. 26.--William Farrell, of this village, has a blooded liver and white pointer dog which has developed great fondness for fishing, and he fishes with such skill that the family have been furnished with several messes of grass pike and catfish.

READING. Penn., Oct. 25.--James A. Herne, of Herne's "Hearts of Oak" company, who completed a two nights' engagement in this city last evening, played a number of practical jokes upon prominent business houses yesterday afternoon which came near costing him the freedom of the city.

LONDON, Oct. 26.--A monster Radical demonstration in favor of the abolition of the House of Lords was held in Hyde Park to-day. More than 100,000 persons were present. A long procession, with bands, flags, , marched through the principal streets. The matchers groaned while passing the headquarters of various Conservative clubs at the West End.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 26.--The blue laws were put into operation at Hamden, near this city, to-day, when F. Hill, John Springsteen, and W. Hemlar were arrested for walking out in the fields with guns on their shoulder, apparently bent on a hunting excursion. A Hamden Justice of the Peace imposed a fine of $34.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 26.--Michael Croghan, 7 years old, son of Policeman Croghan, was instantly killed by a street car this afternoon. He was crossing the street when he was knocked down by the horses and the wheels of the car passed over his neck, completely severing the head from the body. The driver of the car, who had left the charge of his horses to collect fares, is held for a hearing to-morrow.

The Independent Cleveland and Hendricks Scandinavian Club, at a meeting on Saturday evening, voted to support the nominees of the Citizens Committee for county offices. Circulars will be sent to voters of Scandinavian birth urging support of this ticket, regardless of former party preferences.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 26.--The financial troubles of S. Sobel Sons culminated in the seizure last night of their wholesale millinery and dry goods stores. The assets will secure the creditors, whose claims aggregate $25,000.

MOBILE, Oct. 26.--On this the ninetieth day of the drought, a general rain, extending as far north as Tennessee, and perhaps further, has passed over the Country, and rain is now falling steadily here. It comes too late to help the cotton much in these sections which escaped Thursday's trost, but will raise the rivers and permit the resumption of navigation. Fall planting of small crops will now be pushed vigorously.

Father John J. Riordan, the Castle Garden missionary, who returned from his visit to Ireland by the steamship Germanic, which arrived Saturday evening, visited the Garden yesterday, where he was warmly received by Conmissioner Hauselt, Superintendent Jackson, and others. WASHINGTON, Oct. 26.--Judge Ferris, Second Auditor of the Treasury, has completed and submitted to Secretary Gresham his annual report for the fiscal year ended June 30. It shows that the aggregate number of unadjusted accounts and claims on hand in the Second Auditor's office July 1, 1883, was 41,928, of which 36,112 were for arrears of pay and bounty.
Plymouth Church was crowded yesterday to the doors when the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher began his Sunday morning sermon. In the course of his remarks he alluded to revivalists and their work.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 26.--A great commotion has been raised by an endeavor made a few weeks ago by the Faculty of Adelbert College, of the Western Reserve University, to crowd out the young women who are now students there, and to prevent the admission of others.

BINGHAMTON, Oct. 26.--An immense meeting was held in this city to-night to protest against the action of the Italian Government in confiscating the propaganda property at Rome. Men of prominence, both Protestants and Catholics, spoke on the subject and denounced in strong terms the Proposed action of Italy. Among the speakers were Congressman Millard, Judge Downs, and B.S. Cunan.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25.--The third and last days' session of the American Interseminary Missionary Alliance closes this fifth annual convention of missionaries, is which all evangelical denominations have been represented.

The registration figures this year show some interesting results. The increase in the number of persons on the rolls as compared with 1880 is 23,923, or a little more than 11 per cent. In 1880 the increase over the figures of 1876 was 33,961, or about 18 1-2 per cent.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 26.--Residents of the two little villages of Mystic River and Mystic Bridge are worried over the belligerent attitude of Manassah Miner, one of their fellow-townsmen. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 26.--Later advices concerning the wreck on the Manitoba Railroad reported last night says: "A passenger train on the Manitoba Railroad encountered a partially burned bridge 40 miles south of Grookston. The party will pass over the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio and Erie Railways.

BATH, Me., Oct. 27.--Robert N. Parke, D.D., of Brooklyn, N.Y., has accepted the Rectorship of Grace Church here, and will occupy the pulpit on the second Sunday in November.

Cornelius Seguin Johnson, on Jan. 24, 1881, bought of Andros B. Stone and William L. Done, 5,000 shares of Jones Bonanza Mining Company stock, for which he paid $50,000. On Feb. 10, of the same year, an inquisition was begun before a Sheriff's jury, which declared that Johnson was insane and had been for two months previous. Suit was begun against Stone and Done for the recovery of $50,000, which was resisted.

The representation of "Ernani" at the Star Theatre last evening was the least satisfactory performance the Cambiaggio-Sieni troupe have thus far supplied. Hard work tells swiftly upon operatic artists, and many of the shortcomings noticeable in last night's entertainment were clearly attributable to weariness on the part of the vocalists.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Oct. 27.--Mrs Judee Hoag Mosier, aged 100 years and 16 days, died here this morning.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 27.--A mine disaster occurred near Union this afternoon. Two men are known to have been killed outright and several were injured. Over 20 were in the mine at the time of the explosion, and it is feared that all were either killed or injured.

"Welcome to your native county!" was the greeting given to Grover Cleveland in the wide-awake city of Newark yesterday. TROY, N.Y., Oct. 27.--Levi Clapper, aged 50 years, residing at Tomhannock, played the fife for a political parade on Saturday night and returning home was taken ill and died yesterday of heart disease. A physician had advised him that it was dangerous for him to continue playing the fife.

LONDON, Oct. 27.--The Irish party has decided to withhold its vote on the Franchise bill. This will reduce the Government majority to 85 on a division.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 27.--Last week the largest banking house here informed its customers that 8 per cent. discount would be charged instead of 6, as heretofore, and to-day all banks took the same stand. CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 27.--John P. Bonte Co., picture frame manufacturers, Genesee-street, have assigned, with liabilities estimated at $30,000; assets, $18,000. A mortgage for $23,000 was given Charles Brown prior to assignment.

AUGUSTA, Me., Oct. 27.--A body nearly destroyed by quicklime and fire has been found buried in a woods about one mile from the Soldiers' Home at Togus. It is believed to be that of Gabriel Labelle, an inmate of the Home, who disappeared about five years ago, and who is supposed to have been murdered by another inmate, who is known, for a sum of pension money. Labelie belonged in Montreal, where he has relatives.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 28.--Henry Lehr, who was convicted of manslaughter for shooting Joseph Henry Wilson for stealing melons on Sept. 4, has been sentenced to State prison for four years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28.--The depth of Wilbur F. Storey, which occurred about 10 o'clock last evening at his residence, No. 1,834 Prairie-avenue, was not unexpected. For the last few days of his life he had been almost constantly unconscious, and when Dr. N.S. Davis was called yesterday afternoon he informed Mrs. Storey that dissolution was close at hand.

McGlory has sold out to John Kane, a theatrical manager from Sixth-street, Cincinnati, who will produce a variety show upon Monday next.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 28.--Taylor's Opera House to-night contained the largest audience of the campaign. the straightout Republicans were very greatly surprised at the outpouring of citizens. A great many Republicans were on the stage and in the audience.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 28.--A telephone message from Eaton, Ohio, states that Marshal Ryan was murdered about 7 o'clock last night by a rowdy. Some time ago Ryan arrested a murderer and used a club a few times in taking him to jail. A few days ago he was liberated, and has since been looking for Ryan.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 28.--Henry Roberts, colored, was this morning found dead in an empty room of the house where his divorced wife lived with her children. He had been shot. The two had not been living together for soveral months. It is supposed that he visited her last night and that she shot him. She denies that she killed him, and says she does not know how he came to be in the rooms.
FARMINGTON, Me., Oct. 28.--The wellknown Lake Rangeley steamer Mollie Chunkamunk was burned at midnight on Friday to the water's edge and sank in five feet of water near Lake Point Cottage.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 28.--A Tribune special from Good Hope (New-Mexico) Mining Camp says: "Joe Hickman, a well-known miner, was fatally shot here this afternoon. At his ante-mortem examination Hickman said his partners, Frank Beck and Tom Welch, determined to murder and rob another miner who had $900.

The schooner Euphenia A.Hayes, which left Fernandina for Port Spain on Oct. 8, put into this port in distress yesterday. Capt. RAMSGATE, England, Oct. 28.--This town is en fete in honor of Sir Moses Montefiore. The streets are decorated with triumphal arches, and excursion trains from various places have arrived crowded with people. Business was entirely suspended during the day.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 28.--The weavers at the Lancaster mills, in Clinton, who left their looms at noon yesterday, returned to work this morning, having been told that the mills would be shut down it they staid out.

WATERFORD, N.Y., Oct. 28.--The wife of George McCreary, of the Hudson River Knitting Mills, presented him with four children at a birth on Sunday. They are all girls and weighed seven pounds apiece.

Mr.Henry E.Fales, the regular Democratic nominee for Congress in the Ninth District of Massachusetts, declines to withdraw in favor of Congressman Theodore Lyman unless requested so to do by the reassembled delegates who nominated him. There are now five candidates in this district--Republican, Democratic, Independent, Prohibition, and People's.

McDaniel, Congressman Hammond, United States Senator Joseph E. Brown, and other prominent gentlemen spoke. Senator Brown confined his speech of about an hour to Mr. Blaine.

Johanna Buckley, a woman 24 years of age, who lived with her blind mother in a miserable attic room at No. 90 Monroe-street, died there suddenly yesterday, after taking a dose of medicine.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 28.--The law provides for the appointment by the State Registrar of Voters of one Commissioner of Election from each party for every polling place in the parish of Orleans.

BUFFALO, Oct. 28.--There was a large Democratic demonstration and meeting in this cits to-night. Many of the organizations turned out and the streets were crowded with people to witness the display.

CAIRO, Oct. 28.--The plan for Gen. Wolseley's expedition to Khartoum, as finally settled, furnishes him with a total force of 8,500 English troops.

Mayor Edson announced at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon that he had appointed Fitz John Porter Police Commissioner to serve out the term of the late Sidney P. Nichols, which expires Dec. 31, 1889.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--The Navy Department is informed that the Portsmouth left Newport yesterday for Norfolk, but was obliged to put in at New-London on account of heavy winds, where she will await their abatement.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 28.--W.D. Richards, collector and confldential clerk of C.V. Frizell, a candy manufacturer, is missing, and the firm allege that they have already discovered evidence of embezzlement. The amount is not stated, but the fact that he has had almost exclusive charge of the collections leads to the supposition that the amount is large. He is 28 years old and moved in rather fast society.

Murky clouds hung low in the sky yesterterday afternoon when the hour approached for the review of the First and Second Divisions of the National Guard by Gov. Cleveland. Rain fell gently and steadily on the heads and umbrellas of the just and the unjust, the Democrat and the Republican, the street arab, and the brassmounted policeman.

He is a man with a history.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 28.--The Fall meeting of the Southern Tier Rifle Association took place at the association grounds in this city today.

LIMA, Oct. 28, via Galveston.--A large meeting of the foreign residents has been held here to consider what steps should be taken to protect their interests against the Chilian Court of Arbitration, which is accused of injustice. A permanent committee, consisting of three members each from the English, French, German, Italian, and Spanish nations, was appointed.

Mr.Ashbel P.Fitch, who was nominated for Congress by the Republicans of the Thirteenth Congressional District, has declined the nomination on account of business engagements. The name of Mr. Theodore Roosevelt has been suggested for the nomination.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--When Mr. Blaine was in Ohio the fact was widely circulated that, in a dispute with the man who built his mansion in this city, he had declared that $2 a day was enough for any carpenter or journeyman and a dollar a day for a common laborer. Blame telegraphed to Washington for a denial of this assertion.

About 60 or 70 truck drivers and owners of trucks and wagons met in a little room at Cooper Union last night to protest against the proposed building of a street railway through Broadway. Mr. Tobias Cody called the meeting to order.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28.--A special session of the Protestant Episcopal Convention of the Diocese of Maryland began this morning at St. Peter's Church, for the purpose of electing a Bishop to fail the chair left vacant by the death of the Right Rev. Dr. William Pinkney.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28.--The Norwegian bark Loveid, which sailed from Dantzic, on the Baltic, July 29 last, for this port, is now so long overdue that almost every one interested in her has given her up as lost.

A special meeting of the Bar Association was held last evening to receive the report of the Committee on Judicial Nominations. President James C. Carter occupied the chair, and about 80 members of the association were present. John M. Scribner, Chairman of the committee, read the report.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 28.--The strike among the coal miners of the State, which commenced in a small way some time ago, is becoming general. Reports received to-day swell the number of strikers to 3,000. This has caused a suspension of operations in nearly all the principal mines of the State.

UNIONTOWN, Penn., Oct. 28.--The worst fears touching the fate of the men who were imprisoned in the coal mine at Youngstown, four miles from this place, by an explosion of firedamp, which took place there at 4 o'clock last evening, have been fully confirmed. Six of the miners were taken out soon after the disaster.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 28.--A detective employed by the Mobile and Ohio Railroad arrested to-day, near Tupelo, a man named Fielding, who is believed to be the person who displaced rails on that road between Tupelo and Saltillo on the 18th inst., and caused the run oil in which several persons were severely injured.

BRISTOL, Tenn., Oct. 28.--John Pike drove his two daughters from home last evening, and night overtaking them went into camp on the railroad, built a fire, and laid down to rest. While asleep the dress of Mattie, aged 18 years, caught fire and she was burned to a crisp, dying in an hour.

A.E.J. Tovey, editor of the Brewers' Journal, writes to this paper that what are known as brewers' grains are fed to cattle on brewery stock farms only to a limited extent, and that they are considered as au aid to digestion as well as a valuable nutriment.

Davis, met this afternoon and nominated Davis, who declined. They then nominated George E. White, who also declined, and afterward nominated Gen. Charles Fitzsimmons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28.--Somewhat suddenly, but not unexpectedly, Walter Q. Gresham to-day surrendered the Treasury portfolio, and ceased to be a member of President Arthur's Cabinet. Behind the cash counter of a popular up-town restaurant sits the good-looking, stalwart proprietor in a position where he can see nearly every table in the room. In front of him is a little silver bell with a clear, pleasant tone. When a guest enters the door the proprietor taps the bell once. If there are two guests he taps it twice; if a party, four times.

Rosenthal Co., wholesale clothing manufacturers, who recently failed, were filed in the County Clerk's office this morning. CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 29.--At 11:45 this morning Michael Brady, the elevator man in the six-story building at La, Salle and Michigan streets, ran into the engine room and told Peter Donohue, the engineer, that there was fire on the first floor.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 29.--There are a good many independents in Morristown, and they have done a good deal of active campaign work since New-York's Governor was nominated for the Presidency. Not until this evening, however, has any public meeting been held. The rain came down in torrents, and doubtless kept many of the less enthusiastic at home.

By 7:30 the place was packed from floor to roof, and a struggling mass of humanity was pushing and crowding on from behind, trying in vain to enter the auditorium of the theatre.

The Civil Service Reform Association recently addressed a number of questions to candidates for city offices and for Congress; if they believed that the reformed system would promote the civil service, and, if elected, if they would aid in the enforcement of the law. In his answer Mr. W.R. Grace says he believes that the reform system will tend to promote and preserve efficiency and economy in the civil service and to remove abuses.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The second days's matches of the Rifle Association of Southern New-York and Northern Pennsylvania took place to-day. There was a large number of sporting men present. The first match was for members of the association, 100 to 300 yards, five shots each.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 29.--Joseph, son of Gen. G.G. Dibrell, Congressman from this, the Third District, was shot twice last night by Gus Gear. One bullet entered the breast, inflicting a probably fatal wound. The shooting occurred at Sparta, Tenn. Dibrell attempted to separate Gear and a main named Hickey, who were fighting.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29.--The following particulars of the storms on the coast of Lower California were learned this morning. The news was brought here by the Captain of the steamer Newbern, from Guaymas. He says the steamer Estado de Sonora left Mazatlan on Sept. 29. The first storm broke out on the following day. It raged with such terrific fury that the Sonora was unable to put back.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Capt. Stanhope E. Blunt, Ordnance Department, will be relieved from duty in the Department of Dakota, and will report to the Lieutenant-General for duty at the headquarters of the army. It is understood that he is to act as Inspector of Rifle Practice.

In the Russian town of Sysran there is note living a man whose age is 127, a fact of which there is said to exist indubitable proof. He was wounded in the battle of Borodino and afterward entered Paris with the allied army. He is supported by charity.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 29.--The action of the Supreme Court yesterday reversing its own decision as to the constitutionality of the Scott liquor tax law has created a profound sensation in political circles, and at the present time but few leaders of note are disposed to express themselves fully in regard to its effect.

PARIS, Oct. 29.--M. Sardou, the dramatist, has had an interview with Mme. Bernhardt, and describes her as being really ill. Her nerves are unstrung and prostrated. Besides her artistic cares she is subject to money anxieties, arising from neglect of her pecuniary affairs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--It is not known as yet what disposition will be made of the estate of the late Wilbur F. Storey. It has been claimed by A.S. Trude that he has drawn up several wills at different times since Mr. Storey was first afflicted with disease, in 1876, and that these wills are still in existence.

READING, Penn., Oct. 29.--A young man named Levi Bechtel, employed at the Reading Iron Works, was killed on the Reading Railroad this morning. He had jumped on a coal train and by the sudden starting lost his balance, falling between the bumpers on to the track. His legs were frightfully mangled. He died in 30 minutes.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 29.--Col. W.F. Vilas, who was permanent Chairman of the Democratic National Convention, has been nominated by the Democrats for Assembly.

BERLIN, Oct. 29.--The Progressists are disappointed at the result in Berlin of the elections yesterday for members of the Reichstag. Second ballots will be required in four districts which they have hitherto carried. This result is attributed to the Socialist vote, which showed an increase of 38,000 while there was a decline of 10,000 in the Liberal vote.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 29.--Frederick W. Duvernois, for several years a private banker of this city, is missing. He owes depositors from $20,000 $40,000. He was agent for nine insurance companies, to whom he owes an aggregate of over $l5,000. He transferred all of his property to his wife several years ago, but the transfer was not recorded until recently.

Miss Carrie Bachman, daughter of Mr. Solomon Bachman, was married last evening to Mr. Simon Bernheimer, at the residence of the bride's parents, No. 16 East Sixty-second-street. A large number of friends witnessed the ceremony. The marriage service was solemnized beneath a floral arch, the Rev. Dr. Gottheil, of the Temple Emanu-El, officiating.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29.--Coroner Powers's investigation to-day of the unexplained death of Mrs. Johanna McCord, who died suddenly on Tuesday, brought out some pathetic points in a sad life. She was 64 years old and was the widow of George W. McCord, who was the pioneer hat renovater of this city.

ELLISWORTH, Me., Oct. 29.--In the case of the Government against Fred Pressey, Charles Sawyer, Mel Straw, and John Sawyer. Jr., charged with manslaughter in killing Frank Brown at Castine, Oct. 8, the jury to-day returned a verdict of guilty against all the respondents.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 29.--The Hon. Isaac M. Potter, one of the Electors of the Republican ticket, has resigned his position as Director Of the Commercial National Bank in this city, to avoid any possible conflict with the law regarding the eligibility of Federal officeholders.

PRINCETON, Oct. 29.--The largest score ever made on a football field since the adoption of the present rules was made here to-day on the university grounds by the Princeton University eleven against Lafayette's team. It was acknowledged before the game that Princeton would win, but the heavy score they made surprised all the college.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29.--The opening session of the congress of the Association for the Advancement of Women began at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon in the hall of the Young Men's Christian Association. There was a very fair attendance. The opening address was made by the President of the association, Mrs. Julia Ward Howe, of Rhode Island.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 29.--For several days past there have been rumors afloat of a heavy defalcation on the part of George F. Jackson, President of the Enterprise Cotton Factory, and a committee was appointed to investigate the books of the company. Jackson confesses to a defalcation, but cannot give the amount. He claims all responsibility for the deficit.

LEWISTON, Me., Oct. 29.--On account of the shutting down of the mills in this city there is considerable distress among the discharged operatives. The Overseers of the Poor report that applications for assistance have increased rapidly of late. Forty persons left for Canada yesterday.

PRINCETON, Oct. 29.--The students of the college and the townspeople of Princeton filled University Hall this evening to listen to the Hon. John P. Stockton, Attorney-General of New-Jersey, discuss the issues of the campaign. He was followed by Henry E. Davis, an alumnus of the College. The meeting closed with hearty cheers for Cleveland and Hendricks.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 29.--The Hendricks meeting here to-day was one of the greatest political demonstrations ever witnessed in this city. It is estimated that there were 50,000 people in town. The business portion of the city was profusely decorated. Gov. Hendricks spoke in the afternoon from the Leland Hotel.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 29.--W.H. Barrett, wholesale and retail drugs, has sold out to Glascock, Barrett D.E. McMaster, subject to mortgages of $32,000. His liabilities are not given. He is rated at between $20,000 and $40,000. M.J. Verdery Co., brokers, have failed with liabilities of $30,000 and nominal assets $23,000.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 29.--The Baptist State Convention began its seventy-seventh aunual meeting this morning in the Baptist church. Over 500 delegates were present. Dr. Edward Bright, of New-York, presided, and the Rev. J. B. Calvert-acted as Secretary and read the annual report, showing that 90 ministers and 379 churches had been added by the convention.

LONDON, Penn., Oct. 29.--The remains of 14 victims of the Youngstown mine disaster were buried to-day. The funerals were largely attended and the services were impressive. The company defrayed all the expenses, and are doing ...

It was a queer crowd of men claiming to be clergymen who met Mr. BLAINE at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday and presented him with a set of resolutions and drew from him a speech. WASHINGTON, Oct. 29.--Brig.-Gen. S.V. Benet, Chief of Ordnance, has submitted to the Secretary of War his report of the operations of the Ordnance Department during the fiscal year ended June 30. The expenditures of the department during the year, including those attending sales of condemned stores, amounted to $2,015,255. The report of the operations at the Rock Island Arsenal is submitted. BINGHAMTON, Oct. 29.--To-day there was to have occurred a grand Butler meeting, but, owing to the non-arrival of speakers, the expectant crowd separated. The meeting was to have been held at 2 o'clock. Grady, came from Syracuse about 4 o'clock, and spoke to a large crowd, with frequent interruptions.

About a hundred of the followers of St. John were gathered between the white walls of the neat little Methodist Episcopal Chapel in Franklin-street yesterday afternoon. Most of them were members of the regular congregation, and they met in accordance with a request of the National Committee of Prohibitionists to hold a day of fasting and prayer. The Rev. Stephen

Though evidently still suffering from his terrible experience in the arctics, Lieut. A.W. Greely last evening went through the ordeal of the "muster in," and was made a comrade of Post Lafayette, No. 140, G.A.R.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 29. -- The name of John P. Levan, one of the candidates on the Democratic State Electoral ticket, will be printed in place of the name of Chairman Rynder, one of the Butler State Committee,on 100,000 Electoral tickets of the Butler party. They are to be distributed from this city as soon as possible. This step was a concession

Cooley, representing the railroads; G.F. Swift, representing the dressed beef interest, and S.W. Al

Among the passengers of the Cunard steamship Bothnia, which sailed yesterday for Liverpool, were Admiral Sir Fred John Evans, of the British Navy; Col. Saltmarshe, Capt. W. C. Karslake, of the British Navy; Capt.Thursby, Capt. J. Jonasen, and Lieut. George L. Anderson. Among those who sailed for Havre on the
Steamship Anchoria, (Br.,) Small, Glasgow via Moville 11 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Henderson Bros.

EASTON, Penn., Oct. 30.--Andrew Meshach, who lives near the Water Gap, has a housekeeper in the person of his cousin, Hester Titman, who is alone during the day. At noon she went out doors to feed the pigs. As she entered the house a man sprang from behind the door, beat her, and feloniously assaulted her. He subsequently escaped.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30.--Belva Lockwood, the Presidential candidate of the Equal Rights Party, was in this city several hours this morning. She is en route to Michigan.
The following correspondence in relation to the charges made by Judge Donohue as to the naturalization of the Hon. William R. Grace explains itself. The first is a letter to THE TIMES:
THE HAGUE, Oct. 30.--The result of the election for members of the Second Chamber of the States-General shows a gain in the strength of the Liberal Union.

There is a great deal of ignorance among people in regard to animals. A recent inventor, who is probably a man of at least ordinary intelligence, has exhibited an ignorance of the condition of public opinion among mice which is as astonishing as it is deplorable. He has actually taken out a patent for an invention which any one in the least degree acquainted with mice would know to be entirely worthless.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30.--It is known here that within the last three days $60,000 of the Blaine corruption fund has been sent into Virginia for the purchase of votes for the speckled candidate. This is in addition to what has hith erto been forwarded, and more will be forthcoming if developments show that it is worth while.

There was a number of arrests yesterday for violation of the registry laws. On the strength of evidence procured through Pinkerton's Agency, Detectives Reilly and Von Gerichten, of the District Attorney's Office, arrested, on a charge of influencing persons to register illegally, Henry Solomon, of No. 49 Pike-street, ...
BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 30, via Galveston.-- A squadron composed of the principal ships of the Argentine Navy will sail for the South Seas in November on a practice cruise.

The business men's Cleveland and Hendricks parade to-morrow promises to be so large that it is to be divided into two divisions. Gen. J. B. Woodward will command one and E.D. Neustadt the other. About 35 organizations are expected to take part. In addition to those that were in the last parade will be representatives, among others, of the paint and oil and pottery and glass trades.

John Peterson, the proprietor of the resort at No. 107 Chatham-street known as the Cambridge, who is accused of abducting 15-yearold Kittie Cavanagh, of Newark, N.J., was arrested and taken to the Tombs yesterday upon ...

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--The funeral services over the remains of the late Wilbur F. Storey were conducted at his late residence to-day. Considering the great celebrity he had won in his lifetime it was surprising to note that the attendance at the final scene was comparatively small, and was composed mainly of a few old personal friends and those connected with the ...
HAMBURG, Oct. 30.--The Hamburg-American Line steamship Moravia, Capt. Petzoldt, has sld. hence for New-York.

INDIANANOLIS, Ind., Oct. 30.--In the case of Andrew Koerner, sentenced to be hanged tomorrow for wife murder, Gov. Porter to-day granted a reprieve of 20 days. Koerner was convicted on circumstantial evidence, and the reprieve is granted to afford an opportunity for a more careful investigation of the case by the Governor.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 30.--Canada heard with satisfaction the news that the Senate of Mexico yesterday ratified the agreement between Great Britain and Mexico, and that the President approved it.

UTICA, N.Y., Oct. 30.--The Republicans had their final demonstration of the campaign here to-night. Chauncey M. Depew spoke to a large audience in the Utica Opera House, and a procession of torch bearers, with abundant fireworks and illuminations, kept the streets lively till nearly midnight. Clubs were present from Albany, Oneida, Watertown, Lowville, and several of the towns of Oneida County.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 30.--Twenty-nine prominent Republicans of this village have signed a ringing address, which was published in the Democrat this afternoon. It recounts the objections to Blaine, exposes the dangers that would ensue from his success, and pronounces Gov. Cleveland to be in every way worthy of support.

The decision of Judge White that under the law of Pennsylvania a physician must answer a summons from a court to appear and testify as an expert without remuneration has created a great deal of talk among professional men concerned.

Erastus Wiman has purchased in behalf of a syndicate of Staten Islanders the large field known as Camp Washington, and which is now leased to the Staten Island Cricket Club. The property was bought from the heirs of the late George Law. The price paid was $175,000.

From the Springfield (Mass.) Republican, Oct. 30. A few years ago Parson Adams secured for the Berkshire Historical Society the bedstead brought from Connecticut in 1752 by Solomon Deming and his wife, Sarah, who was the first white women in Pittsfield. He has now obtained the table used by them, which is over ...

BOSTON, Oct. 30.--Col. Whipple, who went to New-York to invite Mr. Blaine to come to Boston, telegraphs that the Republican Presidential candidate has consented to accept the hospitalities of the Republicans in this city on Monday. Elaborate preparations will be made for his reception. The parade which was to have taken place to-night has been postponed until Monday, when Mr. Blaine will review it.

Steinway Hall was crowded last evening at an enthusiastic mass meeting of the German Democratic Organization. It was called to order by ex-Judge Michael C. Gross, who said that the German element, which had always ranged itself on the side of honesty, would continue to do so, and had accordingly rallied round the standard of Cleveland, [applause,] the ...

At the offices of the Netherlands-American Steamship Company at No. 27 South William-street and No. 50 Broadway, it was stated yesterday afternoon that no further news from the Maasdam had been received.

Having, with the help of the heads of departments, become acquainted with the esti mates of the various departments and bureaus for the coming year, the Board of Estimate and Apportionment proceeded yesterday to chop them. The board began with the estimates for the legislative branch of the City Government, amounting to $86,250, and cut off $14,000 from Clerk Twomey's estimate of $35,000 for clerk hire and contingencies.

WEST CHESTER, Penn., Oct. 30.--In the Court of Quarter Sessions this afternoon George M. Rupert, Secretary and Treasurer of the Borough of West Chester and Treasurer of the Pennsylvania Mutual Fire Insurance Company of Chester County, entered a plea of guilty to the charge of having embezzled funds amounting to about $27,000 belonging to the above-named corporations. Sentence was deferred until Thursday next, and Rupert was remanded to jail.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 30.--Gov. O'Neal having accepted the resignation of Chief-Justice Robert C. Brickell, of the Alabama Supreme Court, and having promoted Associate Justice Stone to be Chief-Justice to-day appointed the Hon. David Clopton, of Montgomery, Associate Justice in the place of Judge Stone. Judge Clopton was a member of the Congress of 1859-60, and is one of the ablest lawyers in the Gulf States.

NORFOLK, Oct. 30.--With reference to a recent correspondence between Chairman Jones, of the Republican National Committee, and Candidate for Congress Evans, colored, in the Fourth District, asking Evans to withdraw from the contest in favor of Collector Brady, Mahone's nominee, Gov. Cameron said to-day to THE TIMES'S correspondent: " If the people ...

Some time ago the Police Commissioners requested Corporation Counsel Lacombe to advise them whether they have the power, under the civil rervice rules, to employ as uniformed policeman, with all the powers of such officers, for a probationary period of six months, ...
Valenciennes, in France, the native town of Watteau, the painter, has erected a monument to Watteau's memory. Bourg has paid a similar tribute to Joubert, the General of the Revolution.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Oct. 30.--The students at King's College, at Windsor, have rebelled, and demanded the dismissal of President Dart and Profs. Do Formentin and Butler. The original cause of trouble is said to be that Canon Dart treats them continually with contempt. The students burned him in effigy on the college grounds on Monday night. The college lectures have been suspended, and the students are idling about the town.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 30.--Some excitement was caused here to-night by the refusal of the Market Committee to allow Gov. Cameron to speak on Market-square. A city ordinance requires that permission shall be asked of the Market Committee by Political parties who desire to speak on Market-square. A stand had been erected without such permission, and the

Joseph Kopetzky, the candidate for Alderman in the Twenty-second District of the County Democracy and Citizens', workingmen's, and German organizations, denies the rumor that he has withdrawn from the contest.

From the New-Haven (Conn.) Palladium, Oct. 30. Mrs. Maria Rood, a thrice-married lady, of this city, who has resided at No. 42 Orangestreet, was again married on Monday. John Q. Walker, a Texan, is the fourth husband.

NO. 124 HICKS-STREET, BROOKLYN, N.Y. I am told that Stewart L. Woodford is stating that I wrote a letter to Mr. Garfield urging Mr. Blaine's appointment and indorsing his personal character. Mr. Woodford has been misinformed. No such letter was ever written by me. If any letter purporting to be mine, to that effect, is in existence, it is a forgery. H.W. BEECHER

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--C.D. Hoblitt Co., private bankers, at Canton, Ill., closed their doors about 9 o'clock this morning, posting a notice to the effect that financial embarrassments compelled them to do so. Mr. Hoblitt says the liabilities are very large and the assets very small, though he can give no figures.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 30.--The Dominion law, as it at present stands, in regard to international ferries has been found to work adversely to the interests of both the United States and Canada.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--The following NewYork telegram was received on 'Change to-day: "It is thought by careful observers here that the dinner given to Mr. Blaine last night by the leading monopolists of the East will cost the Republicans at least 30,000 votes of the laboring men in New-York, New-Jersey, and Connecticut which they had hoped to get."

Somebody connected with Tammany Hall is engaged in distributing bogus Cleveland Electoral tickets in this city. They contain the names of 6 Democratic Electors and 30 Republican Electors. They are being bunched with tickets bearing the name of Hugh J. Grant for Mayor.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Oct. 30.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Vermont and Canada Railroad was held here this morning, and the following Directors were elected: J.L. Mason, Richmond; J.P. Clark, Milton, and A. S. Hall, C.E. Billings, H.S. Hyde, T.H. Perkins, and Augustus Russ, of Boston. The special meeting of the stockholders called at the request of F.A. Brooks was adjourned to Nov. 26, on account of the absence of Mr. Brooks.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 30.--John P. Frank and Frederick Struck, the former a Justice of the Peaca, and the latter a constable, of Columbia, were to-day convicted of conspiracy to defraud the county by manufacturing cases at law.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 30.--The Scott Temperance act was carried to-day in the counties of Bruce, Ontario, by 1,000 majority; in Dufferin, Ontario, by 700 majority; in Huron, Ontario, by 1,500 majority; in York, NewBrunswick, (on the question for repeal,) by 300 majority; and was defeated in Prince Edward, Ontario, by 126 majority.

Thirty members of the City Reform Club gathered in Lyric Hall last evening and discussed the county ticket. The feeling of the club was almost unanimous in favor of the Hon. William R. Grace as the head of the city ticket. The Executive Committee made a report, in which it said:

HAVANA, Oct. 25.--It is said in official circles that Gen. Castillo, who lately resigned the Governor-Generalship of Cuba, will, by the request of the home Government, remain in office until the arrival of his successor, Gen. Fajardo, who is expected about Nov. 8 by one of the Spanish mail steamers.

Henry Ward Beecher and other speakers addressed an enthusiastic meeting of the Scandinavian independents in Irving Hall last night. Gen. C.T. Christensen presided, and on the platform with him, besides Mr. Beecher, were ex-Gov. Edward Salomon, Major Louis F. Hallen, Henry Willgohs. Dr. Henry J. Garrigan, Prof. Hjalmar H. Boyesen, Capt. C. E. Randrup, L. Ihlseng, F. Narvesen, C. F. Pautorpidan, F.O. Bockman, Hugo Smith, ...

BELLOWS FALLS, Vt., Oct. 30.--The Hon. Hiram Harlow, of Windsor, has resigned his office as President and Director of the National Bank to avoid the possible question of his eligibility as a Presidential Elector.
The people of the Territory of Montana are to vote next Tuesday upon the question of adopting a Constitution under which to ask admission as a State into the Union.

The Unitarians of New-England for many years have befriended the educational efforts of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, placing them under no small obligations. The Rev. Dr. William D. Johnson, of Athens, Ga., Secretary of Education of that ...

PARIS, Oct. 30.--An official dispatch from Gen. Briere de I'Isle, dated Hanoi, Oct. 29, says: "The garrison of Tunyen-Quan repulsed several attacks of the Chinese on the 14th and 19th insts. without loss. The enemy withdrew discouraged. The Governors of Yun-Nan and Liouvinc Phoe [?], have only 4,000 men on the Upper Red River. No Chinese are before Kept-Chu. Our columns are scouring the country near Yen. I am doing my best to suppress piracy."

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 30.--The Hendricks demonstration at Springfield last evening was continued until a late hour. The city was brilliantly illuminated, and it is estimated that 15,000 torches were in the procession at night. Mr. Hendricks in his speech said:

Two or three days ago two of BLAINE'S lieutenants and "workers" appeared in Washington, stopped there for a few hours, and then resumed their journey southward. It was said that North Carolina was their destination. One of these men was R.C. KERENS, of Arkansas and St. Louis, and the other was ex-Senator JEROME B. CHAFFEE, of Colorado and ...

BOSTON, Oct. 30.--A great meeting of business men, independents, and Democrats favoring Cleveland as against Blaine was held in Faneuil Hall it noon to-day. Though a heavy rainstorm prevailed, the hall was packed in every part, and the meeting was most enthusiastic from beginning to end. Upon the platform were leading independents ...

A few minutes before 1 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the frame stables at the rear of Henry Kiefer's brewery, which extends from 136 to 142 Scholes-street, Brooklyn. Thirteen horses were burned in the stables.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 30.--The third and last day's matches of the Southern Tier Rifle Association took place to-day. Many prominent marksmen from all parts of this State and Pennsylvania were present. The first event, Directors' match, distance 200 and 500 yards, five rounds at each, had 13 entries, and was won by P.B. Rutan, of Elmira; prize, gold medal.

HAVANA, Oct. 25.--The new theatre "Trijoa," only recently finished, will be sold at public auction, by order of the Treasury, because of the failure of the proprietor to pay two installments of the money due on the grounds, which were purchased from the Government.

A branch office of the Independent Committee's Nassau-street office has been opened at No. 177 Fifth-avenue, with an entrance at No. 947 Broadway. The committee in charge of it is composed of Charles P. Miller, George Haven Putnam, and Felix Kaufman. The city and county are receiving the attention of these gentlemen and of a large force of clerks.

VINCENNES, Ind., Oct. 30.--A lively shooting scrape occurred last evening at a political meeting at Edwarport, this county, where Senator Jones, of Kentucky, addressed the Democracy. William Atkinson, a miner, of evil disposition, attended, and being intoxicated got into a difficulty with one or two companions.

Officer Jordan, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, had his suspicions aroused on Oct. 24 by seeing three men enter No. 107 Washingtonstreet, each carrying a box of tobaco under his arm. The officer followed them, and met one of them returning, who said his name was Henry Miller and that he lived there.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 30.--Mr. George E. Hutchinson, of No. 847 Euclid-avenue, the owner of considerable mining property in the Western States and Territories, made an assignment this morning to Mr. James Parmelee. The cause of the failure is assigned to be the depreciation in the value of the property.

Gov. Robinson, of Massachusetts, has already issued his Thanksgiving proclamation, and is, apparently, the first of the Governors of the States to do so. He says: "In the solitude of the primeval forest, beset with privations and perils, the early settlers of this Commonwealth celebrated the first festival of thanksgiving to Almighty God, in recognition of his great goodness.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30.--The Protestant Episcopal Convention after taking 19 ballots during the present session, or 32 in all, including the balloting at the May session, seemed this afternoon as far from reaching the election of a Bishop to succeed the late Bishop Pinkney as at the beginning. After considerable discussion another conference committee was appointed, ...
Steamship Adriatic, (Br.,) Parsell, Liverpool via Queenstown 9 ds., with mdse. and passengers to R.J. Cortis.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 30.--Last Sunday Bishop O'Farrell, of this diocese, having just returned from Europe, addressed his congregation relative to the Pope's attitude on the relations of Ireland to England. This afternoon a cablegram from Rome was published, giving the Osservatore Romano's denial of the Bishop's alleged ...
John F. Plummer, the Republican nominee for Controller of this city, yesterday wrote the following letter accepting the nomination to Cornelius M. Bliss, of the nominating convention:

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 30.--The Republican manufacturers of this city are adopting the same tactics which they carried out during the Hancock campaign. At several of the potteries the workmen have been informed that if they did not vote for Blaine and Cleveland was elected, after election the potteries would be closed or run with half the complement of hands, and ...

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 30.--A Winnipeg, Manitoba, special says: "The first flogging ever witnessed in Manitoba took place to-day. John McCormick, who came here from Fargo some time ago, was convicted of larceny and sentenced on Tuesday to eight months' imprisonment.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 30.--The coal miners of the third pool, who recently returned to work at the reduction, held a mass meeting at Nelson's Hollow this afternoon, and decided, in view of the prospects of a rise, in the river and a possible shipment of coal to the lower markets, to strike for the district price. This action has encouraged the men in the first and second pools to remain out against the reduction.

Gov. Cleveland will be busy enough tomorrow afternoon and evening. In the afternoon he will review the business men and in the evening the monster parade of the Tammany Legion. Grand Marshal Thomas S. Brennan expects that at least 40,000 men will be in line.

NEW-BLOOMFIELD, Penn., Oct. 30.--The boiler of a steam thrasher on the farm of Daniel Wentz, of Jackson Township, Perry County, exploded this afternoon killing a young man named David Snyder. The barn was fired and consumed together with 3,400 bushels of grain and many farming implements. The building and its contents were insured for $1,700.
Ellon Dempsey, 45 years old, fell down a flight of stairs at her residence, No. 30 Madison-street, yesterday, and was instantly killed.

Rain and mud did not dampen the ardor of the Brooklyn independent Republicans last night, when their campaign committee of 100 held a mass meeting in the Brooklyn Rink. The doors of the building were thrown open at 7 o'clock, and in less than 15 minutes the body of the hall was nearly filled by those who had come early in order to make sure of good seats.

A familiar face will be missed from the stage and the concert room, and a voice that has charmed many thousand listeners is hushed forever. Pasquilino Brignoli, the well-known tenor and genial man of the world, passed away yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock. He died in a small room on the fourth floor of the Everett ...

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Oct. 30.--Gen. Butler reached here this evening, and was met at the depot by a large crowd. It was raining hard, and he took a carriage for the Opera House, which was filled with people when he arrived. The General was introduced by B.S. Warner, the People's Party candidate for the Assembly. Gen. Butler thanked the audience for coming out in the storm, and made his usual speech.
The following dispatch sent by Mr. Theodore Roosevelt advocating the election of Mr. William R. Grace for Mayor was received yesterday:

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct., 30.--The remains of the mammoth mastodon which were found by a party of workmen while engaged at work in a marl pit, on the property known as the late Dr. Audrews's farm, near Monroe, on Thursday last, have been the subject of discussion for several days past, and the bones thus far found have been looked upon by hundreds of curious people.

Among the additional names of prominent citizens and heads of firms who will vote for William R. Grace for Mayor and use their influence to secure his election are James C. Carter, President of the New-York Bar Association; President Barnard, of Columbia College: J. J. Stewart, bankers; John Jay Knox, ex-United ...

Mrs. Belinda, F. Burke, who was charged with complicity with Cornelius O'Leary, a clerk in the employ of Arnold, Constable Co., in swindling that firm out of several hundred dollars by means of fraudulent bills, was tried again ...

MONTREAL, Quebec, Oct. 30.--Judge Sicotte to-day condemned L.A. Senecal to pay $800 fine or undergo two years' imprisonment for having in the Vercheres election, in 1881, contributed considerable sums of money for election purposes.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--R. Power Palmer, of No. 4,514 Lake-avenue, was found dead in a room at the Revere House to-day. He was a partner in the insurance firm of H.J. Straight, Co., No. 150 La Salle-street, and is throught to have committed suicide. He went to the Revere House on Monday evening, and secured a room for the night, registering as R. Power.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Oct. 30.--The steamer Oceanic, which sailed to-day for Hong Kong, took 1,000 Chinese and $500,000 in coin.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 30.--Ex-Gov. Moses, of South Carolina, who is under arrest, charged with swindling the Rev. Dr. Rexford, the Rev. Mr. Atterbury, and others, attempted suicide this morning by hanging himself in his cell. Mr. Moses was brought into the Police Court this afternoon and charged with swindling. He pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to three months in the House of Correction. His lawyer hopes to effect his transfer to an insane asylum.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30.--Another brave man besides James Carr lost his life in the burning of the Culver Block yesterday. The charred body of Joseph L. Diven, aged 32 years, married, and living at Moreland, was recovered from the ruins this afternoon. He was in charge of the printing department of W.E. Fisher's cigar box factory, on the fifth floor, and second in command of the establishment.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Oct. 30.--Tom De Witt, a locomotive engineer, noted all over the North for daring exploits, died at his home in Susquehanna this morning. De Witt was a man who, in the latter part of 1869, in the railroad war on the Albany Road, ran an Erie engine ...

The severe storm and muddy roads did not prevent over a thousand Germans from assembling last evening at Pohlman's Hotel, on Jersey City Heights, to listen to a speech by the Hon. Carl Schurz. He arrived somewhat late, but was greeted with the most enthusiastic applause. Mr. Schurz said that it was not possible to weigh the great importance of the approaching election.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 30.--The coal breaker at Kaska William Colliery, on Big Vein, was destroyed by fire to-night. Loss, $25,000. The colliery is owned by the Alliance Coal Com pany, of which Cooper, Hewitt Co., of NewYork, are the principal owners. The fire is believed to be of an incendiary origin. Several hundred men will be thrown out of employment.

Among the passengers that arrived yesterday by the steamer St. Germain were a number of French priests, I'Abbe Zieelenbach, I'Abbe Boulard, I'Abbe Chapel, I'Abbe Crouzet, I'Abbe Simon, I'Abbe Prouzet, I'Abbe Veysset, I'Abbe Fayot, and I'Abbe Duchaussoy.
We are permitted to copy the following from a private letter to a gentleman in this city from a lady who left Buffalo on the 8:50 Erie Railroad train on Monday morning:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 30.--At a meeting of the stockholders of the Columbus Baseball Club this evening the proposition of the Pittsburg Club to pay $6,000 for the transfer of players was accepted. This action was taken owing to the small chance for Columbus to remain in the American Association next year, since the disbandment of the Toledo Club.

Frederick Burt, of No. 203 East Eleventh-street, was arraigned at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on the complaint of Edward F. Hauff, a butcher, of No. 74 Thirdavenue, and Officer George Grace, of the Seventeenth Precinct, who had him in charge, asked for a remand.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 30, via Galveston.-- The House this afternoon passed an amendment to the Constitution making the District of Tepic a State. The amendment is now ready for the approval of the Executive.

George McVeatty, of No. 470 Secondstreet, Jersey City, was arraigned on his daughter's charge of having murdered his wife by setting fire to her, in Justice Stilsing's Police Court yesterday morning. A large number of witnesses, who were sworn, testified that when Mrs. McVeatty ran from her apartments, screaming pitifully, and her clothing ablaze, she declared that her husband had poured oil upon her and applied a match to her garments.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 30.--In a friendly scuffle here this afternoon between Robert D. Gentry and Charles Saunders over the possession of a gun to shoot at a mark, the weapon was discharged and the contents entered Gentry's head, killing him instantly. Both men were under the influence of liquor.

A Boston broker "left" a couple of confidence men very neatly the other day. They urged the broker to go around to a house of their selection to play cards, and in their anxiety to bag their game they loaned him $75 to begin playing with. The broker was taken with violent cramps after he had bet $10 and succeeded in getting outside with the other $65 in his pocket.

WADY-HALFA, Oct. 30.--Gen. Wolseley has reached Dahi with his detachment. The hospital corps is forming six camps on the route to Dongola for the use of the troops traversing the Nile. The camel corps has been divided into heavy and light marching regiments and squads. Mounted infantry regiments are forming, and the Fourth Regiment, which has been mounted, has started for the front.

A meeting of lawyers of this city who are in favor of the election of Cleveland and Hendricks was held in the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broadway, yesterday afternoon. It was a notable assemblage in size and enthusiasm, as well as in the character of the men who composed it.
We dare say that the Hon. David Davis was induced to indorse Blaine, just as the late Mr. Stephens, in the goodness of his heart, recommended every patent medicine except "Anti-Fat."

The Central Division Wholesale Dry Goods Cleveland and Hendricks Club held its daily meeting at its headquarters, the Manhattan Hotel, yesterday afternoon. It resolved to act as district committees at the polls on Tuesday next and give the entire day to aid in getting an honest expression of the people.

The cut on passenger rates to Chicago and intermediate points has reached a critical point, from which it is likely soon to turn to ruinous slashing or to an advance to something like the former tariff. Under an agreement between the ticket scalpers and the several roads the scalpers for a fortnight past have been maintaining regular rates for western travel as far as Chicago.

BERLIN, Oct. 30.--" Unser Fritz," Crown Prince of Germany, has become Regent of Brunswick. The title of Duke has been dropped. The Prince's eldest son will succeed to the Regency when his father becomes Emperor of Germany.
Since old Jubal Early got into the lottery business the Yankees who fell into his hands have fared harder than ever.

Twenty-six years ago Samuel G. Simpson, who was then employed in Dubois's jewelry factory, was cutting a piece of gold from a breastpin, when the piece suddenly flew upward, cutting a deep slit in his eye. Although the accident was not painful the sight of the injured organ was destroyed.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct, 30.--The Chamber of Commerce, by a unanimous vote, decided not to hold a session next Tuesday--election day.

The old quarrel in Dr. Newman's church has broken out again, though the Pastor is far away in California. On Tuesday William Ives Washburn, the attorney of Trustee Hopkins, Dr. Ranney, and that faction of the church which is opposed to Dr. Newman, obtained an order from Chief-Justice Sedgwick, of the Superior Court, to show cause why Dr. Newman should not be restrained from acting as Pastor of the church.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 30.--Gov. Cleveland, accompanied by Private Secretary Lamont and Adjt.-Gen. Farnsworth, drove from the Executive Mansion in a close carriage shortly before 10 o'clock this morning to the Boston and Albany Railroad station, where they took the regular train for Pittsfield. There was no demonstration of any sort, in accordance with Gov. Cleveland's expressed desire.

READING, Penn., Oct. 30.--A slight sensation was produced this morning when several witnesses who were testifying before the Almshouse Investigating Committee brought out the fact that the Rev. Mr. Fritch, Pastor of the poorhouse, had a four-mule team load of coal hauled to his residence, the coal being taken from the bin in the almshouse yard. The reverend gentleman was also the recipient of stores and bay from the poorhouse farm.

Guardiola Co., Cuban sugar planters, chartered the brig Georgia some time ago, to ship to this port a cargo of sugar. The cargo was insured for $41,000 in the Insurance Company of North America.

BOSTON, Oct. 30.--The Rev. James Freeman Clarke, in a letter to the press, says that he is confirmed in his conviction that the accusations of gross and habitual immorality brought against Gov. Cleveland constitute one of the basest slanders ever invented for political purposes.

One day last week a negro man who was at work in a field on Mr. M.M. Sims's plantation on Fishing Creek, heard his dog barking for some time in a clump of bushes in the swamp. The man went to see what it was when he saw his dog run up and jump back several times, and finally discovered that it was a large red fox at bay.

When he was nominated his hysterical organs proclaimed that the ticket was going "to sweep the country like a cyclone." His letter of acceptance marked him as "the first statesman of his time."

HAMILTON, Ontario, Oct. 30.--Dr. Carver's visit with a company of cowboys to this city set all the small boys to lassoing. The result is that a small boy named John Carey was lassoed by his companions and dragged along the ground for some distance, receiving such injuries that he died soon after.

Wednesday's efforts were so exhausting that Mr. Blaine did not rise yesterday until the morning was well advanced. Cards sent to his room were returned with the answer that he could not be seen. There were, however, no callers of prominence except Deacon White, of Plymouth Church.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 30.--Rumors have reached here of the lynching by vigilantes of a gang of 17 cattle thieves, who were captured while in camp on Rock Creek, in the Gore range mountains, 20 or 30 miles west of Georgetown. The report is thought to be exaggerated.

The Hon. Frank D. Currier, of Canaan, Secretary of the Republican State Committee of New-Hampshire, has completed arrangements for getting home absent Republican voters. The system adopted in this campaign for that object is more thorough and comprehensive than ever before.

It was accompanied with instructions to keep the fact as secret as possible, and to distribute the funds only at such points in the interior of the State where money is an absolute necessity.

READING, Penn., Oct. 30.--Charles B. Ross, who has charge of the upper ferry across the Schuylkill River, noticed a dark object floating with the current about 9 o'clock this morning. His suspicions being aroused, he procured a boat and pushed into the river just as the floating object lodged against the rope spanning the stream.

LONDON, Oct. 30.--In the House of Commons to-day the motion granting precedence over all other business to the Franchise bill was adopted without debate.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 30.--When I called upon Chairman Bingham, the official head of the Butler party, having his office in New-Haven, to find out where the Butler vote was in the State, he admitted that Butler was not strong in NewHaven. "Go to Bridgeport, Norwalk, Danbury. He is very strong in those places, particularly in Danbury."

"Der Veilchenfresser," a comedy by Moser, was acted at the Thalia Theatre last evening. The company is at its best in light and racy works of this sort, and some excellent performances were enjoyed during the progress of the piece, in which Frau Schamberg and Herren Hitzigrath and Stockel were particularly prominent.

BUFFALO, Oct. 30.--The Blaine "business men" of this city paraded this afternoon, and afterward there was a Blaine meeting addressed by the Hon. Sherman S. Rogers, the Hon. E. G. Spaulding, and others. The whole performance suggests to many minds the desperation of the declining Blaine cause hereabout.

LONDON, Ontario, Oct. 31.--George Dingman, a clerk in the drug store of F.W. Meek Co., at Mount Brydges, who gave strychnine instead of santorine, which mistake caused the death of two little girls, has been found guilty of manslaughter at the Assizes here.

All doubts as to the safety of the passengers and crew of the burned steamship Maasdam were removed yesterday morning when the North German Lloyd steamship Rhein entered Quarantine. The latter vessel had on board the entire crew and all of the passengers of the burned vessel.

While BLAINE will have at the polls the support of many honest but misguided men, his most effective support both in the convention at Chicago and in the campaign has come from a gang of conspirators who are interested in gigantic schemes of plunder.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31.--Gen. Logan visited this city to-day and reviewed a procession gotten up in his honor, which was so small as to be a disappointment to the Republican managers. Later he spoke in favor of a high tariff and waved the bloody shirt vigorously, appealing to the soldiers to vote for him and not go over to the Democrats.

LIMA, Ohio, Oct. 31.--Ben Heffner, a farmer living near Westminster, yesterday shot and killed his wife and attempted to kill his son, daughters and daughter-in-law. He was arrested late in the day and brought here. Physicians will examine him as to his mental condition.
It was decided last night to hold the funeral services of the late Signor Brignoli in Father McDowell's church, Forty-third-street, betweeen Lexington and Third avenues.

The gold medal presented to the widow and children of John Brown is to be taken from the bank in San Jose, where it has been lying for some time, and sent to Owen Brown, of Put-inBay Island, Lake Erie, Ohio. Owen was the only son of John Brown who escaped from Harper's Ferry and took an earnest part in his father's work of freeing slaves. He is now an old man.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 31.--The Herald Publishing Company were robbed to-day of between $600 and $700 by means of the old and seemingly played out confidence game. About noon a man entered the counting room and asked to look over the files.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Oct. 31.--The Hon. C. V.R. Ludington, candidate for Controller on the Republican State ticket in 1877 and a straight Republican from the foundation of the party, announces his intention to vote for Cleveland.

Sara B. Chase, a physician and lecturer, owns No. 614 Seventh-avenue, which is tenanted by Eliza B. Skinner, widow of Otis Skinner. Recently Dr. Chase, on returning from a lecturing tour, received a letter written by Samuel R. Preston, an agent, of No. 201 West Thirty-fourthstreet.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 31.--The Democrats of the Second Assembly District of Monroe County to-night nominated James P. Tumilty.

SOCORRO, New-Mexcio, Oct. 31.--A passenger train last evening, when nearing Escondido, four miles north of here, on the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad, was fired into by a band of masked men, and one woman was shot. The town is up in arms over the affair. Sheriff Simpson and 50 armed men have started in pursuit of the highwaymen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31.--The extension of leave of absence granted First Lieut, James R. Cranston, Regimental Quartermaster, Tenth Infantry, in special orders of Sept. 22, has been still further extended to Dec. 31. Leave of absence for six months, with permission to go beyond the sea, has been granted to Capt. Charles S. Ilsley, Seventh Cavalry.

Fletcher. In error to the Circuit Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana. Docketed and dismissed with costs.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 31.--The Grand Jury at the Carleton Assizes, in making their presentment to-day, expressed themselves strongly against the practice of confining lunatics in jails.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31, 1884. It is estimated that the decrease in the public debt for the month of October is about $250,000.
