About 100 years ago Juan Oxio first called attention to the vast source of wealth concealed in the mud which lay at the bottom of the waters of the Gulf of California adjacent to the eastern coast of Lower California. He discovered there immense beds of the pearl oyster and realized great wealth.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 31.--J. Hendrix McLane, in the First District, and A.G. Johnson, in the Fifth District, both independent candidates for Congress, have withdrawn from the contest, leaving one Democrat and one Republican candidate in each district--namely W. N. Taft in the First and C.C. MacCoy in the Fifth.

MOBILE, Ala., Oct. 31.--Some days ago Frank Ray was tried at Houston, Miss., for killing William Pate by hitting him on the head with a light stick.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 31.--Daniel C. Kiser, one of the most prosperous business men in Southwest Virginia, rode out on his farm, near Bousack, to-day, and cut his throat with a razor. The cause of the suicide is unknown.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Oct. 31.--The Connelly polygamy case was dismissed this afternoon by the United States Attorney. He said that the testimony differed so radically from that before the Grand Jury that he was astounded. The most glaring perjury had attended the evidence here given.

Bail in $1,000 was given by Charles W. Stevens, a butcher, of No. 49 Jamesstreet. More arrests are expected to follow today.

BOSTON, Oct. 31.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day Stephen G. Russell was convicted of gilding English silver coins. The defendant claims that the gilding was not done with criminal intent, but for customers in the prosecution of his business.

After sleeping upon the provisional estimates agreed upon by items Thursday night some of the members of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment concluded yesterday morning to revise certain of their decisions.

ALBANY, Oct. 31.--Gov. Cleveland and party arrived here from Connecticut at 9:45 this morning. The Governor at once resumed his executive duties. To-morrow morning he leaves for New-York to review the business men's parade to-morrow evening. He goes to Buffalo on Monday to vote, returning to Albany on Tuesday night.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Oct. 31.--Last night Dominick Hope and Charles Dougherty, of Brownsville, quarreled while drinking in Mattoon's saloon, and Dougherty drew from his pocket a large dirkknife and threatened to pierce Hope with it.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 31.--Ike Fain, colored, was hanged at Langston at 10 o'clock to-day for the murder of James Curren, section boss on the Cincinnati Southern Railroad, on March 29 last.
LONDON, Oct. 31.--Chinese advices state that the blocking of the Woosung River, on which Shanghai stands, and the massing of troops in the vicinity of Shanghai and Pekin are still going on.
ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 31.--President White delivered his annual address before the students of Cornell University to-day.

During the past month Mr. Jerome Hopkins has visited most of the schools of NewYork, Brooklyn, Jersey City, and Hoboken, with a view of securing the aid of the children in furtherance of his purpose of giving concerts to defray the cost of the Baltholdi statue pedestal.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 31.--Six weeks ago there was no doubt about New-Jersey's Electoral vote. The Democrats were confident, and the Republicans were hopeless. There was a general concensus of opinion that New-Jersey is a Democratic State, and that this year would prove no exception to Presidential years that had gone before.
QUINCY, Ill., Oct. 31.--Joseph Schatzer, a young man of Fowler, Ill., in this county, came here yesterday and sold a horse for $175.

Considerable comment has been excited by the sentences imposed in the Passaic County courts, at Paterson, this term. Henry Lehr, convicted of killing a lad who trespassed on a melon patch, was sentenced to four years in State prison.

FARMERSVILLE, La., Oct. 31.--The jury in the case of Perry Melton and his son William, on trial for the murder of J. W. Cherry, near Spearsville, last April, to-day returned a verdict of guilty, fixing the penalty at death.

In a few rare cases the vintage in the Medoc has commenced to-day, but it will be only after Sunday that the gathering will become general. Proprietors are shivering with apprehension, as recent chilly mornings have warned them that Summer is over and the weather therefore most uncertain.
LONDON, Oct. 31.--Mrs. Weldon, the famous litigant, has been committed to prison for contempt of court.

By his will the late Samuel Willets bequeathed one-fifth of his estate of $8,000,000 to a granddaughter. In a codicil he revoked the bequest. After his death his granddaughter began a contest of the codicil.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 31.--GeorgeSmith, charged with the murder of Henry Struck, in Columbia, on Oct. 15, 1883, this morning, while the jury was being impaneled, withdrew his plea of not guilty and entered a plea of guilty of murder in the second degree.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31.--The gossips of the Stock Exchange to-day thought they saw in the retirement of L. A. Robertson from the Reading management and the election in his place of F.A. Comly evidence that Mr. Vanderbilt had no longer any interest in the Reading Company.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31.--Mr. Hendricks came home from Shelbyville last evening, where he spoke to several thousand people during the afternoon.
CAIRO, Oct. 31.--A dispatch from Sarass reports that a Canadian voyageur named Louis has been drowned there in the Nile.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Oct. 31.--The United States Grand Jury has indicted Lieutenants of Police Michael Mullen and John Burke and Patrolmen Keating and Cunningham on the charge that "by force, threats, and intimidation they prevented qualified voters from exercising the right of suffrage."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 31.--Preston D. Jones, proprietor and editor of the Sunday Dispatch of this city, was found dead in his room in the Girard House this morning, the result of an apoplectic attack.

Mr. William H. Vanderbilt is suffering from a severe cold and a billious attack. He was out driving on Wednesday, but the bad weather of yesterday and the day before kept him indoors. He was suffering no serious discomforts last evening.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 31.--Near here yesterday Tom Phillips, colored, was shot and killed by William Harris, a white man. Harris became offended because Phillips addressed him familiarly as "Harris." Phillips replied that he required the same formality of Harris as demanded by him. A difficulty ensued, which terminated fatally for Phillips. The murderer escaped.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 31.--The composition meeting in the matter of F. Shaw Brothers, under the act of composition passed by the last Legislature, was held at East Cambridge on Thursday. Nearly $3,000,000 of claims were offered for proof, which indicates that the creditors desire a composition as offered by the firm.

IROQUOIS, Dakota, Oct. 31.--D.P. Greely, agricultural implements, has made an assignment. He succeeded Dean Greely in December last, had a capital invested of $3,000, besides which he owned some outside property and was considered worth about $10,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31.--About two weeks ago J. J. Baillie, a bookkeeper in the employ of the National Bank of America, was discharged for drunkenness and gambling propensities.

TORONTO, Oct. 31.--James Holmes and William Bracken, who were arrested a year ago with dynamite in their possession, which, it was suspected, was intended for a fiendish purpose, and who were sentenced in the Spring to six months' imprisonment, were released from jail to-day.

The broad thoroughfare that forms the lower part of Wall-street was blockaded yesterday afternoon by a large and compact multitude of voters, who sent up frequent and enthusiastic cheers for Cleveland and Hendricks. Fully 6,000 persons joined in this great demonstration, which was conducted by the Down-town Merchants' Cleveland and Hendricks Club.

SCRANTON, Penn., Oct. 31.--Col. Henry M. Boies, the Republican delegate to Chicago and President of the Dickson Manufacturing Company, has published a trenchant letter in tonight's Scranton Truth, denouncing the candidacy of J.A. Scranton, the Republican nominee for Congress.

Within the past three months William H. Vanderbilt has presented considerable property to his relatives on Staten Island. The old Simonson homestead, at Clifton, which belonged to a sister of the wife of Commodore Vanderbilt, has been deeded back again to her.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Oct. 31--Joshua Stoner, confined here on a charge of passing counterfeit money, was to-day bailed out by his brother. Rilley Stoner. Soon afterward a telegram was received from Jeffersonville stating that dies and other counterfeiting apparatus had been found in Rilley Stoner's house, and he was arrested.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 31.--The all-absorbing topic of conversation on the streets to-day was the independent Republicans' appeal to the voters of Ithaca. It was a genuine surprise and carried dismay into the Blaine camp.

Mrs. Sarah E. Gardner, of No. 419 West Forty-fifth-street, is the widow of ex-Police Justice Gardner, who died about two months ago. John Bierum, a Dane, was hired to nurse her husband during his illness, and was retained in the house after his death.

The Peter Donnelly Light Guards, of Jersey City, have made arrangements to serenade THE TIMES on Monday evening. The object, writes the Captain, Charles D.J. Noelke, is "to show our appreciation of the stand you have pursued to stem the tide of corruption in the Republican Party and for supporting NewJersey's favorite son, Grover Cleveland."

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 31.--Prof. H. P. Wright, Dean of the Senior Class, has offcially announced that there will be no more annual examinations in Yale. The Faculty unanimously voted such a course advisable, and though the corporation has not yet approved it, their sanction to the Faculty's action is a mere form and follows as a matter of course.

GIRARDSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 31.--This afternoon, while three Hungarians named George Kraposks, John Mollenwitz, and John Unglovitch were cutting coal in a mine breach near Centralia, a huge rock above them fell, fatally injuring all of them.

LONDON, Oct. 31.--The editors of Charles Dickens's correspondence have discovered his diary, which contains his directions upon the conduct of the Daily News while he was its editor. The subjects of the leaders are noted down with instructions as to the manner of their treatment.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 31.--The Convention of Christian Workers, led by Moody and Sankey, began here in Mechanics' Hall this afternoon. The proceedings were opened witha prayer and praise service, led by H. M. Moore, of Boston.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 31.--A telegram from Parrsborough states that the schooner Harry Morris, of that port, is ashore at Eatonville in a badly damaged condition. The vessel is of 98 tons burden and is two years old.

UTICA, Oct. 31.--A gentleman who has just returned from a thorough canvass of Herkimer, Otsego, and Oneida Counties said to-day that the strength of the silent vote on Tuesday would be a surprise to politicians who have been claiming an overwhelming majority in those counties for Mr. Blaine.

MADISON, Ind., Oct. 31.--The Democrats had a street parade numbering 1,600 men this afternoon, and to-night a second parade with 700 torches in line. The city was gayly illuminated, cannon were fired, and there was an abundance of enthusiasm and shouting for Cleveland and Hendricks.

One explanation of this anomaly is that without New-York Blaine may be elected, but Cleveland must have the State to win.

Mme. Adelina Patti arrived from Europe last evening in the Cunard steamship Oregon. The Oregon arrived at the bar early in the afternoon, but was detained there several hours for want of water to cross, so that she did not arrive at Quarantine until a few minutes after sundown, and consequently was too late to come up to the city.

"The Catholic Church and Political Life" was the subject chosen by Mgr. Capel, at the Cathedral, last evening. The reverend gentleman showed that the Catholic Church, by the doctrine she preached of obedience to those in power, was a living model of duty. Nowhere in the world was there a more open field for her than in the United States.

As a step in the execution of a carefully thought out plan of M. Tricoupis for raising Greece to a more assured position among the maritime powers of Europe, the launch of the Alpheos at Blackwall yesterday from the dockyard of the Thames Ironworks and Shipbuilding Company is an event of interest.
The platform of the Thirty-seventhStreet Methodist Church was covered with palms and flowers yesterday at the services in commemoration of the founding of the church 33 years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2.--More than 2,000 employes of the Government and a large number of Washingtonians who have retained legal residences in their home States have already left to vote for President on Tuesday. Enough remain, however, to make the interest in the election evident to the most casual observer. Nothing else is talked or thought about.

One of the Bates College boys who is at home in Massachusetts writes that he has recently applied for registration. He was asked his business and replied that he was a student in the Senior Class of Bates College, in Lewiston, Me. "Can you read?" was asked; "Yes," was the reply. He was required to read from the Constitution and write his name. Members of his own family were on the Registration Board.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 2.--A special to the News from Brackett, Texas, says: "Last night Peter Johnson, clerk in a store in a village near here, was assassiaated, and the store was robbed. The Sheriff is in pursuit of the murderers."

CHICAGO, Nov. 2.--Election betting in the cool rooms was quite active yesterday. Other standing bets are $100 to $90 that Blaine carries Indiana; even money that Cleveland carries ...

It is computed that once every 30 years, since the appearance of Chapman's translation beloved of poets, a metrical or prose translation of Homer has been printed in English. Of late the average has increased far beyond the normal ratio. Three versions of the "Odyssey" appeared in 1861-2, two in 1869, Bryant's in 1872, two in 1879, two in 1880.

CHARLESTON, S.C. Nov. 2.--United States Marshal Tuomey has appointed 36 Deputy Marshals for service at the polls in Charleston on Tuesday, and has made up an additional list of 361 deputies who will be commissioned to-morrow for service at country precincts throughout the State.
PARIS, Nov. 2.--The decision of the court in the Patti divorce case will be given Nov. 7. The court will grant a divorce on the demand of the Marquis de Caux.

Fathers Donnovan and Lavelle as deacon and sub-deacon, and the Rev. James W. Kelly master of ceremonies. The sermon was delivered by the Rev. Edward S. YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 2.--Last September Charles Helb, of Cincinnati, came here, representing himself to be an iron broker. By a frequent and obtrusive exhibition of some money, many checks, and alleged contracts he led people to believe him to be wealthy and highly connected.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 2. The Danner Land and Lumber Company made an assignment on Friday afternoon to J.C. Strong, the company's Secretary and Treasurer. The debts amount to $70,000. The nominal assets are $250,000.

Curtin and James K.P. Hall, both Democratic candidates for Congress in the Twentieth District, it was agreed, in the interest of harmony, and to save the district, that Hall be withrdawn, and that Curtin be the only Democratic candidate, thus assuring his re-election.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 2.--A quartermile race between Mr. Hudson, of Oshawa, and T. Moffatt, of Montreal, for a purse of $1,000, was won easily by Hudson. Time--0:51. Considerable money changed hands on the result.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 2.--Counsel for Dr. Richmond, convicted of manslaughter on Thursday last, has moved for a new trial. The motion will be argued in a few days.

The French chorus singer was in a state of violent mental agitation when she reached her apartments at 11 o'clock on Saturday evening. More than this, her usually neat appearance had given place to an exterior of confusion and dishevelment. Her bonnet was pushed away, her shoes were mud-bespattered, and the fascinating bang hung limp and tangled.

CHATHAM, Ontario, Nov. 2.--Lord Lansdowne returned this evening from St. Ann's Island, where he has had a successful week's duck shooting. He will be presented with an address to-morrow morning by the Mayor and corporation, after which he leaves for the East.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 2.--Frank P. Davis has mysteriously disappearod from his home, at Halford's Landing, on the Genesee River, just north of the city line. His wife is seriously ill with a broken leg. She has three small children. The family was found by a neighbor in a starving condition. Davis is a drinking man, and it is thought that he has been drowned in the canal or river.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2.--The commission appointed at the last session of Congress to visit Mexico and the countries of Central and South America in the interest of the commerce of the United States expect to leave New-York on the 10th inst. for the city of Mexico. Thence they will go to San Francisco, where the business men of that city will be heard on the trade with the southern countries.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 2.--Augustus Eason owned a large farm near Hickory Ground, in this county. Last week he posted notices forbidding all persons from trespassing on the same. Yesterday Frank Williams and Abram Johnson attempted to drive a horse and cart across the farm and Eason objected and said they should not do it. They thereupon shot him, killing him instantly. Williams and Johnson, who were negroes escaped.

ALBANY, Nov. 2.--The close of the Presidential campaign finds Gov. Cleveland and his friends confident of winning next Tuesday. Reports received here from the States which are considered doubtful indicate that New-York, New-Jersey, and Nevada will surely go Democratic.

Felix McCabe, 11 years old, while crossing the street car track in Meeker-avenue, Brooklyn, last night, was run over by a Grand-Street and Newtown Railroad car. The wheels passed over his body, killing him almost instantly. The body was taken to his father's home, No. 117 Meekeravenue, and the driver and conductor of the car were arrested.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 2.--While Annie Smisson, 13 years old, was on her way to the village store at Northwest Canal, Norfolk County, yesterday, she was set upon by a negro named John Henderson and feloniously assaulted. Hendorson choked her until she was nearly unconscious. Some hunters in the neighborhood, hearing the girl's cries, gave chase to Henderson and fired four shots at him, but he escaped.

J.R.M. Hernz, of New-York, and D.A. Avery, of Monticello, killed two in one day near Black Lake, in the latter county.

Gault, member of Parliament, ex-President of the bank, for $105,000, overdrawn by Thomas Craig during Gault's Presidency, and the other against E.K. Greene, a Director, for $16,000 overdrawn to satisfy the City District Savings Banks for a claim against Thomas Craig, which had been assumed by Greene and George W. Craig.

The Crown Prince of Austria is having some very rare sport--elk hunting in Eastern Prussia. It may interest your readers to hear something of the country and the sport in question. In the Memel delta, between the mouths of the rivers Russ and Gilge, is situated the royal domain and hunting station of Ibenhorst.

OVID, N.Y., Nov. 3.--Only the newspapers supporting Blaine reached here this morning, and none of the Cleveland journals were received. The New-York Tribune, the Rochester Democrat, and the Elmira Advertiser came promptly, while THE NEW-YORK TIMES, World, and Herald, and the Syracuse Courier failed to reach their subscribers.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 3.--A young woman with a strikingly good complexion, and wearing an extremely tight black jersey, sat today in Judge Arnold's Common Pleas Court, just where the sunlight streaming through the freshly scrubbed window panes could strike upon her intensely yellow bangs.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 3.--This afternoon Marion Beard, age 28, was instantly killed at the Locust Point Dry Dock. He was engaged in blocking up the iron hull of the burned steamboat B.S. Ford, which turned over and caught him under it.

The Hon. Robert T. Lincoln, Secretary of War and the eldest son of the martyred President, was in St. Louis yesterday. He came here to testify in the case of David Thomas, alias Dobey, charged with collecting money from his colored friends under pretense of being a United States Pension Agent.
The Hon. R.J. Bright, of Indianapolis, sent the following dispatch yesterday to the National Democratic Committee:
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 3.--Seventeen prisoners were arraigned in the United States Court to-day charged with violating election laws. One of them was Thomas Cogan, a member of the Ohio Legislature.

Lottie Francis, age 13, of Jamaica, Long Island, who some days ago borrowed her father's pocket knife and cut her throat with intent to commit suicide, died yesterday. Her mind became affected, it is said, by domestic troubles between her parents and her grandfather.
Miss Fanny Davenport is at the Everett House.

BOSTON, Nov. 3.--Butler have his dying political gasp to-day, speaking at Natick and Marlborough. He said if he had remained at his profession he could have made $5 for each $1 he had made working for Blaine and Logan.

Shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday Christian Schaffer, a tinsmith of this city, went into the refining room of the Miners' Oil Company, at Seventh-street and West-avenue, Hunter's Point, for the purpose of repairing an oil tank. He carried his soldering pot, filled with burning charcoal, with him.

In response to an offer of 3 per cent. stock and bonds of the city of New-York aggregating $1,290,000 the Controller yesterday received bids amounting to $5,377,600. The successful bidders, with the amount of stock and bonds awarded them, were as follows: A syndicate composed of Vermilye Co., Blake Brothers Co., and George K. Sistare's Sons.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 3.--Vice-Chancellor Simrall, in the case of W.H. Delaney and others asking for an injunction against the city of Louisville to restrain it from collecting taxes owing to an alleged flaw in the tax law of the State, to-day refused to grant an injunction. The amount involved was about $100,000,000, and the decision makes necessary the payment of taxes long withheld by certain citizens.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 3.--At a trial heat at the Fair Grounds this afternoon Maud S. trotted a mile in 2:13 . If all the conditions are favorable on Thursday she will then trot to lower her record.

There was a notable gathering at Roslyn, Long Island, yesterday afternoon, to commemorate the birth of the poet William Cullen Bryant, by planting trees on the village green. These trees were grown at Cedarmere, the poet's country ...

ABILENE, Kan., Nov. 3.--Henry Pigorsch, a German farmer of this county, was killed yesterday by John Sweeney, a railroad laborer. Sweeney and others were hunting on Pigorsch's farm, when the latter came out with a gun and warned them off. Sweeney thereupon wrested the gun from Pigorsch and beat him to death with it. Officers are in pursuit of the murderer.

Little Lizzie Engelman, the child who was found by J.M. Jarvis, of Williamsburg, in Lutheran Cemetery with a handkerchief tied around her throat Saturday afternoon, was playing in the rooms of Assistant Superinvendent David Avenuis yesterday as happily as if she had lived there all her life.

BOSTON, Nov. 3.--Chief Supervisor Hallett is busy to-day issuing warrants for the arrest of illegal voters, to be served if they cast ballots to-morrow. The Supervisors in their canvass have found a large number of disqualified persons upon the voting lists in various places, including Boston, and if they vote many of them will be arrested at the polls and at once arraigned.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 3.--Private dispatches received in this city from San Francisco report the arrival there yesterday of the whaling steamer Thrasher. She reports the total catch of the fleet to be 180 whales. The season is icy and cold.

All the hotels and betting resorts up town were thronged last night with crowds of loungers and sporting men, apparently anxious to employ the few remaining hours before election in staking their money upon the result of the great contest which ends to-day.

PANAMA, Oct. 25.--The meeting of the Presidents of Honduras, Salvador, and Guatemala terminated most amicably, yet all appear convinced that the results obtained have not promoted the much desired formation of a Central American Federation.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 3.--The interview with Mr. C.B. Lockwood, the life-long friend of the late President Garfield, published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, in which he states that Blaine was not Garfield's friend, has created much comment throughout Northern Ohio.

LONDON, Nov. 4.--The Times's Alexandria correspondent states that upon careful inquiry he learns that the report of the fall of Khartoum originated from the following source, and gives it for what it is worth.

M. Victor Julien, a well-known merchant at Marseilles and a special friend of M. Paul do Cassagnae, has lately committed suicide under circumstances of a very painful character. M. Julien was a confirmed invalid, and had nearly lost the use of his legs.

Funeral services over the body of Pasquilino Brignoli, the famous tenor singer, who died last Thursday, were held yesterday morning, and the remains were placed in the receiving vault of the Marble Cemetery, in Seventh-street, until the brother and sister of the dead man who are in Paris, decide upon a burial place.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 3.--The Blaine Republicans in their desperation have appointed 160 Deputy United States Marshals to control the polling places here to-morrow.
Mr. Lowell M. Palmer, a large barrel manufacturer of Brooklyn, has addressed a communication to his workmen declaring his intention of voting for Cleveland and Hendricks.
Some enthusiastic gentleman has written a book to show "How to Live on a Shilling a Week," or, to put it another way, "How Not to Live on a Shilling a Week."

Charles A. Payne, alias Bishop, who lives at No. 788 Eleventh-avenue, and who describes himself as a theatrical agent, was brought before Justice O'Reilly, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, charged with the larceny of two watches, valued at $30, from Ada Hickey, a variety actress, living at No. 230 West Nineteenth-street.

The Erie Railway yesterday made a passenger rate of $12 to Chicago to meet the rate of the West Shore, and the New-York Central offered tickets at $13.50. There is no doubt that cuts were made from even these rates, especially to persons purchasing a number of tickets.

HAVANA, Oct. 30.--During last week two deaths from yellow fever occurred in this city. The income of all the Custom Houses on the island during the month of August last amounted to $945,386.63, against $1,433,241.53 for the corresponding period last year.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 3.--The committee who examined the books of the company report the defalcation of George T. Jackson, the President of the Enterprise Factory, to be $152,000.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 3.--T.S. Sutherland Son, boilers, have made an assignment to George H. Morrison. The firm was composed of Thomas S. Sutherland and his son, Charles H. Sutherland.

Mr. Whittier's dwelling in Amesbury is exceedingly simple and exquisitely neat, the exterior of a pale cream color, with many trees and shrubs about it, while, within, one room opens into another till you reach the study that should be haunted by the echos of all sweet sounds, for here have been written the most of those verses full of the fitful music.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 3.--Twenty-five men charged with being repeaters were arrested here this morning and sent to the County Jail for five days. The country for miles around is flooded with tramps to-day, and each party bitterly charges the other with efforts to colonize voters. A number of false registrations have been discovered.
A Southern Presbyterian Synod has recently censured a Presbyterian Professor in a theological seminary for teaching evolution.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 3.--In continuance of the spirit of the whole campaign the Blaine Republicans are neglecting no trick or expedient, however infamous, to intimidate or corrupt voters known to be favorable to Cleveland. Certain manufacturers have resorted to the despicable course of threatening their employes with discharge if they fail to cast their votes for Blaine. Three such cases are cited.
PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Nov. 3.--Last night two daughters of Capt. Gephardt were aroused from sleep by a man at their bedside. His actions were unmistakable.

At the conference of the Vegetarian Society, which was held the other day at Manchester, one speaker declared very truly that overpressure at school is more due to underfeeding than to overteaching.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3, 1884. In the Criminal Court to-day the case of Will iam Jones, indicted Nov. 25, 1881, for an assault and battery with intent to kill Charles J. Guiteau on the 10th of the same month, was taken up and tried. The jury, after an absence of 20 minutes, found a verdict of not guilty.

The vote of to-day ends a campaign of unprecedented heat and passion. THE TIMES has done its full share of the earnest work, and it has used some very plain language, not hesitating to call a spade a spade whenever the interests of the cause it fought for demanded blunt words.

The Trustees of the Madison-Avenue Congregational Church met last evening and interchanged compliments in the church parlor very much in the manner of last Winter. Trustee James R. Breen presided, and the others present were Treasurer Seymour and Trustees Nicoll, Knapp, and Cooley, all of them adherents of the Newman faction, while Trustee Hopkins sat deflant and alone against a pillar to represent the opposition.

Property worth nearly $500,000 was endangered yesterday morning by a fire which started in a vault at No. 103 Fulton-street. The basement and first floor of the building is occupied by F.W. Devoe Co., dealers in paints, brushes, varnishes, and artists' materials. The vault, where the fire broke out, is under the sidewalk.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 13.--James A. McGuire, the engineer of Carroll's foundry, was found this morning lying in the engine room with the back of his skull crushed in. He is still living, but has not regained consciousness, and the physicians say he will die. Two men who were seen in his company last night were arrested to-night on suspicion of having made the assault.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Nov. 3.--The barn on the farm of Mary Ann Davies, tenanted by Adam Miller, in Lower Providence township, was destroyed by fire at an early hour yesterday morning, together with the hay and grain crop, some of the farm machinery, and ten cows and three horses.

MONTREAL, Nov. 3.--The customs and inland revenue receipts of Montreal show a falling off for the month of October of $129,000, as compared with the same month last year. The customs decrease is attributed by some to the general dullness of trade, while others claim it is caused by the influence of the Scott Temperance act and the consequent shrinkage in the volume of business in spirits and beer.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 3.--This city has been on a tip-toe of excitement for days, as it had been announced through tho daily press that a grand Belva Lockwood parade would take place to-night under the management of High School students on, which occasion Mrs. Lockwood would be present and make a speech.

BUFFALO, Nov. 3.--Gov. Cleveland arrived in this city from Albany soon after 7 o'clock this morning. He was not expected until afternoon. His friends proposed to give him a reception, but he preferred that there should be no demonstration, and therefore informed no one of the hour of his arrival.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3.--The Italian bark Marte, the last of the vessels expected in this port from Cette, France, where the cholera raged with such violence arrived here to-day. She has a cargo of terra alba. She sailed from Cette on the 31st of August, after the breaking out of the scourge. In view of the character of the cargo the Health authorities did not deem it necessary to detain the vessel.

The design of the marble altar to be erected in St. Gabriel's Church, in East Thirtyseventh-street, in remembrance of the Rector, the late Rev. William H. Clowry, has been selected by his Eminence Cardina McCloskey.

NEW-ORLEANS, Miss., Nov. 3.--The indications to-day throughout the State of Mississippi are that the election to-morrow will probably be the most quiet ever known here. In most parts of the State the Democrats expect to have an easy road to victory, but this, the Third, ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3.--The decision of the Supreme Court last week in the case of Capt. Charles Morton, Third United States Cavalry, affects the interests of between 900 and 1,000 officers of the army, and it will require between $400,000 and $500,000 to satisfy their claims.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 3.--To-night there is very little indication of trouble in the State to-morrow except in a few counties where excitement is running high.
The Directors of the Erie Railway have deferred payment of the interest, due in November, on the first mortgage bonds of the Chicago and Atlantic Road.

TEXARKANA, Ark., Nov. 3.--Charles Mitchell, a negro who assaulted Mrs. Waddell, a white woman, in Little Rock County, was arrested on Sunday night in that county. He confessed the crime after a mob of 200 persons had put a rope around his neck, and declared that the woman's husband had hired him to commit the deed. Waddeil was also arrested. The negro and Waddell were both lynched.
I understand that the Japanese missions in Europe have just received intimation from their Government of the creation by the Mikado of a national peerage.

William C. Rhinelander, who shot John Drake, was bailed out yesterday in the sum of $10,000. His bondsmen were Michael Reilly, a builder, of No. 1,976 Fourth-avenue, and Charles A. Fuller, real estate, of No. 137 Broadway, who are friends of Hugh McGuiness, the brother-in-law of Rhinelander.
GUILDERLAND STATION, N.Y., Nov. 3.-- Fifty years ago the Jupp family, famous Hudson Valley butter makers of that day, occupied the farm now belonging to Charles McChesney near this station.
The medical world has reason to be proud of one of its members who died this week, as the consequence of a really heroic act performed in the course of his professional duty.

QUEBEC, Nov. 3.--On Saturday the bark Bussorah, (British,) Capt. Pike, of Sunderland, arrived at Quebec. She left Sourabaya May 8, for Montreal, and had favorable weather to June 15, she being then off the west end of Madagascar.
At a regular weekly meeting of the Baptist Pastors at No. 9 Murray-street, yesterday. Mr. W.M.F. Round, the Secretary of the Prison Association of New-York, read a paper on prison reform.

Among the passengers that arrived on the steamship Oregon from Liverpool yesterday was a tall, muscular man, dressed in a neat walking suit, with a high hat, and carrying a fancy gold-headed ebony cane.

CHESTER, Penn., Nov. 3.--A still at the Chester Oil Works exploded to-day, burning three men, two of them, Alexander Smith and Martin Ryan, quite seriously, and damaging the place by fire to the extent of over $5,000.

Yesterday afternoon Mr. H.M. Stanley, the African traveler, was entertained at a defeuner at Manchester, by Mr. Hutton, President of the Chamber of Commerce. Afterward Mr. Stanley addressed a general meeting of the Chamber at the Town Hall, and had a very cordial reception.

The management of the Democratic campaign in New-Jersey has not been entirely satisfactory to the National Committee up to within a few days. Local aspirations have been allowed to interfere with work for the National ticket, and, in the judgment of some, to seriously compromise its prospects.

The reconstruction of the edifice on the corner of Beacon and Park streets reminds an elderly Bostonian of certain civic ceremonies of an early period of his life. General the Marquis de Lafayette had returned to the country he had served so well and loved as fervently.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 3.--The Street Railroad Benevolent Association, composed mainly of car drivers, to-day sent a committee to wait on the railroad Presidents and obtain a final answer to their new tariff of wages.

District Attorney Olney and his staff are continuing unabated their efforts to ferret out contemplated election frauds and have made many interesting discoveries. One of the most important of these is the unearthing of a plot to run gangs of ruffians to the polls during the first hour after the opening thereof and vote them on the names of reputable citizens.

CAMP LITTLE CHICAGO, on the Menominee River, Upper Peninsula of Michigan, Oct. 22. --We woke up this morning to find snow four inches thick on our canvas tent and the woodland round.

The funeral services of Mrs. Virginia Loyall Farragut, widow of Admiral Farragut, was hold yesterday morning at the Church of the Incarnation, Madison-avenue and Thirty-fifthSreet. The interment was at Woodlawn, where the body was placed beside the remains of her husband.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3.--Gen. John Newton, Chief of Engineers, has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of War. The following-named business men, most of whom are cotton merchants, in addition to those whose names have already been published, have given their signatures in indorsement, of William R. Grace for Mayor.

All the district leaders of both parties and of the various factions were engaged last night in distributing the bags of ballots to their trusted henchhmen, and in giving them instructions for to-day.

Flames lit up the East River last evening about 9 o'clock, in the vicinity of Pier No. 18. The steamship Ramon de Herrera, Capt. Uritibosca, of the Spanish-American Line, was on fire, and for a time the shed and dock of the Bristol Line steamers and the vessels lying near were in great peril.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 3.--Some weeks ago Henry Johnson deserted his wife and four small children, leaving them in destitute circumstances and sick. This morning one of the children, a 12-year-old boy, was found dead in bed, having perished of starvation and exposure. A younger brother was also nearly dead. His wants were at once relieved.

Delegations from the Cleveland clubs, representing the various business interests in this city, met in Clarendon Hall, East Thirteenthstreet, last night, for the purpose of arranging for work at the polls today. The meeting was a very large one and was marked by great enthusiasm.
ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 3.--Four students have been arrested at Kharkoff. A manifesto inciting to disturbance was found in their possession.

Last night, at the Birkbeck Institution, Prof. Tyndall delivered an address based on the experiences of his life. He said: * * * "The students of the Birkbeck Institution may grant me the honor of ranking myself among them as a fellow-student of a former generation.
MONTREAL, Nov. 3.--The Canada Pacific Railroad Company have determined to make a magnificent exhibit at the World's Exposition at New-Orleans.

Last night a troop of men in Prince Albert coats, high hats, with Cleveland canes, followed by a uniformed Cleveland and Hendricks club, marched up Park-row to the music of Eckert's Jersey City Band, and stopped in front of THE TIMES office.
DUBLIN, Nov. 3.--The corporation of the city of Dublin has decided to change the name of Sackville-street to O'Connell-street. The tradespeople on that street are greatly irritated by the change.

HUNTINGTON, Penn., Nov. 3.--A dwelling house belonging to the Pennsylvania Canal Company, two miles west of this city, occupied by James Holt and George Rogers and their families, the former having a wife and four small children and the latter a wife and three children, was burned this morning at 1 o'clock.

Charles. P. Shaw, who has secured the Republican nomination for the Assembly from the Fifth District of this city, is counsel to the Cable Railway Company and the notorious lobbyist who created so much scandal at Albany last Spring by his open work in behalf of the cable swindle.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 3.--The General Assembly met to-day, and adjourned until tomorrow, no quorum being present. The adjournment from day to day will be continued until the 7th, when the extra session ends and the extension agreed upon 10 days ago begins.

Herr von Madal, in his annual report upon the vehicular traffic of Berlin, as bearing upon its control by the police, gives some information as to the number of cabs and the various regulations which are in force with regard to their circulation.

But it was election day, and something had to be done to keep people quiet; so the Jerome Park extra day's racing had a fair attendance in spite of the unpromising skies.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5.--The very large vote polled in this city indicates that the Democrats have carried the city by perhaps 2,500, which would make Mr. Blaine's majority about 3,500. The vote cast for Congressmen indicates that the Republicans might get four out of the six.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 4.--There were no State officers voted for to-day, the balloting being solely for Presidential Electors. As was expected the little State went Republican, but by a majority so much less than was expected as to show that the record of the Knight of the Dirty Plume was not wholly satisfactory to the Republicans of the State.

A large crowd had collected in Goodwin's saloon and about Joseph Phillips's corner, and many of them were intoxicated.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 4.--The vote is very heavy. In Indianapolis alone it averages 1,000 to the ward. Gov. Hendricks, in answer to numerous inquiries, has answered that Indiana has gone Democratic by 5,000. He feels confident that the plurality is greater than this, but does not claim it.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 4.--Pennsylvania has gone for Blaine by a majority of 30,000 to 35,000. The total vote is largely in excess of any ever before cast; it will largely exceed 900,000. The Republicans have elected 20 of the 28 Congressmen, including the member at large.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 4.--Cleveland's majority will be about 25,000. Eight Democratic Congressmen are elected.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Nov. 4.-- Returns from 140 towns give Blaine 28,241; Cleveland, 12,694; Butler, 578; St. John, 1,168. Blaine's plurality, 15,547. The same towns in 1880 gave Garfield 32,368; Hancock, 13,317; Weaver, 1011; Garfields's plurality 19,051. If the remaining 120 towns give a proportionate vote to the above, Blaine's majority will be upward of 25,000. The vote for St. John is drawn mostly from the Republicans, while Butler's comes from the Democrats.

The annual election day games of the Manhattan Athletic Club were held on the club grounds yesterday afternoon. The number of entries in each contest was very large, and the sport on the whole proved of interest to the large number of spectators present. Several very close finishes were the result of good handicapping.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 4.--In William R. Morrison's district--the Eighteenth Illinois--the old war horse is again elected. Needles, his opponent, expected to score large gains in East St. Louis and Belleville, but he has run behind his ticket in both these cities. In the country Morrison has a sure majority and besides carrying East St. Louis and Belleville he will secure St. Clair County by nearly 1,000 majority.

Since the 1st of the present month the oyster dredgers have been at work in the Chesapeake Bay and Potomac River. Reports from all the oyster counties show a greater aggregate of licenses to tongmen than ever was known before, and the number of licenses to dredgers has risen to 1,100.

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 5.--Alexander de Stieglitz, the Russian banker and railway financier, is dead.

Clifton W. Tayleure, a theatrical agent, was indicted recently for assaulting A.K. Fulton, a proprietor of the Baltimore American, on Sept. 24, on Fourteenth-street, near Broadway.
The Alumni Hall of Seton Hall College, at South Orange, N.J., was opened at 8 o'clock last evening. The hall is 70 feet long, 40 feet wide, and 76 feet from the ground to the ridge of the roof.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 5.--The Legislature met at 10 o'clock this morning. W.A. Little, of Muscogee, was elected Speaker of the House, and H.H. Carleton, of Athens, President of the Senate.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 5.--Charles McDonald, of Waterford, one of a party of suspected election repeaters sent to Mechanicsville yesterday, jumped from the train 10 miles south of that village. His mangled remains were found on the track to-day.

A fire which broke out at 10:30 o'clock last night in a three-story building in the rear of Beach Sherwood's pickle warehouse, Nos. 139 and 141 Franklin-street, gave the Fire Department more trouble to put out than it has had at a fire for many years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5.--The Signal Corps station at Cape May Point, N.J., roports that the steamer John Taylor, belonging to a porpoise fishing company, came ashore during a gale at 3 o' clock this morning. She is a total wreck. The crew and all property were saved.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 5.--Unofficial returns from all but three counties in the Second Congressional District indicate the election of Dougherty, (Dem.,) over Bisbee, (Rep.,) by 700 plurality. The State is Democratic by 4,000 majority.

The regular Fall eight-oared race between the Freshmen and Sophomores of Columbia College was rowed on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon.
The trial of Julius Blank, of No. 180 Eldridge-street, for registering under another person's name on Oct. 25, at No. 38 Rivingtonstreet, was ended yesterday in the Court of General Sessions.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 5.--"Gophers" blew open the safe of the Academy of Music early this morning, securing $450. When Treasurer Shannon arrived at 10 o'clock he found one of the windows in the office broken and the room full of dust, and the safe literally smashed to pieces.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5.--William Laudenslager, aged 19, was fatally shot this afternoon on Light-street bridge by John Luckhart. They had been on a gunning excursion and Luckhardt's gun was accidentally discharged.

Mrs. Elizabeth House, residing at No. 1,820 Richmond-street, is the possessor of a parrot which she claims to be 109 years old. She has had the parrot for upward of 40 years, and she say she can trace the bird back from 15 years before she got it.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 5.--The Department of Marine has decided to place a small sailing vessel of 10 or 15 tons on the coast of Sable Island, so that it may be able to communicate with the mainland in case of wrecks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5.--Patrick Doyle, who was shot in a mob on the streets last night, died early this morning. He was an expoliceman, W.H. Thurston, a sewing machine agent, has been arrested as guilty of the shooting.

We have information that the National Republican Committee in New-York have telegraphed Mahone to know if the Republicans can depend on Virginia's vote as it is very important. This indicates that the Republicans have given up New-York but hope to secure the vote of Virginia for Blaine. This however, they cannot get.

Returns have been received from one-half of the voting precincts of the State, and these reduce Mr. Blaine's plurality to less than 3,000. Should anything like these returns keep up through the rest of the State, Cleveland's plurality will be large.
Miss Kate Field is at the Victoria Hotel. Stilson Hutchins, of Washington, is at the St. James Hotel.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 5.--The election of ex-Gov. Hahn, Republican, to Congress from the Second Congressional District by 1,433 majority, defeating Judge W.T. Houston, was a great surprise to the regular city Democrats. Gov. Hahn was nominated by the Independent Labor Party.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 5.--De Witt Clinton Boutelle, a well-known American artist, who has lived many years in Bethlehem, died suddenly this evening at 7 o'clock of paralysis of the heart, or apoplexy, in the Eagle Hotel, while conversing with friends. Mr. Boutelle was a member of the New-York Academy, and has contributed many fine works to American art collections.
MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 5.--The evidence in the capias case of Gale against young Harold De Wolfe, of New-York, a clerk, for a claim of $200, is being taken in the Superior Court.

"The belief that blind people don't care about smoking is all nonsense," said William Chapin, the Principal of the Pennsylvania Institution for the Instruction of the Blind, yesterday, "although it is one that has been largely indulged in.

The funeral of William J. Donnelly was very largely attended at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning. The solemn requiem mass for the repose of his soul was celebrated by the Rev. Cornelius T. Donovan, assisted by the Rev. ...

VIRGINIA, Nev., Nov. 5.--Blaine, Woodburn, and the entire Republican legislative ticket in Story County are carried by from 300 to 400 majority. The Republican State Central Committee claims Nevada by 1,100 majority.

LONDON, Nov. 5.--The Atlantic steamship companies of Hamburg, Bremen, Antwerp, and Havre have favorably received the proposals of the English steamship companies to fix the passenger steerage rate to ports in America at the minimum price of 5 guineas per head, the arrangement to go into effect next February.
LONDON, Nov. 5.--The Cunard and the Guion Steamship Companies have made arrangements to amalgamate.

ALBANY, Nov. 5.--The latest semi-official returns show a Democratic majority in the State of 3,266. It is not believed in Democratic circles here that this will vary more than 200 either way. The Argus estimates the Electoral vote at 219 for Cleveland, 122 for Blaine, and 60 doubtful.

BATH, Nov. 5.--The ship Henry Hyde was launched here this afternoon from John McDonald's yard. She is of 2,783 tons burden and is the largest ship ever built in Maine. She is owned by Benjamin R. Flint, of New-York, and will be commanded by Capt. P. Pendleton. The launch was witnessed by 5,000 persons.
ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 5.--There is no clue to the murderer of Lizzle Wilson, who was killed here last evening. Two negroes have been arrested, but their guilt is considered doubtful.

BOSTON, Nov. 5.--"Twelfth Night" was presented at the Globe Theatre to-night by Henry Irving for the first time in this country. The piece, which was splendidly mounted, was received with marked favor by the large audience.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5.--Newell Martin and Charles B. Alexander, of New-York, were admitted to practice in the Supreme Court to day.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 5.--The new Government steamship Lansdowne was successfully launched yesterday from the shipyard of J. O'Brien, at Maccan.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4.--The case of Richard French, convicted of murder in the first degree in causing the death of Mrs. Augusta Zill, came up before Judge Ludlow to-day on an application for a new trial. After hearing argument the Judge refused to grant a new trial, and sentenced the prisoner to death.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5.--Very little attention has been paid to Ohio to-day as it has gone largely Republican. The majority will probably exceed 30,000 and may reach 40,000. Twenty-seven counties show net Republican gain over October of 6,755, not including Hamilton County.

The vote in this city on Presidential Electors, as corrected yesterday, showed a total of 227,640 ballots cast. Of these 133,080 were for Cleveland, 89,847 for Blaine, 3,422 for Butler, and 1,291 for St. John.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5.--Lieut.-Commander F.E. Chadwick has been ordered to examination for promotion: Lieut. Charles Belknap to duty at the Naval Academy; Lieut. G.W. Lowry to duty as Assistant Inspector of the Eleventh Lighthouse District. Lieut. Charles J. Banger has been detached from the Alert, and ordered to duty at the Washington Navy Yard in ordnance instruction.
Major Lewis R. Redmond, the King of the Moonshiners, is now engaged in the peaceful pursuits of a pastoral life, and in the solitudes of his native mountains is building up his broken body.
A repetition of the murder of 1881, when little Eddie Soden was shot by James Graves, came very near taking place in Newark yesterday.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 5.--H.F. Bridewell Co., manufacturers' agents, filed a suit yesterday making an assignment to creditors.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 5.--About 2 o'clock this morning, while the streets were crowded with people learning the election returns, some one threw a dynamite cartridge at the building at the corner of Ninth and Market streets.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 5.--Complete returns from this county give Blaine 26,245 votes: Cleveland, 24,757; Blaine's plurality, 1,488. Less complete returns show that St. John received 741 votes and Butler 274. Farquehar is elected to Congress by 225 plurality over Lockwood, thus surprising everybody.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 5.--The Central Presbyterian Church, of this city, has extended a call to the Rev. J. McLochlin, of Waterloo, N. Y., which has been accepted.

The full and correct returns from Richmond County give the following figures: Cleveland, 5,131; Blaine, 3,163; Butler, 75; St. John, 90; Cleveland's majority, 1,803.
LONDON, Nov. 5.--In the House of Commons to-day Mr. Frank O'Donnell, Home Rule member for Dungarvan, was suspended for disregarding the authority of the Speaker.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 5.--The Chairman of the Democratic State Committee speaks as follows: There can be no further question as to the result in Indiana.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 5.--At the State Department to-day a charter was issued to the Associated Producers' Company, of Bradford, McKean County. The company proposes producing and selling oil.
CAIRO, Nov. 5.--The English troops are advancing all along the Nile. The Staffordshire Regiment has gone from Wady Halfa to Donogla in boats.
CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 5.--Two hundred and forty one towns and wards give Blaine 39,106; Cleveland, 34,983; St. John, 1,425; Butler, 507; Blaine's plurality, 4,118.

The Tribune has not yet recovered from the shock of the election sufficiently to inform the public on what day it proposes to close all our manufactories and to reduce the wages of working men to fifty cents a day.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 5.--Returns are in from a considerable number of the precincts in this State, and about four-fifths of the vote is counted.

FATHER POINT, Quebec, Nov. 5.--A fearful snow and wind storm from the East has been raging since midnight last night all along the coast. The wind averages 70 miles as hour, and the sea is tremendous, and has crossed the highways and inundated the fields of all the parishes along the coast.

LONDON, Nov. 5.--American coteries in Paris and London have been greatly excited over the Presidential election in the United States. The various news rooms were kept open throughout the night, and, as the conflicting accounts were received, each party became alternately Jubilant or depressed.

Coroner Mitchell commenced his inquest yesterday over the body of Richard McErlane, who was shot on Monday night by James Wing in a political fight after a parade at Hastings-onthe-Hudson. The prisoner, Wing, was present but refused to say anything.
LEWISTON, Me., Nov. 5.--A dispatch to the Journal says: "Two hundred and twelve towns give Blaine 51,352; Cleveland, 37,120; Butler, 2,872; St. John, 1,505. Blaine's plurality is 14,232.
WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Nov. 5.-- One hundred and sixty-seven towns gave Blaine 33,000; Cleveland, 14,804; Butler, 617; St. John, 1,325; Blaine's plurality, 18,196, with 73 towns to be heard from.
PARIS, Nov. 5.--The Senate, by a vote of 145 to 117, has abolished the life Senatorships.

John R. Flanagan, one of the old-time lawyers of this city, died yesterday at the Florence Flats, Fourth-avenue and Eighteenthstreet. He was born 71 years ago in this city, and had passed his life in it.

The population of the parish of St. Mathieu, in the County of Rimouski, were thrown into a state of great excitement during several days last week by the painful uncertainty prevailing with regard to the fate of two children of a farmer named Dionne, aged respectively 12 and 8 years, who had been sent into the bush near their father's residence to cut a few branches of cedar.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 5.--In the seven Congressional districts of Mississippi the Democrats elect all their Congressmen. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and his injury is considered serious. She was locked up.
Dr. Franz Boas, who has traveled along the shores of Baffin Bay and Labrador, read a paper on the Esquimaux of those regions last evening before the German Social Science Association.

The State ought to furnish a single ballot for each voter containing the names of all candidates for State and national offices registered up to within a reasonable time before election.

There was scarcely any abatement in the excitement over the election returns in Brooklyn yesterday. Men neglected their business to gather in the City Hall Square and around the different political headquarters in search of news. The local fight seemed to have no interest for the people.

HAVANA, Nov. 1.--Owing to the splendid condition of the canefields on some estates grinding will begin about the 15th inst. In 1869 there were in Sancti Spiritus 21 sugar estates, 47 tobacco vegas, 731 stock farms, and 431 farms.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 5.--Official returns from all the counties in the Fourth Congressional District give Henry R. Harris, (Dem.,) 13,157; Henry Persons, (Ind.,) 5,488; R.F. Milner, (Rep.,) 4,151. The Democratic Presidential Electors carry the district by about 8,000 majority.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5.--The will of the late Wilbur F. Storey was filed in the Probate Court here to-day. It bequeaths his entire estate, including the Times newspaper, to his widow, Eureka C. Storey, with the privilege of selling the same.
The next Assembly will consist of 75 Republicans and 53 Democrats. The Senate, which holds over another year, contains 19 Re publicans and 13 Democrats.

QUEBEC, Nov. 5.--A rival of the unfortunate Capt. Webb named W.J. Webster, from Boston, who is represented to be a celebrated swimmer, has arrived here for the purpose of attempting the perilous feat of going over the Montmorency Falls in a balloon filled with compressed air for a wager of $2,000.

HARDFORD, Conn., Nov. 5.--Cleveland carries the State by 1,200 Plurality. There is no election of Governor by the people, Waller (Dem.) failing of a majority by about 1,200. The Legislature is largely Republican and will elect Mr. Harrison. This is definite and reliable, and the result will not be changed.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 5.--The Republicans elect A.H. Pettibone in the First Congressional District, L.C. Houck in the Second, and Zachary Taylor in the Tenth a gain of one. The Democrats elect the rest. The vote for Governor is very close. Should Bate (Dem.) be elected, it will be by a very small majority. His majority two years ago was 28,000.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 6.--There is great rejoicing here, as the news of Cleveland's election seems to be confirmed. The vote in this State will not be full, on account of the lack of opposition. The majority for Cleveland will probably reach 50,000. The Congressional election returns eight Democrats. As far as heard from, there was not even a fisticuff on election day. The Legislature of Alabama meets next Tuesday.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Nov. 6.--At the home of John A. Greely to-night Lieut. A.W. Greely was presented with a silver service by the Greely Testimonial Committee. Lieut. Greely leaves to-morrow for Washington.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Nov. 6.--West Florida official returns thus far sustain the estimated Democratic majority of 1,250. So far one Senator and five Representatives have been gained by the Democrats in counties west of Apalachicola River. Escambia County, the home of Perry.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 6.--The car drivers' strike here still continues. No street cars are running, and much inconvenience is caused. The City Council to-night decided almost unanimously to instruct the City Attorney to take the necessary proceedings to annul all rights and privileges granted by the city to the street railroads for violating their contracts with the city in failing to run their cars on schedule time.
AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 6.--The Democrats here seem quite confident of the election of their ticket and to-night they are having a celebration of the victory they claim.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 6.--The interest in the result of the election continues unabated in this city. The streets in the vicinity of the newspaper offices present a most remarkable appearance to-night.

A revise of all of these returns will give the Democrats the State by not much less than 7,000 majority. Complete official returns are likely to increase this. The Democrats have elected seven Congressmen beyond all doubt.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 6.--The statement of assets and liabilities in the affairs of the assigned Lockport Banking Association was made public to-day by the Assignee and filed in the County Clerk's office.
PARIS, Nov. 6.--Several cases and one death of alleged Asiatic cholera have occurred in this city within the past 24 hours. During the same time there were five deaths at Nantes and one at Oran.

It is a fact, perhaps not generally known, that Ohio has more so-called colleges than any other State in the Union. While Illinois and New-York have 28 each, and Pennsylvania 26, no other State having more than 19, Ohio has 35.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 6.--Litigation of the greatest importance to brewers was inaugurated here to-day by the service of an injunction order upon Marion Warren in an action instituted by one James Sargent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6.--Mr. George W. Childs gate the Farmers' Club dinner to-day at his country horse, Wooton. Among those present were Gen. Simon Cameron, ex-Speaker Samuel J. Randall, the Hon. Wayne Mac Veagh, George B. Roberts, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad; Senator J.D. Cameron, Judges Green and Biddle, and D.O. Mills, and R. Lennox Kennedy, of New-York. BALTIMORE, Nov.6.--The third Plenary Council of Baltimore, which meets on Sunday, Nov. 9, will form the largest gathering of Catholic prelates that has assembled since the celebrated Council of Trent in the sixteenth century, except the Council of the Vatican, which adjourned in 1870 before completing its labors.

DENVER. Col., Nov. 6.--A special from Silver Plume to the Tribune reports that the entire business portion of that town was burned this morning. The loss will reach $100,000. The streets are filled with crowds of excited and homeless people.

LONDON, Nov. 6.--The steadiness of American securities on the Stock Exchange under the election excitement is the subject of comment by the press. The Pall Mall Gazette holds that this steadiness is a striking illustration of the stability of democratic institutions.

The crew of seven men and two women took to the small boat and landed to-night four miles below here. A tug is in search of the vessel.

A very dangerous counterfeit of the American five-dollar piece was recently taken by the Oliver Chilled Plow Company and sent to the United States Mint in this city for examination.

VIRGINIA CITY, Nev., Nov. 7.--Nevada has gone Republican by a safe majority. The figures will vary but little from those previously reported. The official vote of Storey County gives Blaine 368 majority. Woodburn, for Con gress, has 518 majority.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7.--While the excitement over election news from New-York is much less than last night, the anxiety here is almost as great as ever.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov 7.--The brigantine Sophia, of Liverpool, from Jordan River, for Montevideo, with lumber, is reported to be a total loss, on Englishman's Bank, near Montevideo.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 7.--At a meeting of the Board of Trade this morning a majority favored a shut-down next week. An agreement to close on Saturday night for one week has been signed by mills representing 1,000,000 spindles, and enough are expected to sign this afternoon to bring the number up to 1,400,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 7.--Robert Williams, (colored,) alias "Blinky Bob," convicted of the murder of Charles Dyes, (colored,) was to-day sentenced by Judge Roman to be hanged at such time as the Governor shall direct.

At the election on Tuesday 20 States gave pluralities for Cleveland for President, and will cast 219 votes for him in the Electoral College. Eighteen States, having 182 votes in the Electoral College, gave pluralities for Blaine.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7.--Dr. Lewis H. Steiner, of Frederick City, for a number of years a member of the Maryland Senate and one of the most literary men of the State, has been appointed Librarian of the Enoch Pratt Free Library. He will at once visit the large libraries of New-York and the Eastern States, and collect data before purchasing books.
The blackbirds are rapidly seeking the warmer clime. A flock fully a mile long passed south this morning.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 7.--Gov. Hendricks has received a great many congratulatory telegrams to-day, and has been busily engaged in receiving and entertaining callers, among whom were many Republicans, personal friends. An Associated Press reporter found him this evening in conversation with a number of politicians. Senator Voorhees among them.
QUEBEC, Nov. 7.--A light snow has been falling all day, and sleighing is now good. The weather is cold.

Three complaints were made at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday against August Gregory, alias Ruggles, alias Hoyt, the young hotel thief whose operations occasioned so much annoyance to the hotel proprietors in this city and to the police.
The agents of the lines in the emigrant pool met yesterday at Commissioner Fink's office, and discussed the prevailing demoralization of passenger rates so far as it affected the emigrant business.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7.--The second preliminary meeting of prelates previous to the opening of the Third Plenary Council was held to-day at St. Mary's Seminary in this city, and was presided over by Archbishop Gibbons, apostolic delegate.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 7.--The singlescull race to be rowed at McKeesport, Penn., tomorrow afternoon, between Peter H. Conley, of Boston, and John Teemer, for $500 a side, is attracting considerable attention. Conley is to have 10 seconds start. Both men are in excellent condition, and a stubbornly contested race is expected.

FLINT, Mich., Nov. 7.--Returns from all but 111 precincts in the State indicate that the State is Republican by 2,800.

Hon. A.J. Dufur and wife, who have just returned from a visit to their old home in Orange County, Vt., after an absence of 30 years, report having had a very pleasant trip. They traveled extensively in Wisconsin and southern Illinois, but saw no place which suited them so well as Oregon.

The vote in South Carolina on Tuesday was exceedingly light, and chiefly so on account of the stringent provisions of the election law. No one can vote under the State law who has not registered as a voter, and who does not produce his certificate of registration when he offers to vote.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 7.--The street car drivers' strike has been ended by a compromise. They demanded $60 per month, and the companies agree to pay them $55 per month for 15 hours' work per day. The former' pay was $45 per month for 18 hours' work daily.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 7.--The Democrats are firing 219 guns to-night in honor of Cleveland's election.

Then, as now, the question of the tariff was a knotty one, and friend quarreled with friend, neighbor was at daggers drawn with neighbor, kinspeople forgot their ties of consanguinity, in one wrangle upon the subject of the tariff.

The board is composed this year of four Democrats--Controller Alfred C. Chapin, Attorney-General Denis O'Brien.

Aside from results the independent movement, which has attracted so large a share of public attention during the canvass, is a most healthy sign of the times. No element has over been developed in our politics that has been subjected to more vituperation.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7.--In the Criminal Court this morning Judge Phelps sentenced Gilbert W. Hazeltine, convicted of manslaughter for killing Mamie Thorpe, to eight years in the penitentiary. Hazeltine was a resident of Jamestown, N.Y., and shot the girl Thorpe at a disreputable house in this city on the 19th of July last.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 7.--Gottlieb, Strauss Co., dealers in hats and caps, have made an assignment to Henry Lauer. Their assets are estimated at $60,000 and their liabilities at nearly $100,000.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 7.--There is tremendous excitement in this city this evening. The square in front of the Journal office is filled to suffocation by a mass of men who believe that Cleveland is elected.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov 7.--James Leathewood, a livery stable keeper of this city, was assassinated at about 3 o'clock this morning by being shot through a crack in the wall, the bullet piercing the top of his head and ranging downward into the body. He was instantly killed. There is no clue to the murderer.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 7.--The town is wild with excitement to-night over the news confirming Cleveland's election. Red paint pots, tin horns, new brooms, and everything that would in any way give way to pent-up enthusiasm have been called into requisition by the Democrats.

Admiral Sir William Dowell and Mr. Warren, the Vice-Consul, attempted to land at Mamoi Point, where the British Consulate stands, a few days ago, but were fired on by Chinese soldiers on the hillside.

Having made up their minds that Cleveland's election is an accomplished fact, the business men of this city showed a disposition yesterday to calmly discuss the effect of his triumph. Contrary to the startling ante-election predictions of some of the Blaine campaign speakers, there does not seem to be any apprehension in business circles that the accession of the Democratic Party to power is going to throw the country into confusion.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 7.--The latest returns from over the State confirm the report previously sent that Mississippi will send a solid Democratic delegation to Congress.

THE TIMES has now received complete official figures, revised and corrected, from every county in New-York State. The figures of the 86 counties already in and estimates on the missing ones show that Cleveland and Hendricks have a plurality of about 6,500. PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 6.--The Grand Jury to-day returned a true bill of indictment against Daniel E. Stanton, a fugitive, charging him with murder in causing the death of his friend, Frederick P. Nash, by shooting him on the 19th of October in the neighborhood of Germantown Junction.

He had not been naturalized. He had never even seen Castle Garden. He cared little for Cleveland and less for Blaine.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 7.--The town of Leno, Iowa, is on fire, and probably will be entirely consumed. Creston and St. Joseph were telegraphed to for assistance. The Creston Fire Department has reached there and is now at work. The fire is the work of an incendiary.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, Nov. 7. --This evening the House committee reported strongly in favor of the ratification of the conversion of the English debt.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 7.--Secretary Chandler arrived here this morning from Warner, where he has been in conference with Prof. Solay, Librarian of the Navy Department, since Wednesday morning concerning his annual report. The Secretary stated that he had not been telegraphed for to go to New-York, that he had not been there, and that he did not intend going there till Monday.
MONTREAL, Nov. 7.--The Rev. Father Chiniquy preached last night in the CanningStreet Presbyterian Church and was again interrupted by a band of young men, apparently students.
The failure of the Labrador fishery is the most serious we have had in that quarter for many years. The quantity of codfish taken, on a moderate-calculation, will be one-half below the average.

MADRID, Nov. 7.--The floods at Alicante have destroyed the Faubourg Caridad, and a rock thrown down by an avalanche battered down the old stone walls of the city. The towns of Carcajente, near the river Jucar, Alcira, (a walled town on an island in the river Jucar,) and Rida, all in the Province of Valencia, have been submerged, causing great damage to factories, bridges, and residences.

PARIS, Nov. 7.--During the 24 hours ending at 4 o'clock P.M. Thursday, there were four deaths from cholera at the St. Antoine Hospital in this city. At the Tenon Hospital there were seven cases and three deaths. Elsewhere in the city four deaths occurred. From Wednesday morning until noon to-day there was a total of 21 cases and 13 deaths in Paris.

QUEBEC, Nov. 7.--A boy named Demers, living on St. Foye Road, applied a match to a canister of powder to-day and an explosion followed, wrecking the house and seriously injuring his mother and three sisters.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 7.--The Republican State Committee estimate their majority in the State to be 4,000 for Blaine and 3,000 for the Congressional ticket. For the State ticket they estimate an average majority of 2,500. The Democratic State Central Committee give no figures, but claim that the above majorities are overestimated.
PARIS, Nov. 7.--The Tonquin Committee of the Deputies has voted a credit for reinforcements to be sent to the French forces in Tonquin.

AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 7.--The latest advices received here from New-York are to the effect that the Republican committees, State and National, after a careful examination of the whole ground, are satisfied that the State has gone for Blaine and Logan.

READING, Penn., Nov. 7.--By an order of the Board of Public Charities 35 insane persons confined in the insane department of the Berks County Almshouse were to-day removed to the State Lunatic Asylum at Danville.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7.--Officils of the Pennsylvania Railroad, passenger department, deny the reports that a cut in rates has been made by that company. They say that business is already conducted at losing prices, and that they do not intend to join in the movement.

MADISON, Ind., Nov. 7.--The Kentucky River Packet Company's steamer Fannie Freeze, owned by Baker, Ginn Co., was burned to-day in port with a cargo of hay, pigs, and cattle. The boat was valued at $6,000 and was not insured; the cargo was worth $2,000. No lives were lost, but the engineer, Thomas Coger, and the barkeeper, Charles Chasten, were, badly but not dangerously burned.
AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 7.--Texas gives a majority of at least 85,000 for the Democratic Electoral ticket.

The Republican managers virtually gave up the fight last night, under an ignominous display of bravado. Mr. Blaine's dispatch to Chairman Jones and the warmed-up returns of the Associated Press encouraged them to this final effort to declare themselves victors for an hour.

ST. ANNE DE MONTS, Quebec, Nov. 7.-- The storm which visited here on Wednesday took much the shape of a cyclone. Fifteen houses were destroyed, and a considerable quantity of wood, which the fishermen had in store, was swept away.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 7.--The store of L.C. Robinson, in Salisbury Township, bordering on the Welsh Mountain, was robbed several days ago, the suspected parties being a number of negroes connected with the Buzzard gang.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Nov. 7.--The news of the election of the Democratic candidate for President has set the people of this city fairly wild, and business has been almost entirely suspended.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 7.--St. John was burned in effigy in front of the Republican office this evening in the presence of 5,000 persons. The figure was then dragged burning through the streets.
LONDON, Nov. 7.--In the House of Commons to-night the Franchise bill was read a second time by a vote of 372 to 232.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 7.--The boiler in the sugar house on the Eames plantation, near Lee Station, exploded last night, killing nine men and wounding several others.

READING, Penn., Nov. 7.--Up to noon today the bodies of three of the seven men buried under the ruins of the dismantled stack at Robesonia furnace were recovered. They were burned beyond recognition. Four other bodies are buried beneath several hundred tons of debris. The force of the dynamite explosion at Stouchsburg was felt within a radius of 30 miles.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 7.--The copper product of Lake Superior mines for October is as follows: Calumet and Hecla, 1,430 tons; Quincy, 251; Atlantic, 202; Franklin, 200; Allouez, 145; Huron, 125; Peninsular, 80; Copper Falls, 61; Hancock, 40. There is a great falling off in the Calumet and Hecla output, owing to a severe fire in the underground workings of the mine which a long time threatened large damage, but was finally got under control.

Last year the members of the Richmond County Fish and Game Protective Association obtained a thousand quail and released the birds on Staten Island. The expense was borne by a few enthusiastic sportsmen.

PARIS, Nov. 7.--The Suez Canal Company will send a committee to Egypt on the 12th inst. to examine and report upon the feasibility of widening the present canal, or whether a necessity exists for the building of a second canal. M. de Lesseps and his son will accompany the committee.

EUFAULA, Ala., Nov. 7.--The city is wild with excitement over Cleveland's election, and a mass meeting was held in the Opera House tonight. Speeches were made by Senator Pugh and other prominent citizens.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 7.--South Carolina has not been so stirred up since 1876, and everybody except the Federal officeholders is happy. No Presidential struggle has ever excited half the interest, and the result of no previous election has ever been received with more heartfelt satisfaction.

This district gave the present incumbent, Gen. Dibrell, a majority of 700, and Hancock about 2,000.
