CHICAGO, Nov. 7.--The latest returns from the Congressional vote in the State indicate that Landes, Democrat, has defeated McCartney, Republican, in the Sixteenth District. This leaves the Illinois delegation with 10 Republicans and 10 Democrats, and there can be no change. The last returns make the State Legislature a tie on joint ballot, but there may be changes in this, the Democrats having the best chance for a majority.

The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher sat serenely composed in the lecture room of Plymouth Church last evening, musingly noting each member of his congregation who entered. He noticed a great many. There was an unusually large gathering in the room, composed of ladies and gentlemen in about equal numbers.

ROME, Nov. 7.--The Pope has approved of the division of the Diocese of Three Rivers, Canada, by the creation of a new see at Nicolet. His Holiness has appointed a new Commissary Apostolic to go to Canada.

S.V. Beckwith, of Winsted, was called to Plantsville last week to the funeral of his brother-in-law, who died of a most singular disease. A few days before his death the man saw a dark spot on his arm.
BATAVIA, N.Y., Nov. 7.--Last night the Democrats had a rousing impromptu celebration of their victory, which was conceded by about all Republicans.

The public rehearsal preparatory to the first concert given this season by the Philharmonic Society of Brooklyn was held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. The attendance was as large as usual, and the attention accorded the performance, which was quite as finished as to-night's is likely to be, was as close and continuous as in the past.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 7.--The city is fairly wild with excitement to-night, and the Democrats in every city in the State are holding demonstrations in honor of the election of Grover Cleveland.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 7.--The body of R. Taylor Johnson, a prominent man, who disappeared on Oct. 29, was found in the Erie Canal to-day. It is supposed he committed suicide.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 7.--In the Hustings Court to-day, Judge E.M. Mann presiding, W.W. White, late Teller of the Planters and Mechanics' Bank, who was indicted by the Grand Jury for making certain fraudulent entries on the books of the bank, was arraigned for trial.

LYONS, N.Y., Nov. 7.--Mrs. Grover Youngs, a middle-aged woman, while cleaning a stove this morning, had her clothing set on fire and was burned to death.

In the Orphans' Court yesterday Rufus W. Pier, Esq., was appointed Trustee of the estate of Frederick Kaiser, in place of Mr. Frank C. Henry, deceased. Samuel Sehlup, who offered the petition, stated that Kaiser died in June. 1882, and that he is one of his rightful heirs.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 7.--The Democrats here fired 100 guns in honor of Cleveland's election.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 7.--Mr. Jonas G. Clark, of this city, a native of Hubbardston, in this county, has offered to that town a free public library building and other real estate valued in all at $50,000 for library purposes. The gift was accepted and properly acknowledged at a town meeting this week.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 7.--In the case of Evans, charged with polygamy, the mother of the second wife testified that her daughter married Evans. His second wife, admitting the marriage with her, said it was not with his first wife's consent. The jury thereupon convicted Evans.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 7.--This city is celebrating Cleveland's election, At 11 o'clock this morning, amid the ringing of bells, the firing of cannon, and the blowing of whistles, an immense crowd bearing banners, flags, and red shirts on poles, entered the Capitol, took the Legislature by storm and adjourned that body.

NEW-MILFORD, Conn., Nov. 7.--There is a great celebration here to-night by Democrats and independents over the election of Grover Cleveland. One hundred guns were fired, and whistles in all the factories were blown. A rousing celebration will be held to-morrow night.

WHEELING, W. Va., Nov. 7.--There is intense excitement here, and Democrats are bitter in denouncing the Associated Press people. The Republican headquarters are dark and the Republicans are despondent. West Virginia goes for Cleveland 4,500. The Democrats fired 100 guns this evening.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Oct. 20.--The fine Autumn skies and gorgeous tints of maples, with other beautiful trees, in and about Northampton should give a visitor here as pleasant an impression of the old town (recently made city) as when he comes in midsummer days.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 8.--A mass meeting was held at 2 o'clock this afternoon in front of the City Hall by the Democrats of Baltimore, as an occasion for rejoicing at the election of Cleveland and Hendricks. Speeches were made by ex-Senator W.P. Whyte and others. Resolutions were adopted pledging the use of every honorable means in carrying out the will of the people. Several thousand people were present.

John R. Brown, lime and cement commission merchant, of No. 5 Coenties-slip, made an assignment yesterday to Robert A. Reed, giving preferences to Warren-Ackerman, $8,000; the Cobb Lime Company, $4,000; Burgess, O'Brien Co., $3,000; A.F. Crockett, $2,000; Perry Brothers, $2,000. Mr. Brown was regarded as one of the oldest merchants in this line in the city, and represented some of the best companies in the country.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 8.--In honor of the election of Grover Cleveland to the Presidency the Democrats are "painting the town red" tonight. In Lucas Market square huge bonfires are burning and in front of the Court House there is a monster meeting. Even the editor of the Globe-Democrat concedes Cleveland's election and is paying bets he lost on Blaine.
PARIS, Nov. 8.--The divorce of Mme. Patti from her husband, the Marquis de Caux, was to-day made absolute.

M. Forel, a French savant, has observed a remarkable reddish halo round the sun from a position in the Bernese Alps on Aug. 25. At an altitude of 1,000 meters the phenomenon was visible, at 1,500 meters it was quite distinct, and at 3,000 meters it appeared of striking splendor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8.--Albaugh's Grand Opera House, which has just been erected by the Washington Light Infantry Corps, in connection with a new armory on Fifteenth-street, near Pennsylvania-avenue, in this city, was thrown open to-night for private view to a number of prominent citizens, although a large force of workmen are still busy with the finishing touches for its formal opening next Monday evening.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8.--The third preliminary meeting of the Plenary Council, to be open at the cathedral here tomorrow, was held in the cathedral to-day. All the members of the Council, including the Archbishops, Bishops, Abbots, heads of religious orders, theologians, , to the number of 260, were present.

The steamship City of Berlin, of the Inman Line, sailed yesterday for Liverpool. Among its passengers were: Prof. Robert S. Ball, F.R.S.; the Hon. George P. Pomercy. United States Consul at Cairo; Prof. John Wingfield, Capt. Hugh Roso, and Dr. J.S. Stallard.

BRATTLEBOROUGH, Vt., Nov. 8.--The Democrats fired 100 guns here to-day in honor of Cleveland's election. Arrangements are being made for a great county celebration here the first of next week, which is expected to surpass anything of the kind ever seen in the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8.--The new hall of the Philadelphia Musical Academy, on Sprucestreet, above Sixteenth-street, was opened this evening with an excellent concert. The hall is a fine, large apartment which Mr. Zeckwer has built at the rear of the building occupied by the Academy. It is of ample size for chamber concerts, and is comfortable, well lighted, and well adapted to its purposes.

PRINCETON, Nov. 8.--This afternoon Princeton's football team played against the eleven from Johns Hopkins University here. QUEBEC, Nov. 8.--The exodus of ship and other laborers from Quebec this Fall to seek employment in the southern ports and in the American and Canadian lumber woods is altogether unprecedented. Barlow, Miller, Stickney, Vanderpoel, and Stetson continued their canvass of the Presidential vote at the Bureau of Elections yesterday morning, and finished at noon, when they left for their headquarters at the Hoffman House. None of them would give any figures, claiming that their additions had not been made.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 8.--A large public meeting was held at the Corn Exchange this afternoon, called by President Kerry of the Board of Trade, to urge upon the Canadian Government the importance of having the Dominion of Canada well represented at the World's exposition at New-Orleans.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 8.--The firing of a national salute in honor of the Democratic victory was about concluded here to-day when the caisson of the cannon exploded, injuring about a dozen persons, including eight small boys. NEW-ORLEANS, Nov. 8.--Samuel Johnson, colored, was shot and killed last night, at the corner of Sister and Royal streets, by Charles Hyle, who was in company with Special Officer Dupre. Johnson resisted arrest by Dupre and shot at the officer, striking him in the forehead, when Hyle fired at Johnson, killing him. Hyle surrendered himself.

CHINO VALLEY, Arizona, Oct. 7.--I am afraid I was somewhat hasty in my last letter in saying that Arizona is not progressing as well as could be desired. I think more gold and copper are being taken out this year than ever before and less silver, the latter on account of a strike of the miners.

Wolf's comet, discovered in Germany a few weeks ago, now a telescopic object near the zenith in the evening, is shown to have an elliptic orbit and to make a complete revolution once in about six-years. It is, therefore, a new member of the Jupiter group of comets, a group which reach out from the sun about as far as Jupiter's orbit, at their greatest distance, and then approach much nearer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8.--Disgruntled Benjamin F. Butler has submitted to an interview with a newspaper representative, in which he talked a good deal and said little. He did, however, make a significant statement in reply to a question as to whether his vote came up to his expectations. "My vote," said Gen. Butler, "was larger than I expected. You see, my vote was not counted except in Michigan.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 8.--Gov. McDaniel was to-day inaugurated in the Capitol to serve his second term. His address was short.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8.--Gov. Hoadly refuses to order the troops into the Hocking Valley until he is convinced that the Sheriffs have done all in their power to quell the disturbances and have failed.

WHEELING, West Va,, Nov. 8.--Returns from nearly all the counties in this State at midnight indicate the majority for Cleveland at from 4,200 to 4,700. These figures will not be materially altered by subsequent corrected counts. The Republicans attribute their loss of the State to a lack of organization.

He was a passenger on a south bound train, which reached the station at 7:10 o'clook, and was the last person to leave the cars.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 8.--The official vote of Burlington County gives Blaine 6,740; Cleveland, 6,858; Butler, 1,557; St. John, 387. For Congress, Buchanan, (Rep.,) 7,325; Gauntt, (Dem.,) 6,374; Howell, (Prob.,) 339; Dobbins, (Butler,) 158.

CALDWELL, Idaho, Nov. 8.--Indicatioms now point to the election of Hailey, (Dem.) as Delegate. His majority foots up about 1,200, with northern counties to hear from which will be in favor of Singiser, (Rep.,) but it is not thought they will overcome Hailey's majority.

CAMERON, Texas, Nov. 8.--A triple murder was unearthed to-day at Bryant station, 12 miles west of Cameron. Bernard Schiller, an old Bohemian, his wife, and a 3-year-old daughter were found murdered, lying near a straw stack. Schiller and his wife had been shot through the head and the child's skull had been crushed. They had been dead several days. The cause of the crime is a mystery. No arrests have been made.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 8.--Mr. Robert Bonner, who arrived here on Thursday last, superintended the shoeing of Maud S. this morning, and directed that her trainer, W.W. Bair, should give her two exercising miles, to keep her up for a cup performance next week, should the Indian Summer last. As the weather had been bad and the mare short of work, nothing great was anticipated.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 8.--The single scull race for $500 a side between Peter H. Conly, of Boston, and John Teemer, which was to have taken place at McKeesport this afternoon, has been declared off. Teemer's backers assert that he is not in condition, and have forfeited $100 stake money, besides the $150 given to Conly for his expenses. Conly's backers left for Boston this morning.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 8.--The Rev. James McLeod, formerly of Buffalo, and now Pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church here, who has just returned from his former home, is authority for the statement that President-elect Cleveland is soon to wed a lady of Buffalo, whose name is not given.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 8.--The next Legislature of Wisconsin will stand--Senate, 20 Republicans and 13 Democrats; Assembly, 61 Republicans and 31 Democrats.

NEWBURG, Nov 8.--The Democrats of this city turned out on masse last evening and celebrated Cleveland's election with a monstrous and enthusiastic procession. During the parade Marshal Weston's horse became frightened at a West Shore locomotive, in Water-street, and giving a wild jump, landed in the centre of Moscow's band, which was at the head of the procession.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 8.--The long-con. tinued trial of Dr. Ira Richmond was brought to an end to-day, the counsel for the prisoner moving for a new trial in the County Court. This was denied, and the Judge then sentenced the prisoner to Auburn Prison at hard labor for six years. Richmond had been convicted of manslaughter in the third degree in causing the death of a girl named Lizzie Cook by malpractice.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 8.--Inspector ward received a dispatch to-day from Sault Ste. Marie stating that two of the Michipicoten desperadoes, Wallace and McGillivray, who were in hiding while the Toronto police were there had, after they had left, committed several lawless deeds, had been arrested by United States detectives and handed over to the authorities there. Wallace was the foreman of a gang of Italians, and was implicated in a stabbing affray last Winter.

OTTAWA, Nov. 7.--It has been apparent for some time past that sooner or later the Dominion Government would have trouble with the Indians on the northwest coast of British Columbia. Frequent disturbances have arisen at Metlakabtla of late owing to religious interference, which has necessitated the dispatch of a British war vessel to that locality.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--Chief Engineer Charles H. Loring, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy on the operations of the Bureau of Steam Engineering, says that of the $1,000,000 appropriated for steam engineering last year $993,765 was expended. The sum of $327,454 was expended for the machinery of double-turreted monitors.

EUFAULA, Ala., Nov. 10.--The third incendiary fire in this city within the past three or four days was discovered last night when the stable of Capt. Kaiglier was found to be burning. An examination showed that dry grass in the vicinity had been gathered to start the fire and on this was piled light wood.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States today in what are known as the Alabama claims cases, namely: The Great Western Insurance Company and John P. Paulison, Receiver of the Columbia Insurance Company, vs. The United States.

The anxiety which is felt in regard to the various schemes now on foot to transfer this State to the embraces of a party which has no claim upon it, according to the expression of the people's will made on Tuesday last, has called forth some very emphatic utterances from men who are accustomed to weigh their words.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10.--Frank Hawthorne, a laborer, livington Cedar-street, Manayunk, has been on a spree for the past two weeks, and when he returned home last night he was delirious from drink.
Much excitement was caused along the line of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad yesterday morning by the discharge of a large number of employes, mostly trainmen.
UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 10.--A convention of Christian Workers conducted by Mr. Dwight L. Moody was opened here, to-day in the First Presbyterian Church.

COBOURG, Ontario, Nov. 10.--William Keating, Narcisse Fauchier, Alexander Armour, and Philip Hearn were sentenced to 10 years each with hard labor in the penitentiary for criminally assaulting a married woman named Davey. The Judge said this is the full term of punishment the law allowed or he would make it more severe.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Nov. 10.--A steam tug passing the East Erie Canal on Sunday afternoon, near Auriesville, Montgomery County, came in contact with with an obstruction and the engine stopped.

Roscoe Conkling has consented to act as counsel for the Democratic National and State Committees in any question that may arise in the pending canvass of the Electoral vote of this State. This conclusion was reached at a late hour last night.
BERLIN, Nov. 10.--The North German Gazette publishes the text of a circular issued by the Duke of Cumberland, which has been addressed to all the German sovereigns except the Emperor William.
The Board of Directors of the Maritime Association of the Port of New-York held their regular monthly meeting yesterday, President Charles F. Elwell in the chair.

The Consolidated Gas Company of NewYork entered upon a corporate existence yesterday. BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Richard C. Gunning, an insurance agent, of the firm of Crosby Gunning, formerly of Chicago, Ill., was to-day arrested charged with illegal voting. Gunning readily gave bail, and claims to be able to prove former residence, legalizing his vote.

A young woman who, it is claimed, had a delusion to the effect that she was inside a whale, who held conversation with imaginary voices, and who was in the habit of whistling to imaginary birds, was confined in the Long Island Home and Hotel for the treatment of the insane, at Amityville, in June, 1883.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10.--The new comic opera "Desiree," the libretto of which was written by Edward P. Taher, and the music by John Philip Sausa, both of Washington, was produced at Haverly's Theatre this evening by the McCaull Opera Comique Company. The theatre was packed, and the opera was a great success. The author, the composer, and Col. McCaull were called before the curtain.
Miss Fanny Davenport and company opened a five weeks' engagement at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre last evening, the play being "Fedora." A large and very appreciative audience was present.

The representatives of the Republican Party were assured at Chicago by ELKINS and his assistants that BLAINE was the ideal candidate because the people of the great Republican States wanted him and would give him huge majorities.
State Civil Service Commissioners John Jay, Augustus Schoonmaker, and Henry A. Richmond met in the New-York Hotel yesterday and discussed the annual report, which will soon be issued.
A fire, the origin of which has not been ascertained, broke out about 11 o'clock last evening in the Cheesebrough Manufacturing Company's sheds, on Delevan-street, near Richards, Brooklyn.
MARYVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 10.--While Miss Ann McGhee, a White lady of considerable wealth, was yesterday sitting in front of a fire at her home, her clothing caught fire and she was burned to death.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 10.--News has just reached Washington that the dead body of an unknown man was found a night or two since lying in the road near Beallsville with a bullet hole in him.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 10.--The determination of the negro population to burn that part of Palatka which escaped the conflagration of Saturday morning was again exemplified at 2 o'clock this morning.

Mr. Mapleson's season of Italian opera was entered upon, at the Academy of Music, last evening with a representation of "Il Barbiere." The familiar concomitants of a first night were not wanting, and there was the usual large audience, the usual applause, and the wonted profusion of flowers.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10.--In the ragged and unkempt crowd of petty criminals brought into Judge Allison's Court of the Quarter Sessions to-day for trial were 15 boys. The youngest was 12 years of age. He pleaded guilty to the theft of several dollars that he invested in two kettledrums, six flutes and some toys.

ALBANY, Nov. 10.--The first trial of a Chinaman in an Eastern State for murder was begun before Judge Peckham to-day. Ah kay, who was indicted for the murder of Wee Kee, his partner in the laundry, was defended by Col. C.S. Spencer, of New-York, and District Attorney D. Cady Herrick appeared for the prosecution.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 10.--To-day the advance force of track layers of the Baker City Branch of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company going east reached Huntington. Oregon, and there met the advance force of track layers of the Oregon Short Line coming west.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--The annual report of Lieut.-Gen. P.H. Sheridan has been made to the Secretary of War. It covers the period from his assignment to the command of the army, Nov. 1, 1883, to Nov. 1, 1884.

As a means of guarding against insufficiency of the Croton water supply, the Bronx River was tapped during the Summer, and for about two months the houses above Harlem bridge, on the east side, have had water from the new pipes alone. The water was bad, being dis colored and of offensive taste and odor.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 10.--Frank Cook, 21 years of age, was found dead with a gunshot wound in his abdomen in the woods near Bantam Lake, Litchfield, about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Considerable feeling has been exhibited between the Republican and Democratic County Committees regarding the official canvass of the vote of the county to-morrow.
BOSTON, Nov. 10.--Advices from Turk's Island, under date Nov. 2, state that the brig Julia E. Haskell, Capt. Paine, sailed from Nassau Oct. 11 for Baltimore with grain.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--The stage at the Chicago Museum presented a scene last night which, though not on the bills, was decidedly realistic and thrilling. The house was packed. The Australian Novelty Company was announced to appear.

WILKESBAREE, Penn., Nov. 10.--The Enterprise Colliery, at Port Bowkley, operated by Andrew Langdon, of Buffalo, in which the recent cave-in took place, will shortly be reopened for work. A force of men has been at work for some time clearing up the wreck and putting the workings in order.

LONDON, Nov. 10.--The show in celebration of the entrance into office of the new Lord Mayor of London took place to-day. It passed off with immense eclat.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 10.--Wednesday morning of last week Joseph Bashaw, a laborer, found on the banks of the Nashua River the dead body of an infant wrapped in straw matting.

Section 4,609 of the United States Revised Statutes provides that no shipping agent shall charge more than $2 for procuring a berth, to ship, for any sailor.

The sun was not up sooner yesterday morning than the dopositors of the East Chester Savings Bank. Although the bank was not to open its doors until 10 o'clock, there was a crowd in front of the building long before 8 o'clock.

LONDON, Nov. 10.--Warren Bey telegraphs me to-day as follows concerning the cholera in Paris: "I believe that the epidemic will prove mild and limited in its scope, because of the good sanitary conditions of Paris, the absence of anything like a panic and the lateness of the visitation.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 10.--Some time after midnight Sunday night a crew train on the Erie Railroad found the body of a man lying on the track near Great Bend, Penn. The car wheels had crushed the shoulders and chest and otherwise mutilated the body.

COHOES, N.Y., Nov. 10.--There is much talk here over the fact that Hall, Harmon Co., grocers; John Sanford, dry goods dealer, and David White, a slater, are being openly boycotted by their Republican customers because they worked and voted for St. John and the Prohibition ticket. Sanford was a candidate for Congress and White for the Assembly on the temperance ticket.

Prof. John M. Laflin, who was knocked out by Lulu Hurst in Wallack's Theatre last Summer, suffered a triple defeat last evening in Madison-Square Garden at the hands of the great master of the manly art, John L. Sullivan.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10, 1884. The President to-day appointed Gov. Schuyler Crosby, of Montana, to be First Assistant Postmastergeneral.

NEW-MILFORD, Conn., Nov. 10.--The independent Republicans, "mugwumps," "Pharisees," and Cleveland Democrats united in a grand celebration over Cleveland's election on Saturday night.
CAIRO, Nov. 10.--Rumors of the fall of Khartoum and the death of Gen. Gordon are now arriving by the way of Massowah.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10.--To-day's session of the Plenary Council lasted several hours. The entire episcopacy of the United States, with a single exception, is attending the Council. The absent prelate is Bishop John Tuigg, D.D., Bishop of Pittsburg and Administrator of Allegheny, who is detained by illness.

CANTON, Miss., Nov. 10.--A. W. Schield, large merchants at Durant and Greenville, Miss., have made an assignment. Liabilities, $85,000; assets not stated.
LONDON, Nov. 10.--The loss incurred by Messrs. Stewart Brothers Sponcer by the burning of their oil works at Strood will amount to 250,000.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 10.--Reports are being sent all over the country about heavy iron contracts being countermanded and large glass orders being canceled in consequence of Clevelands election as President.

The election of officers of the St. Nicholas Society took place last evening at the Brunswick. Two tickets were in the field, but the only important contesting nominations were between John Jay and Cornelius Vanderbilt, for the Presidency, and between Robert Stuyvesant and Carlisle Norwood, Jr., for the first VicePresidency.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10.--W.H. Bulkley, the Quincy-street harnessmaker, of faith-cure fame, and W.R. Torrey, his colaborer, returned Saturday from Watertown, Wis., where, since Oct. 16, they have held a series of meetings for the purpose of curing the sick and making converts to the Free Methodist faith.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10.--Albaugh's Grand Opera House, the first edifice worthy of that designation ever ereeted in this city, was opened to the public for the first time this evening with a performance of "Semiramide" by the Abbott English Opera Troupe.

Early yesterday morning Officer Krauch discovered that a burglary had been committed on his post at No. 192 Canal-street, where the store of Nathan Cohen had been robbed of tailor's trimming worth $30. He went to the station house, in Elizabeth-street, and reported the case.

PANA, Ill., Nov. 11.--In a dense fog this marning a "wild" engine running on the time of the northwest-bound freight train on the Ohio and Mississippi Railway ran into that train. Both engineers and the fireman of the freight train were killed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11.--Dairyman A.M. Clapp, who has been at the head of the establishment set up in this city for milking Federal employes in the interest of Blaine, Elkins, and Jones; appears to be out of work.

LONDON, Nov. 11.--The master of the steamer Lochiel, which vessel was chartered by the Government to take the battalion of police to the Isle of Skye, refused to proceed, and the owner of the steamer has canceled his agreement.

NASSVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 11.--The national convention of, the Phi Delta Theta, College Fraternity met in this city this morning, with an unusually large number of delegates and all the general officers present. An address of welcome was made and responded to. The exercises will continue four days.

Having been badly hurt by tripping and falling on a bit of bad pavement, Timothy McBride sued the city for damages. A jury in the Supreme Court decided that the city had been negligent, but awarded McBride only 6 cents damages. Judge Lawrence has act the verdict aside, holding that if the city was negligent McBride's injuries, being serious, demanded greater compensation than 6 cents.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11.--Corrected returns from the counties in the First Congressional District of California give Henley (Dem.) 59 majority. The Republicans concede his majority, but will insist upon a recount. Henley will be the sole representative in Congress of the Democracy of the entire Pacific coast.

HALIFAX, Nova Sootia, Nov.11.--A cablegram has been received by Daniel Cronan, owner of the brigantine Elsie Cronan, reporting that that vessel is at Inagua in distress. All her sails and rigging had been lost, and a portion of her cargo had been jettisoned, and she was without possible assistance.

Charles R. Parker, who for 10 years past had held the responsible position of cashier st the Fifth-Avenue Hotel, committed suicide yesterday morning at his residence, No. 272 West One Hundred and Twenty-seventh-street, by shooting himself in the head with a revolver.

EBENSBURG, Penn., Nov. 11.--Seven prisoners escapted from the jail here ar 4 o'clock this afternoon. Three of them were afterward recaptured and the other four are still at large. The escape was made by taking the keys from the jailor and placing him in a cell, while they broke the locks on the door of the jail yard.

BUFFALO, Nov. 11.--The Blaine meeting in this city, this evening, was a laborious attempt to put a solemn face on a farce. Its purpose was to protest that the Cleveland men should not protest against fraud.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 11.--Thomas Deardon and Samuel Bell were run over by a train on the Canadian Pacific Railroad near Rat Portage on Sunday night and instantly killed. An express train from Port Arthur yesterday morning, on the same road, this side of Rat Portage, ran into a wood train, killing one man and injuring four others.

BOSTON, Nov. 11.--E. Poppelhawer, who has done business under the firm name of the Boston Diamond Cutting Company, is said to be missing with diamonds belonging to various Boston firms and private customers valued at a large sum.

Theodore Roosevelt spoke last evening before the Nineteenth Century Club, at the house of Courtland Palmer, on "The Spirit of Republicanism." The house was crowded and the speaker was listened to attentively. Since the time that Grant ran for his second term, he said, there had been comparatively few differences between the two opposing parties.

Pope, Minister of Railways and Agriculture; John Carling, Postmaster-General; Alonzo Wright, member of Parliament, and Secretary C. Dinkwater, of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company arrived in this city to-day from a tour of inspection of that road, having traveled from Ottawa to Port Moody, in British Columbia.

Manager Amberg, of the Thalia Theatre, yesterday concluded an engagement with Mrs. Victoria Morosini-Hulskamp for six months in concerts, and after that in opera bouffe. TROY, N.Y., Nov. 11--Simon West, of Wischer's Ferry, Saratoga County, entered the hotel of George H. Smith, at that place, last night, and attacked Smith with a butcher's knife. The trouble is said to have arisen over an election dispute.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 12.--A boiler exploded at Kling's foundry this morning and demolished the two-story brick machine shop in which 40 men were working. Only five persons were hurt, and these slightly. Heavy pieces of iron flew through Gibney's foundry, also, and tore the roof off.

The Tribune, with an assumption of calmness and complacency, declares that the special verdict of the people against the candidacy of Mr. BLAINE, which was demanded and expected by the independents, has been whittled down to the lean and barren end of nothing because CLEVELAND receives the Electoral vote of this State by a slender plurality.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 13.--A man named Jack Cook shot and killed a man named Phillips to-night. He used a bouble-barreled shot gun, and put 17 buckshot into Phillips's body. Both men were railroad engineers. Do mestic matters are the cause.

It is an interesting fact to note that Monday, the day on which the dedication exercises of the Newport Historical Society's new building took place, was also the anniversary of the natal day of the venerable and distinguished President of that organization, the Hon. Francis Brinley.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 13.--In the case of the Commonwealth against Thomas Whyte, late Cashier of the Planters and Mechanics' Bank, which was set down for trial in the Hustings Court to-day, a nolle prosequi was entered at the suggestion of the Commonwealth Attorney, who stated that he was frank enough to admit that it would be useless for him to go to trial with the case with the testimony he had been able to get.

"The Dangers of Railroad and Corporation Riots, and How Best to Counteract Them" was the title of a paper read yesterday by Gen. E. L. Molineux before the members of the Military Service Institution at Governor's Island. "Immense as was the damage caused by the riots of 1877," he said, "the rioters could have doubled it with impunity before it was possible to check their career.

HIGH POINT, N. C., Nov. 13.--The largest crowd that ever attended the Eastern field trials in North Carolina was present to-day. In the Membership Stakes Buckellew beat Dashing Novice, Brimstone beat Vixen, and Slocum beat Lucia. Each member handles his own dog.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--A report, which is said to come from good authority, was circulated in the Pension Office to-day, to the effect that Gen. Beaver, of Pennsylvania, had been offered the position of Commissioner of Pensions, made vacant by Col. Dudley's resignation, and pact declined the honor.

The widow and daughter of the late William J. Skidmore, of North Hempstead, Long Island, are seeking to recover $150,000 from the estate of the late Abram P. Skidmore, who was lost on the Seawanhaka about four years ago and who was the Administrator of William J. Skidmore's estate at the time of his death.

MANCHESTER, N. H., Nov.13.--At a meeting of agents here this afternoon a general cutdown in wages of operatives was agreed upon, to go into effect Dec. 1. In the Amoskeag and Stark corporations it will be 5 per cent. The Amory reduction will not exceed 8 per cent.; the Langdon will not exceed 10 per cent. The Manchester corporation reduction is not announced, but will probably be in the same ratio as the others.

The New-York Indian Association held its yearly meeting in the chapel of the Broadway Tabernacle yesterday forenoon. This association is composed of charitable ladies of this city, and is an auxiliary to the National Indian Association of Philadelphia.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 13.--Gov. Thomas J.Jarvis was to-day asked what effect Cleve land's election would have upon the colored vote in the South.

While the people of New-Rochelle were yesterday discussing the elopement of John E. Quinn with Miss Hattie Marshall on the previous evening, preparations were being perfected for another quiet wedding in the same place.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13.--The regular November meeting of the Board of Trustees of Princeton College was held to-day. President McCosh stated to the board the prosperous condition of the institution, and announced that the departments of study had been divided into three systematized groups: Science, literature, and philosophy.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 13.--The following returns to the Railroad Commissioners will be published to-day: The total income of the NewYork, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad for the year ended Sept. 30, 1884, was $6,847,258; total expenses, including taxes, $4,828,245; net income, $2,059,012; rentals and interest, $499,841; surplus for the year, $9,171; total surplus Sept. 30, $2,459,306.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 13.--The editorial in to-day's issue of THE TIMES entitled "An 'Opinion'" causes a great deal of comment in reference to the alleged extra-judicial decision or opinion in the case brought by two of the Dutchess County canvassers before Judge Bernard yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 13.--For sev eral days past the Mohawk in the neighborhood of Hoffman's Ferry has been black with boats filled with men searching for the body of Jacob Mohr, the rich farmer who disappeared mysteri ously last Friday night.
CHICAGO, Nov. 13.--At their session today, the architects adapted a constitution and bylaws fixing the name of the new organization as The Western Association of Architects.
"Lords and Commons" will be produced at Daly's to-morrow night, with new scenery and a notable cast.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--The National Rupublican has for two succeeding days given to Washington people tables alleged to show the returns from New-York as sent "by the Asso ciated Press and official."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 13.--Final arrangements for the cattlemen's convention, which convenes here next week, have been made. The report of the delegations show that about 1,000 cattlemen will be present.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 13.--Official re turns from the Ninth District show that Wads worth, (Rep.,) is elected to Congress by 300 ma jority over Powers, (Dem.)

The report was circulated among the politicians last night that Mayor Edson had made his peace with John Kelly, and would give evidence of his fidelity to Tammany about Dec. 11. On or about that date the terms of Public Works Commissioner Hubert O. Thompson and of Corporation Counsel Lacombe will expire.

Mr. George W. Cable has lately been chosen an honorary member of the Woman's Club of New-Orleans and has acknowledged the compliment in a letter in which he says: "I like the idea. Rightly managed, the think is certainly good. It ought to do good.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 13.--Three men, named Charles Young, of Buffalo, N.Y.; Louis La Branche, of New-Orleans, La., and one Woodson, who claimed to be a detective, camped last night near Lavergne, a town 40 miles from Nashville.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 13.--Two years ago Harrison Becker, of this city, was transferred as an incurable lunatic from the Utica Asylum to the Willard Asylum. At that time Frank Becker, of Schenectady, was in the same asylum.

The Unity Club of this city is engaged in wrestling with the political history of the late civil war. Last Wednesday evening elaborate papers were read by E. Cort Williams, H. J. Buntin, and Dr. Walter A. Dun.
The nominal rates of the railroads engaged in the passenger war remained unchanged yesterday. There were, in fact, no such things as established fares.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 13.--Two boys were walking along an old deserted lane on the Atterbury farm, near West State-street, at about 10 o'clock this morning. When midway between the residences of William H. Rawle and Gen. Dickinson, they were startled almost out of their wits by suddenly stubling upon the body of a dead man.
Late Honolulu papers bring intelligence of the death in that city on the 15th ultimo of Bernice Pareahi Bishop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--Lieut. Greely called at the War Department to-day, after reporting his arrival to Gen. Hazen at the Signal Office, and paid his respects to Secretary Lincoln. In company with Gen. Ruggles he afterward called upon Commodore Schley. The Commodore was absent from his room when the call was...

The Fire Commissioners yesterday directed Chief Shay to reorganize Engine Company No. 36, in Fourth-avenue, near One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, which is in a demoralized condition owing to the misconduct and insubordination of some of its members.
The recent experiments made at Spezia to ascertain the penetrative power of the 120-ton gun have shown that no armor yet made can resist the new steel projectile thrown by this monster gun.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13.--The National Associ ation of Stockmen commenced its second annual session at the Sherman House this morning. There were upward of 200 of the most prominent stockmen in America in attendance, represent ing Arizona, Colordo, Dakota, District of Columbia, ...
MACPHERSON, Kan., Nov. 13.--August Tuxhorn, a farmer of this county, to-day set fire to his house, barn, and granary, and then blew his brains out with a shotgun.
CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 13.--The meeting of the American Racing Association to-day was devoted to a revision of the rules. The most important action was in regard to post bookmaking.
VIENNA, Nov. 13.--The Polititsche Correspondenz says that Mr. William W. Astor, the American Minister at Rome, resigned his position as soon as he received news of the election of Gov. Cleveland.

Capt. Alexander S. Williams happened along Wednesday night when Matthew T. Griffin and Thomas Preston, waiters at the FifthAvenue Hotel, were fighting at Broadway and Twenty-fourth-street, and he arrested them.

The result of the vote for President has been declared by the Boards of Canvassers in all the counties of New-York State except Erie, Franklin, and New-York. The result in Kings was announced yesterday, and it increased Gov. Cleveland's plurality by 19, St. Lawrence added ...

Some years ago a most interesting "find" of fossils was made at the Portland stone quarries. They were of high scientific value, and it was decided to send them to Yale College for preservation and study.

BOSTON, Nov. 13.--At a meeting of the Overseers of Harvard College to-day it was voted to concur with the President and Fellows in the election of Whitman Gurney as a Fellow of the corporation in place of Alexander Agassiz, resigned.

WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 13.--Official returns from all the counties in this State from the October election show that the Democrates have elected 38 Representatives and 15 Senators, and the Rupublicans 26 Representatives and 11 Senators, to the Legislature. The Democrates have a majority of 14 on joint ballot.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov.13.--This after noon at about 5 o'clock the house of Hugh Wise man, on South-avenue, was broken into and the trunks and wardrobes were opened and robbed. The family were absent at the time, so that it is impossible to tell how much was stolen.
QUEBEC, Nov. 13.--The steamship Scotland, from London, which is now passing inward between Father Point and Quebec is reported to have a case of smallpox on board.
Yesterday was "Reporters' Day" at Brighton Beach, and the races were witnessed by a large number of persons. Following is a summary of the events:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13.--The General Committee of the Board of Church Extension of the Methodist Episcopal Church assembled here this afternoon, Bishop Bowman in the chair. The Rev. J. H. Wilbur, of Washington Territory, conducted the devotional exercises. The roll was called by the Secretary.
From all the railroads that run near the village of Freehold, in Monmouth County, N.J., a slender column of granite, towering above intervening trees and hills, is visible upon a distant slope.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 13.--Official re turns elect N.B. Eldridge (Dem.) to Congress in the Second District by 23 majority. The other districts remain as heretofore reported. This gives one Democratic gain on Congressmen in this State.

There has been some comment on the fact that the Chorus Society, of which Theodore Thomas is the director, and the Oratorio Society, for which Dr. Damrosch wields the baton, both gave their first concerts last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- Mr. Blaine's spacious and elegant horse on Dupont-circle, in this city, was brilliantly illuminated to-night from top to bottom in honor of the election of Cleveland and Hendricks, and the long procession of Democrats, bearing gigantic roosters...

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Nov. 13.--An explosion of dynamite occurred on Willow-street this morning, occasioned by a spark from the pipe of a workman at the water works falling on and exploding a package of cartridges. Three men were injured, David Foley severely. He will probably lose his sight.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13.--A new bark--the Julia Rollins--the first square-rigged vessel built in this city since 1878, was launched this afternoon from the shipyard of William Skinner Sons. She is 147 feet in length. 34 feet beam and 16 feet 9 inches depth of hold.

The Oregon and Transcontinental Company has prepared a circular containing a proposition to its stockholders to take a new collateral trust loan of $10,000,000 at 8 per cent. interest on the company's securities now held by the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 13.--At 10 o'clock this morning, as a train from Grapemont, on the Colorado Central Railway, was drawing into the Beaver River station, the two rear cars were thrown from the track down a five-foot embankment and several passengers were painfully injured, though none fatally.

TROY, N. Y., Nov. 13.--John Maxwell, of South Argyle, Washington County, who had been insane for many years, and who was confined in an old outhouse, was burned to death yesterday by the destruction of the building by fire.

PARIS, Nov. 13.--The cholera epidemic seems unquestionably to be spreading gradually throughout the city. In spite of this, however, the people show no signs as yet of panic. Pre cautions of every kind are being taken by the public and by individuals to impede, as far as possible, the deadly progress of the plague.

QUEBEC, Nov. 13.--The mail steamship Parisian will make her last trip from this port for the season on Saturday, and the Circassian and Brooklyn, which sail on the Saturday following, will be the last steamers hence this year.
CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 13.--A shock of earthquake was felt in the northern and western sections of this city last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--Secretary McCulloch to-day received the following petition in regard to the importion of old rags from Europeau ports:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 13.--The PhiDelta Theta fraternity are holding a large and most enthusiastic national convention in this city, 49 active and 8 Alumi chapters being represented. The delegates yesterday visited the Vanderbilt University in a body.
The new number of that excellent periodical, the Jahrbuch of the Berlin Museum, contains the account of a notable artistic discovery or rather identification.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 13.--Intelligence was received here to-day from British Columbia of a murder which was committed in the Pro vincial Penitentiary in New-Westminster on the 4th inst.

ALBANY, N. Y., Nov. 13.--The Governor to-day transmitted to the State Board of Health a communication from the National Board of Health on the subject of cholera. Immediately upon its receipt Dr. Alfred Ludlow Carroll, Secretary and Executive Officer of the State Board of Health, issued the following:

The charters of 721 national banks, with an aggregate capital of over $189,000,000, will expire during the year 1885. This is more than one-third of the entire number of national banks now in existence.

Among a crowd of young men who left their seats and hurried out to see another man between the acts of a play at the Brooklyn Theatre wednesday night was when the police called "a flashily dressed swell." He sat well forward in the orchestra chairs during the performance, attracting the attention of the people around him by his mellifluous laugh and curly black hair.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 13.--The Hon. E.B. Washburne delivered an address to-night in this city before the State Historical Society of Wisconsin, reviewing the career of Henry Gratiot, a pioneer of Wisconsin, upon the occasion of the presentation of his portrait to the society.
MADISON, Ind., Nov. 13.--Ballard, the mail agent arrested here for robbing the Post Office, pleaded guilty at Indianapolis this after noon, throwing himself on the mercy of the court.

A pretty home wedding took place yesterday at No. 79 Fifth-avenue, Miss Isabella Banks being married to Dr. Thomas E. Satterthwaite. The bride was attended by two sisters as bridesmaids, Miss Josie M. Banks and Miss Maria Banks.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 13.--The Executive Committee of the Women's Foreign Missionary Society of the Methodist Episcopal Church continued its session to-day with Mrs. Dr. Warren presiding.

At the track of the New-York Driving Club, in Morrisania, better known as the Fleet wood track, a hundred or more gentlemen went when Mr. Isidor Cohnfeld's splendid team. Maxey Cobb and Neta Medium, trotted a mile in 2:15 , lowering the record of 2:16 , made by Frank Work's team, Edward and Dick Swiveller, by a half second.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 13.--The extensive cooper shops of the Standard Oil Company in this city will close down indefinitely next Monday on account of the scarcity of orders.
The Queens County Board of Supervisors, as a Board of County Canvassers, met again yesterday morning at the County Clerk's office, Jamaica.

The regular monthly meeting of the Trustees of the Actors' Fund took place yesterday afternoon in the Fund's rooms in the Theatre Comique. Harry Miner, the President, was in the chair, and A. M. Palmer, Samuel Colville, Harrison Grey Fiske, W. W. Tillotson, W. E. Sinn, and Assistant Secretary B. A. Baker were present.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--It appears by a dispatch of the 4th of September last to the Department of State by Mr. Foote, the United States Minister to Corea, that Mr. Thomas A. Edison has been granted permission to place his system of electric lights within the palace grounds and buildings at Seoul.

NEW-LONDON, Nov. 13.--The centenary of the Seventh Day Baptist Church at Water ford, near this city, one of the few churches of the faith in the country, was celebrated with literary and other exercises by a large company of men and women in the old church on Tues day. Timely papers were read by many clergymen.

Edward Jeans, a member of the firm of Jeans Taylor, builders, of No. 103 South Fifthavenue, charged Augustus Heck, a constable, of Haverstraw, N. Y., with extortion at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 13.--Bullion from Holland to the amount of 60,000 was again purchased in the open market yesterday for shipment to America.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Nov. 13.--This has been a great day for the Thorn Creek pool. Not only has its production been augumented by several thousand barrels but its hitheto narrow limits have been extended and unknown, possibilities beyond opened up.

BOSTON, Nov. 13.--The Shoe and Leather Insurance Company, of Boston, will retire from the business of fire insurance. By a vote of its Directors to-day its Boston City business and that of its New-England agencies was reinsured with the Niagara Fire Insurance Company, of New-York.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13, 1884. The Treasury Department to-day purchased 870,000 ounces of silver for delivery at the New-Orleans and Philadelphia Mints.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--Postmaster-General Hatton has been giving some attention to a demand for greater postal facilities between New-York and Brooklyn, the complaint having been made by business men in New-York that...

"While engaged as a compositor on a leading New-York newspaper on the night of Nov. 12-13, 1833, it was my good fortune," says James S. Drake, an employe of the Sunday Leader, "to be detained at the once is Wallstreet until a very late hour.

The Trunk Line Presidents' Committee, which was in session for two days, concluded its work yesterday. Freight matters alone were considered. East-bound rates, especially from Chicago, have been thoroughly demoralized since July. Grain and flour are now being carried from Chicago ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 13.--The coal miners' conspiracy cases will be called for trial at Washington, Penn., next Monday. True bills have been found against President Costello and seven or eight others engaged in the late troubles at Coal Centre and Wood's Run.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Nov. 13.--Thomas Horne, R. Rattray, H. Watts, and W. Hamilton, of Wolfe Island, were drowned last night, it is supposed by the swamping of their boat, while crossing from Cape Vincent to Wolfe Island.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 13.--Mr. F.W. Own bey, of Bakerfield, Cal., arrived in the city to day and stopped at the St. James Hotel. He is here for the purpose of arranging for the con veyance over the Union Pacific of 1,500 negroes from Tennessee to California.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13.--Annie Van Reed pleaded guilty in the Quarter Sessions Court to-day to a charge of throwing vitriol upon Henry Myers. The latter testified that on the night of Sept. 17, as he was standing at Eighth-street and Fairmount-avenue, the girl came up to him and said that she wanted him to be "as good to her as he had been."

MANSFIELD, Penn., Nov.13.--Masked robbers last night at 10 o'clock entered the residence of Capt. John Morrow, an aged invalid, and, after binding and gagging Mrs. Morrow and a lady friend named McCoy, ransacked the house and secured $500 in cash aud other valuables.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 13.--There was no legislative session of the Plenary Council to-day. Services were held at the cathedral, where a requiem mass for deceased prelates was solemnized.

Ex-Gov. Daniel H. Chamberlain, of South Carolina, furnishes the Independent, of this week "a calm view of the election," in which he says that no canvass has ever interested him more deeply and none ever excited in him less bitterness or uncharitableness.

Recently an old man from a New-England State went into the Treasury Department in Washington and said that about 20 years ago he had found some old bonds among the papers of an uncle, a man of national reputation for ability and wealth from 1820 to 1836, whose name he...
BUENOS AYRES, Nov. 13, via Galveston.-- Another case of cholera has appeared here, causing great alarm. The strictest quarantine will be observed on all vessels proceeding from France.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 13.--The Governor to-day respited Warren Price, the Johnson County murderer, until Dec. 12, and commuted the sentence of Henry Cato, the De Kalb County murderer, to imprisonment for life. Both men were to be hanged to-morrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn, Nov. 13.--Judge Fitiletter to-day issued a writ of capias for the arrest of Edward Lowe, in a suit instituted by David White to recover $5,000 damages for the aliemation of his wife's affection.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Nov. 13.--An inmate of the Sullivan County Poorhouse named David Whaley lately died at that institution, near Monticello. Whaley came to the house in 1837, and was about 70 years old at the time of his death. He was always insane, but was never kept under restraint except for punishment, as he was regarded as harmless by the keepers.

The annual meeting and commencement exercises of the Brooklyn Maternity and NewYork State School for Training Nurses attracted a large audience to the hall of the Long Island Historical Society, in Brooklyn, last evening.

PHILADELPHIA Nov. 13.--All the members of the Gun Foundry Board were in secret session again to-day at the rooms of the American Iron and Steel Association. During the morning a consultation lasting more than two hours was held with Mr. Townsend, President, ...

Henry Fleck, a German cook, 38 years of age, who lived with his family on the second floor of the tenement house No. 625 First-avenue, shot himself in the right temple with a revolver last night, inflicting a fatal wound. He had been in bad health for some time, and, being unable to obtain employment, was despondent.

The first concert given this season by the Now-York Chorus Society took place at Steinway Hall last evening, in presence of the usual overflowing audience. The most important number of the programme was Dvorak's "Stabat Mater," which the society first performed last Spring, and the selections included, besides, Beethoven's...

EUFAULA, Ala., Nov. 13.--Two incendiary attempts were discovered and thwarted at 2 o'clock this morning. One was in the rear of Bearringer, Strauss West's store, in the heart of the business block on Broad-street.

Three hundred people crossed the East River to Blackwell's Island yesterday afternoon to bid farewell to the eighth, and so far the largest, graduating class of trained nurses, who, in the language of the hospital report, are doing their utmost to sweep away the abuses incident to the reign of "Betsy Prig" and "Sairey Gamp."

Peter Dalton, who was arrested in Yonkers on Wednesday for the death of Maria Morihan in Newark, arrived in the last-named city yesterday. Maria Morihan was the dissipated wife of a watchman employed at Gill's factory, in Orange.

Prof. Albert Gabriel, alias Griswold, who was charged with forgery at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday by Detective James K. Price, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, is one of the most persistent swindlers that the police have ever had to deal with.

The Board of Aldermen has rescinded its resolution of Aug. 30 and given its consent anew, subject to certain conditions, to the Broadway Surface Railroad Company to construct a horse railroad on Broadway from the Battery to Unionsquare.
Among the immigrants who arrived yesterday on the National steamship The Queen were Rosa Sehuminchler and her seven children, who came to this country more than a year ago,...

After a spirited contest the Board of Chosen Freeholders at Newark last evening elected Dr. L.S. Hinkley, of New-York, Super intendent of the Essex County Insane Asylum. His competitiors were Dr. Charles Young, at present Visiting Physician, and Dr. Booth, of the State Asylum at Morris Plains. Edwin J. Heus tis was elected Steward and Rebecca Bail Matron.
ALLENTOWN, Penn., Nov. 13.--Some time ago John J. Shadt, of this city, sent a beautifully flnished horseshoe bearing the word "Luck" to Gov. Cleveland.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 13.--A large quan tity of powder stored in a shed on Delaware Creek, four miles from this city, exploded at 10 o'clock this morning, making a report which was heard for 40 miles in every direction. The windows of houses in that quarter or the city near the scene were generally broken.

Mr. Van Wiel, representing the Amsterdam bondholders of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad Company, has returned to this city from his tour of inspection over that road. There are now three members of the foreign bondholder's committee in New-York, and they expect to begin work on their report right away. These three members represent the English, French, and German interests.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 13.--On Sunday morning last at 2 o'clock Theodore Gilliens, a well-known brakeman on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was found dead on the track of the Erie Railway, near Great Bend.

WORCESTWER, Mass., Nov. 13.--Three weeks ago some of the students at the Worcester County Free Institute, in this city, led a horse belonging to one of the Professors up two flights of stairs to the school chapel where they left him over night.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 13.--At a meeting of the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church of this city to-night, a call was unani mously extended to the Rev. Lawrence M. Col felt, of Philadelphia, for 10 years Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of that city, but now supplying the Oxford Presbyterian Church at Philadelphia. The salary was fixed at $3,600.

The Committee of One Hundred of the Brooklyn Independent Republicans, which did so effective work for the election of Grover Cleveland to the Presidency, held its first meeting since the campaign last night at the Assembly Rooms in the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Dr. William L. Hardy, City Physician, read a paper last evening before the Society of Medical Jurisprudence upon the Rhinelander case. He had himself examined young Rhinelander while in prison, and this examination,...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--The acceptance of the resignation of Second Lieut. George H. Cameron, Seventh Cavalry, to take effect Nov. 20, 1884, having been revoked by the President, special order No. 150, July 10, 1884, announcing the acceptance of said resignation has been rescinded.

The tenth annual dinner of the NewYork Jewelers' Association took place at Delmonico's last evening. The organization numbers only 35 members, but 115 persons sat down at the five tables, which were decorated with handsome silver pieces from the counters of the members' stores.
PARIS, Nov. 13.--Prime Minister Ferry communicated dispatches to the Cabinet this morning from which it would appear that Gen. Gordon had been shot dead while passing from Khartoum to Berber.

PARIS Nov. 13.--The Patti divorce case, a decision in which was rendered yesterday, has excited much remark. Mme. Patti first presented a petition for divorce from her husband, the Marquis de Caux. The Marquis thereupon presented a cross petition.

Mme. Patti's agent, Signor Lavelli, was found last evening in his apartments at the NewYork Hotel. "By the terms," he said, "of Mme. Patti's contract with Col. Mapleson the Colonel was to have had deposited with August Belmont Co., in this city, on Oct. 15, $16,000, which sum was to have been paid over to her immediately on her arrival in this country.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 13.--Miss Pearl Tyler, daughter of the late ex-President Tyler, was married at 5 o'clock this afternoon to the Hon. William Mumford Ellis, member of the House of Delegates from Montgomery County.

The Belleville and Carondelet Railroad Company applied to the Stock Exchange nearly 18 months ago to have $500,000 of its 6 per cent, first mortgage bonds placed on the regular stock list. The bonds, which were of the denomination of $1,000 each, were rejected by the Stock List Committee on the gronnd that the workmanship of the engraver was not up to the required standard.
Mr. Samuel Brandram, the English reader, recited the "Merchant of Venice" last evening, at Chickering Hall, at the first of the International Star series of entertainments for this season.

The New-York Society for the Relief of Ruptured and Crippled held its twenty-first annual meeting in its building, No. 135 East Forty-second-street, yesterday afternoon. Willlam H. Macy was in the chair. James Knight, M. D., Surgeon-in-Chief, reported that the number of new cases treated during the year...

An international exhibition of inventions will be held in London in 1885, and an official, announcement to that effect has been made through the British Consulates. The exhibition will be under the patronage of the Queen, and the Prince of Wales will be its President.

Several of the Republican ward associations in Brooklyn have taken up with great earnestness the business of expelling such of their members as are known to have voted against the Republican candidate for President.

There is still some excitement in Mount Vernon over the failure of the banking house of J.M. Masterton Co., but it has been tempered down so that the depositors are now disposed to let the matter be settled in a judical manner in the courts.

The wit, the tenderness, the playful tatire, and the humanity of Shakespeare's "Much Ado" charmed an audience that filled every part of the Star Theatre last evening. Would that it might be written that the play and its performance were tokens of the prevailing theatrical taste, for then there would be no...

There is discord in St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Peekskill. The Rector, the Rev. George M. C. Fiske, has resigned and accepted a call to St. Stephen's Church at Providence, R. I., and he will preach hie farewell sermon in Peekskill on Sunday, the 30th inst.

Mrs. Louisa Wolcott, the agent of the Eighth District Charity Organization, at No. 214 East Forty-second-street, was robbed on Wednesday evening last. She was about to close up the office and start for home, just before 6 o'clock,...
The crew of the whaling bark Eliza had a peculiar experience north. Aug. 15 the vessel was hemmed in by the ice, and for five days she did not move.
It was stated yesterday by one of the officers of the Metropolitan Bank, of this city, that a majority of the stockholders had assented to the proposition to wind up the affairs of that institution.

HAVANA, Nov. 13.--Dispatches to the Diario de la Marina from Madrid, dated Nov. 5, says that Senor Cassa, now civil Governor of Guipascoa, has been appointed Secretary of the Government of the island of Cuba.
The Board of Canvassers resumed the work of counting the vote cast for the Electoral tickets at the late election in Kings County yesterday morning. The Twenty-third Ward was the first taken up.

The Democratic headquarters in the Hoffman House were visited last night by a delegation from Tammany Hall, composed of ex-Senator Forster, W. Bourke Cockran, Senator Cullen, Maurice F. Holahan, Henry Bischoff, Jr., John E. Wade, and Philip Malone. They held a conference with Chairman William E. Smith, of the State Committee, and Senator Gorman, of the National Committee.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 13.--A repre sentative of the Times visited Olothe, Kan., yes terday and interviewed ex-Gov. St. John upon the political situation.

Ex-Alderman Samuel A. Lewis was taken to the Sheriff's office yesterday to give bail in a civil suit brought by his sister, Harriet L. Lewis, of No. 309 West Fifty-fourth-street, who charges that he has kept from her $1,130, which had been intrusted to him by her for investment.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 13.--About 3:30 this morning, while attempting to arrest a burglar caught in the act in Newport, Ky., Policeman Joseph Edgar was fatally shot. The burglar escaped.

A long procession, preceded by six stout police officers of the Broadway squad, bearing a black, cloth-covered coffin, filed yesterday afternoon from the house at One Hundred and Fiftyfifth-street and the Grand Boulevard, and wended its way to the Church of the Intercession, three blocks higher up the boulevard.

The steamship George W. Clyde, Capt. Holmes, which arrived yesterday from Turk's Island, brought the Captains and portions of the crews of the brigs R. M. Heslin, Julia E. Haskell, and Emma L. Hall, and of the bark Cairo, which vessels were lost during the hurricane which visited the neighborhood of Turk's Island about the middle of October.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 13--A joint reso lution was introduced in the House to-day ask ing the Government to divide the United States surplus in the Treasury among the States for school purposes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--It is understood that the question raised by the counsel for Judge-Advocate Gen. Swaim, with regard to the legality and authority of the court-martial appointed in the latter'a case has been decided adversely to the accused, and that the court will assemble and the trial begin on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13.--The Special Press Commissioner of the New-Orleans World Exposition is perfecting arrangements to have a Congressional excursion of Senators and Representatives from here to New-Orleans, to be present at the opening of the Exposition on Dec. 16.
ALBANY, Nov., 13.--Albany County-- Official: Cleveland, 18,345; Blaine, 17,698; St. John, 312; Butler, 983.

GALVESTON, Texas, Nov. 13.--United States District Judge Sabin this afternoon dis solved an injuction, granted some days ago on application of the Western Union Telegraph Company, restraining the Baltimore and Ohio Company from using the franchise along the line of the Texas Pacific Railroad through the Red River country.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 13.--A dispatch from Jef ferson City says that 110 counties give Cleveland 228,903; Fusion, 196,427; St. John, 1,498; Cleve land's plurality, 32,476; majority, 30,978.

A young woman known as Lillie Ellis, or Elliott, was taken late on Wednesday night from the wine room of the Grand Central Theatre, at No. 145 East Eighthstreet, to St. Vincent's Hospital, suffering from a pistol-shot wound in the right temple, which it is believed was inflicted by herself. The bullet lodged in the young woman's brain.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 13.--The schooner W.C. Silver, from North Sydney for Halifax with coal, is reported to have been wrecked on Bras d'Or Lake. The vessel is in sured for $5,000 and the cargo for $400 in Halifax offices. She was of 107 tons register, built at Whycocomah in 1875, and owned by Jacob S. Hart, of that place.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 13.--The trial of James Wilsey, for killing Allan McClure, at Deposit, some months since, in a barroom fight, by a blow of his fist, was finished to-day by the conviction of Wilsey for manslaughter in the second degree. The trial excited great interest among medical men all over the country.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Nov.13.--About two years ago the wife of Peter Westbrook, a dissolute man of Port Jervis, was obliged to leave her husband on account of his intemperate, indolent, and vicious habits. Their two young children were taken by the mother to the house of her father. Charles C. Van Auken, near the village of Port Jervis, and all found care and shelter.
BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 13.--The liabilities of Ferdinand Fischer, currier, of Cambridge, exclusive of one claim, the amount of which is unknown, are $29,450; unincumbered assets light.
A lecture will be delivered by the Hon. James W. Gerard, at the University Law School, this evening at 8 o'clock.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 13.--Robert Standring and wife were discovered dead yesterday morning in their house on the Ranche station, seven miles from Pine-Grove, a small station on the South Park Road. Circumstances indicate that they were murdered for money.

WASHINGTON, Nov.13.--Mr. George Douglass, an assistant attorney of the Department of Justice, who was specially detailed by the Attorney-General to take charge of the general management of the star route civil suits, to-day submitted a preliminary report in which he says that in pursuance of instructions received July...

CATO, N.Y., Nov. 14.--The burning of Mortimer Van Auken's barn at midnight is the latest of a series of incendiary fires that have made sleep a stranger to the inhabitants of this neighborhood for a year or more. Thus far it has been impossible to detect the incendiaries.

ALBANY, Nov. 14.--The Governor has pardoned Robert W. Batting. This convict was on April 22,1875, in Ulster County, sentenced to imprisonment for life upon a conviction of murder in the second degree, the offense being committed Oct. 21, 1874.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 14.--A motherly looking woman called on Secretary Crew, of the Society for the Protection of Children from Cruelty, to-day, and told him a strange story, which is now being investigated.

The one hundredth anniversary of the consecration of the first American Bishop, Samuel Seabury, was celebrated yesterday at Trinity Church, which was fittingly decorated with flowers for the occasion. CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 14.--As Truman B. Handy, a grain speculator, was driving home in a buggy to-night, the horse became frightened and ran away. At the corner of Vine-street and McMicken-avenue the vehicle collided with a street car, and Mr. Handy was thrown to the ground. His skull was fractured and his physicians think he will die.

A variety of rumors are afloat regarding the purposes of the Mayor in respect to the appointment of a Commissioner of Public Works and a Corporation Counsel when the terms of the present incumbents of those offices shall expire, on the 10th of December.
MONTPELIER, Vt., Nov. 14.--In joint assembly this forenoon the Legislature elected Supreme Court Judges. The Hon. Homer E. Royce, of St. Albans, the present incumbent, was chosen Chief-Justice.

Mayor EDSON has called the attention of the police, none too soon, to the impropriety of allowing prize fights in public. The fact that these fights are contested with "gloves" seems to be about as much of an extenuating circumstance as if they were contested with brass knuckles.

Walker, Gioconria Co., stock brokers, having an office in the Mills Building, have procured an attachment against the property of Jacob and Thomas Hodgson, who have until recently done business under the name of Hodgson Brothers, at No. 45 William-street.

The afternoon rehearsal prefatory to the first Philharmonic concert of the present season took place at the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon.

The astronomers among the students of Columbia College, under Prof. Rees, sat up all of Thursday night in the observatory on the Law School building and watched for the usual shower of November meteors.

The Aldermanic Committee on Railroads heard arguments yesterday on applications for street railway franchises by the Chambers-Street and Grand-Street Ferry Railroad Company and the Chambers-Street Railroad Company. W.C. Troll appeared for the Chambers-Street and Grand-Street Ferry Company.
Bradstreet's reports 187 failures in the United States during the week, against 166 in the preceding week. About 82 per cent. were those of small traders, whose capital was less than $5,000.

CAIRO, Nov. 14.--Letters from Gen. Gordon arrived at Bebbeh to-day. The Cameron Highlanders will start up the Nile on Sunday.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 14.--Tramps attempted several burglaries in this town last night, but were chased and shot at, and at midnight their den was raided. Eight were caught, and this afternoon six more were captured after two raids.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14.--The Lecture and Publication Bureau of the Catholic Total Abstinence Union of America met to-day at Barnum's Hotel. All the members were present, viz.: the Right Rev. Bishop Ireland, of St. Paul, Minn.;

READING, Penn., Nov. 14.--Episcopal clergymen and laymen, numbering over 100, from churches all over the Central Pennsylvania Diocese, met here to-day, when appropriate ceremonies were held and a formal introduction took place to the Right Rev. N.C. Rulison, D. D., of Cleveland, Ohio, just installed as Assistant Bishop of the diocese.

The Junior Class of the Law School of the Univerisity of the City of New-York listened to a lecture, last evening, by the Hon. James W. Gerard, on "Practical Success in the Law." A number of friends of the school, and members of the legal profession in this city, were present.
The large covered pier at Prentice's Stores, in Brooklyn, at the present time presents an unusual appearance even to those who are accustomed to see unusual cargoes landed from an incoming steamer.

When the eight stout policemen who guard the Board of Canvassers filed into the Aldermen's Chamber, at 9:55 yesterday morning, they found our reporter, two or three spectators, and a little old woman to protect. The little old woman flew from desk to desk with a big feather duster and whisked away at imaginary dust like a little private cyclone.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--A dispatch from Woodstock, Ill., states that James Dacey, convicted of the murder of Alderman Gaynor, in Chicago, and who was under sentence to be hanged on Friday, Nov. 21, has secured a writ of supersedeas from the Supreme Court.

The work of canvassing the county ticket and sending back the returns for correction, including those made and already canvassed on the Electoral vote, was continued yesterday in the chamber of the Kings County Board of Supervisors.
A young Italian girl named Catharine Levanzo was brought here last Summer by her brother. He not only beat her, but forced her to live in a disreputable stale beer saloon in Thompson-street.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 14.--Since the marriage of John J. Junio, a widely known labor agitator, and Mrs. Ida M. Brewer, on Wednesday morning, there have been reports that he has another wife living. "Yes, Sir," he replied on being asked if his first wife was dead.

TROY, N.Y., Nov 14.--John Maxwell, a well-known citizen of South Argyle, Washington County, who was burned to death Wednesday, had been insane for some years, and being at times quite violent was kept in confinement in an old house adjacent to his residence.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 14.--During a Democratic celebration at Wellington, Kane County, last night, Mrs. John Schnarr was struck in the eye by a skyrocket and instantly killed. Another rocket, erroneously placed went driving into the office the Phillips House, striking the night clerk in the mouth and coming out behind the ear.

Two boys, Henry Guy Morgan, of No. 244 West Thirty-first-street, and George McLaughlin, of No. 320 West Forty-seventh-street, while rowing yesterday afternoon on the lake in Central Park in one of Capt. Dick's boats, found the body of a man near the bridge at the end of the Ramble.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 14.--Two warrants charging criminal assault were to-day procured for the arrest of George W. Williams, alias Rarus, alias Morgan, alias Norris, now in the County Jail on the charge of horse stealing and cruelty to animals.

BUFFALO, Nov. 14.--While Sheriff Koch was at dinner to-day three prisoners in the jail, who, with a number of others, had been let out of their cells into an open court on the ground floor, slipped away from their fellows and made their way to the sixth or top story of the jail.

Alexander, Fifth Auditor, which was submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury to-day, shows that the consular fees collected during the past fiscal year amounted to $895,780, and the consular expenses aggregated $872,345, being an excess of receipts over expenditures of $23,435. BOSTON, Nov. 14.--Official returns show the total vote in the city of Boston to have been as follows: Blaine, 20,827; Cleveland, 32,573; Butler, 3,718; St. John, 1,251. Cleveland's plurality, 11,746. For Governor--Robinson, 24,981; Endicott, 29,057; McCafferty, 3,733; Seelye, 977. Endicott's plurality, 4,076, Cleveland thus running 7,670 ahead of his ticket.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 14.--Late last night the mangled remains of Benjamin Shorten, of Berea, a young man of 21, were found on the Lake Shore track. His head had been entirely cut from the body and rolled away from it, while the right arm and left foot had been amputated by the car wheels.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 14.--The decapitated and otherwise shockingly mangled body of Benjamin Shortens was found on the railway near Berea this morning. When last seen alive he had money, a pocketbook, and a revolver, none of which were on the corpse. It is believed he was murdered by tramps, robbed, and left on the track.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--The Storey will case came up this morning in the Probate Court before Judge Knickerbocker. Mrs. Storey came into court accompanied by her mother, and testified to having seen the will dated Aug 16, 1879, but not the one drawn Feb. 1, 1881.

LONDON, Nov. 14.--The steamship Borderer, (Br.,) Capt. Hill, from Boston Nov. 5 has arr, at Queenstown, land, Oregon, via Queenstown, has put into Plymouth. She was in collision with an unknown large steamship and is much damaged.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 14.--Peter Louis Otto, 32 years old and a confectioner by trade, this morning at 11:30 o'clock entered the house at No. 206 Broadway, where he lives with his mother, wife, and four children. His wife was at work in the kitchen.

The next Legislature, in joint session, will elect a State Controller and Treasurer and State Director of the Joint Companies, besides Commissioners of Deeds and Police Justices. The principal offices are now held by Republicans.
PHILLIPSBURG, N.Y., Nov. 14.--After being idle for some time, one of the Andover furnace stacks was started to-day with a full complement of men.
