BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 14.--Capt. William Smith and his son, William E., arrived at this port this afternoon in a 20-foot sailboat from Portland, Me., bound for St. Augustine, Fla. They left Portland Sept. 25, and expect to reach their destination Dec. 15

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 14.--A very sensational feature in connection with the attempted assassination of Sylvester T. Everett, Manager of the Union National Bank, by Horace P. Weddell, the millionaire banker, and the attempt to kill his children has just been made public.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14.--An official letter has been written by direction of the President to JudgeAdvocate-General Swaim's counsel, saying that the President of the United States has authority to order such a court-martial as has been called to try Gen. Swaim, and that the court will assemble to-morrow.

A writer in an English scientific journal fancies that he has discovered that North America was at one time colonized by the Romans. The argument with which he supports this view is purely philological. He claims that many of the so-called Indian names of rivers, mountains, and valleys in this country are really Latin names slightly misspelled.
George W. Carhart retires on Dec. 1 as foreign Freight Agent of the Erie Railway in New-York. F.N. McClune, his chief clerk, will become export agent, and G.W. Sheldon Co. the import agents.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 14.--John Donaldson, who shot and killed his sweetheart, Annie Slippich, on July 17 last, was convicted of murder in the second degree to-day and sentenced to 12 years in the penitentiary.

LOCKPORT, Nov. 14.--The closeness of the Electoral vote of this State and the possible importance of a single ballot suggest an explanation why the plurality of Cleveland over Blaine in Niagara County is stated at 318 by the official canvass instead at 319, as reported to THE TIMES on the day after election.

The nervous insistence with which a few of the organs of Mr. BLAINE are holding out the preposterous hope that the canvass in this county will still give that gentleman a plurality in the State begins to weary their brethren. It has ceased for several days to worry the public here, which, with great unanimity, has turned to its ordinary business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14.--Mr. H.D. Cooke, of the firm of H. D. Cooke Co., bankers, who recently closed their doors in this city, has made an offer of compromise to the creditors looking toward the immediate settlement of minor claims and an extension of time on larger ones.

JACKSON, Mich., Nov. 14.--A jury was secured to-day in the Crouch murder trial. The court has been occupied since Nov. 5 in the selection of a jury. The case was opened this afternoon ...

LONDON, Nov. 14.--St. Paul's Cathedral was the scene to-day of a stately service in commemoration of the one hundredth anniversary of the consecration of Bishop Seabury, the first American Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church. The service was conducted by the Archbishop of Canterbury, assisted by the Bishops of London, Winchester, Durham, and Albany.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 14.--George Travis, the Tioga County murderer, will be hanged on Jan. 15, the Governor having fixed that date.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 14.--The British ship Matterhorn, which arrived here this evening from Dundee, reports the total loss of the British bark Clwyd off Cape Horn. The Captain, officers, and all the crew except three were saved.
ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 14.--The State militia from this city and surrounding towns went to the Freehold celebration by special train over the Long Branch Railway.

PANAMA, Nov. 5.--Peace has been restored in Cundinamarca and Santanda owing to the active intervention of the Federal Government. This interference disgusts many of the upholders of "State rights," who would, if they could, keep the little patches of "sovereign" territory in continual uproar.

CHICAGO, Nov., 14.--R.G. Austin, manager of the Australian Novelty Company, and nine members of his troupe, mostly Arabs, who were held to the Criminal Court by Justice Kistler, last Tuesday, for a disturbance at the Chicago Museum on Sunday, were taken from the jail into the presence of Judge Tuley to-day on a writ of habeas corpus.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 14.--Samuel Darling, a reputable man aged 63 years, hanged himself in his woodshed early this morning. He had been in the insurance business and a dealer in wood and coal.
PARIS, Nov. 14.--A dispatch to-day from Shanghai states that the French forces have occupied Tameni. M. L'Amoureux will succeed the late M. Vaucorbeil as Director of the opera.

The annual report of the twelfth year of the McAuley Mission, No. 316 Water-street, founded by the late Jerry McAuley, has just been issued. The receipts of the mission for the past year from donations were $2,462 63, and from interest on invested funds $150.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14.--In a letter to the National Convention of Stockmen, read at the session this morning, Prof. James Law, of Cornell University, criticised the work of the Bureau of Animal Industry of the National Department of Agriculture and handled the subject without gloves.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 14.--James Bowe, of Rondout, finding his wife drunk when he returned home for dinner this afternoon, felled her to the floor with a club and stamped upon her, inflicting injuries from which it is believed she cannot recover. Bowe was arrested.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14.--The work of the Plenary Council to-day consisted of the reports of several of the committees, and it is expected that some of the subject will be voted upon Sunday next at the public session at the cathedral.

Charles H. Roome was tried at Paterson, N.J., yesterday on an indictment for forgery. He is a young man of excellent family, in Sussex County, but is the scapegrace of the family. LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 14.--Joseph Keck, an old Frenchman, has kept a fruit store in the upper part of this city for many years. He had a very pretty black-eyed daughter, named Rosa, who became the centre of attraction of the store and made it a popular stand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14.--Commodore Montgomery Sicard, Chief of the bureau of Ordnance, Navy Department, in his annual report makes the following estimates for that bureau for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1886: Fuel, tools, material and labor, small arms, machine guns, batteries for third rate ships,

A gentleman whose knowledge of the Ten Commandments is perhaps limited entered the office of the Metropolitan Job Printing Establishment, at No. 38 Vesey-street, during dinner hour on Wednesday, and went away in a hurry with his bank account increased to the extent of $500. The day's receipts of the establishment are left in a common tin money box.
The official circular of the Oregon and Transcontinental Company proposing a new loan of $10,000,000 was issued yesterday, and formed one of the leading topics of discussion in Wall-street.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 8.--In the centre of three acres of ornamented ground, which occupies one block in the interior of the city of Milwaukee, stands the palatial residence the Hon. Alexander Mitchell, the millionaire railroad king of the West.

MUNCIE, Ind., Nov. 14.--Doxey's Opera House, at Anderson, Ill., was burned this morning. The loss is $80,000; no insurance. Hunt's livery stable was also burned. There is no fire department in Anderson. The Indianapolis Fire Department arrived too late to save anything.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 14.--The body of the Rev. Henry S. Williamson, who committed suicide yesterday, has been removed to Elizabeth, and will be interred in the family vault there. Bishop Scarborough took charge of the remains. He says that Mr. Williamson was not in his right mind.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 14.--Meineke, the alleged murderer of Katie Broedhaupt, who has had one trial at Elmira, was to-day brought to this city. He was manacled hand and foot and in charge of the Sheriffs of Broome and Chemung.

WESTBURYPORT, Mass., Nov. 14.--Early risers this morning found Gen. Butler hanged in effigy on Browne-square.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 14.--A movement is on foot among the descendants of Sybrant Quackenboss, the story of whose terrible ordeal during the French and Indian war is barely known to the present generation of them, to rescue his grave from the obscurity and neglect into which it has fallen, and to erect a suitable monument above it.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 14.--The Travelers' Protective Association began their semiannual session here to-day with a fair representation. The objects of the association are to secure legislation rescinding the drummers' tax, particularly in Southern cities, and to promote the general welfare of the fraternity.

THE TIMES announced a day or two ago that Stock Broker J. Rhinelander Dillon, the Treasurer of the Twenty-first Assembly District Blaine and Logan Club, would sell $2,600 worth of bearskin hats, leggins, capes, and torches at a bargain.

PARIS, Nov. 14.--According to the terms of the divorce recently granted in the Patti-De Caux case Mme. Patti has the right to remarry. M. de Caux's claims upon Mme. Patti's property depend upon the terms of the marriage contract. These have not been made known. The recent judgment merely changes the decree of separation into a decree of divorce for the benefit of the husband.

Samuel Gillespie, Assistant Superintendent of the Hudson County branch of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, is confined in the Hoboken Jail to await examination upon charges of forgery. The prisoner had charge of the Hoboken office and is alleged to have defrauded the company by altering returns made by collectors and forging their signatures to false vouchers.

A screen, on which were painted portraits of Cleveland and Hendricks, flanked by a merchantman and locomotive as emblems of commerce, and with a goddess of Liberty between the portraits, stretched clear across the back of the stage in Irving Hall last evening, where a jollification meeting was held over the result of the election.

The big braves and little braves of Tammany Hall had a hearty and good humored jollification last night over the election of Cleveland and Hendricks. There were not seats enough in the spacious hall to accommodate all of the participants.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 14.--A difficulty occurred to-day on board the American barkentine Rebecca J. Moulton between Charles Furlong, the mate, and Morris Peterson and John Keiser, sailors, in which the sailors were dangerously wounded.

LEBANON, Penn., Nov. 14.--John Miller, who killed Bernard Ebich on the 10th of Sep tember, was to-day convicted of murder in the second degree and sentenced to 12 years in the penitentiary.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 14.--Eleven students of the free institute have confessed complicity in putting a horse in the chapel. Ten of them were among the 29 suspended yesterday for refusing to answer questions. Those who are not guilty have been reinstated. The Faculty is now considering the punishment of the guilty.
LONDON, Nov. 14.--Edwin Arnold publishes in January next a volume of poems. The title poem is called" The Secret of Death," being a version of Katha Upanishad, from the Sansckit.

OWEGO, N.Y., Nov. 14.--A party of young men and girls left this village on Wednesday morning to go to the farmhouse of James Smith, at Ross Hill, Tioga Township, where a party was to be held in the evening.

PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 14.--William L. Thompson, an engraver, was arrested to-day on suspicion of being one of the parties that have been flooding Camden with counterfeit ten-dollar bills on the Third National Bank of Cincinnati. He was given a preliminary hearing before United States Commissioner Morgan, and held in $2,000 bail for a further hearing next week.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Nov. 15.--A.M. Hawk, a native of Sullivan County, but now residing at Pond Eddy, a few miles west of this village, made an assertion 15 years ago that he would not shave again until a Democratic President was elected.

NAPANEE, Ontario, Nov. 15.--Judge Armour has declared that the Lennox election for the House of Commons is voided through bribery of the agents of Mr. Pruyn, Conservative, and Mr. Allison, Reformer. The latter was elected last November by five votes.

UTICA, N.Y., Nov. 15.--The committee of Democrats appointed last evening to arrange for the holding next Thursday of a barbecue in celebration of the election of Cleveland, at its meeting to-day unanimously voted to invite exSenator Roscoe Conkling to be one of the orators of the occasion.
LONDON, Nov. 15.--Since the Reichstag elections in Germany it has been ascertained that no less than 650,000 ballots were cast for the Socialist candidates.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 15.--The Rev. William Taylor, Pastor of the Universalist church, who, while at a theatre witnessing the play of "Hazel Kirke," a few weeks ago, was stricken with paralysis, died this evening from the effects. He was 50 years of age. The dead Pastor was Chaplain of Tibbits Post, G.A.R., and of the Tibbits Veteran Corps.

WINCHESTER, Va., Nov. 15.--An unprovoked murder was committed here last night. Soon after the Democratic procession Wesley Honesty and Clint Banks, negroes, attacked Joseph McFall, a quiet, inoffensive white boy, aged 19 years, from Mount Jackson, Shenandoah County.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Nov. 15.--The County Court has been in session in this city during the past week, the Hon. C.F. Brown presiding, and several important suits have been laid over or finally disposed of. Among the latter is the hotly contested case of Bernard Manning against the village of Port Jervis, which has been before the courts a long time.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15.--A few additional facts concerning the new system of ranking adopted by the Trustees last Thursday have been made public. He replied very innocently, "I come here to look at you." The young teacher blushed and smiled at the same time and the lecture ceased.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15.--Two men called at the residence of Joachim Demlow, two and a half miles south of Des Plaines, at 9 o'clock last night, and called Demlow out into the yard, where they attacked him with a club and corn cutter. His wife ran to his assistance and was also attacked.

Col. Taylor had been a widower for 10 years, and owns considerable property in Chicago.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 15.--Further efforts to secure the commutation of the death sentence on Mrs. Boutel have been met with a positive refusal from the Governor-General, and the unfortunate woman will be hanged on Thursday next at Quebec.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 15.--The official vote of the State for President, except two counties, the vote of which is estimated, is as follows: Blaine, 153,396; Cleveland, 90,030; Butler, 17,044; St. John, 4,273; Blaine's plurality, 63,366. Martin, Republican, for Governor, has a plurality of 38,559. The Congressmen are all Republicans.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 15.--The Rev. Charles E. Taylor has been chosen President of Wake Forest College by the Baptist Convention, which is now in session. To-day he formally accepted the position. For some time he has been President of the Board of Trustees of the college.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--President Arthur has set to work earnestly to fill up and get out of the way the list of vacancies which has been lying on his desk and increasing in length for a long time. To-day he promoted Deputy Pension Commissioner O.P.G. Clarke to the vacancy made by the resignation of Commissioner Dudley. The appointment was expected and was well received.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 15.--The Stevens Institute football team, of Hoboken, came here this afternoon and defeated the Lafayette College eleven 17 to 4. The winners made their points in the second inning, scoring one goal from the field and two from touchdowns. The four points for Lafayette were scored in the first inning from a touchdown. The game was very cleverly played on both sides. The umpire was E.H. Munkwitz, of Stevens Institute.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--The Democratic parade here to-night in celebration of the election of Cleveland and Hendricks was one of the largest demonstrations ever held in this city.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 15.--Alfred Manchester was convicted in the Court of Oyer and Terminor to-day of manslaughter in the first degree for killing an old woman at West Falls, a few miles from this city, last April.

This letter states that the steamer which bore Cols. Stewart and Power and M. Herbin, the French Consul, and some Greeks, left Khartoum Sept. 10.

READING, Penn., Nov. 15.--The Pennsylvania Schuylkill Valley Railroad Company and the Reading are again at loggerheads. The former road has been building trestle work west of the Pennsylvania-street bridge for a a track along the canal, which is leased by the Reading.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 15.--On Thursday night Mrs. Leduc, of St. Rock's, Quebec, was awakened by the cry of one of her children, and, in getting out of bed, upset a lamp, which exploded, setting fire to her nightdress.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--The trial of the prisoners charged with conspiracy to blow up the Niederwald Monument, in the Fall of 1883, will begin next January. The German Government officials have accumulated a very large amount of evidence against the accused, and are confident of securing their conviction.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 15.--The following story is given on the authority of respectable citizens of Woodland Hills-avenue concerning one of the oldest farmhouses in the suburbs of Cleveland. When its owner, Dawson, died in 1868, his family moved to Iowa, and the old house passed into other hands.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 15.--The monthly meeting of the spinners will be held on Tuesday next. In his circular calling the meeting Secretary Howard reviews the condition of the market, giving figures showing that a reduction in wages has always been followed by a depression in trade.

PARIS, Nov. 15.--The total number of deaths from cholera in this city yesterday was 56, all but 16 of which occurred in the hospitals. In the 12 hours ending at noon to-day there were 29 deaths. There was one death from cholera at Nantes to-day and one at Toulon.

We are able to-day to give an account of the proposed National Liberal Club. The building, which will face on the Embankment and Whitehall-place, will be of Portland stone and handsome elevation, and is to cost over 120,000.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 15.--Quite a number of papers in this State are urging the appointment of Senator Lamar to a Cabinet position. Relative to this subject the next issue of the New Mississippian will say: "The New Mississippian does not speak without knowledge when it says that Col. Lamar does not expect to have a Cabinet office tendered to him, and has no intention of accepting such a position if it should be tendered."

Lieut. E.L. Zalinski stood, smiling and serene, on the piazza of his house at Fort Hamilton yesterday afternoon. He was care fully attired in brand-new apparel, much of which, he declared, had come into his possession when Mr. Cleveland was announced as future President of the United States.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 15.--The strike of the river coal miners is at an end. The miners of the third and fourth pools went in at the reduction several weeks ago, and nearly all of those in the first and second pools have within the last two days notified the operators that they were ready to return to work at the latter's terms. Many of the mines will resume work Monday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 15.--In an altercation here this afternoon between William Sincebaugh and Edward Smith the former had his skull fractured. After the exchange of words between the combatants Smith struck Sincebaugh two or three times on the head with a wooden bung starter, cutting a gash nearly three inches long. The injury is pronounced very grave. Smith has been arrested.

She was dressed in the garments becoming her sex, and was quite presentable in appearance.

The Wesleyan University and Rutgers College football teams met yesterday on the Manhattan Athletic Club's grounds, in the presence of about 125 dudes and two young ladies, who heartily applauded their efforts to drive each other through the face of the earth.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15.--Mme. Ristori closed her first week playing in English in America at the Chestnut-Street Opera House here this evening. She appeared in three great impersonations as Queen Elizabeth, Marie Antoiuette, and Mary Stuart, and received a grand ovation at every performance. The receipts for the week were $14,320.

A shopkeeper near the City Hall elevated railway station broke up a few old boxes yesterday and left the wood piled up on the curbstone. Two persons went into his store and asked him for it. One was an Irishman, ablebodied, apparently strong, and rich enough to own a paper of chewing tobacco.

A game of football, played at Sing Sing yesterday, between the St. Austin eleven, of Staten Island, and the Olympics, of St. John's school, resulted in a score at the end of the second half of 57 to 0 in favor of the Olympics.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 15.--Donald G. Mitchell, "Ik Marvel," is delivering lectures on English literature to the college. He has been retired for some years on his farm of Edgewood, near Westville. The course begins before the Norman conquest and traces the development and growth of the English language.

Greene, of the Corps of Engineers, United States Army, pays much attention to the successful operation of underground electric wires in Washington. NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 15.--The society gossips of this place are at present much excited over the rumor that a young lady well known here, Miss Folsom, of Buffalo, is engaged to President-elect Grover Cleveland.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 15.--Official returns from 90 of the 99 counties in this State, and the remainder closely estimated give a Republican plurality of 18,742 over the Fusionists. This is a gain of over 16,000 over the Republican plurality last year. The St. John vote will probably reach nearly 2,000 in the State. There will be contests in the First and Sixth Congressional Districts.

LONDON, Nov. 15.--Torquay, the fashionable Winter watering place on the south coast of England, is at present stirred by a sensation of a most ghastly character. Nearly adjoining Torquay is the smart fishing village of Babbicombe.

HIGH POINT, N.C., Nov. 15.--The field trials were continued to-day. The weather was dry and clear and the grounds were in good condition. Brimstone beat Princess Helen, Diana II, beat Gertrude. Brock beat Gus Bondhon. In the third series Buckellew beat Diana II, and Brock beat Brimstone. In the fourth series Buckellew beat Brock. Buckellew wins the first prize in the Members' Stake; the second prize has not yet been awarded.

BATH, N. Y., Nov. 15.--A mandamus was served on the Board of County Canvassers in Steuben County yesterday to compel them to count two votes for Blaine which were returned by the Inspectors of the Third Election District as defective. In the opinion of the Attorney-General the ballots were clearly defective. A hearing is to be had in Corning next Monday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 15.--The Travelers' Protective Association met again to-day. The next convention of the association will be held at Philadelphia during the last three days of June, 1885.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15.--Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan is at Fortress Monroe to-day. He will leave there on Monday for a trip by sea to Boston, returning by rail to Washington.

On Friday the rooms of two guests at the Sturtevant House were surreptitiously entered and an overcoat was stolen from each. Yesterday Detective J.N. Haight caught an old man who had entered Room No. 265, but who had not stolen anything.

The shippers of the immense cargo of cabbages of the steamship Katie, from Gothenburg, Sweden, will probably be losers this time. For the past two years the cabbage crops in this country have partly failed, and several merchants in Sweden conceived the idea of supplying the American market with that vegetable.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16.--To-day the second solemn session of the Catholic Plenary Council was held at the cathedral in this city. There being no procession in the streets as on the opening day, there was a marked decrease in the number of spectators, but the cathedral itself was crowded with worshipers at 10:30 A.M.

Louise Gemott, a half-witted mulatto, was locked up in the Fourteenth Precinct Station House yesterday for shooting her husband Christopher, who is several shades darker than the, at No.269 Elizabeth-street, rear. They were married in 1879 and have had six children, all of whom have died.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 16.--Deacon Daniel Goddard, 88 years old, and Warren McFarland, 74 years of age, two of the most prominent citizens of Worcester, died to-day.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 16.--The cornerstone of the Passionist Monastery of St. Joseph, two miles west of this city, was laid this afternoon with imposing ceremony, in the presence of upward of 5,000 people.

Affair-faced, fresh-complexioned, goldenhaired German girl, accompanied by a portly gentleman, some years her senior, rang the door bell at No.121 Bloomfield-street, Hoboken, three weeks ago, and asked to be shown rooms that had been advertised to let. They said they had been recently married, and wanted to find accommodations pending arrangements they were making to go to housekeeping. They were suited with the apartments and engaged them.
AUBURN, N.Y., Nov. 16.--An interesting case, involving the validity of a will, is now pending before Surrogate Teller.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 16.--Dr. Samuel A. Fisk, aged 63, ex-President of the Massachusetts Medical Society, lecturer at Smith College, and Trustee of the Clarke Institute for Deaf Mutes, died at Northampton to-day, of organic disease of the heart.

All day long yesterday the wards and balls of the Mount Sinai Hospital were thronged with visitors, the occasion being the usual yearly reception given by the Directors and Directresses of the Ladies' Auxiliary Society.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 16.--Patrick McLean, a miner, residing at Cork-lane, near Pittston, was examining a revolver this morning when it went off, the ball striking his wife in the abdomen and inflicting fatal injuries.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 16.--Robert Bryce McPhun, a young Scotchman, said to be of noble birth, was arrested here to-day on an extradition warrant, by Sergt. Webb, of the Calcutta (India) police, charged with forgeries to the extent of $100,000.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16.--D.D. Drennen was a member of the Warren City Council, and bad voted on a number of important measures before it was discovered that he was an alien and could not hold office at all.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 16.--The Lehigh Valley is overrun with tramps, and they are committing various depredations. Of the 14 arrested on Friday 4 are held for burglary and the rest have been driven out of town.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 16.--It has been accepted here for several days that the New-York count would show the election of Cleveland, and there has therefore been little or no interest all the week. The crowds disappeared from in front of the newspaper offices on Mondny last, and all the week quiet has reigned, with a general acceptance of the result by men of both parties.

The end of a strange career is reported from the Union Workhouse, Dartford, Kent. It appears that on the 8th of this month a Frenchman was found in a very exhausted condition in the locality of Bexley by the police.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16.--Several cases have been prepared in Cleveland to recover taxes paid under the Scott liquor law, lately declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court, and will have their first hearing on Wednesday. Attornney-General Lawernce will be here to aid the defense.

They now say in Boston that Mrs. Blaine had a reason for not being present at the dinner offered her at the Brunswick on the evening of the great Republican torchlight procession, When she arrived at the hotel she found no private parlor assingned her, and without giving any notice to her fair hosts, she hustened to Young's Hotel. The Boston women ate their dinner without her.

The ship Pactolus, which arrived yesterday from Kobe, Japan, has on board the second and third officers of the ship Reindeer, of Philadelphia, which was wrecked among the Marshall Islands, in the Pacific, last January. The experiences of the Reindeer's crew were of an unusual nature.

PARIS, Nov. 16.--During Saturday there were 22 deaths from cholera in the city and 50 in the hospitals. Between midnight last night and 6 o'clock this evening there have been 4 deaths in the city and 17 in the hospitals. Two deaths from the disease occurred at Nantes to-day.

The marriage of Miss Leontine Huebsch, daughter of the late Rabbi Adolphus Huebsch, of Temple Ahawath Chesed, at Lexington-avenue and Fifty-fifth-street, to Mr. Joshua Kantrowitz, associate editor of the Hebrew Standard, was solemnized last night at the residence of the bride's mother.

ALBANY, Nov. 16--President-elect Cleveland spent the day quietly at the Executive Mansion, although he was at his desk at the Executive Chamber for an hour or two this afternoon attending to private correspondence.

ALBANY, Nov. 16.--As long as the President-elect remains Governor of New-York all rumors about his Cabinet will be mere idle gossip. His official duties will fully occupy his time here, and it is not his habit to cross a stream before he gets to it, or to declare his intentions until the time for action comes.

The Central Labor Union yesterday received a communication from the Secretary of the Hocking Valley Miners' Relief Committee and the President of the Ohio Miners' Amalgamated Association. The Secretary wrote that a committee, consisting of delegates from the five subdivisions of the miners' association, met at Straitsville, Ohio, on Wednesday, and distributed relief to the strikers.

LONDON, Nov. 16.--Gen. Gordon's latest letter says his position at Khartoum is very secure and that his troops are in excellent spirits. Gordon warns the French Consul-General at Cairo that the Mahdi possesses M. Herbin's cipher code and may make use of it.

The Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn celebrated the solemn high mass in St. Stephen's Church, in East Twenty-eighth-street, yesterday morning. The sermon was delivered by the Rev. Charles N. Colton. The Rev. Dr. Downes, of Kilmalloch, Ireland, will personally take up a collection in this church next Sunday.

Mrs. Josephine Wilder, widow of Waldo wilder, an actor at the Union-Square Theatre who died in August, 1882, has been more or less of an invalid for some time. To alleviate pain she used an eilxir, a remedy that her husband took when suffering from rheumatism.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16.--Cleveland has been made the headquarters of the Salvation Army of America. The Euclid-avenue Roller Rink, in the very centre of the business portion of the city, has been leased for five years. It will be concerted into a tabernacle. Major Frank Smith has been appointed to the chief command, and an aggressive fight is going to be made this Winter.

Karnegay Co., the Messenger printing office and building, together with several large stocks of merchandise and a quantity of cotton. The total loss will exceed $250,000.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Nov. 17.--Returns from all the counties of the State show the vote in the recent election to be as follows: Cleveland, 235,972; Fusion, 202,261; St. John, 1,506; Cleveland's plurhlity, 33,711. For Governor-- Marmaduke, (Dem.,) 219,015; Ford, (Fusion,) 207,893; Brooks, (Proh.,) 10,449; Marmaduke's plurality, 11,122; majority, 573. This vote will be declared officially as soon as the Governor returns to the city.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 17.--The Salvation Army was mobbed at the barracks in the Green-Street Railroad Station to-night. Stones were thrown through the windows and several persons inside were hit. The railroad officials have ordered the army to leave their promises.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 17.--Near Geddes, last night, there was a collision between two West Shore freight trains. Two cars were burned, together with their contents, consigned to New-York. No one was hurt.

PHILADELPHIA, NOV. 17.--John T. Harker, proprietor of an extensive pie bakery at Fifth and Taylor avenues, Camden, N.J., made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors to Joseph E. Roberts, a builder. The liabilities are said to be between $17,000 and $20,000, while the assets are not known, but it is understood that they will cover all claims.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17.--Eight carloads of Maryland exhibits at the New-Orleans Exposition leave to-night for that city. The collection embraces specimens of the products and resources of the State of every variety, including over 400 pieces of native woods and 200 of marble, granite, and other building stones. The display of ores and minerals will be fine. One of the cars, which will be loaded at Cumberland, will contain a huge pyramid of coal.

RIO JANEIRO, Nov. 17, via Galveston.-- The steamer Matteo Bruzzo, which left Montevideo with cases of cholera on board, has arrived here. The Brazilian Government will supply provisions and everything required by the steamer to continue her voyage to some other port.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 17.--Capt. George MeClure, of Detroit, master of the schooner Frank Morris, navigated his vessel into Port Huron to-day alone, his crew--William Clark and John Clifford--having been knocked overboard by the fore boom off Forester, on Lake Huron, at 5 o'clock this morning, during a terrible gale, which still continues. WORCESTER, Mass., Nov.18.--The Grand Army posts of Worcester County united in a reception to Commander-in-Chief Kountz and staff in Horticultural Hall this evening. Mayor Reed was the only civilian who spoke. The formal reception was followed by a camp fire at Grand Army Hall, where the exercises were continued until a late hour.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 19.--The work of the Plenary Council to-day, was principally the consideration of the reports of committees, several of which were so far advanced that the decrees formulated by them will be acted upon tomorrow at the public session at the cathedral.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 19.--The Democratic Congressional Convention of the Fourth District assembled in this city to-night, and on the fifth ballot nominated Gen. John Bratton, of Fairfield, to fill the unexpired term of the late J.H. Evans. Gen. Bratton commanded a brigade in the Confederate Army.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--Samuel Wakeling and Thomas Webster, representing the heirs of the late William H. Ruddach, filed caveats with the Register of Wills to-day protesting against the admission of his will to probate. Dr. Ruddach had been married privately to Mrs. Dixon three days before his death. He leaves an estate worth over $200,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--The will of the late Charles D. Colladay, admitted to probate today, bequeaths $500 to St. Mark's Evangelical Lutheran Church, Thirteenth and Spring Garden streets. The decedent left personal property to the value of $125,000 and real estate valued at $50,000.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 19.--The official vote of Maryland, as filed in the office of the Secretary of State, is as follows: Cleveland, 96,932; Blaine, 85,699; St. John, 2,794; Butler, 531. Cleveland's plurality, 11,233, and majority, 7,908.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Nov. 19.--In June last Charles W. Farciat, of this city, at that time a member of the firm of Farciat Wehrle, embezzled $50,000 from Andrew Wehrle, Sr., an extensive wine manufacturer at Middlebass Island. Farciat fled to Belgium.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--An air of sadness pervades the National Fat Stock Show this morning. BUFFALO, Nov. 19.--The names of three or four prominent society ladies of Buffalo have been mentioned at different times as prospective brides of President-elect Cleveland. Now rumor has it that the Governor is to marry none whose names have been heretofore mentioned.
AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 19.--Mr. Blaine, Miss Blaine, and Miss Sherman left for Ellsworth this afternoon, where they will spend several days as the guests of Senator Eugene Hale.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--The reduction of wages of ingrain carpet weavers of from 16 to 20 per cent. decided upon at a secret meeting of carpet manufacturers held at the Girard House last Friday, comes in force to-morrow. Twentyeight establishments and about 5,000 employes will be affected.

The plan of reorganization for the Republican Party in this city which was adopted last year requires a re-enrollment each year of the Republican voters who are to have the privilege of acting at primary elections.

READING, Penn., Nov. 19.--An epidemic known as "blackleg" has broken out among young cattle in the western section of Berks County. The disease is very loathsome, and many young cattle have succumbed to its ravages. The animals become lame and death ensues in several days. The State Health officials have been notified.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 19.--At the opening of the third day's session of the National Cattlemen's Convention at 10:30 o'clock this morning, Gen. Bersbie, Chairman of the Committee on Credentials, presented a report embodying 1,180 names of accredited members of the convention.

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 19.--Henry Young, Charles E. Taylor, Charles Fisher, and John Welsh, charged with robbing Henry Keller of a pocketbook containing $210 in front of the Post Office, on North Queen-street, in August last, were found guilty in the Quarter Sessions Court yesterday.

The New-York members of the Archaeological Institute of America, which has explored the ruins of Assos and founded a school of archaeology in Athens, met last evening in the residence of Mr. Frederic J. De Peyster, a prominent member, to organize themselves into a local society.

The new steel cruiser Atlanta, which was built for the United States Navy by John Roach Son, arrived from Chester, Penn., early yesterday morning. After remaining at anchor off Red Hook for a few hours she was towed up to Roach's shipyard, at the foot of Ninthstreet, where the fitting in of her machinery ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 19.--The banners of Cleveland and Hendricks and Blaine and Logan are still flaunted along the corridors of Vassar College, and as it had been reported that because of the onslaught of the Cleveland girls upon the Blaine and Logan girls one evening before election, the college authorities had refused ...

ELMIRA, N.Y., Nov. 19.--At his residence in Potter, Yates County, a wealthy farmer named Peter Boots carved his neck with a butcher's knife yesterday in attempting to commit suicide. Not succeeding, he hanged himself.

BOSTON, Nov. 19.--A registered certificate of the city of Boston's 5 per cent. water loan for $100,000, in favor of the United States Trust Company, of New-York, Trustee, for Caroline S. Astor, was issued to-day. This is a gift from William Astor to his daughter, who was yesterday married to Marshall O. Wilson.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 19.--A Christian convention, conducted by Dwight L. Moody, opened in this city this morning. The meeting was held in the large Central Presbyterian Church, and though admission was only by ticket the church was crowded to overflowing.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 19.--Official figures have been received from all but nine counties in this State, showing the vote on the recent eleclion to be as follows: Blaine, 185,057; Fusion, 183,783: St. John, 18,163. Blaine's plurality, 1,274.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov, 19.--A convict named Fauteux, escaped from the St. Vincent de Paul Penitentiary after a desperate conflict with the guards, one of whom he shot trough the leg. He was traced to a house of ill-repute.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 19.--A call will be issued in a few days for a convention of river and railroad coal miners to be held in this city on the 27th inst. The objects of the convention will be to consider the subject of arbitration for the railroad mines, to settle grievances of the river miners and to elect officers.
BOSTON, Nov. 19.--Contracts have been given to Charles Dillon, a young Boston artist, for a bronze equestrian statue of Paul Revere, double life size, to be mounted upon a granite pedestal.

Since July last the stock yards, stables, and other places in which large numbers of cattle are kept in this city, Brooklyn, Long Island, and Jersey City have been frequently visited by a committee of veterinary inspectors, as agents of the new Bureau of Animal Industry of the Department of Agriculture.

The twenty-sixth annual report of St. Luke's Hospital has just been published. It covers the work for the year ending Oct. 18, 1884, which has been uninterrupted and successful. The institution has an enviable position among the hospitals of New-York, and the Board of Managers say that steady insistence on the rule ...

Thirty men and two women climbed the muddy slopes of Mount Olivet, Long Island, yesterday, to lay the cornerstone of the new crematory temple. The structure was already finished to the ground level. A paper read before the Medico-Legal Society, of this city, some weeks ago by Dr. Johnson, of Brooklyn, upon "Poisoning by Canned Goods" attracted the attention of Dr. Thomas Stevenson, of London, Government Analyst, and he wrote a short monograph on the same subject and sent it to the society.
At the morning session of the State Medical Association yesterday Dr. Gouley submitted a resolution to empower the Council to secure permanent headquarters for the association in this city.

Another phase of the trouble that has brought division between Pastor Theodore Dresel and the Trustees of the Evangelical Lutheran Church, on Schermerhorn-street, Brooklyn, was discussed last evening.

A Cashier in one of our city banks was riding up Brady-street the other evening. Between his feet he had a valise. A gentleman sitting on the opposite side of the car glanced at the valise and then said "Good-bye," whereupon the Cashier became very angry. Why, we cannot explain.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 19.--The steamer Saratoga, bound north with passengers and freight, ran aground near Coxsackie before daylight this morning. The passengers were sent to Albany by the steamer City of Hudson. The Saratoga was obliged to have tugs to get her off.

CLAYSVILLE, Ala., Nov. 19.--R.A. Howard entered the house of a farmer named Peake, while the family were dining, to settle an old feud the other day. When Howard went into the room Peake shot him through the abdomen, inflicting a fatal wound. In his dying throes Howard raised his shotgun and killed both Peake and his wife.

Hazard, President of the Gramme Company, said yesterday: "In the memoranda which I submitted to the Bridge Trustees I stated ...

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Henry A. Hurlbert, A Lockport retail grocer, assigned today to D.E. Brong, a suit by Oppenheimer Co., of Rochester, for a bill due, being the cause. The preferred creditors are Miller, Greiner Co., Buffalo, $321; D.R. Saunders, New-York, $40, and other small amounts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--Not content with the expectation of enormous crowds of guests during inauguration week, landlords of the leading hotels here are on the lookout for the honor of entertaining Gov. Cleveland, previous to his taking possession of the White House. What is called "the Presidential suite" of ...

Vice-President-elect Hendricks got off a train at the Pennsylvania Railroad station at 11 o'clock last night, grabbed his valise from the baggage car, hurried into a cab, and was in his room at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel before any one who knew him was aware of it.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Nov. 19.--Gen. McClellan arrived here this morning, and is the guest of Dr. E.R. Mayer. He will speak at the Democratic meeting in Keystone Rink to-morrow afternoon and lead the Cleveland demonstration in the evening.

CANTON, Miss., Nov. 19.--Isaac Johnson, colored, was executed here to-day for the murder of Bella Booker in April last. The execution was private, and took place in the jail yard. He acknowledged his guilt, said his sins were forgiven, and he hoped for glory. His neck was broken.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 19.--Col. S.H. Church, Superintendent of Transportation of the Pan Handle Railroad, and Miss Margaret, daughter of John Joyce, were married last night at the residence of the bride's parents in this city. The wedding was a brilliant one, and a ...

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19.--Upon the assembling of the Swaim court-martial this morning, Major Gardner, the Judge-Advocate, stated that, owing to a misunderstanding of a part of the argument of the counsel for the accused on the demurrer to the first specification, and because the court had asked him several questions of law, he desired a reargument of the demurrer.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--About 20 breeders of Poland-China hogs met at the Sherman House this morning to form a national Poland-China breeders' association. Eight Middle and Western States were represented, and the object of the association formed is to consolidate the records of Poland-China swine. Four of these records now exist.

LONDON, Nov. 19.--The steamship Castle Eden, (Br.,) Capt. Gray, which sld. from Baltimore Nov. 6, has arr. at Liverpool.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 19.--The steamer Captain Sam, plying between this city and Selma, exploded her boilers last night at Hadnot's Bar and the boat was badly wrecked. About 25 passengers were on the steamer at the time of the explosion.

Had it been Mr. BLAINE'S purpose to destroy the lingering traces of the illusion, at one time quite general in the Republican Party, that he was a statesman, he could not have gone about it in a surer way than in his Augusta speech of Tuesday evening.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Nov. 19.--The Rev. Father Fleming, of Tweed, states that smallpox prevails in seven families in that village. The people are terrified, and many are leaving the place.

The annual meeting of the National League of Baseball Clubs was held in the FifthAvenue Hotel yesterday. Every one of the eight clubs was represented, and for hours the baseball kings sipped their apollinaris and addopted rules for the welfare of their association.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19.--The Yale football team to-day defeated the eleven composed of graduates of Yale and Princeton by a score of 14 to 0. The game was stopped during the early part of the second inning by the rain.

The Board of County Canvassers met for the last time yesterday afternoon, and after listening to the reading of the minutes of the previous meetings received from the County Clerk, they confirmed by the bare majority of the board present the official statement of the vote in this city for Electors and State and municipal officers.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 19.--The Western Export Association has agreed to reduce the capacity of its distilleries from 36 to 32 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--As the result of an investigation by Coroner Powers, the mystery surrounding the death of James F. Colgan, a saloon keeper at No. 1,828 South Secondstreet, who was found in a dying condition late on Monday evening on Vine street, below Fourth, was pretty well cleared up to-day.

The Tribune has at last found out that Cleveland is elected. The discovery may possess some interest for a limited circle of readers, but the day when any deliverance from the paper "founded by Horace Greeley" was deemed important by the country long since passed.

In considering whether the editor of the Tribune is criminally liable for the persistently untrue representations of his paper, continued for a week after the election, it is to be borne in mind that the untruths were beyond all question willful.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Antiquarians throughout this region are much interested in the cache recently found on the farm of Mr. George Stowe, about two miles north of this city and one mile south of Port Dickinson. It is the tomb of an Indian chief, the skeleton of which is partially preserved, while the ...

Marie Arp, a pretty young girl, over whose blonde head 14 of the Fatherland Summers had passed, left her home in Hamburg four years ago, and came to seek her fortune in America. Her family were in comfortable circumstances. No quarrel or dispute prompted her departure.

Witchcraft was made unusually interesting to a large audience of ladies and gentlemen by the Rev. John W. Chadwick, last evening, in the Art Rooms on Montague-street, Brooklyn, where the New-England Society, of that city, held its fifth public meeting.

Mr. W.E. Miller, an actor, residing at No. 87 Fourth-avenue, caused the arrest yesterday of an English actor named George Fox, who resides at No. 458 West Fifty-eighth-street, and has been but a short time in this country. Fox was arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--A refined-looking woman, well dressed in black silk, was put on trial in Judge Thayer's court, of the Quarter Sessions, to-day, charged with the larceny of five pairs of stockings, valued at $1 per pair, from the store of Strawbridge Clothier.
The statue of the late Hon. George Brown in Toronto, Canada, is to be unveiled on Tuesday, 25th inst.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--A special to the Times from Lancaster, Penn., says: "The Lancaster Cremation and Funeral Reform Association has completed, and on next Tuesday will formally open, the cremation furnace which it undertook to build about the time the Lemoyne Crematory at Washington, Penn., was ...

READING, Penn., Nov. 19.--A very sad case of destitution, ending in insanity, came to light to-day. A young widow named Huechler since the death of her husband has been obliged to support herself and several children. She rented the rear portion of the building in which a number of law and other offices were situated.
DONGOLA, Nov. 19.--Eight mild cases of smallpox have occurred here among the British troops. The camping ground has been changed and every precaution has been taken against the spread of the disease.

PARIS, Nov. 5.--A Russian commentator upon the grand manoeuvres of the German Army complains of their too great uniformity. "When you have seen one you will have seen all," he says, "for in all is to be noticed the same logical development, the same practical application of a conception always identical with itself;

PARIS, Nov. 19.--Admiral Courbet telegraphs that the appearance of several Chinese blockade runners has compelled him to make an extension of his line of blockade on the coast of Formosa. The French squadron still remains on the defensive and is awaiting the arrival of reinforcments.

Officer Wilson, of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, on July 8 saw Florence Oliver and Tommy Hascomb climb into a wagon on the grounds of the Home for Children and Seminary for Young Girls, in One Hundred and Fifty-third-street.

The canvass of the vote cast in Kings County so far as the Electoral ticket is concerned, was closed yesterday, and the result officially announced by Deputy County Clerk Barnard. Cleveland's vote is 28 votes below the number accorded to him on the face of the official returns ...

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 19.--Worcester scientists are taking great interest in the discovery of the mastodon's teeth and bones in Shrewsbury, and efforts are being made to have the ground thoroughly explored under the direction of the Natural History Society.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 19.--In the Circuit Court to-day a verdict of $10 each and one day's imprisonment in the County Jail was rendered against the Mayor and Aldermen, to be enforced unless by Jan. 1 the market house, condemned as a nuisance, be removed.

The assignment made by the firm of Seidenbach, Schwab Co. to William Sulzbacher for the benefit of the creditors of the firm, as alleged, has been set aside as fraudulent by Judge O'Gorman, holding Superior Court, Special Term.

BRATTLEBOROUGH, Vt., Nov. 19.--John Coombs, aged 25 years, was arrested yesterday charged with numerous acts of incendiarism in Westminster, and was to-day sent to the county jail under $3,000 bonds. It is said that he is very eccentric, and many believe him to be irresponsible for his acts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--The American Woman's Suffrage Association began its annual session here to-day. There was an informal meeting in the forenoon, at which short addresses were made. In the afternoon the Committees on Credentials and other matters were appointed, and addresses were delivered by Mary A. Livermore and Lucy Stone.

Mrs. Margaret Oxford, of No. 79 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth-street, called at Police Headquarters last night to report the disappearance of her mother, Mary McQuaid. She was last heard of on Tuesday, when she took a Third-avenue car at One Hundred and Twenty ...

The Common Council yesterday amused itself by increasing the provisional estimates agreed upon by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment by $504,662. As the estimates go again to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, and as that body invariably overrides any excesses indulged in by the Common Council, the work of yesterday is as if never done.

The concert of Mme. Victoria HulskampMorosini takes place at Steinway Hall to-night. The Overseers of Harvard College have appointed Mr. William Warren, the famous comedian, one of the committee for the examination of students in rhetoric and oratory.
WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 19.--The official majorities of three of the four Congressional districts in this State are: In the First District Goff (Rep.) has 204 majority over Brannon, (Dem.)
A man giving the name of Thomas Reilly, and his residence as this city, appeared in Port Richmond, Staten Island, on Tuesday with a fine and costly trotting horse hitched to a common vendor's wagon.

A play in five acts, neatly constructed, and rich in strong situations, was presented for the first time at the Union-Square Theatre last evening under the cumbersome title of " Duprez Son, Bankers and Brokers."

BOSTON, Nov. 19.--The action of Mr. Albert A. Palmer, of the Madison-Square Theatre, for an injunction to restrain Richard M. Field, of the Boston Museum, from producing "The Private Secretary" has been decided in favor of Mr. Palmer by Judge Colt, of the United States Circuit Court.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19.--In spite of the inclemency of the weather a large and attentive audience, composed of upper classmen and Professors, assembled in President McCosh's library this evening to listen to a paper upon "Theism and Evolution," read by Mr. A. Campbell ...

A coat of black paint was put on the statue of John Harvard by the students one night last week. On the same night that the statue of Harvard was defaced the students painted the figures "88" in black about 4 feet long on the front side of Appleton Chapel.

NEW CASTLE, Penn., Nov. 19.--While two plumbers were at work at the residence of George C. Hagan yesterday a gasoline forge they were using exploded, sending the flames and pieces of the forge in all directions.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 19.--President Costello, of the Miners' Union, with 50 other strikers, were before Judge Hart to-day, charged with conspiracy in intimidating miners at work for J.S. Neal at Coal Centre a few weeks ago. Eminent counsel from Pittsburg took charge of the defense.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19.--The charge of larceny against Charles A. Leland was stricken from Judge Smith's docket to-day, State Attorney Mills having become convinced that it was groundless.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 19.--Mrs. Esther Stewart, an aged colored woman, died at her residence here this morning. She was horribly burned by her clothing taking fire while standing too close to a stove.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 19.--A meeting of the Colorado and Utah pool was held here today. All the roads in the pool were represented. The principal business of the meeting was to receive from J.F. Tucker, the pool arbitrator, the award of percentages ...

YARKER, Ontario, Nov. 19.--Two Frenchmen, while erecting telegraph poles on the Wapanee, Tamworth and Quebec Railway, were blown up while in the act of heating dualin. One was killed instantly and the other is not expected to live.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Nov. 19.--Snow began falling shortly before midnight last night, and this morning there were two inches on the ground and snow was still falling. It has now changed to sleet. At Monticello there are four inches, and along the Erie Railway westward there is a much greater quantity, say, from six to ten inches.

BUENOS AYRES, Nov. 19, via Galveston.-- The Italian steamer Perseo arrived here yesterday, having been refused admittance into the port of Montevideo. Rossini's "Semiramide" was sung by Col. Mapleson's opera company at the Academy of Music last evening with Mme. Patti as Semiramide and Mme. Scalchi as Arsace.

A further consequence of the election of Mr. Cleveland, and one resultant from the political rehabilitation of the South, will be the further decline of sectionalism. The attitude of the two sections toward one another is more friendly to-day than it has been for 50 years past.

"Why, I thought Blondin had gone to heaven long ago," said some one in a railway carriage the other day, as he conned an advertisement in his paper which announced that the hero of Niagara was walking the tight rope at the Britannia Theatre in far-away Hoxton.

Ah Ku, the Chinaman who was arrested a few days ago on landing from the vessel John Sanders, Capt. Thorndyke, from Calcutta, in violation of the anti-Chinese law, was yesterday, by United States Commissioner Shields, remanded to the custody of the Deputy Marshal who arrested him until the time when the vessel sails for Calcutta.
LYNCHBURG, Va., Nov. 19.--A tale of deep distress comes from Buchanan, Wise, and Dickenson Counties. These counties occupy isolated positions on the extreme western limit of Virginia.

EASTON, Penn., Nov. 19.--This afternoon Miss Elizabeth T. Warne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark T. Warne, was married at her home to Robert K. Buchman, a merchant of New-York City. Though the wedding was a quiet one, the prominence of the bride in fashionable circles here made the event an important one in Easton.

At Southampton, in England, were recently on exhibition several rebel flags, captured by Gen. Gordon in China, and some facsimiles of a message written in Arabic cipher and sent out by him from Khartoum, secreted in a quill. There was also on view the last letter written by Nelson before the battle of Trafalgar.

Miss Bessie Taylor Benham, a daughter of Mr. James M. Benham, was married in Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights, at 7:30 o'clock last evening, to Mr. William C. Sheldon, Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William A. Snively, the Rector of the church.
BERLIN, Nov. 19.--The session of the Congo Conference to-day was presided over by Count von Hatzfeldt, the German Minister of Foreign Affairs.

While in the act of taking a drink last evening in a liquor saloon at No. 219 Centralavenue, Brooklyn, Cornelius Bart, aged 49, dropped dead. Bart was collector for a Jersey City brewing firm and resided at No. 29 South Third-street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, Nov. 20.--A large meeting of the Land Restoration League was held in St. James Hall last evening, Michael Davitt, Henry George, Miss Helen Taylor, and several members of the House of Commons were present. Miss Taylor moved a resolution that land inalienably belonged to the people.

OTTAWA, Nov. 19.--It is reported to-night that the Governor-General this afternoon granted a respite of the sentence of Mrs. Boutel, who was to be hanged at Quebec to-morrow morning for poisoning a married woman named Lavers at Bay St. Paul.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19.--The suit of Collis Levy against Algernon S. Roberts, which has been on trial before Judge Biddle since Monday, concluded this afternoon, and, after brief deliberation, the jury rendered a verdict in favor of the plaintiffs for $888. The plaintiffs' claim was for a balance owing to them after a series of stock transactions.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange yesterday continued their discussion of the question of arranging for an exclusive stock telegraphic service. There was much talk, but, according to Secretary Ely, no definite action was taken.

HAVANA, Nov. 15.--Senor Don Jose A. Cortina, director and proprietor of the Revista de Cuba and one of the leaders of the Autonomist Party, died yesterday of typhoid fever.

MADRID, Nov. 20.--England has resumed negotiations with Spain looking to the formation of a new commercial treaty.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 20.--Capt. George H. Selig, of the Lunenburg brigantine Leo, was washed overboard and drowned while on a passage from Lunenburg for Porto Rico. He leaves a wife and four children.

BARNEGAT, N.J., Nov. 20.--The steamer Guadalupe, of the Mallory Line, commanded by Capt. Nickerson, with a crew and 50 steerage and 3 first class passengers, from New-York and bound for Galveston, struck on the outer bar off Barnegat inlet last night at 10 o'clock.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Nov. 20.--A writ for a special election in the Nineteenth Congressional District, composed of the counties of Adams, York, and Cumberland, has been issued for Dec. 23, to elect a successor to the recently elected Congressman, William A. Duncan, deceased.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Nov. 20.--It is understood that the Nova Scotian Government has disposed of the new $400,000 5 per cent. loan to local tenderers, at prices ranging from 100 to 107, the purchasers paying the accrued interest in addition.

PARIS, Nov. 20.--There was a sharp frost again last night, and it is believed that it will have a most beneficial effect in repressing the cholera. There were 30 deaths from cholera in Paris yesterday, all but five of which occurred in the hospitals. From midnight to 6 o'clock tonight there have been 7 deaths by cholera in the city and 19 in the hospitals. Two deaths are reported to-day at Nantes.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., Nov. 20.--Benjamin Garlock, the wealthiest farmer in this town, dropped dead while hitching his horse by the roadside to-day. He was 80 years old.

The Democrats of Brooklyn held a jubilee last night to celebrate their victory in the recent political campaign. The Hon. Thomas A. Hendricks was present, escorted to the Rink by a torchlight procession, and put the climax upon the enthusiasm by a ringing speech upon the reforms that the Democratic Party proposed to inaugurate.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 20.--Charles Frink, who resided near Millington, Tuscola County, had been missing since Nov. 18. His body was found to-day half a mile from his house, and it is believed that he was murdered. William Kenny, of Millington, has been arrested on sus picion of being the murderer.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--Maurice M. Despres died to-day at his son's residence, 3,314 Vernonavenue, at the age of 103 years. The deceased is known from authentic records to have been born at Tomblane, near Nancy, France, Aug. 15, 1781.

Dr. John F. De Planque and wife, of Beach-street, Stapleton, Staten Island, on Wednesday evening celebrated their golden wedding. The German residents of that locality attended the anniversary in large numbers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--The National Fat Stock Show closed this evening. Matters were very quiet there to-day, there being very few visitors. The butchers consumed most of the day in removing the dressed carcases to the long table provided for them in the southeast corner of the building.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 20.--Official returns have been received at Baton Rouge from all the parishes in the State, and they were tabulated to-day. Their promulgation is only delayed by the necessity of the signature thereto of an absent State officer. The Democratic Elector who received the highest vote was Gaskins, who received 62,546. The highest vote cast for a Republican Elector was 46,347, for Beattie. The majority for Cleveland is 16,199.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20.--The North Chicago Rolling Mill Company will, owing to the present condition of trade, shut down its mills at South Chicago on Saturday. This decision throws between 1,500 and 1,800 men out of work, and how long they will be out depends upon the state of trade--certainly two months.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 20.--The Hon. James Speed, who was Attorney-General under President Lincoln, is quite ill from a sudden attack of vertigo, brought on by indigestion. He was stricken while arguing a law case. His advanced age makes his friends very uneasy about his recovery.

The nominal passenger rates to the West remained unchanged yesterday. The brokers' rates to Buffalo ranged from $3 down to $2.50, showing a slight advance. This was largely due to the accumulation in Buffalo of Chicago tickets, which are used in making the low Buffalo rate.

PRINCETON, Nov. 21.--The annual meeting of the Governing Committee of the Classical School at Athens, Greece, was held this afternoon at the residence of Prof. Sloane. This is the first business meeting that has been held in Princeton since the founding of this foreign classical school.

A young man who left home in Connecticut several years ago to seek his fortune recently wrote from Texas saying: "I've settled here." It has since transpired that he was right. He settled at 20 cents on the dollar.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21.--A meeting of the President's Commission appointed to foster trade relations between this country and Central and South America, with the members of the Chamber of Commerce and merchants generally, took place here this afternoon. There was a large attendance. Papers on the various branches of trade which could be encouraged with the Pacific coast were read. A second meeting will be held to-morrow. The commission will leave on Monday for Mexico.

PARIS, Nov. 21.--There were 31 deaths from cholera yesterday in Paris, all but 11 of which occurred in the hospitals. From midnight of Thursday to 6 o'clock to-night 8 deaths from cholera have occurred in the city and 15 in the hospitals. Fourteen deaths occurred to-day at Oran and one at Nantes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21--None of the features of the Cattle market were to-day greatly different from those noted for yesterday. There was a liberal though not excessive supply, and under a good general demand the feeling remained unequivocally firm. Sellers tried, but ineffectually, to gain a further advance. Shippers were disposed to buy freely at previous rates.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 21,--Last night Harvey Johnson, colored, living in the southern part of the city, after quarreling with his wife struck her on the head with some heavy instrument, then fatally cut her throat and set fire to the house. The woman managed to drag herself nearly outside the burning house, but her feet were nearly burned off. Johnson escaped.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 21.--The libel suit of D. M. Osborne Co., of Auburn, N.Y., against G. Esterly Son, of Whitewater, Wis., was discontinued this forenoon by Judge Dyer, of the United States Circuit Court, upon the stipulation of both parties. Neither party was required to pay any costs.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 21.--This evening Acting Mayor Brooks issued an order to the Chief of Police directing that all the gambling houses in the city be closed. Several arrests were made, including that of "Doc" Boggs, one of the most successful confidence men in the country. For some weeks the newspapers here have waged a war of extermination against gamblers, confluence men, thieves, and others of like ilk.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 21.--The evidence in the examination of Koppersmith, engineer of No. 2 Engine, arrested because of his suspicious relations with an incendiary, was so convincing that the Police Board to-day, after carefully considering the same, suspended the fire company and ordered a strict investigation of the case made against the company in the evidence above mentioned.
SHANGHAI, Nov. 21.--The Chinese ironclads Cho-lung and Yung-wei have arrived here. They intend to force the French blockade of the island of Formosa.

Judge McGill, in Jersey City, yesterday, sentenced William Cunningham, Benjamin Grandon. James Brown, and James Norton to five years' imprisonment each for a brutal assault upon May McDonald on the Jersey-avenue bridge a month ago.

Ismail Pasha has arrived in Paris from Vienna, and has taken up his abode in the Grand Hotel, where he intends remaining for several weeks. His health has greatly benefited from his sojourn at Marienbad, and he shows less than ever any visible trace of the vicissitudes he has encountered during the last five years.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Nov. 21.--The local papers in the counties visited with the fatal scourge make only brief mention of its ravages, but further information shows that the former reports were not exaggerated.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 21.--William Star, engineer of the steamer Captain Sam, which was wrecked by the explosion of her boiler, died to-day in the hospital here. Two negroes of the crew each had a leg amputated to-day, and another has entirely lost his eyesight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 21--The conditions of Michael H. De Young, proprietor of the Chronicle, who was shot by Adolph Spreckels on Wednesday night, is becoming more serious. WASHINGTON, Nov. 21,--The jury in the case of Frank Minor, (colored,) charged with the murder of his wife, Victoria Minor, in October, 1882, this morning rendered a verdict of "guilty as indicted." At a previous trial Minor was convicted and sentenced to be hanged, but the court, in General Term, awarded him a new trial. His counsel to-day gave notice of a motion for a new trial.

McClellan in the late campaign, and setting forth that if New-Jersey is to be represented in the Cabinet Gen. McClellan should be the man. The last of the series of resolutions was that "Gen. BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 21.--Gen. and Mrs. P.H. Sheridan and Col. J.F. Gregory, United States Army, are in the city to-day. They arrived by the steamer from Norfolk, Va., this morning, and go south again this afternoon. The trip was taken for the benefit to be derived from the brief sea voyage.

While John Drummond, of No. 35 East Seventeenth-street, was passing the corner of Canal and West streets last night he was attacked by William Watson, 23 years old, of No. 472 Washington-street, who seized him by the back of the neck and attempted to snatch his watch chain. MONTREAL, Quebec, Nov. 22.--By the latest order from the Pope Laval University has been designated as the only one in the Province of Quebec, and the colleges were required to affiliate with it. BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 22.--Gov. Cleveland has engaged a suite of rooms at the Genesee Hotel, in this city, from Feb. 4 to March 3 next. This city will be the office seekers' Mecca for a month at least.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 22.--In the case of Wells against McGeoch Judge Mann this morning rendered an important decision in refusing the motion of Wells to Compel McGeoch to surrender the books and accounts of litigants, showing their wheat and lard transactions of a few years ago. QUEBEC, Nov. 22.--Several places on the north and south shore of the St. Lawrence River, between St. Flavien and Gaspe, were visited by a shock of earthquake last evening. The shock lasted in some places as long as 45 to 50 seconds. No casualities are reported.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 22, via Galveston.-- Two bombs thrown by a Chilian war ship during the blockade of Callao, which were preserved in a house in that city, exploded while a 12-year-old boy was playing with them, instantly killing him. The house sustained serious damage.

LONDON, Nov. 22.--The great franchise fight is off. The King of France has marched his men down hill again. After four months of the fiercest and loudest cannonading, of yells of defiance, and after the direst threats, returning peace finds nobody hurt in the least.

COLUMBIA. S.C., Nov. 22.--The Board of State Canvassers have completed the tabulation of the vote in this State for Presidential Electors. The highest Democratic Elector received 69,890 votes and the lowest 69,764. The highest Republican Elector received 21,733 votes, and the lowest 21,551.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 22.--The steamer Secret, plying between St. John, New-Brunswick, and Annapolis. Nova Scotia, has been stopped by the Inspector of Hulls. The vessel had previously been certificated by officers of the United States Government, but as she was carrying passengers between two Canadian Provinces she needed a Canadian certificate. Three officers of the Marine Department have been directed to hold a survey and report.

Stanley. He said Farmer Petty had heen shot three times in the head, and his wife had been outraged and murdered.

An accident, due to the recklessness of a conductor and a locomotive engineer, occurred yesterday morning on the Hudson River Railroad at Seventy-sixth-street and the North River.

MADISON, Fla., Nov. 22.--On Wednesday night a negro broke into the house of a widow and daughter, living on the outskirts of the city, and attempted to assault them, but was defeated in his purpose. Armstead Williams, a negro, was arrested on suspicion and lodged in jail to-day. He was identified as the author of the outrage. This afternoon several hundreds people went to the jail, broke it open, and shot Williams, killing him instantly.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22.--Thomas Price, a workingman, was assaulted by footpads early this morning. One of his assailants, named Pat McDermott, a notorious character, was captured by a police officer, but succeeded in breaking away. When called upon to halt he refused, and the officer fired at him inflicting a fatal wound. McDermott told the name of his confederate and he was arrested.

The premium list of the New-Orleans Bench Show has been issued and provides for 80 classes. The prizes for mastiffs, rough-coated St. Bernards, smooth-coated St. Bernards, pointers, English setters, Irish setters, fox terriers, and collies are $20 each for the best dog and the best bitch.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22--Robert G. Austin, the manager of the Australian Novelty Company, began a suit to-day against the Chicago Musuem Company, laying his damages at $10,000. Austin was imprisoned for several days last week on complaint of Mr. Goodwin of the museum, that he had been guilty of riot in his place, and had also been arrested on a civil suit for alleged breach of contract. The proceeding is to get square for all that.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 22.--Since the announcement of the election of the Democratic Electors the formation of President Cleveland's Cabinet has been slated for him in many quarters, and curiosity if no other motive has naturally turned to the Southern States the eyes of the Cabinet makers.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 22.--Two freight trains on the Richmond and Danville Railroad collided last night at Keysville. C.V. Marshall jumped from the caboose car of one of the trains and was run over and killed. He was Sheriff of Charlotte County and the son of Judge Hunter H. Marshall, of this city.

The steamship Westphalia, of the Hamburg Line, which arrived yesterday, called at Havre after the cholera had broken out in Paris, For this reason all the passengers were carefully examined at Quarantine, and their baggage was disinfected. The vessel was detained several hours longer than usual on account of the precautionary measures which Health Officer smith felt it his duty to take.

ST. LOUIS. Mo., Nov. 22.--FLORENCE McElcuddy, a laborer, living in East St. Louis, Ill., shot his wife last night when he returned home from a drunken spree. The woman will die. McElcuddy has been arrested.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 22.--An insurance expert who was appointed by the Underwriters' Association to inquire into the condition of Ottawa, so far as it is protected from fire, has reported that it is at present threatened with such a conflagration as laid Chicago in ashes, and that should a fire break out in the lumber district at Eddi's Island, the city would fall a prey to the flames and be swept out of existence.

The bitter warfare waged by the Chicago Board of Trade against the bucket shops has taken on a new phase, and one which is likely to have very serious consequences. The Directors of the board have given the Western Union Telegraph Company notice to remove from the Board of Trade Hall all its instrument and operators, on or before Nov. 28.

JACKSON, Mich., Nov. 22.--The trial of Daniel Holcomb for the murder of the Crouch family was postponed two days on account of the sickness of a juror. This morning the Prosecuting Attorney, Frank E. It will not generally be known, but at present there is a very remarkable conjunction of comets in our evening skies. If one leg of a pair of imaginary compasses be placed at a point on the celestial equator whose right ascension is 23 hours, and a circle be described on the sky with a radius of about six degrees, it will contain within it three periodic comets.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 23.--A slight shock of earthquake was felt here at 12:30 o'clock this morning, followed 16 minutes later by a very heavy one lasting several seconds, during which large buildings were shaken. MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Nov. 23.--For several years past the number of acres sold at auction for unpaid taxes in Ulster County has been very large. By reason of unpaid State taxes on such lands, the county is largely indebted to the State. The debt keeps growing larger every year.

Bernard Connelly keeps a liquor store at No. 165 Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn. Late yesterday afternoon Connelly was in his saloon alone, "putting things to rights," and had both his front and side doors locked. He was standing behind the bar when suddenly he was startled by a series of tremendous blows on the side door.

PETERSBURG, Va., Nov. 23.--Indian Summer weather prevailed here to-day. All day long light rains have fallen on the Atlantic coast line. To-night the heaviest rain for weeks fell in this city and vicinity, and it is still raining, with indications of continuing through the night.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 23.--A report comes from Murray City, a mining town in the Hocking Valley, to the effect that last Friday a large number of miners determined to quit work. Detectives employed by the syndicate prevented them from carrying out their design, and a fight ensued, in which the officers used the butts of their rifles as weapons. Several miners were severely hurt, but none fatally.

When the usual Sunday morning service was begun at the Methodist Episcopal Tabernacle in Greenpoint yesterday morning the church was $25,000 in debt. Justice Manisty's action on Saturday has created a great outburst of popular wrath. BERLIN, Nov. 24.--A sensational suicide occurred here yesterday. Max Hamburgher, a merchant doing business in New-York, Paris, and Berlin, visited his mother's grave and then took his own life. Business losses are said to have led him to this step.

BOSTON, Nov. 24.--An unsuccessful attempt was made last night to rob the safe in the office of the North-Avenue savings Bank in Cambridge. Holes were bored in one of the doors, through which several pounds of powder were poured and exploded. The safe was badly damaged, but not sufficiently to allow the hurglars to get at the valuables.

At the offices of the Mallory Line yesterday it was stated that they still hoped to float the stranded Guadalupe. What they feared most was that a shoal would form around her.
