PARIS, Nov. 24.--The Sanitary Commission has ceased to hold daily sessions. The cholera epidemic is considered at an end. There were 19 deaths from cholera in Paris yesterday. From midnight of Sunday to 6 o'clock this evening there have been six deaths.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 24.--The Frankstown Rolling Mill, which has been idle for four months, resumed operations to-day, and it is thought will be kept running all Winter. It is expected that the now pipe mill, recently built by the same firm, will start up on Wednesday, giving employment to 600 men.

HAVANA, Nov. 24.--The following appeared in La Voz de Cuba of the 19th inst.: "Recently arrived passengers from St. Thomas report that the Cuban insurgents residing in that island, to the number of about 100, intend to invade the island of Cuba, for which purpose a steamer is expected there from New-York. The attempt is to be made in the early part of December."

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 24--A "pauper," known as "Old Eliza," has died at the Home for the Aged. On her box being examined, $2,000 in gold and $2,000 in other money was found. She had been supported by charity for 32 years. Her surname is unknown.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 24.--The Gentile taxpayers began suit to-day to resist the collection of a special school tax voted by the polygamists of the Seventh Ward. They allege that the tax is illegal, and that the school is conducted in the interest of the Mormon church, by Mormon teachers exclusively. This is the first test ever made of Utah's sectarian school laws.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 24.--The State Board of Canvassers completed the canvass of the returns for Presidential Electors to-day, with the following results: Blaine, 197,089; fusion, 177,286; Republican plurality. 19,803. WASHINGTON, Penn., Nov. 25.--Ben Cox was lodged in jail this morning for the murder of George Carter. The shooting occurred on Sunday last, but Carter lived will this morning. It is understood the shooting was without provocation.

TURNER'S, N.Y., Nov. 25.--The engine, baggage car, and two passenger coaches of the "Monitor" train on the Erie Road were thrown from the track this evening just west of this station. The accident was caused by a switch being turned wrong, locked, and the switch lights put out. The engine ran to its length on the bridge and then stopped. No one was hurt.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 25.--A few days ago, near Plainsville, Tenn., while John Henry, a respectable young man, was watching a neigbor chopping wood, the axe flew from the handle, and, striking Henry on the side of the head, cut through his ear and crushed in the skull. At last accounts the young man was said to be dying.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 25.--The season on the Delaware and Hudson Canal is fast drawing to a close. The company stopped granting permits on the l5th inst., and the boats that left tidewater on that day went up the canal on their last trip. Yesterday the last one of the boats was loaded with coal at Honesdale and started toward this point.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Nov. 25.--Corrected returns from all counties in Washington Territory except four show that Charles Voorhees, son of Senator Voorhees, will have at least 60 majority over Armstrong (Republican) for delegate to Congress. Voorhees was elected on a platform of the entire forfeiture of unearned lands of the Northern Pacific Railroad.

FONDA, N.Y., Nov. 25.--There is much alarm among farmers here over a disease that has made its appearance among swine. TORONTO, Nov. 25.--The Province of Ontario is alarmed at the rapid spread of smallpox in the township of Hungerford, Hastings County. JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 25.--An attempt was made this morning at 4 o'clock to burn the town of Salamanca. Four barns were fired, three of which were destroyed, and two efforts were made to destroy the fourth. Six horses and three cows were burned. RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 26.--Claude Perkinson, who lives about six miles from here, in company with a negro boy, went opossum hunting on Saturday night last and his dogs halted at the foot of a pine tree which had been blown down. HAVANA, Nov. 22.--The announcement of the conclusion of the Spanish-American treaty has been joyfully received here. The Conservatives have sent a cable dispatch to Madrid congratulating the Chamber of Deputies on the successful termination of the negotiations.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 27.--J.H. Bailey, of Atlanta, Ga., a commercial traveler for Deere, Mansur Co., of St. Louis, committed suicide here this afternoon, the result of a protracted spree. He was author of a book on political economy, which attracted considerable attention a couple of years ago.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27.--The official vote in Tennessee, with three counties to hear from, gives Cleveland 133,258; Blaine, 124,078; St. John, 1,131; Butler, 957.

The hog that was to be guessed for at Gabe Case's yesterday was mistaken for an Alderman, and the crowd began guessing on Gabe himself. The face of the hog was enough to deceive an Albany investigating committee and the size of Gabe was enough to deceive the guessers.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 27.--To-night the Secretary of State gives the following as the corrected and revised official vote of Indiana for President: For Cleveland, 244,992; Blaine, 238,480; Butler, 8,716; St. John, 3,018. Plurality for Cleveland, 6,512. Gray's plurality over Calkins was 7,392.

PORTSMOUTH, Va., Nov. 27.--A grand Democratic parade was had here to-night in honor of the election of Cleveland and Hendricks. It was the finest ever seen in this part of the State. The city was splendidly illuminated.

Edward H. Ludlow, the veteran and widely known real estate broker, died at his residence, No. 21 East Twenty-fourth-street, yesterday afternoon, at the age of 75 years. He had been in feeble health for some time, but he continued to give attention to business affairs until quite recently.
A wandering son of Richmond College-- one who shared its benefactions in his youth-- was some time ago asked to make, out of his now ample means, a contribution for the benefit of his Alma Mater.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 27.--Thanksgiving was generally observed in this city in the several churches, but the centre of attraction was the Naval Academy, where the usual Thanksgiving athletic exercises took place.

Charles W. Sands called at the Brooklyn Police Headquarters last night, for the purpose of leaving a description of a negro who robbed his house, in Richmond Hill, near Jamaica, on Wednesday evening, and assaulted his wife in a brutal manner. The house, which is a handsome villa, stands in the centre of a large plot of ground, surrounded by a low fence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--In the case of George Hough, the printer who has been on trial in this city for the killing of a companion named William McMahon in a drunken brawl several months ago, the jury, after a session of 17 hours, to-day brought in a verdict of manslaughter. Sentence was deferred.

BOSTON, Nov. 27.--The Rev. James Elijah Latimer, D.D., Dean of the School of Theology in Boston University, died suddenly to-day at his residence in Auburndale, aged 58.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 27.--Vice-Presidentelect Hendricks and family attended the performance of Ciara Morris to-night at Dickson's Grand Opera House. The box occupied by the Vice-President-elect was decorated with choice flowers, flags, and bunting.
The steamship Wyanoke, of the Old Dominion Line, which sailed for Norfolk last Tuesday, was towed into this port yesterday by the steamship Colorado, of the Mallory Line.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 27.--There is an air of ancient elegance about Montgomery that must attract any stranger visiting the place for the first time. Its best streets are lined with spacious, substantial residences of the impressive style favored 30 or 40 years ago. New buildings and new sidewalks are being added to the place, business is spreading and roads are being repaired, ...

BERLIN, Nov. 27.--Thanksgiving services were held to-day at the American Chapel. The communion table was draped with the American flag. One hundred and twenty members of the American colony, including Minister Kasson, his staff, and members of the legation were present.

BERLIN, Nov. 27.--Count von Hatzfeldt, Minister of Foreign Affairs, presided at to-day's session of the Congo conference. The Congo Committee made its report, which was adopted. LONDON, Nov. 27.--Lord Lytton, in a long study published in he Nineteenth Century, upon Mary Anderson's Juliet, declares that the criticisms in some of the London papers are misleading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--The President came into the city this morning from the Soldiers' Home Cottage and attended church. He afterward drove back to the Soldiers' Home, where he took dinner with his daughter and his sister, Mrs. McElroy.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 27.--The Exposition Commissioners have ordered an assessment of 25 per cent. on the notes of guarantors to meet the deficiency caused by the expenses of this year's exhibition exceeding the receipts about $20,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27.--In a cell in the Seventeenth District Station House to-night lay Sabean Salvatore, 75 years old, a Tuscan by birth and a barber by trade. His dusky face was pale with the loss of blood which had poured from 17 different stab wounds in his diminutive body.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27.--It was a gloomy, drizzling, disagreeable day, but thousands were not prevented from attending the different churches. Perhaps the most notable Thanksgiving service was at the Chicago-Avenue Church, where an immense amount of provisions was collected and distributed among the poor.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 27.--Business was pretty generally suspended, and the observence of Thanksgiving Day here was general, with appropriate exercises and big dinners at all the State and private institutions.

PARIS, Nov. 27.--A tragedy which has caused a great sensation occurred here to-day. The wife of Deputy Clovis Hugues, with a revolver, shot and killed M. Morin, the commission agent at the Palais de Justice, because he had slandered her.

NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 27.--A question involving the possession of a little island in the Caribbean Sea was raised in this city to-day by the seizure of a vessel's cargo. In order to fully understand the case it is necessary to explain the law.

In his Thanksgiving sermon yesterday the Rev. R. Heber Newton spoke of some of the strange revelations of Thanksgiving Day, shown by mankind's lack of appreciation of Divine blessings and lukewarm praise therefor, as instanced by the general small attendance at places of worship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27.--Between 60 and 70 applicants for clerkships in the Government departments were examined by the Civil Service Commissioners yesterday in a room in which possibly 35 or 40 could be comfortably accommodated. More room is one of the most pressing needs of the commission.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 27.--In the month of August, 30 years ago, Mrs. James Patterson, of Ringgold, Ga., was bitten on the log by a rattlesnake that had entered her room.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--Mr. Gladstone, the Marquis of Salisbury, and others, held a further conference to-day upon Parliamentary questions. A definite agreement upon a Redistribution bill was reached, and a hitch is now considered impossible.

LONDON, Nov. 27.--Earl Granville, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, has resumed his effort to arrange a peace between China and France. It is stated that he has modified the indemnity proposals, and has sent the modification to Pekin through the Marquis Tseng, the Chinese Ambassador.

Seventeen long tables covered with cloths of spotless linen were ranged side by side in the dining room of the Newsboys' Lodging House yesterday afternoon. At each were 17 places and at each place was a deep blue bowl, a spoon, and a shining knife and fork. At short distances apart were masses of yellow butter and bowls of powdered white sugar.

The hall of the University Club, Twentysixth-street and Madison-avenue, assumed a bright and attractive appearance last evening. It had been tastefully decorated and the tables loaded with fancy articles for a fair in aid of the West Side Day Nursery.

In a second-story window of an up-town residence, fronting on a cross street, a dignified young man sat reading one warm Sunday morning not long ago. The rising sun was preparing to ride high in the heavens, and people were going to church.

CANTON, Miss., Nov. 28.--Alfonso Stadeker, Jr., a member of the firm of J. Stadeker Son, of this city, which failed on the 15th inst., having $100,000 of liabilities and only $25,000 in assets, and his brother Henry, a late clerk for the firm, were arrested to-day and bound over until Tuesday next. They are charged with conspiring to defraud their creditors by taking and concealing goods and other assets of the firm.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 28.--In Woonsocket last night Stephen Flanagun, aged 60 years, a laborer, while drunk entered John Mitchell's saloon, an Sayles-street, and while quarreling with others in the room drew a heavy jackknife and stabbed John Dwyer, aged 25 years, in the breast, making a wound three inches deep, which may prove fatal. Flanagan was arrested, but was afterward released on $1,000 bail.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 28.--The Finance Minister states that it is probable the question of Government life insurance will be taken up the coming session. He believes, however, that the regular life insurance companies will offer strong opposition to the Government taking hold of insurance, which they regard as interference with their vested rights.
GENEVA, Nov. 28.--Several violent shocks of earthquake were felt here at 11 o'clock last night.
FORT PLAIN, via Canajoharie, N.Y., Nov. 28.--The interest in the Smulsey fasting case increases by the report of the approaching death of the young woman.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--A staff correspondent of the Philadelphia Press found at Lewes, Del., to-day, Marshall Bertrand, the young pilot who was the chief sufferer still surviving the 60 hours' exposure and the cannibalism in the skiff of the pilotboat Turley's crew, which was lost on Monday last.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 28.--Herman Linde, of New-York, the Shakespearean reader, is in the city, and while looking through the "Polytechnic Art Gallery" discovered a picture which, he says, is Rembrandt's "Slaughter of the Innocents," a painting celebrated in history, for which connoisseurs have been searching for years. Mr. Linde purchased the picture for $100 from the owner, Robert Magness. How the picture came here is unknown.

The assault upon Mrs. Sands at Richmond Hill, Wednesday evening, is the subject of excited comment throughout the county. Mrs. Sands, who is still at the house of O.W. Greaves, is very much prostrated, having had severe hysterical fits at intervals since the assault.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 28.--A British Columbia dispatch says that the Government of that Province has been formally notified that the Canadian Pacific Railway Company has decided to make Coal Harbor, on the Barrand Inlet, the western terminus of the railway, in place of Port Moody.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 28.--Last evening Norris Eaton, a farmer of the town of Manlius, who had been annoyed by skunks stealing his chickens, shot at a black spot in a straw stack and killed an unknown man who was hidden there.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 28.--The discussion in regard to the abolition of compulsory attendance at morning prayers at Harvard has recently resulted in the draft of a petition to the Board of Overseers which is receiving the signatures of many students, and which prays that attendance at prayers be made voluntary ....
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Nov. 28.--Isaac Weatherwax, a well-known hay and grain dealer of Hoffman's Ferry, was struck by a New-York Central train at that village yesterday and instantly killed.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 28.--Another national bank has been swamped by the unaccountably stupid confidence of its President in a brilliant but rascally grain speculator. One week ago any prominent man in this village of creameries and manufactories would have borrowed all the money he could get to buy stock of the Middletown National Bank at $125.
FONDA, N.Y., Nov. 28.--The boot and shoe store of S. Lenegar Son was closed today by the Sheriff. The firm has confessed judgments amounting to $10,000. The assets are about $5,000.

OLEAN, N.Y., Nov. 28.--Abraham James, whose singular discovery of the once famous Pleasantville oil field, in 1868, is one of the curious reminiscences of the Pennsylvania petroleum country, is reported dead in Oregon at the age of 77. James came into the oil regions in the early days of the excitement in Oil Creek.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 28.--It was not until yesterday that complete returns of the recent election were made to the Secretary of State at Madison.

Among the immigrants who were in the Castle Garden rotunda yesterday was a very neat-looking woman, apparently about 45 years of age. Her manners and language showed that she was an educated and cultivated woman.

The corridors of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel were at no time yesterday free from groups of college men discussing Thursday's football match. Excitement had in large measure subsided over night, and the debaters were more or less bedraggled and worn, but there was a steady current of anger on the part of wearers of the orange and black, while the blue ribbons were far from serene.

Henry Tillson, 25 years of age, a longshoreman, was arrested yesterday on the complaint of Adolph Linzer, of No. 131 Libertystreet. Early yesterday morning Mrs. Linzer went into the yard of her house.

MONTREAL, Nov. 28.--The deputation appointed by the Carnival Committee to wait upon President-elect Cleveland and tender him an invitation to attend the carnival will leave for Albany next week. Erastus Wiman, of NewYork, will be asked to form one of the deputation. WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--The annual report of the Treasurer of the United States shows that the net revenue of the Government was less than that of 1883 by $49,767,712, having been $348,519,869, while in 1883 it amounted to $398,287,581. The decrease in the receipts from customs was $19,639,007; in the receipts from internal revenue, $23,134,296, and in the receipts from miscellaneous sources, $8,849,248.

MACHIAS, Me., Nov. 28.--The schooner Loyalist, from St. John for Boston with hemlock bark, went ashore in the late storm near Head Harbor Island, Jonesport, and went to pieces. The crew of five men were on the rocks all night and were rescued the next day.

BOSTON, Nov. 28.--About noon to-day the coal sheds of Lewis S. Adams Co., on Cottage-street, alongside the New-York and NewEngland Railroad, fell in, burying two men, Henry Knox and Thomas Hendricken, under a mass of coal and timbers. It will probably take a day or two to remove the ruins and recover the bodies. The men were probably killed instantly.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 28.--James C. Pusey, Chief Clerk of the Kansas State Penitentiary at Leavenworth, has disappeared under a charge of defrauding the State of about $3,000 by means of false vouchers. It now transpires that he was recognized in this city last evening. An examination of the books may show further defalcations. Pusey was formerly connected with the Missouri Pacific Railway at St. Louis. It is thought that he has gone toward Mexico.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 28.--The Brown failure created a good deal of talk and excitement here. Mr. Brown came to Indianapolis several years ago from Middletown, N.Y., and formed a partnership with Mr. R. L. Boyd, under the firm name of Brown Boyd, for the transaction of grain and commission business. This firm carried on an extensive business here for several years, but was dissolved about a year ago.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 28.--William H. Weinland and the Rev. John R. Killbuck, graduates of the Moravian Theological Seminary, have received and accepted calls as missionaries to take charge of the Moravian Mission among the Esquimaux in Alaska. The Rev. Mr. Killbuck is a Delaware Indian, and during the Rev. A. Hartmann's absence in Alaska had charge of the Moravian Indian Mission in Canada. Both gentlemen graduated with high honors from the seminary.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28.--It is now believed that the strike of coal miners in the Hocking Valley, which has lasted nearly six months, will be smothered out completely after Dec. 1. FRANKLIN, Tenn., Nov. 28.--Bill Youngerman made himself obnoxious to a negro congregation last night while drunk. Youngerman was found, lying on the public square dead and literally riddled with bullets.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 30.--Hog cholera, which has existed in Connecticut since the beginning of last Summer, has begun to spread with great rapidity. It is now raging in Fairfield County, near Danbury, and is proving very fatal. No remedy for the disease seems to be of any use, and it cleans out every herd of swine it attacks.

DONGOLA, Nov. 30.--Advices from Khartoum state that the Mahdi continues to summon Gen. Gordon to surrender, and that the latter replies by firing into the enemy. On one occasion Gordon told the Mahdi to dry up the Nile and come across if he be a real prophet, and that he (Gordon) would then surrender. The rebels are intrenched at Wady Gamar.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30.--The balloon "Eclipse," the largest ever constructed in California, which is intended to make a trip across the Rocky Mountains, made a trial ascension today, but suddenly descended into Racoon Straits, 10 miles from this city. The occupants and the balloon were picked up by boats from Angel Island. The owner intends taking the balloon to the World's Fair at New-Orleans.

In a third story back room of Morris's Hotel, No. 20 Commerce-street, Newark, about 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Dr. F. De Castro ended his life by shooting himself in the head. He was about 45 years of age, and had been living on the charity of a number of friends for months.

Mr. Asa Hutchinson, of the famous Hutchison family of singers, formerly of Lynn, Mass., died in Hutchinson, Minn., on Tuesday. Nov. 25. He leaves a son and six grandchildren. He was 6l years old, and sang in concerts for over 40 years. His brother, john W., still resides in Lynn.

BERLIN, Nov. 30.--The sitting on Saturday of the Congo Conference Committee lasted four and a half hours. The committee unanimously decided in favor of the freedom of trade within the limits of the newly defined Congo basin.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30.--Another solemn session of the Plenary Council of the Catholic Church was held in the cathedral to-day. High mass was celebrated by Bishop Loughlin, of Brooklyn, the music, which was of the Gregorian, being sung by two choirs and 40 seminarians.

TOLEDO, Nov. 30.--A rumor was current in this city to-day that Sir Charles Neville, the bigamist, had committed suicide in the jail where he is confined. On inquiry at the jail it was found that Neville arose this morning in a very melancholy frame of mind, and said little to his fellow prisoners, contrary to his usual custom.

WHEELING, West Va., 30.--At Hinton, Sumner County, on Friday, Carrie Scott, a notorious woman, placed the muzzle of a revolver in her mouth and blew the top of her head off. Her lover's defection and disgust with her life prompted the act.

CLEVELAND, Nov., 30.--The family of Simon Searles, living near Findlay, left a child, 3 years old, alone in the house last evening. While they were away its clothing in some way caught fire and it was burned to a crisp. The child was still alive when found, but died soon after.

COHOES, N.Y., Nov. 30.--A branch of the Salvation Army, under the command of Capt. Bovall, was opened here this afternoon. The army has secured quarters for a year, and it is proposed to hold meetings twice a day during that period.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 30.--The answer of Dr. Walter Kempster, whose wife is suing for a divorce and alimony, has been prepared and is quite interesting. The answer denies that Mrs. Kempster and her children are living on the charity of Oshkosh people and are in a destitute condition, as the complaint in the divorce case affirmed.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 30.--The Rev. G. McC. Fiske, Rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church here, delivered his farewell sermon this evening, before leaving for his new field of labor at Providence.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 30.--The general feeling among business men is daily growing more hopeful. Some large orders for railroad supplies were placed last week with manufacturers, and bids for others have been asked for. The feeling among iron men is decidedly better on account of the receipts of fair orders for the product of their mills.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Nov. 30.--Diphtheria in a malignant form is prevalent here. Ten deaths from the disease have occurred during the past week.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 28.--The Unitarians of New-England and New-York State will be surprised to learn that the Rev. Martin K. Schermerhorn has left their ranks and joined the Protestant Episcopal Church. CLEVELAND, Nov. 30.--Henry Just, a stranger to the city, engaged a room in the Weckerling Block a few weeks ago, and then advertised for 50 girls to travel in a spectacular drama.

MALDEN, Mass., Nov. 30.--Andrew Benson, who was arrested last night on suspicion of having murdered Mrs. Margaret Benson on Middlesex-street, was released this mording on his own recognizance to appear in court to-morrow morning. Medical Examiner Sullivan now pronounces it a case of suicide, and says that the deed was done about 1 o'clock Saturday afternoon. It is thought tho woman was temporarily insane.

Leimbach, on South Broadway. She was a Spiritualist, and the remark meant that she knew her mother's spirit would call for her.

Mr. McClave entered his office in the morning, vexed and agitated over newspaper paragraphs touching on the joint occupation of it by him and Mr. Mason. Mr. Mason arrived an hour later and with an air of gayety invaded Mr. McClave's privacy.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 1, via Galveston.-- Sefior Diaz was quietly inaugurated as President of Mexico to-day. The United States South American Commission arrived here yesterday.

Boyd, charged with fraudulently selling railroad passes issued to persons by the Chicago and Alton Railroad Company, rendered his decision to-day by sustaining the motion.

Mayor Franklin Edson, Commissioner Hubert O. Thompson, and Gen. Alexander Shaler met last evening as an Armory Board, at sanitary headquarters, and decided on plans for the new Twenty-second Regiment Armory, at Sixty-eighth-street and the Boulevard, and the new Eighth Regiment Armory, at Ninety-fifthstreet and Fourth-avenue. The plans of H.F. Kilburn were accepted for the Twenty-second Regiment, and the Eighth Regiment Armory will be built on those of John R.Thomas. .
WOOD'S RUN, Penn., Dec. 1.--George Rankin, while carelessly handling a shotgun yesterday, accidentally shot and killed his aged mother. The young man did not know the gun was loaded.
AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 2.--The Maine Electoral College met this afternoon and after electing Abner Coburn Chairman adjourned until tomorrow.
MADISON, Ind., Dec. 2.--George Walters, head sawyer at the Madison ship yard, was crushed to death by a large log rolling upon him to-day.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 2.--No event for years has created such a profound impression on the public mind here as the assassination of Capt. R.H. Murphy, and a bitter feeling is manifested against his slayers.

BOSTON, Dec. 2.--The litigation between Manager R.M. Field, of Boston, and A.M. Palmer, of New-York, over the presentation of "Nunky" and " The Private Secretary," has ended, an amicable settlement having been reached by the parties concerned. Mr. Palmer discontinues giving any further performance of the latter play until after Jan. 1, the date on which the right of Mr. Field to play "Nunky" expires.

Edward A. Condict, of Orange, who is known as an expert forger and check operator, was arrested some time ago in Jersey City. He had swindled merchants with bogus and raised checks. Pending trial he was committed to jail in default of bail. Two fashionably dressed women have visited him regularly since his imprisonment. One, he paid, was his sister. The other was supposed to he his wife.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 2, via Galveston.-- President Diaz has appointed the following Cabinet: Minister of Foreign Relations--Senor Ignacio Mariscal, now Minister to England; Minister of War--Gen. Pedro Hinojosa; Minister of Justice--Senor Joaquin Baranda; Minister of the Treasury--Senor Manuel Dublan; Minister of the Interior--Senor Manuel Romero Rubio. The Minister of Public Works has not yet been appointed.

Four hundred German gentlemen sat about six long tables in Beethoven Hall last night and participated in a "Jubel-Commers" in honor of the election of Cleveland and Hendricks. The hosts were the Central Campaign Club of the German-American Independent Association.

READING, Penn., Dec. 2.--The sensation of to-day here has been the story of the visit of a local newspaper reporter to the mountain lair of Abe Buzzard, the notorious Welsh mountain outlaw. The arrangement to see him was made through Mart Buzzard, his brother. Abe is safely ensconced far up in the hills in a hut which is covered with a thick undergrowth.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 2.--Ashland Lawrence Barrett, an expert miner and prominentmine contractor, was killed this afternoon at the Centralia Colliery, owned and operated by L.A. Riley Co., by a heavy fall of top coal. Barrett had charge of the opening up of new breasts and other improvements at this colliery.

HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 2.--At the charter election in this city to-day Henry L. Gregg (Dem.) was elected Mayor by 341 majority, and Henry W. Dakin (Rep.) was elected Treasurer by 6 majority. Horace Payne, the Republican candidate for Assessor, had no opposition.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 2.--Capt. John H.Dingman, a prominent and successful oil operator, while hunting to-day lost his left arm below the elbow by the accidental discharge of his gun. Capt. Dingman enlisted in the One Hundred and sixteenth New-York Volunteers, at Angola, Erie County, in 1862, went through the Red River expedition under Banks, and served in the valley under Sheridan.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 2.--Ex-Senator Charles Stanford recently purchased $150,000 worth of stock in the McQueen Locomotive works from New-York shareholders, and to-day $6,000 was deposited in the bank to meet bills.

QUIENCY, Ill., Dec. 2.--Twenty years ago the wife of George W. Haynes died, leaving him two baby girls. He was poor and had no means. He gave one girl to a gentleman of this city, Henry Shley, now deceased, who adopted her as his own.

The Amphion Musical Society of Brooklyn gave its first concert this season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday evening. The audience was, as usual, very numerous, and the pleasant social character of similar entertainments in the past was distinctly perceptible in last night's affair.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 2.--In 1880 Thomas Cahill was employed in the Stewart mills at Glenham. He was standing on a ladder in one of the mills, adjusting a belt, when the ladder broke and Cahill's arm being caught in the machinery was torn from the socket at the shoulder.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 2.--This morning Ed Turner, a young man, was found dead in the barn of Walton Bross, his employer. A revolver was clutched in his right hand and a bullet from it had done the work, entering at the young man's ear and coming out the other side of his head.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2, 1884. After the adjournment of the Senate to-day the Republican Senators held a brief caucus. Scott; Junior Vice-Commander--Newman J. Weeks; Quartermaster--William Salters; Surgeon--William Handy; Chaplain--Carrol S. Waldron; Officer of the Day--Jacob E. Westervelt; Officer of the Guard--Aaron L. Cristie; Delegate to State Department Encampment--E. A. Holloway.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 3.--The control of both branches of the Legislature by the Republicans, while a natural cause of gratification to the politicians of that party, bids fair to be accompanied by some unpleasant internal complications.

BERLIN, Dec. 3.--In the Reichstag to-day Prince Bismarck declared that the reintroduction of Dr. Windthorst's motion to repeal the law empowering the Government to expel or intern priests for illegally exercising their functions after its recent rejection by the Bundesrath was disrespectful to the Bundesrath. Moreover, he said, the last two Prussian Ministers of Public Worship had not applied the law.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 3.--The Hon. Henry B. Harrison, of this city, the Republican candidate for Governor, who, though receiving a minority of the votes cast, will be elected Governor of the State by the Legislature in January next has made, public the following ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--In the Supreme Court of the United States to-day the following business was transacted: No. 119--The Independent School District of Ackley, Hardin County, Iowa, plaintiff in error, vs. F.G. Hall.

NECHESVILLE, Texas, Dec. 3.--An affray occurred here last evening resulting in the death of L.V. Simpson and Dr. Calhoun Lawrence. Both men were well-known citizens. The difficulty grew out of the settlement of a small debt. Simpson fired first, mortally wounding Lawrence in the abdomen.

Acting upon the suggestion of Mayor Edson, the Controller recently sent to the heads of the various city departments a circular letter asking for an estimate of the amount of money they would need to escape the embarrassments which the new constitutional amendment might entail.

BOSTON, Dec. 3.--The American Bell Telephone Company to-day declared the usual dividend of $3 per share, payable Jan. 15 to stockholders of record on Dec. 31, and an extra dividend of $3 per share, payable Dec. 15 to stockholders of record at the close of business to-day.
The Actors' Fund benefit takes place at the Academy of Music this afternoon.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 3.--The Rev. Erastus W. Spaulding, Dean of All Saints' Episcopal Cathedral, has suddenly resigned his position and has gone to his former home in New-Jersey.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--Benjamin S. Owens, a young man of good family, and the Secretary of the Board of Managers of the Academy of Music, who fled to Chicago after having stolen nearly $900 of the Academy funds, and was brought back on a requisition, pleaded ...

The New-York Free Circulating Library, which is situated at No. 49 Bond-street, is about concluding the fourth year of its usefulness. Its Trustees in their annual report make a very gratifying exhibit of its affairs during the past ...

ALBANY, Dec. 3.--It is semi-officially announced that Col. Gillette, of Elmira, will be Military Secretary to Gov. Hill. Will. E. Smith, of Plattsburg, says that he is not to be Gov. Hill's private secretary. The impression is that the statement in THE TIMES last week that C.P. Bacon, of Elmira, will fill that place is more nearly correct than any others.

The prospects are now that elevated railroad trains will be rattling through the streets of Brooklyn before the 1st of next February. The disconnected sections of road structure, which have been propped up for years awaiting, dilatory litigation and legislation-- claim stakes put up to warn off other settlers-- have all been connected into one long, zigzag chain, full of kinks and twists, winding through ...

The Trunk Line Presidents' Committee met at Commissioner Fink's office yesterday and agreed to advance the live stock and dressed beef rates, on Monday next, to 40 and 70 cents per 100 pounds, respectively, from Chicago to New-York. Rates to and from other points will be on this basis.
"Yes, don't mention it," said handsome Mrs. Connor, as she greeted a TIMES reporter in her elegantly furnislied rooms at the St. James Hotel last night. "I'll tell you all about it."

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 8.--The most remarkable trial recently held on the civil side of the courts in this State was concluded on Sunday. Mrs. W.B. McDaniel, the soprano singer in the Baptist church choir in this city, and Mr. W.H. Huntt, the organist, met in the choir gallery about midday in last May.

Although few of the laity ventured into the Park-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, where the convention of Presiding Elders began formal session yesterday, the three meetings of the day were attended by the delegates in force, and were evidently of much profit to all concerned.

Walter C. Allen, a good-looking young man, dressed in the height of fashion and wearing a short drab overcoat, stood at the bar at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to answer five distinct charges of forgery.

The auction sale of securities belonging to the estate of the late Samuel Willets was resumed yesterday by Adrian H. Muffler Son in the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broadway. The following sales were made:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Hugh McCulloch, of Maryland, to be Secretary of the Treasury; Frank Hatton, of Iowa, to be Postmaster-General:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--There is great difference of opinion among Democratic members of the House of Representatives as to what should be done about the tariff during the short session. Mr. Carlisle has expressed his belief that no attempts will be made to revise or correct the present law during the present Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--An elopement which took place in this city to-day has not been made public long enough to become generally known in society circles, but it will excite a great deal of interest in Washington and New-York because of the high standing of one of the parties and the distressing features of the affair.
The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association yesterday passed on the following cases:

LEWISTON, Me., Dec. 3.--Elmer Haskell, son of Frank Haskell, and Willie Jordan, son of Roscoe E. Jordan, were drowned in the river tonight. One broke through the ice and his companion lost his life in trying to save him.
A meeting of the Directors of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad was held yesterday to go over the business of the road for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 3.--In Roxborough on yesterday Howard Clayton, aged 11, was sent by his father to a neighbor to borrow a gun. On the way home he put his mouth to the muzzle for the purpose of ascertaining if it was loaded, and at the same time he had sprung the hammer with his toot. While in this position his foot slipped, and the gun went off and the boy was instantly killed.

Mr. Blaine made several visits yesterday, among them a call upon the wife of Senator Hale, of Maine, who was at the Fifth-Avenue hotel. During his absence there were numerous callers at Mr. Elkins's house and also after his return. He saw no one except a few intimate personal friends.

The steamship Santo Domingo, Capt. Kelly, which arrived from San Domingo City and Turk's Island Tuesday evening, brought 26 destitute British sailors belonging to the barks Invincible and Spinaway, which were lost in the Caicos Passage on Nov. 6.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 3.--The Produce Exchange of this city today adopted an address to the railway managers of the country, setting forth the fact that at the much higher valuation of Western products in the past few years transportation rates were based upon the principle of "what the tariff would bear."

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 3.--There was a wedding this evening at the residence of Charles L. Ray, one of Milwaukee's richest citizens. His eldest daughter, Lucille M., a niece ox Lieut. Ray, of arctic fame, was married to Angus S. Hibbard, a young business man. The bride received a small fortune from her father as a wedding present.

COBLESKILL, Dec. 3.--Investigation into the frauds committed against this county by Merritt Baker, ex-Clerk of the Board of Supervisors, is being continued at the Court-house. One Supervisor said he thought the frauds would reach $10,000.
A young man who was so embarrassed that he could hardly keep his eyeglass in his eye stood with an elderly gentleman before Justice Power, in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday.

Russell A.S. Blackwell, manufacturer of shoes at No. 94 Reade-street, made an assignment yesterday to Noah Tebbetts, giving preferences for $3,300. He began the present business in September, 1883, having previously been in the same line in 1882. The failure is attributed to dull trade, poor collections, and insufficient capital. The liabilities are reported at about $15,000.

The dispatch which was sent from Boston to yesterday morning's papers concerning the difficulties between Manager Palmer, of the Madison-Square Theatre, and Manager Field, of the Boston Museum, was complicated enough to still further confuse people who have kept half an eye on the matter.

The United States Underground Cable Company was a concern that, from all accounts, never possessed much stability. Something over $200,000 was subscribed to the capital stock of the concern, but the amount paid in, the Receiver states, was only about $10,000.

It is said that the Jersey City Gaslight Company and the People's Gaslight Company, of Jersey City, have consolidated, with a view to leasing their works to the United Gas Improvement Company, of Philadelphia. The Philadelphia company guarantees the People's Gaslight Company a dividend of 4 per cent. on ...
A year ago a dozen ladies started a nursery at No. 316 Last Twentieth-street, where small children might be cared for while their mothers were at the work necessary to earn their subsistence.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 3.--Lieut.-Gov. Hill is a resident of Elmira, 59 miles west of this city, but he has many friends here who admire him for his character and worth as a man and his ability as a lawyer.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 3.--Arguments on a motion to set aside the Bell Telephone patents, which are being heard by the Minister of Agriculture, will be concluded late to-night. The court has been sitting for the past two days and will probably sit until midnight.

Mr. Henry Parsons Farnum, an old California pioneer, while standing in the drug store at Madison-avenue and Fifty-third-street at 5 o'olock yesterday afternoon, suddenly fell back, and, before assistance could be rendered, expired. Mr. Farnum had been suffering from ill-health for some time past, but in starting out from his ...

BERLIN, Dec. 3.--Sir Edward Malet's pro memoria states that England, in the interest of traders, had established a protectorate extending northward to Benin, southward to Ambas Bay, thus comprising the whole lower Niger country to a junction with the Benone River.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 3.--Gov. Cameron and Oyster Inspector J.F. Hunter left here tonight in the new State oyster gunboat Chesapeake for a cruise up Chesapeake Bay after oyster pirates. This is the third expedition of the kind the Governor has led during his term of office.

ALBANY, Dec. 3.--Flowers in pretty forms decorated the desks of many of the Electors when Eugene Kelly called the Electoral College of New-York together this morning. The Rev. Joseph U. Mulford, of Troy, offered prayer.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 3.--The Schenectady County men drafted in 1863--the first draft in this county--held a convention yesterday. The complaint of the drafted men is that during the war there were four drafts ordered by the Government, and in one-half of the State ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--On motion of Gen. Swaim's counsel to-day, a subpoena duces tecum was issued by the court-martial for the production in court of the books of Bateman Co. Judge Shellabarger then asked that the further cross-examination of Mr. Brown be postponed ...
LONDON, Dec. 3.--A dispatch from Hong Kong to the Times says: "It is believed here that China is determined to resist France a outrance.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 3.--Baseball cost the stockholders of the Hartfort League Association a little more than $400 over the receipts last season, but they have determined to organise a nine for 1885, and three players have already been engaged. At Bridgeport a State league nine is also to be formed.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 3.--A case which served to revive the speculative "graveyard insurance" craze which swept over the country several years ago, and one which attracted general interest, terminated in the Schuylkill County Court to-day, after occupying its attention for over a week.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 3.--Several carloads of negroes, numbering 150 persons, and embracing men, women, and children, passed through this city to-day en route to Argenta, Ark.

ALBANY, Dec. 3.--President-elect Cleveland some days ago accepted an invitation to attend the charitable entertainment to be given in the Academy of Music, New-York, to-morrow afternoon, for the benefit of the Actors' Fund.

NYACK, Dec. 3.--The Republican club organized in this place last Summer for work in the recent campaign has decided to become a permanent organization in the interest of the Republican Party in the future.

TRENTON, Dec. 3.--The funeral of the late Gen. Gershom Mott took place to-day. The religious services at the family residence in Bordentown, were conducted by the Rev. Dr. Kolb, of the Baptist Church of that place, of which the deceased was a member. Gov. Abbett, ex-Govs. Joel Parker and Ludlow, Gen. Sewell and staff, ...

CLEVELAND, Dec. 3.--The overthrow of the Scott taxation law by the Democratic majority of the State Supreme Court has even yet worse confused the already well-mixed question of temperance reform in Ohio.
A proposition to make the Treasurership of the Produce Exchange a salaried position has given rise to some discussion in that Exchange.
NEWBERRY, S.C., Dec. 3.--When the news of Cleveland's election reached this town the court was in session, and a lawyer requested Judge Pressley to allow him to tell the jury ...

LYONS, N.Y., Dec. 3.--Frederick Koehler, a German farmer, while assisting his daughter in drawing water from a well on his farm last evening, lost his balance and fell into the well, breaking his neck and crushing his skull. The body sank in 20 feet of water. The Coroner held an inquest, and a verdict in accordance with the facts was returned.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 3. via Galveston.--President Diaz has raised sufficient funds for the temporary needs of the Treasury and to pay the Government employer in full. He has also made arrangements with the National Bank, commencing this month, to reduce the Custom ...

It was 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon when the mummified remains of the unknown woman found among the ashes in the subcellar at No. 20 Frankfort-street on Tuesday were dumped on one of the dissecting tables connected with the Morgue.

Adam M. Singer, a son of the late Isaac M. Singer, the inventor of the sewing machine bearing his name, has filed a petition in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court asking to have the accounting of David Hawley, the Executor of his father's estate, reopened on the ...

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 3.--The inside facts of the killing of Thomas H. Watkins, editor of the Vienna Herald, by John Diggs, editor of the Vienna Courier, have just reached here. These two men were regarded as "fighting editors from Bitter Creek," with all that the term implies in the far away woodland, ridge ribbed, rocky region of ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 3.--A cablegram was received in this city to-day saying: "The crew of the German ship Salisbury, from Philadelphia Sept. 26, for Fiume, mutinied at Gibraltar and attempted to set fire to the ship. Assistance was sent to the vessel. The mate, who was stabbed, was taken ashore and imprisoned, and the vessel was left to the mercy of the mutineers."

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec 3.--The people, in the case of Willett, on trial for the murder of Kelland, rested their case this afternoon. They proved that Willett admitted to a friend in NewYork that he clubbed Kelland to death.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 3.--The State Board of Electors met in the Senate Chamber of the State House this afternoon. Thomas M. Kays was chosen President, Ephraim H. Emson, Secretary; A.A. Hardenburgh and James Lord, Jr., Tellers, and John H. Lavil messenger to take the ...

The largest meeting of business men that has yet been held in the rooms of the NewYork Board of Trade and Transportation occurred yesterday. It was called for the purpose of urging upon Congress to take immediate action on the Lowell bankrupt bill.

The Electoral College of the State of New-York, having received a blessing and effected an organization on Tuesday, yesterday settled down to real work and cast thirty-six votes each for CLEVELAND and HENDRICKS.

The second session of the New-York and Hudson River Conference of Unitarian and other Christian churches was begun late yesterday afternoon is the Church of the Messiah. Mr. John Harsen Rhoades occupied the pulpit as Chairman with the Secretary, the Rev. Rus sell N. Bellows. Among the delegates and clergymen present were the Rev. Robert Collyer, ...

The settlement of the Senatorial and Speakership questions was reputed to be the object of the unusually large gathering at the Gilsey House last night of Republicans from the interior of the State. James D. Warren and Collector Charles A. Gould, of Buffalo; ...

LINCOLN, Ill., Dec. 3.--O.A. Carpenter arrived herd from Dakota yesterday morning. Last evening, as he was sitting in the office of Uriah Hill, on Broadway-street, W.H. H. Burns, the father of Zora Burns, saw him there.

BOSTON, Dec. 3.--Mrs. Howe, of the Woman's Bank, after having served three years in the House of Correction for swindling depositors, and whose case attracted great attention at the time, has, it is reported, announced herself as agent in a new enterprise on Concordstreet, which, from the advertisement, seems to ...

According to a published report dated 1884, the Young Men's Republican Club of this city has a membership of over 300. It desires to increase its usefulness and efficiency, and to that end last evening instructed its Committee on ...

LONDON, Dec. 3.--A dispatch from Dongola to Reuters News Ageney says: "The Mudir has received news that the Mahdi is dead, and that his followers are dying very fast. The camel corps and the Staffordshire regiment will start for Ambukol next week."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2.--The surgeons of the Jefferson College Hospital, in this city, have been very much interested recently in a somewhat unusual case that has been in their hands for treatment. It is that of a man who may be described as a human barometer. So far, however, from boasting of his power to foretell ...

PARIS, Dec. 3.--The leaders of the majority in the Chambers have been in consultation to-day with the committee of the Chamber of Deputies which has charge of the Senatorial Reform bill. The Republican Union has also taken part in the conference, and it is expected that an understanding will be reached.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3.--The General Mangers of the Missouri River lines succeeded to-day in agreeing upon rates to and from Missouri River points, and the Western rate war is at an end. The rates agreed upon are $7.50 between Chicago and St. Louis and $12.50 between Chicago and Kansas City.

BERNE, Dec. 3.--The building of a railway through the great St. Bernard Mountain is under discussion. Application has been made to the Federal Council for a concession to enable the work to be attempted.

ALBANY, Dec. 3.--Frank F. Curtis, President of the Sixth Avenue Railroad Company, and John E. Burrill, counsel for the company, appeared before the Railroad Commissioners today and made a motion for a rehearing of the application of the Sixth-avenue Company for an increase of capital stock from $750,000 to $1,500,000, which was recently denied by the Commissioners. The board reserved their decision.
Lord TENNYSON'S new poem will unquestionably find its admirers among the numerous class of readers who believe that poetry should be purified of the prosaic presence of ideas.
We are able to give this morning a complete table of the popular vote at the late Presidential selection side by side with that of the election of 1880.

A watchman passing through the halls of the Sturtevant House at 3 A.M. yesterday smelled escaping gas and found it came from room No. 401. The door, which had been bolted, was broken open, and M.L. Paul, a commercial traveler from Syracuse, was found dead in the bed and the room filled with gas.
RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 3.--Governor-elect Scales has appointed Charles H. Armfield, son of ex-Lieut.-Gov. Armfield, his private secretary.
The Westchester County Railroad Company has made applicatton to the Yonkers Common Council for permission to build, operate, and maintain a street surface railroad through the following streets:

BOSTON, Dec. 3.--The stockholders of the Shoe and Leather Insurance Company of Boston, at a meeting to-day decided to wind up the affairs of the company and retire from business. The marine risks have been reinsured in the Insurance Company of North America, of Philadelphia.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 3.--A meeting of the members of the Liquor League was held this evening. There was a large attendance, and the deliberations, for the most part, were conducted in secret.

Appraiser Ketchum, of New-York, was in this city to-day on business connected with the Treasury Department, and had some talk with Secretary McCulloch about the case of Tea Examiner James R. Davies, who has been charged with taking bribes from tea importers ...

The annual meeting of the New-England Society of Brooklyn was held last evening in the Directors' room of the Academy of Music. Mr. John Winslow occupied the chair. The annual report of the Treasurer showed that there was a balance on hand of $11,243.99.

James Kennedy, who shot his wife on Tuesday night in Third-avenue, had but little to say to Justice Power when arraigned in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday, except that he had not intended to kill her and did not know how many shots he had fired until the morning papers informed him.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Dec. 3.--The attacks of Orangemen upon the Redemptionist Fathers continued three days--Wednesdar, Friday, and Saturday. They were brutally driven out of Conception Bay amid hootings, stone pelting, and violent execrations. Great indignation exists among the Roman Catholics. The protection of the United States Government for its citizens has been invoked.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 3.--In the United States District Court to-day J.P. Horbach, late manager of the Dismal Swamp lottery of this city, was convicted on two indictments charging him with sending lottery tickets through the mails and fined $200.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 3.--Lawyer Lyman E. Munson, a leading attorney, is sued by Mr. Elkanah Lane, in Court of Common Pleas, for the recovery of $300, with interest since 1873. The plaintiff claims that Munson, who was his attorney some years ago, after being paid for his services, retained the $300 unknown to him.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 3.--Surrogate R.C. Scott to-day delivered a decision in one of the most remarkable will contests known in Northern New-York, which involved between $300,000 and $400,000. James Chase was a wealthy farmer living in the town of Theresa, in Jefferson County.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 3.--A young man named Griffiths, son of John Griffiths, of Shenandoah, was instantly killed yesterday afternoon by his gun going off accidentally, the entire charge passing into his head. He was out gunning on Dunn's Hill, with another young man named Rushworth, and had stepped upon a rotten stick which gave way under him, throwing him against the gun with the result stated above.
BOSTON, Dec. 3.--W.E. Russell (Dem.) was elected Mayor of Cambridge yesterday by 1,085 a majority over Fox.(Rep.)

SALEM, Mass., Dec. 3.--The case of Thomas Lowe, who is charged with the murder of Neilie Sullivan, at North Andover, was given to the jury at 4 o'clock this afternoon, and they returned at 8:10 o'clock with a verdict of murder in the second degree. Lowe was sentenced to life imprisonment in the State prison.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3.--District Attorney Tuthill and Marshal Jones appear determined to probe to the bottom the Democratic fraud in the Sixth Senatorial District, and they are still finding important witnesses for the Federal Grand Jury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3, 1884. Senator Mitchell has prepared and will to-mor row introduce a bill granting a tension of $5,000 a year to Gen. Grant for life, beginning with the date of his retirement from the Presidency.

The beauties of friendship are strikingly displayed in the tender anxiety shown by the friends of Mr.B.P. Powell, late of No. 118 Prospectplace, Brooklyn, as to his welfare, and especially as to his whereabouts. Mr. Powell is a gentleman of about 35, tall, dark, slender, and a good conversationalist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3.--A letter received at the Post Office Department to-day stated that the Post Office at Charco, Goliad County, Texas, was entered by Mexican robbers on the night of Nov. 24, and the office robbed of money and other valuables. Upon leaving the robbers fired upon and killed the newly appointed Postmaster, Caesar Bazaar.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 4.--There is much indignation felt by the members of the Grand Army of the Republic of New-Jersey at the treatment of Department Commander Navins and staff, as well as the members of Wilks and Bayard Posts, G.A.R., of this city, and visiting comrades, who took part in the funeral of the ...
An interested gathering followed Mr. Henry H. Ragan in "Ramblings through Spain and Morocco" at Chickering Hall last evening.

The new ferryboat Brooklyn, the second steel vessel constructed for the Union Ferry Company, was launched yesterday morning at the Continental Iron Works, in Greenpoint. A large number of spectators, among whom were many ladies, witnessed the launch.

One thing was settled to the satisfaction of the Republicans who met in conference at the Gilsey House Wednesday night, and that was that until it was authoritatively established by President Arthur himself whether or not he would be a candidate for United States Senator his friends would be completely at a loss how to proceed in the Speakership contest, and, in consequence, would fritter away much strength that ...

A correspondent of the Pall Mall Gazette has called attention to the alarming mortality among Bishops' wives. It appears that at present them are six Bishops who are widowers, five who have been married twice, and one, the Bishop of Liverpool, who has been married three times.

CAIRO, Dec. 4.--The rebels made an attack upon Suakin at midnight on Wednesday lasting three hours, when they were repulsed with a loss of 15 killed and a large number wounded. During a pursuit blood traces were found for a distance of five miles. There was no loss to the British troops.

A meeting of the First Ward Republican Association of Brooklyn was held last evening in the Atheneum, at Clinton-street and Atlanticavenue, for the purpose of taking action on the proposed expulsion of the members of the association referred to in the following resolution, adopted at a previous meeting:

When William I. Phillips, a member of the Produce Exchange, fled from this city last May he left behind him many mourners who held promissory notes of the firm of which he was the head, or warehouse receipts forged by him.

The Chamber of Commerce Special Committee on Revenue Reform, after a presumably careful examination into the working of the new Barge Office, reports that it is a failure, and recommends an immediate return to the former practice of landing at the steamers' docks.
Rugg, the murderer of the Maybee woman, who is awaiting the decision of the General Term for a new trial, came very near making his escape recently from the Queens County Jail.
A dozen men were engaged yesterday morning off the Fulton Fish Markst hauling a large skeleton from the deck of the fishing schooner F.A. Brooks.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Dec. 3.--A sad story, the outcome apparently of idle and malicious tongues, comes from Red Hook, Dutchess County. A few weeks ago Prof. Uriah H. Brown, Principal of the Union Free School there, and his wife had a happy home. Now Mrs. Brown fills a suicide's grave, and there is reason to believe the Professor's mind has been affected by the severe mental strain and grief to which he has been subjected.

Many people remarked yesterday of the crowd that assembled in the Court of Oyer and Terminer that it was totally unlike the usual audiences which assemble to listen to judicial proceedings. This was at once evident. The room was filled with well-dressed men, all apparently very much in earnest, and without doubt belonging to that numerous class known as merchants. They had come prepared to wait.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4.--William H. Neilson made a deposition to-day before a notary in the libel case of Miss Hill, plaintiff in the celebrated Sharon divorce case against the Daily Alta California, in which he stated under oath that the letters purporting to have been addressed to Miss Hill ...

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4.--Gov. Hoadly has appointed a commission of eight members, of which J.D. Cox, of Hamilton County, is Chairman, to procure and present to Congress a statue of the late President Garfield, as a part of the contribution of Ohio to the National Gallery in Washington. The statue is already is preparation.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 4.--The non-explosive lamp works resumed operations this morning. The firm is now the brass and lamp works of W.J. Gordon. The latter paid $20,000 for the machinery. The Assignee says the creditors of the old company will not get more than 10 cents on the dollar.
A gas drop light in the back parlor of the boarding house of Frank M. Leonard, No. 232 East Thirtieth-street, set fire to the house in some unknown manner last evening.

The Widow Faulkener opened a new beer saloon in Newark, N.J., on Wednesday, and invited all the "sports" she had ever heard of to attend the opening. Among others who responded were Arthur Chambers, the pugilist, and his wife.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--The circular sent by ex-President Franklin B. Gowen to the stockholders of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, saying that he was preparing a plan for the reorganization of the company and soliciting proxies for use at the annual meeting in January, was the subject of ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--The interest manifested in New-York about the election of a United States Senator to succeed Mr. Laphum is shared in Washington by members of both houses and by many politicians out of Congress.

Funeral services over the remains of Francis D. Moulton, whose death was announced in yesterday's TIMES, will be held at his late home, No. 580 Lexington-avenue, at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The news of Mr. Moulton's death was a great surprise to his friends and acquaintances who did not know of his illness.

A genial spirit of harmony pervaded the smoke-laden atmosphere of Republican Hall last night, and the members of the Republican County Committee pursued their task of framing a new constitution and new bylaws amid ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Otis P. G. Clarke, of Rhode Island, to be Commissioner of Pensions; Calvin B. Walker, of Indiana, to be First Deputy Commissioner of Pensions; Noah P. Loveridge, of Michigan, to be Second Deputy Commissioner ...

ERIE, Penn., Dec. 4.--Levy, the cornet soloist, who has already had considerable experience as a marrying man, was married again to-night at the Reed House in this city. The bride is Miss Stella Costa, a singer of his concert company, and the ceremony was performed by the Rev. Mr. Carstensen.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--A report was widely circulated to-day that the body of Howard Sullivan, the murderer of Ella Watson, who was executed at Salem, N. J., had been stolen.

On the 7th inst. commenced at Baku a congress of persons interested in the petroleum trade, including the Presidents of the four railway companies over whose lines much of the products are carried, and the Presidents of steamboat companies also engaged in carrying them.

A mysterious group of five men, who were hanging suspiciously around the corner of Clinton and Fulton streets, Brooklyn, late yesterday afternoon, attracted the attention of Detective Mahoney, of the First Precinct. All were fairly well dressed, and they wandered around apparently with no particular aim in view.

The ballast scow Mayflower, which was lying alongside the bark Harriet Upham at Pier No. 55 East River, was run into at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning by the steamer Capitol City, which was bound up the Sound.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 4.--On Tuesday night there died at the State Insane Asylum here one of the most singular of its many hundred demented inmates. His name was Asa T. Churchill, and he was about 40 years of age.
The receipt of $1 from W.S. Baldwin, of New-Haven, for the Bartholdi statue pedestal, is acknowledged.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 4.--The motion for a new trial in the case of Neiveille, the bigamist, was argued to-day, and was overruled. Neiveille was then sentenced to seven years' imprisonment at hard labor in the penitentiary, that being the full extent of the law. He was taken to Columbus to-night.
The police have at last been too powerful for the District Attorney and his private detectives. That, at least, will be the explanation generally accepted of the escape of "Mother MANDELBAUM."

OTTAWA, Dec. 4.--A few days since it was reported that the three-ton sloop which left Victoria, British Columbia, with 19 Chinamen and 2 white men on board, bound for the American shore, which Chinamen were to be smuggled in, had swamped, and that all hands were lost.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association finished its labors in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday. Fifty cases were acted on and the members were kept busy. They adjourned to meet in Chicago, May 12, ...
CHICAGO, Dec. 4.--Judge Tuley to-day entered a formal order appointing Horace A. Hulbert Receiver of the estate of the late Wilbur F. Storey, editor and proprietor of the Chicago Times.
Miss Fanny Davenport will act Fedora for the three hundredth time at the FourteenthStreet Theatre this evening.

The Council of the Nautical School of this port, selected by the Chamber of Commerce, has issued its report of the tenth annual examination had on the schoolship St. Mary's. Since the organization of the school, in 1874, 1,020 pupils have been received and 368 of them have been graduated.

BOSTON, Dec. 4.--Mr. Byron Somes, managing editor of the Troy Telegram, was married to-day to Miss Althea White Barry, granddaughter of the late Hon. Charles Barry, long known for his connection with financial institutions in New-England. The ceremony, which was attended by only a few friends, was performed in the Dudley-Street Unitarian Church by the Rev. W.H. Lyons.
ALBANY, Dec. 4.--The Evening Journal says: "It appears that the Hon. James D. Warren is in the race for the Senatorship.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Dec. 4.--The Democratic conferrees of the Nineteenth Congressional District met here to-day and nominated Dr. John A. Swope, of Gettysburg, as a candidate for the unexpired term in Congress of William A. Duncan, deceased.
A package of Bank of England notes was sent by a down-town broker to the foreign exchange office of Zimmerman Forshay yesterday, to be converted into American currency.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 4.--A majority of the Standing Committee of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States have signified their assent to the consecration of the Rev. Dr. William Paret, of Washington, recently elected Bishop of the Diocese of Maryland. After the consent of the Bishops arrangements will be made for his consecration, which will take place in Washington early in January.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 4.--To-day was the most sensational of any in the trial of William Menken, charged with the murder of Katie Broadhaft at Elmira.

ALBANY, Dec. 4.--Those friends of Mr. Arthur who have been trying to link together the fortunes of the next United States Senator and of the Speaker of the new Assembly are finding it up-hill work. Some of them started off with the determination to boom George Z. Erwin, of St. Lawrence, for Speaker, and Levi P. Morton, of New-York City, for Senator.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 4.--The law officers of the parish are busy with the Ford case. The Judge, who is charged with the slaughter of Capt. Murphy, is in the Parish Prison, but he there occupies the place of a hero rather than that of a felon.

President-elect Cleveland left Albany at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, and came to this city as rapidly as a special train could convey him and his party, to attend the first of this season's benefits for the Actors' Fund of America.

LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 4.--George B. Schaum, the largest furniture dealer in this county, failed to-day. Liabilities, $70,000; nominal assets, $12,500.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 4.--Gov. Thompson was inaugurated at 1 o'clock this afternoon with impressive ceremonies. The Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court administered the oath of office to both the Governor and to Lieut.-Gov. Sheppard.
A young woman was seen wandering aimlessly in the vicinity of Grand-Street Ferry yesterday. She was dressed in a neat plum-colored silk dress and wore a black silk circular.
OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 4.--Cook Teets will be executed at Owen Sound to-morrow. It is altogether unlikely that the Privy Council will interfere with the carrying out of the sentence.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Dec. 4.--The visit of Walter D. Wellbrene, of the Southeastern Tariff Association, has had a bad effect among property holders in this city, for the fire insurance companies which are included in that insurance organization have issued a new set of rates, which are regarded as exorbitant even by the local insurance board in this city.

A decree annulling the marriage of Louise Le Sure Hitchcock to Charles P. Woodworth has been granted by Judge Van Hoesen, in the Court of Common Pleas, on the report of Frank S. Glass, the Referee before whom the suit was tried.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 4.--The examination of William R. Smith, charged with embezzling State funds, was continued this mornin the Police Court, and resulted in his acquittal in one case, in which he was alleged to have embezzled $1,552. The trial of the other case against him was postponed until Saturday, and he was admitted to bail in the sum of $1,000.

PARIS, Dec. 4.--Gen. Briere de 'l'Isle commander of the French forces in Tonquin, telegraphs that an imperial decree, urging the natives to poison the French, has been placarded in Lock-Nan. It was issued, he says, by order of the Viceroy of Kwang-Tung.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4.--In the Parish St. Scholastique 20 children have died from diphtheria lately, and there are 70 cases reported as now existing in the parish.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 4.--The Governor received the official report of the Warden of the Chester Penitentiary to-day showing that there were 689 convicts in the prison Nov. 1.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4.--During this season of navigation the arrivals of sea-going vessels at this port were 626, with a tonnage of 649,374. The arrivals last year were 660, with a tonnage of 664,263. The arrivals of inland vessels were 4,804 this year, against 5,477 last year.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 4.--Among the many harmless manias which have swept over this State roller skating may be counted as one that has more completely takes possession of its people than any other.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 4.--A delegation representing the Marion County Democratic Soldiers and Sailors' Veteran Association called on Vice-President-elect Hendricks this evening and tendered their congratulations on the result of the recent election.

The cornerstone of a new church edifice for St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, at Mamaroneck, Westchester County, was laid yesterday morning, with appropriate services, by Assistant Bishop Henry C. Potter, assisted by a number of clergymen from neighboring places.
LONDON, Dec. 4.--Mr. Wood, the sculptor, has completed the memorial statue of the Canadian patriot Brandt at his studio in Chelsea.
NEW-STRAITSVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 4.--The Minor's Central Relief Committee yesterday distributed among the destitute over $2,000 in cash and about $1,200 worth of merchandise.

Edward Farrell, the walking delegate of the Plumbers and Gasfitters' Labor Union, was before Justice O'Reilly, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning, to answer a charge of disorderly conduct made against him by Thomas Cochrane, a boss plumber, of No. 223 West Thirty-sixth-street.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 4.--At a meeting of this year's football team held to-day Tracy H. Harris, '86, was elected Captain of the team for the coming year. He has been one of the effective rushers of the Princeton team during the past two years, and will make a good Captain.

A deliberate murder was committed shortly before noon yesterday at No. 393 Bowery, when, for apparently trivial cause, Philip Lohges shot his brother-in-law, John Heston. Christian Scharfenberg and Gottlieb Schmalzricht were varnishing the inside of a tank at Fregenspan's brewery, on Freemanstreet, Newark, yesterday afternoon, when the gas from the varnish became ignited by the lights which they carried.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 4.--The report that the Eastern furnacemen contemplate a reduction of $1 per ton in order that they may compete with the Southern furnaces is causing much uneasiness among the Pittsburg iron men, who say that if the reduction is made they also will be compelled to make a reduction in order to hold their trade.

An important meeting of the Communal Council was held two or three days ago, when the Syndic gave a brief report of proceedings during the epidemic which is now passing away. One of the first duties he performed on the breaking out of cholera was the establishment of sanitary commissions for all the 12 quarters of the city.

The great scheme of the Manchester Ship Canal is to be brought before Parliament in the coming session for the third time. Its fate in two former sessions has curiously illustrated some of the chief defects of the management of local business in Parliament. The whole subject has been investigated four times.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 4.--About the time of the American Revolution Peter Tufts emigrated from England to Massachusetts and settled on the site of the present city of Malden, where he acquired by possession and purchase a large and valuable portion of the ground now covered by the city.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., Dec. 4.--The eight California Presidential Electors met yesterday and cast their ballots for Blaine and Logan. The Hon. Henry Egerton was chosen messenger to deliver the certificates in Washington. The Secretary of State announces the official vote of California as follows: Republican Electors, 102,416; Democratic Electors, 39,288.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--Capt. Charles M. Callahan, Fourth Cavalry, has been ordered before the Army Retiring Board in Arizona.

VIENNA, Dec. 4.--The Government has submitted to the Reichsrath bills to prolong for a year the suspension of trial by jury in Vienna, Kornenburg, and Wiener-Neustadt.

The only business of importance transacted at the weekly meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors yesterday had reference to the purchase of the new county farm. The Commissioners of Charities sent a communication to the board recommending the purchase of a tract of 924 acres on the north side of Long Island.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Dec. 4.--The loss of three schooners and all hands is announced from Rose Blanch, on the west coast. The vessels were coal laden, wound from Sydney to that port. No particulars have been ascertained. A fishing schooner and crew also sank. All these disasters occurred during the storm of Saturday night.

The hearing in the suit of David Stewart against C.P. Huntington and others was continued before Judge Van Vorst, in Supreme Court, Part I. yesterday. The testimony given, which was all in the form of depositions, was chiefly cumulative and corroborative of that of the two preceding days.

BOSTON, Dec. 4.--Judge Nelson, of the United States District Court, has rendered a decision on the petitions for limitations of liability in the cases brought against the Boston and Savannah Steamship Company for damages arising from the loss of the steamer City of Columbus.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Dec. 4.--This morning, while John Tully, Anthony Buckley, and George Bush were daring each other to go on the thin ice of Grow Pond, in this city, the ice broke and the three lads were drowned.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 4.--Again the Plenary Council held two sections to-day, only the higher orders of the clergy participating. The work is being rapidly completed, and there is said to be entire harmony among the members on all the subjects agreed upon. Two days more will finish the labors of the Council, and Sunday's session will close the largest and most important Catholic Council ever held in the United States.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 4.--Winter rac-- ing over the Louisiana Jockey Club course will commence on Jan. 20 and continue-for 35 days. The racing will be under the management of Leon, Mothe Co.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 4.--The new mill of Zug Co. closed last night until after the holidays. To-day the employes of the old mill were notified that work would be suspended this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--The striking weavers were in high spirits to-day, Thomas Taylor, at Howard-street and Lehigh-avenue, having agreed to take back his hands at the old prices--at 5 and 6 cents per yard.

CAMBRIDGE, Md., Dec. 4.--The house of Caleb Hurley, in the southwestern section of Dorchester County, was burned yesterday morning. In the ruins was found the body of Hurley, but no part of the head could be discovered, and there is a suspicion of foul play.

BERLIN, Dec. 4.--The subcommittee to which was referred by the General Congo Committee the questions relating to the proposed navigation laws for the Congo River have concluded their report, which will be presented to the General Committee to-morrow. The subcommittee is composed of delegates from England, France, Germany, Portugal, and Belgium.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 4.--Fire broke out this morning between 5 and 6 o'clock in what is known as the Chemung Hollow Ware Works, operated by a Detroit firm in the State Reformatory here.
