In response to a request made by many who are engaged during the week, the American Art Association has consented to open its galleries to the public on Sunday afternoon next between 1:30 and 6 o'clock. The admission fee will remain as usual--25 cents--but no charge will be made for illustrated catalogues, every visitor being entitled to one free.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 4.--Christian Naumann, a German, 63 years of age, committed suicide early this morning by hanging. He was a cabinet maker, and for six years was in the employ of Zwicker Bedlingmeyer, at No. 450 St. Clair-street.
Overtures are now being made by the elevated railroad companies for a settlement of the claims which the city has against them for unpaid taxes.

COAL BLUFF, Penn., Dec. 4.--Michael Boyle and John Sharpless, miners, were injured yesterday by a fire-damp explosion. Although terribly burned they will probably recover. The explosion was caused by the carelessness of the miners.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4, 1884. Mr. James, of New-York, introduced a bill in the House to-day limiting the appropriation for the new public building in Brooklyn to $1,500,000.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 4.--Alexander Maas., haling from New-York, was arrested here last night charged with passing a worthless check on a firm of this city. He is wanted at Shreveport for a similar offense.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--Alexander S. De Walowski, a music teacher, who was recently arrested on a charge preferred by his daughter of having criminally assaulted her, was found dead in his house, No. 940 New-York-avenue, this morning.

MADISON, Ind., Dec. 4.--Charles Coyle, of this city, was arrested in Louisville this morning for highway robbery, having decoyed, knocked down, and robbed a farmer of Brandenburg, Ky., named Thomas Northern. The amount stolen was over $300. Coyle is a young man and has nine brothers and two sisters here.

LONDON, Dec. 4.--Prince Bismarck, has acknowledged, through Sir Edward Malet, the British Minister to Germany, to Earl Granville, his reception of the note from England proposing plans for the settlement of the Egyptian debt.

PORTAGE, Wis., Dec. 4.--Mrs. Jonathan Whitney, of Port Hope, near this city, attempted last night to kill her husband with an axe. She then cut her own throat. Both are yet alive, but they cannot possibly recover. Domestic troubles are supposed to be at the bottom of the double tragedy.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 4.--The residence of Mrs. O.H. Waldo, on the west side, was robbed early this morning, the thieves effecting an entrance through a window. Mrs. Waldo was awakened by the flash of a dark lantern in her face, aad sprang from her bed.
SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 4.--Gen. Larkin Smith, a veteran of the Mexican war and a Confederate General, died here last night, aged 71. He was buried to-day with military honors.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 5.--Sehuylkill County is at present infested with a gang of tramps and professional robbers who are making nightly raids on business places throughout the region, especially in the farming districts.

The Ladies' Club for Out-door Sports, of New-Brighton, Staten Island, last evening gave a ball in the Pavilion Hotel at that place. The dining room of the hotel was tastefully decorated for the occasion.

ALBANY, Dec. 5.--Attorney-General O'Brien late this afternoon heard arguments of counsel in the quo warranto proceedings in the New-York Police Commissionership contest. Charles P. Miller appeared for the appellant Mason, and Elliott F. Shepard and Samuel Hand for McClave. The case was agreed on as to the facts, the question in dispute being simply one of law. The Attorney-General gave both sides 10 days in which to file briefs.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5.--At 11:30 o'clock to-night the grave of Sullivan, the executed murderer of Ella Watson, was opened by the Salem County officials, and it was found that the body had not been disturbed.

The Rev. Father Michael B. McEvoy, Rector of St. Raymond's Church, at West Chester, died last Tuesday from a complication of liver complaints. He was born in 1838, and was educated at St. John's College, Fordham.

A deaf family in New-Hampshire has been traced back to the fourteenth century in England, and in all that time has regularly shown a succession of deaf-mutes. In Maine there is a family in which there are 95 deaf mutes, all of them connected by blood or marriage.

The fight which has been going on for some time between the Trustees of the FleetStreet Methodist Episcopal Church, (colored,) and the Bishop who has charge of the district in which the church is situated has at length culminated in a lawsuit.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--There were no new features to-day in the war between the bucket shops and the Board of Trade. Many of the members of the board are in favor of having the quotations freely distributed, and claim that it creates business.

The members of the American Yacht Club, at a recent meeting, resolved to extend to all officers of the United States Navy in good standing an invitation to make free use of the club's elegant new rooms in Fifth-avenue, opposite the Windsor Hotel.

TORONTO, Dec. 5.--On Wednesday morning there arrived by the Great Western Railway from the Suspension Bridge a woman of fine stature, weighing about 200 pounds, and handsomely attired in a rich sealskin cloak and cape. A young man supposed to be her son accompanied her.
The funeral of Charles Lincoln, late manager of the annual exhibition of dogs by the Westminster Kennel Club, took place yesterday from Trinity Church.
"W.B.M."--Queen Victoria's family name is Guelph. "E.M.V."--Police Justice Murray fixed the amount of Mrs. Mandelbaum's bail.
MONTREAL, Dec. 4.--In the Parish St. Scholastique 20 children have died from diphtheria lately, and there are 70 cases reported as now existing in the parish.

The people of this city are fortunate in having a supply of wholesome water. The use of water that is contaminated by sewage causes disease. Contaminated water also spreads diseases that have been caused by other agencies.

MONTREAL, Dec. 5.--An action for $41,000 has been taken by the Exchange Bank against F.E. Gilman for an alleged overdrawn account. A large amount of this, it is claimed, was advanced for his transactions in the stock of the Royal Canadian Insurance Company.
A German committed suicide the other day, assigning as a reason that when a man loses his hair, and his teeth and eyes refuse duty, it is time for him to depart.

OWEN SOUND, Ontario, Dec. 5.--Cook Teets, the blind man convicted of murdering his wife by administering poison to her a year ago, was hanged here this morning. Since the sentence of the court a month ago he conducted himself with great composure.

Two tierces, containing 594 pounds of indigo, valued at $794, which had arrived by the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad, consigned to R.W. Brown, of No. 126 Pearl-street, were stolen from the pier of the Central Railroad of NewJersey at the foot of Liberty-street, North River, on the night of June 27.
John Purscht, an iron railing maker, committed suicide some time Thursday night at No. 437 West Thirty-second-street, and he was found dead in bed yesterday morning.

Promptly with the beginning of its session yesterday the Common Council took up and passed, over the Mayor's veto, the resolution granting to the Broadway Surface Railroad Company consent to construct a railroad in Broadway.
President Cleveland is expected to visit Chicago soon after his inauguration. A Louisiana negro man attempted to shoulder five bundles of cotton ties at once the other day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--Mr. J.H. Hilard, General Freight Agent of the Omaha Road, is in the city to-day in response to the wishes of the manager of the Missouri River roads, by whom he has been requested to accept the office of Referee created by the late agreement as to the passenger rates.

The building erecting for the American Bank Note Company, in Church-street, at the rear of Trinity, has for a month been made a lodging place by hundreds of tramps, who made themselves comfortable by surrounding smoldering fires used during the day by the workmen.

A pretty young Swedish woman wandered into the Yorkville Police Court yesterday. She wanted a sailor punished who had promised to marry her on the 30th of November and was in the city now, but had not even come to see her.
Norris Winslow, of Watertown, N.Y., is at the Gilsey House. Prof. O.C. Marsh, of Yale College, is at the Buckingham Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5.--Another move was made in the fight between the Pennsylvania and the Reading Companies to-day. The Junction Railroad is a short stretch of tracks in West Philadelphia, connecting the tracks of the Pennsylvania, the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore, and the Reading systems.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5.--Out of work, declaring that nothing could be added to the sufferings they have experienced for the past two weeks, 1,500 hatters of South Norwalk to-day gave almost full vent to the desperate feelings which have been animating them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--President Arthur has spent a part of to-day in earnest conference with his friends Gen. George H. Sharpe, Commissioner Stephen B. French, and Chairman James D. Warren, who are all here for the purpose of reaching some conclusion as to what ought to be done at Albany in January about electing a Senator to succeed Mr. Lapham.

Personal glimpses of Vandyck are so very rare and precious that exceptional interest attaches to the following story--remarkable, too, as an extraordinary example of oral tradition-- which we are assured has never before appeared in print.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 5.--Shortly after 9 o'clock this morning a check for $200 was presented at the banking house of Raymer, Seagrave Co., when the holder was informed that there were no funds on hand to pay it with.
BERLIN, Dec. 5.--The Congo subcommittee to-day considered the clauses of the act of navigation relating to neutrality on the Congo and Niger Rivers in the event of war.

The official report on the budget of fine arts was distributed yesterday among the members of the Chamber. It appears by it that the Opera since 1879 has been carried on with capital furnished by private investors. Since 1882 the receipts have failed to equal the expenditures.
LONDON, Dec. 5.--The Franchise bill was read a third time in the House of Lords this afternoon and was subsequently passed by that body.

The Citizens' West Side Improvement Association met last evening at Seventy-secondstreet and Ninth-avenue. About 20 property holders were present. Mr. W.H. Barker presided and Mr. W.G. Owens was Secretary.

CANTON, Miss., Dec. 5.--In the Stadeker case, after a trial lasting three days, the State utterly failed to make out a case against Alonzo and Henry Stadeker, who were arrested on a charge of conspiring to defraud the creditors of J. Stadeker Son, and they were honorably acquitted.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5.--Everything was quiet in the Hocking Valley to-day. The Nelsonville News, which has strongly upheld the miners in the past, now admits that the end of the strike in its every feature is near, and intimates that the time is short for those that desire work to obtain it, as the places are being rapidly filled up.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 5.--Since District Attorney Adams has dispensed with the services of the local police, and associated with him those able attorneys, ex-Judges Luzenberg and Whitaker, he has met with no difficulty in obtaining ample evidence to convict the assassins of Capt. Murphy.

Philip Lohges, the young man who on Thursday shot and killed his brother-in-law, John Heston, in the tailor's shop of the latter, on the ground floor of No. 393 Bowery, was arraigned before Justice O'Reilly, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning, for examination on the charge of murder.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 5.--The Hon. Ephraim K. Wilson, one of the Associate Justices of the First Judicial District of Maryland, has resigned his office, to take effect on the 31st inst. Mr. Wilson was elected by the last Legislature a United States Senator from the 4th of March next, and resigns to assume that position.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 5.--Fleischman Gaff's distillery and yeast manufactory, at Millstone, N.J., was destroyed by fire at 4 o'clock this morning. The building and machinery are a total loss.
Members of the Niagara Falls Park Commission met in the office of Andrew H. Green yesterday to discuss the form of a report of their labors, which is to be presented to the next Legislature.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5.--Considerable curiosity as to the outcome of an accident to the recently elected Mayor, George F. Holcomb, is shown here.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 5.--The Narragansett Park buildings and grounds were offered at auction at a mortgagee's sale this noon. The bidding started at $27,000, and the property was struck off to the committee representing the syndicate of members of the Narragansett Driving Association for $30,000. The syndicate numbers 74 members.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 5.--The Dominion Government have been making rigid inquiries in regard to the alarming influx of Chinese into the Province of British Columbia, and as a result it is shown that the greater part of those now arriving are destined for the United States.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5.--The December crop report of the Ohio State Board of Agriculture, based upon about 600 township returns from all the counties in the State, gives the following State averages: Area sown compared ...

While walking in a political procession on the night of Nov. 1. Jeremiah Lynch, a lad of 14 years, got into a fight with Lawrence Phoenix, a lad of 17, at the corner of Second-avenue and Forty-eighth-street.

Signor Nicolini's hoarseness prevented the performance of "Romeo e Giulietta" at the Academy of Music last evening, and "La Traviata" was represented in its stead. Considerable disappointment was felt at the non-appearance of Signor Nicolini, for tried and conscientious tenors are always scarce, and particularly so this season, but we are not sure that the sense of ...

A slender and poorly clad young German passed through the gates at the New-York end of the bridge about 7:30 o'clock last night and walked slowly toward Brooklyn. He carried a bulky bundle under his arm and attracted the attention of several persons by his odd appearance and actions.
DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 5.--President T.C. Abbot, of the State Agricultural College, has resigned, after 26 years' connection with that institution, 22 of which were as its head.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 5.--Shortly after 12 o'clock this morning John Fisher, a defeated candidate for the office of foreman of Jackson Fire Company, No.18, was stabbed to the heart by a member of the company named Augustus Labuzan.
Patrolman Martin Fay, of the Twentyninth Precinct, came into the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning, his head swathed in bloody bandages.

Mrs. Mary E. Paxton, formerly Miss Willard, who was married on Wednesday to a young patent lawyer, and who left her home without money or clothing, except what she wore, has returned to this city, but has not yet visited her mother.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 5.--AttorneyGeneral James McCartney, the defeated Republican candidate for Congress from the Sixteenth District, has filed a notice of a contest of Landes's seat.

Mr. James D. Warren did not return from his Washington trip last night, but he is expected to-day. It is supposed that he will be the bearer of important political news when he does arrive concerning the intentions of President Arthur.

Unlike the rehearsals preliminary to symphony and philharmonic concerts in general, Mr. Van der Stucken's entertainments make known so many new works that it is a matter of simple justice to composers and performers that judgment upon both should be withheld until a second ...

Horticultural Hall, in Twenty-eighthstreet, west of Broadway, was filled last evening with tables tastefully arranged and loaded with fancy articles. The occasion was a fair in aid of the Working Girls' Vacation Society.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 5.--The State Assembly of Congregational ministers at Bridgeport two weeks ago appointed a committee to wait upon the Railroad Commissioners of the State and secure, if possible, some action relative to the regulation of the running of railway trains on Sunday.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 5.--The following resolution was adopted to-day by the Alabama Senate:

In the trial of the suit of David Stewart against Collis P. Huntington, in Supreme Court, Part I., yesterday, the entire day was consumed in arguments of counsel on the motion made by Roscoe Conkling on Thursday to dismiss the suit without allowing it to go before a jury. The court room was again crowded.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 5.--A committee of the Police Board appointed to investigate charges of complicity in incendiarism made against Fire Company No. 2 reported to-night.
ALBANY, Dec. 5.--A decision was handed down by the Railroad Commission to-day which is of much importance, in that it will have a bearing on other roads in which like questions may arise.
Mr. W.H. Pratt's concert choir, formerly known as the Murray Hill Vocal Society, gave its first concert of the present season at Chickering Hall last evening.

The unidentified heap of bones found in the Carleton House cellar, which furnishes the most impenetrable local mystery of the day, was yesterday carried away from the Morgue in a plain pine coffin and buried in the paupers' field.

PRESCOTT, Arizona, Dec. 5.--Judge Howard to-day sentenced the convicted polygamists Ammon M. Tenny, Bishop P.J. Christofferson, and C.I. Kemp to each pay a fine of $500 and be imprisoned for three and a half years in the United States House of Correction at Detroit, Mich.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--The leave of absence granted Post Chaplain Benjamin L. Baldridge has been extended one month. Major Thomas H. Handbury, Corps of Engineers, will, in addition to his present duties, temporarily relieve Major William H.H. Benyaurd, Corps of Engineers, of the works under his charge.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 5.--W.S. Towner, general jobbing tobacconist, of this city, has made a general assignment to Earl B. Putnam. The failure is caused by the general assignment of the Assignor's father, H.W. Towner, of Waterville, N.Y., in whose business W.S. Towner was in some manner interested.
RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 5.--Last Spring, in Mitchell County, E.W. Ray and Charles Anderson killed three men while disputing for the possession of a mica mine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--The following letter, written by J.J. Barker, a former clerk in the office of the First Controller of the Treasury, and addressed to Representative Springer, was read by Mr. Springer to his Committee on Expenditures in the Department of Justice at its meeting to-day:

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 5.--The United States Grand Jury yesterday indicated the following persons for fraud in connection with the Otoe Indian land sales: The Hon. N.K. Griggs, late Consul to Chemnitz; Capt. W.H. Ashby, of Wymore, a newspaper man; ex-Register Parker, of the United States Land Office at Beatrice; Wheeler, the auctioneer, and Beemer, the storekeeper at the reservation. It is charged that by collusion the parties bought in the lands at a nominal figure.

The report of the Postmaster-General affords an interesting comparison with that of blind Mr. FAWCETT, recently deceased and deeply deplored in England. Under him the English Post Office was a singular exception to the hatred of novelty which is, or is libelously alleged to be, characteristic of Englishmen in general, and Englishmen in office in particular.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 5.--Senator Pendleton, whose seat will so soon be occupied by the Hon. H.B. Payne, may, as is reported, have an ambition to go into Cleveland's Cabinet, but if he succeeds it will be by force of his own personality and not by the cordial backing of any number of Ohio Democrats.

RIVERHEAD, Long Island, Dec. 5.--The excitement in this village over the elopement of Deacon Terry and Mrs. Clara Downs, wife of the Pastor of the Northville Congregational church, has not in the least abated. Mrs. Terry, the deserted wife, is prostrated by the treachery of her husband.

Immediately after the discovery by her that her husband, Harold C. De Wolfe, had left her and had entrapped Bebe Vining, the actress, into a marriage with him. Mrs. Mary Louise De Wolfe brought a suit in the Supreme Court for an absolute divorce from him.

OTTAWA, Dec. 5.--An accident happened on a mixed train on the Kingston and Pembroke Railway this evening, which, although not accompanied with fatal results, will long be remembered by the terrified passengers who miraculously escaped a horrible death.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--The rumor from Washington that when Frank Hatton ceases to edit the Post Office Department he will come West to edit the Chicago Times is denied at the Times office, where they think they ought to know something about it.
The annual meeting of the Twenty-second Regiment Veteran Corps last night at the armory brought out a full attendance, as it was expected that the new by-laws would be adopted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--When the Swaim court-martial convened this morning the JudgeAdvocate announced the decision of the court upon the question raised yesterday afternoon of the admissibility of testimony from Bateman as to a conversation had with him by his bookkeeper concerning one of Swaim's checks.

There was a little afterpiece at Harrigan and Hart's Theatre Thursday night in which a dog played a principal role and all the members of the "Investigation" cast took part. John G. Sparks plays the part of Lorenzo Hogan, the foreman of the famous candle factory.

Mrs. Julia Ward Howe met a party of ladies yesterday at No. 208 Fifth-avenue for the purpose of organization for representation from this State in the Woman's Department of the New-Orleans Exposition. Mrs. Howe has charge of this department.

The Mayor, Controller, and Corporation Counsel, to whom the Board of Estimate and Apportionment referred the statements as to the money they would need to escape the embarrassments of the operation of the constitutional amendment, yesterday made a report to the board.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 5.--The project to restrict the production of pig iron by banking the furnaces for a month or more has been allowed to die quietly. Instead of further restriction, reports have been received at the office of the Pig Iron Association, in this city, to the effect that a number of furnaces will "blow in" during next month.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--W.H. Miller, Secretary of the Kansas City Board of Trade, and H.M. Kirkpatrick, a prominent member of that institution, were among the visitors on 'Change to-day.
MONTREAL, Dec. 5.--President-elect Cleveland has declined the invitation to attend the Winter Carnival here owing to the pressure of business.
A dividend of 10 per cent. is now being paid to the depositors of the wrecked WallStreet National Bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5.--The annual report of the Secretary of the Navy was made public to-day. Secretary Chandler says that the dispatch steamer Dolphin has been launched. Her speed is 16 knots. A fracture of her shaft delays formal acceptance.
Bradstreet's reports 296 failures in the United States during the week, against 246 in the corresponding week of 1883. Additional comparisons are given in the following table:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Dec. 5.--The cotton crop report for the Memphis District, which embraces West Tennessee, North Arkansas, North Mississippi, and North Alabama, to be issued to-morrow by Messrs. Hill, Fontaine Co., will say: ...

SANTIAGO, Chili, via Galveston, Dec. 5.-- The first general meeting of shareholders of the lately established Santiago Bank was held here to-day. The shareholders are well satisfied with the reception accorded the bank by the public, and have decided to increase the capital to $500,000.

In trying conclusions with Mr. Chamberlain, I never wished for more than a fair field and no favor. He has recently indulged in some ancestral references. Would you, in your kindness, allow me, for a brief moment, to follow his example?
CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--Joseph Williams, colored, was found guilty of murder in the Criminal Court to-day and sentenced to imprisonment for life.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 5.--To-day was ended one of the most interesting murder trials ever held in this county, and one which has attracted hundreds possessed of morbid curiosity to the Court House.

Obstructions were encountered Thursday evening in a drill-hole--charged with dynamite--at a Weehawken brewery. Henry Ludlow, one of the drillers, tried the experiment of removing the obstruction by drilling a hole into the side of the rock.
HAVANA, Dec. 5.--The gunboat Caridad has captured off the coast of Manzanillo a boat containing 15 men, among them the Cuban bandits Bonachea, Varona, Peralta, and two estradas.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 3.--Matters athletic are agitating Harvard students just now as they never did before, for the warnings of the Faculty that great changes might be expected have proved true, and the students are threatened with the total abolition of one sport, and ...

Mr. James G. Blaine arrived here this afternoon about 4 o'clock on the limited express from New-York. As he stepped from the cars he was greeted by Mr. William Walter ...

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5.--The cap of a boiler at the Belmont Oil Works blew out this evening, and John Simpson, an employe, was scalded so badly that he died shortly afterward. Joseph Taylor and Hugh Gantz were also badly burned, but will recover.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 5.--There is understood to be a movement on foot to place John McCullough, the tragedian, in an asylum, so that his mind can receive proper treatment.
Competition for the highest public honors in this country has come to be largely a matter of purchase, if not with money then with political pledges.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 5.--The Hon. Alfred M. Scales, Governor-elect and member of the present Congress from the Fifth District, has sent to Gov. Jarvis his resignation as a Congressman, to take effect on the 30th of this month.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5.--The announcement of the determination of the Reading Company to hereafter mine and ship coal without regard to the New-York companies engaged in the same business has greatly pleased the friends of the company here.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 5.--On Wednesday last Mr. John Webber, a farmer living in Green County, went to Goldsborough and sold several bales of cotton. Night overtook him on his return home, and he was assaulted and robbed of his money, and was then dragged out of the road into the woods and left for dead. He was found, and stated that his assailants were negroes. He died the next day.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 5.--The steamer Newcastle City, which sailed hence today for London, took the largest single shipment of apples ever made at this port, comprising 50,000 barrels from Annapolis County.
The funeral services over the body of Francis D. Moulton took place at the family residence, No. 580 Lexington-avenue yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 5.--For the last 10 days the manufacturers operating the glass factories in Bellaire, Bridgeport, and Martin's Ferry, Ohio, opposite this city, have been in secret conference relative to the matter of wages.

ALBANY, Dec. 5.--The Governor has pardoned John Bowes, who was convicted in the county of Wyoming of arson in the first degree and sentenced on Sept. 13, 1879, to imprisonment in the Auburn Penitentiary for the term of his natural life.
ALBANY, Dec. 4.--The new system of convict employment termed the "State account system" is now demanding the closest attention of the Superintendent of State Prisons, Mr. Isaac Baker, Jr.
John Delaney and William Ford, two young men of Port Richmond, Staten Island, were deeply enamored of the same pretty young woman, Kate Karll.

"Tipping is practiced all the world over, always has been, and always will be," sagely remarked Herr Trenck, who was a waiter for 11 years at the Hoffman House, and at other hotels here and abroad for lesser periods, until he was able to establish a cafe of his own.
SUAKIN, Dec. 5.--Fifty mounted rebels to-day advanced to within 800 yards of the Egyptian forts, killing several men and women and capturing 42 camels.
The report of the Post Office Department for the year 1883 showed that during that period the receipts from all sources exceeded the expenditures in 17 States.
There are three ways of destroying the phylloxera, but, according to M. Balbiani, Professor of the College of France, not one of them can be relied upon as thoroughly efficacious.

TROY, N.Y., Dec. 5.--Nathan W. Buckmaster was arraigned in the Court of Oyer and Terminer this afternoon on two indictments charging him with defrauding a wholesale grocery firm here of $1,200. Buckmaster, who is a prominent citizen of Corinth, Saratoga County, ...

ST. PAUL, Dec. 5.--Important steps have been taken in relation to the future of the Northwestern Manufacturing and Car Company of Stillwater. The plan contemplates the complete reorganization of that corporation under a new name and the ultimate purchase of all its assets by the creditors.

Several of the stockholders of the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad Company have assessed themselves $10 each for the purpose of defraying the expenses of legal opposition to any attempts at foreclosure of the mortgage which covers the bonds.

Ex-Assemblyman J.J. Stillwell, whose mind was affected by an overdose of chloral which he took on Monday night to induce sleep, was found the following day aimlessly wandering about the farms in the vicinity of his home near Coney Island.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 5.--Last May George Jenne and William Ellis, of Tidioute, had a dispute in a cemetery over the possession of a log chain.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 5.--On yesterday morning the Court House and jail in the town of Williamston were discovered to be on fire. The town is entirely without water works, and both buildings were burned down.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5.--A favorite anchorage for New-York yachts cruising through Long Island Sound is the harbor off Stony Creek, in this State, made by a number of islands collectively known as "The Thimbles."

CHICAGO, Dec. 5.--The Federal Grand Jury to-day returned an indictment against B. T.O. Hubbard, and in default of bail he was committed to jail. Hubbard was Cashier of the First National Bank, of Monmouth, Ill., which failed last Spring for about $400,000. The charge is that he embezzled $270,000, which, it is said, he lost in speculation. He disappeared for a time, but was arrested at Waukegan, Ill., in September.

DOVER, N.H., Dec. 5.--The result of the Strafford dynamite explosion will be worse than was anticipated. Of the eight persons injured George L. Goodwin, aged 27, has already died.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 5.--On yesterday morning the Court House and jail in the town of Williamston were discovered to be on fire. The town is entirely without water works, and both buildings were burned down.

"William Tell" was repeated at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening, "Don Juan" not being in a sufficiently advanced state of preparation to warrant its production.
Two strangely conceived, but effectual, suicides have just been committed. One case was that of a young man whose great horror was the prospect of military service.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 5.--Leo Heller, a young ironworker, attempted to kill Miss Inn in the office of Justice of the Peace Dunning, but, being prevented by the latter, deliberately shot himself dead.

Blessings brighten as they take their flight. The Star Theatre was crowded last evening with a fashionable audience who witnessed, with keen interest and sympathy, a singularly smooth and artistic representation of Mr. Wills's poetic play.

PARIS, Dec. 5.--The Temps says that the French Government would hail with delight the Chinese attack upon Admiral Courbet's fleet, which, it is stated, has been ordered by China, and for which purpose 12 Chinese men-of-war are reported to have proceeded to Formosa, as it would break the monotony of the blockade.
DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 5.--The output at Lake Superior copper mines for November was as follows: Calumet, 2,043 tons; Quincy, 450; Franklin, 289; Atlantic, 180; Huron, 125, and Hancock, 37.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 5.--The report published to-day that M.L. Blanton, Receiving Freight Agent of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway, was short in his accounts is declared by the officials of the road to have been wholly unauthorized.

Advance sheets from the Controller's report give some interesting figures concerning the City Government.

CAIRO, Dec. 5.--Count de Lesseps and the commission have completed their examination of the Suez Canal at Ismaila and approved the plans for widening the waterway.

On the large paint frame at the Grand Opera House hangs the drop curtain which is to be the central decorative figure of the new Standard Theatre. Drop curtains usually cost about $500; this one, when finished, will be delivered to the owners for the neat sum of $2,500.

The Radical opposition to the Redistribution bill which is reported from London is founded on no principle. It is simply the result of a tardy discovery that the bill, or rather the scheme of which the bill is an integral part, will be apt to give the Conservative Party at least a temporary advantage in elections to the House of Commons.

Lucy Macklen, over whose head 40 cruel Winters have passed, was a prisoner in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, charged with begging. Officer Ciardi, who made the arrest, said the woman was in the habit of making her rounds in the Wall-street district and that she claimed to be a poetess.

INEKHBOLI, Western Anatolia, Oct. 15.-- The splendid weather which has accompanied us from Armenia is deserting us at last, and the persistent rain threatens to make our projected trip to Mount Olympus a duty rather than a pleasure.

Two brothers, Frank and Philip Colamer, aged 22 and 17, respectively, were prisoners at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning to answer charges of burglary.
The little village of Woodlawn was thrown into a whirl of excitement yesterday afternoon by the report that young Charles Disbrow, son of Mr. Joseph P. Disbrow, had shot himself through the head.

PALMYRA, N.Y., Dec. 6.--Never have the people of this village been in such a state of excitement as during the past few days. The excitement is due to the sudden and mysterious disappearance of Mrs. Thomas Farrell, a wealthy lady of Palmyra, from her home about two weeks ago.

LONDON, Nov. 22.--I have just returned from a flying visit to Northern Italy, hoping to be able to report a general recovery from the prostration of trade which had overtaken that unhappy country by the cholera plague.
A letter from Trieste has just been published on the subject of the influence of the Arlberg Railway on the trade or the Adriatic ports.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 6.--The Rev. Edward Brennan, age 65, Pastor of the Catholic Church at Cumberland, Md., was found dead in bed today at the residence of the Very Rev. E. McColgan, of St. Peter's Church, in this city. He was here on a visit and died of heart disease.

TORONTO, Dec. 6.--The wholesale buttons and dress trimmings house of Clinton E. Brush Brothers, No. 33 Front-street, West, is in trouble, and will very probably have to make a composition with its creditors.

RALEIGH, N.G., Dec. 6.--The extreme drought in this State, which commenced about July 1, was broken by a copious rain last night, which has continued incessantly all day. In many localities wells and springs have become dry, and the farmers have been unable to plow and plant wheat, oats, rye, and small grain. The rain has been general all over the State.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Dec. 6.--Walter Grunewald, Lee Stroud, and two other lads, whose ages range from 12 to 15 years, went gunning Oct. 12 on Harvey's Canal. One of their guns was accidentally discharged in the direction of a party of men also gunning on the canal.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6.--A handsome Philadelphia widow, with a fortune of $500,000, her marriage to an adventurer who already had one wife living, the bigamist's successful plot to get $10,000 from the wealthy widow his flight, and the annulment of the second marriage, are the elements of a rare romance which culminated in this city yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6.--J.H. Hilard, General Freight Agent of the Omaha Road, left this city for St. Paul yesterday still undecided whether or not to accept the position as Referee offered him by the managers of the roads engaged in the late passenger war.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 6.--At Margarettesville, yesterday, in Northampton County, there was horse racing and betting. A quarrel about the race ensued between a man whose name is unknown and Millard Peebles, both white men, and a fight took place. Peebles had a knife plunged into his brain and died in a few minutes. TORONTO, Dec. 6.--The outbreak of smallpox in Hungerford, in Hastings County, is of much greater magnitude than was at first supposed. MADRID, Dec. 7.--The text of the new commercial treaty between the United States and Spain is made public here. It was signed on Nov. 18 last by Mr. John W. Foster, the American Minister, and Seuor Don Salvador de Albacete y Albert, formerly the Foreign Minister of Spain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7.--The Sunday Herald says: "For several months past there has been considerable friction between Lieut. William M. Wood, in command of the Fish Hawk, and Major T.B. Ferguson, of the Fish Commission, and specific charges against the latter have been filed by Lieut. Wood at the Navy Department. The nature of these charges has not been made public, but the Herald's article foreshadows an investigation."

The Star published a statement yesterday that appears to come from Mr. Milliken, of Maine. Mr. Milliken is a friend of Mr. Blaine, but if he made the statement attributed to him it is plain that he ought to have taken advice before he rushed into print.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7.--Donald Harrold, a member of the company that has been playing "Dreams" at Haverly's Theatre, was found dead beside the railroad track this afternoon. LONDON, Dec. 8.--The Berlin correspondent of the Daily News says he has good authority for stating that England's convention with the African International Association will be ratified within a few days. Mr. Henry M. Stanley's visit to London had reference to this subject.

CAIRO, Dec. 8.--It is reported at Dongola that the Mahdi has accepted the challenge to his prophetic powers proposed by Gen. Gordon. It is asserted that he tried to make his followers walk across the Nile and thereby lost 3,000 men.
Among the nominations sent in to-day by the President was that of Mr. Robert F. Crowell, of Minnesota, to be Auditor of the Treasury for the Post Office Department.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 8.--In the Court of Oyer and Terminer to-day, Judge Daniels presiding, the trial of Peter Louis Otto for the murder of his wife, Susan, at their home on Broadway, Nov. 14, was begun.
George B. Skinner Co.'s silk mills, at Yonkers, were quiet yesterday, the firm having been forced to suspend, owing to the general depression in business.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 8.--A dispatch from Hamden, Delaware County, states that a large number of milch cows have died during the past few weeks in that town of a disease the symptoms of which are the drying up of their milk and dysentery. Cattle afflicted with the disease die in one or two days after its appearance. The Town Clerk has notified the State Board of Health.

The Seventh Ward Republican Association of Brooklyn held a long and lively meeting last evening. The engrossing subject, and the only one discussed, was the question whether the mugwumps in the association should be expelled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8.--In the trial of Gen. Swaim to-day the objection made on Friday by the defense to the reception of Mr. Bateman's testimony in regard to the circumstances attending the making of the five-thousand-dollar due bill was considered, and argument was made at length upon the subject. At the conclusion of the argument the court went into secret session, and when the doors were reopened the motion was overruled.

THE TIMES has rendered the public a service by bringing the text of the new commercial treaty with Spain as a special cablegram from Madrid. Simultaneously with its publication Minister Foster has come home to render such assistance as he may in securing its ratification by Congress. We have abstained from comment upon this important negotiation, in order to have the document itself before us.

BOSTON, Dec. 9.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New-York and NewEngland Railroad to-day was, as was expected, largely attended, and the ballot for Directors was preceded by a most animated discussion, in which the opposition to the present arrangement freely expressed itself and Receiver Clark and others in accord with his management as freely answered their critics.

MAHANOY CITY, Penn., Dec. 9.--A small mining village known as Trenton, or Park Place, situated four miles from Mahanoy City, was the scene of a big fire at 4 o'clock this morning, by which a block of houses was destroyed, and six persons were burned to death.
SCHENEVUS, N.Y., Dec. 9.--Great excitement was occasioned in this village this morning by the action of Peter H. Mitchell Co., bankers, in closing their doors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--Copies of the correspondence on file in the Department of Justice relative to the employment of United States Deputy Marshals at the Congressional election in Ohio last October have been sent by the Attorney-General to the House Committee on Expenditures in the Department of Justice, of which the Hon. William M. Springer is Chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9.--Thomas P. Macauley, who has been for a number of years a trusted clerk in the office of the Fidelity Trust and Safe Deposit Company, was arraigned at the Central Police Station this morning charged with stealing 10 consolidated mortgage bonds of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, valued at $12,000.
LONDON, Dec. 9.--The Prince of Wales will not ask Parliament for an allowance for his oldest son, Prince Albert Victor, until the young man is married.
BINGHAMTON, Dec. 9.--William Menken, the murderer of Kate Broedhoeft, his sweetheart, stood at the bar of justice at noon to-day, and received his death sentence for the second time.

Miss Mary G. Caldwell, of this city, has offered to the Roman Catholic church of this country $300,000 to be used in founding a Catholic university similar in its scope and work to the Catholic universities abroad.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 9.--Charles Coleman, who is under arrest here charged with the robbery of the East St. Louis Treasury, says he is a brother to Coleman, the pitcher of the Athletic Baseball Club.

When the suit of David Stewart against Collis P. Huntington came up yesterday in the Supreme Court, Juror Schellenger, who had been ill on the previous day, announced that he was again robust and able to endure the fatigue of the trial.

TROY, Dec. 9.--It has just been discovered that on Thanksgiving Day two very young couples, whose parents reside in Lansingburg, went to Melrose and were married. A young lad named McKnight married a girl named Collins, and a boy named Boskey married a pretty child named Brayton. None of the contracting partirs are yet 18 years old, and the youngest is the McKnight boy, who is hardly 16.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Dec. 9.--"Mother" Mandelbaum was not brought up at the police court to-day for examination. Her case will come up to-morrow. The United States Government will send a man from New-York to watch the case. Mrs. Mandelbaum is charged on the police books with vagrancy.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 9.--Rufus J. Childress, a local poet of some fame, was ajudged insane to-day. Childress has written a large number of widely copied humorous and pathetic poems for the Courier-Journal, and his insanity seems not to have affected his poetic faculty in the least, as he continues to write. Disappointment of a political nature in the recent municipal election caused his insanity.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Dec. 9.--A wrestling match for $600 and the mixed wrestling championship of the world, between Duncan C. Ross and Tom Cannon, took place last night at the California Theatre.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9.--Justice Jette to-day gave judgment in the case of Mrs. Lyman, ordering that she be at once liberated from the Longue Pointe Lunatic Asylum and given into the charge of Alfred Perry.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 9.--Less than 12 months ago Mrs. Hugh Blair, of this county, gave birth to three children, all of which are living and in good health. Saturday evening the same lady gave birth to two boys and a girl, making six children born to the lady in less than a year.

HARTFORD, Dec. 9.--Under a statute passed in 1874 the Connecticut House of Representatives must be called to order at the opening of its first session by the Speaker of the preceding House, who must administer the oath to members; in his absence these duties devolve upon "the member present who is the senior member of any previous House of Representatives."

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 9.--In the Legislature to-day Wade Hampton was elected United States Senator as his own successor, receiving the entire vote of both houses, with the exception of three votes for Smalls, cast by colored Representatives from Beaufort County, and two for Whipper, cast by colored Senators from Beaufort and Berkely Counties.

Members of the County Democracy were very confident last night that the name of any man who may be sent in to the Aldermen as the successor of their chief, Commissioner of Public Works Hubert O. Thompson, to-day would not be confirmed.

BERLIN, Dec. 9.--The Committee of the Congo Conference has accepted England's proposals regarding the Niger without reservation, but subject to the sanction of the conference itself. This sanction is regarded as certain to be given. England's position on the Niger is left altogether unchanged.

The new buildings of the Union Theological Seminary, at Fourth-avenue and Sixtyninth-street, were dedicated yesterday. In the morning the Rev. Dr. Roswell D. Hitchcock made an address, tracing the history of the Seminary through its early experiences.

BOSTON, Dec. 9.--The city election passed off very quietly to-day. The city voted by Aldermanic districts for the first time.

MADISON, Ind., Dec. 9.--James Divine shot "Lafe" Gammons dead in a quarrel at Bedford, Ky., 10 miles south of this city, last night, and was arrested to-day. Divine had been previously severely stabbed by Gammons's father.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 9.--Pierre Prefaux, an old blind beggar, who for years has been a familiar figure on the streets of this city, died a few days ago while on his way to the hospital. Investigation into his affairs disclosed the fact that he had on deposit in the Dollar Savings Bank at the time of his death over $5,000. He died intestate and left no clue to his heirs.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 9.--A reception to the delegates to the Centennial Conference of Methodism, which will begin to-morrow, was held tonight at the First Methodist Episcopal Church, Mr. Germon H. Hunt presiding.

The Ladies' Union of Grace Church Harlem, will hold a fair in the Sunday School room of the church, in One Hundred and Sixteenth-street, near Third-avenue, on every afternoon and evening of this week, except Saturday. PARIS, Dec. 9.--It is announced that for political reasons the Government has telegraphed to Admiral Courbet and Gen. Briere de l'Isle to maintain a defensive attitude until they receive further orders.

The Dietz will contest engaged the attention of Judge McCarter and the other Judges of the Orphans' Court, at Newark, yesterday. When James M. Dietz died at his home, in Orange, he left an estate valued at $200,000. Two wills have been offered for probate.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 9.--Dr. William M. Hudson, of Hartford, will write the report of the Fish Commissioners to be submitted to the Legislature in January. The catch of shad in the State this year was less than usual, the falling off being mainly in the Connecticut River.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., Dec. 9.--A cave-in occurred on the line of Shenandoah branch of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad near William Penn, just after the 7:20 train passed this morning. A new road will have to be surveyed and built around the break. The ground in that neighborhood has shown signs of caving in for several days.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 9.--Senator Grady, Chairman of the Standard Oil Investigating Committee, to-day presented to the Governor the report of the committee agreed upon at the meeting in Philadelphia last Friday and signed by all the members.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 9.--In the Court of Sessions yesterday, Frederick Rose, a railroad engineer, who recently tried to kill his sweetheart after she had married another man and then shot himself in the shoulder and temple, was sentenced to eight years in the Auburn Prison.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 10.--Just as the congregation of the Berkley Baptist Church was about to begin worship to-night the building caught fire, and was burned to the ground in spite of all efforts to save it. The congregation did not worship. The loss is about $4,000; partial insurance. The cause of the fire was a defective flue.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., Dec. 10.--No murder occurring within the last 10 years has caused so much excitement among the people of Georgia as that of Mrs. Ella Beck and her sister, Miss Addie, the husband and brother-in-law being the criminal.

Judge Ingraham, holding Superior Court, Chambers, has denied the motion, made on behalf of Commodore Garrison, for the removal of Prof. Theodore W. Dwight from the post of Referee in the trial of the suit of Peter Marie and others against the Commodore.

The reciprocal commercial treaty between the United States and the Hawaiian Islands, which was ratified in 1876, has been renewed, so far as the consent and approval of diplomatic representatives of the two Governments can renew it, for a period of seven years from the date of its second ratification.
ALBANY, Dec. 10.--It is beginning to be believed that President Arthur will, notwithstanding the protests of his friends to the contrary, be a candidate for the United States Senatorship.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Dec. 10.--Maria Gregor was arrested here to-day, charged with bigamy. She married T.C. Edwards, a minor, in this city on Nov. 6, being at that time the wife of William H. Gregor, of Toronto. The certificates of both marriages were put in evidence, and the woman was committed for trial.

Mayor Edson told Alderman O'Neil, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, that he would send to the Common Council when it met nominations of successors to Commissioner Thompson and Corporation Counsel Lacombe.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10.--The securities forming the greater part of the assets of Ladner Brothers, the bankrupt bankers and brokers, who are accused of swindling a great many of their depositors and customers, were sold to-day at public sale in the auction rooms of Thomas Sons by William F. Harrity, the Assignee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10.--Prince Alexis Saigo, of Japan, who has been a member of the household of Baron de Struve, the Russian Minister in Washington, for several years, died this morning from an attack of typhoid fever.

Col. Charles B. Morton, ex-Assistant Postmaster of Brooklyn, who mysterously disappeared from that city about six months ago, returned yesterday morning quite as mysterously. BOSTON, Dec. 10.--A mass meeting of Harvard students was held in Cambridge tonight to see if by any means the game of football could be retained at Harvard.

"Don Juan" was represented at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The production of Mozart's opera enlisted the services of most of the prominent artists of the company, and it introduced, besides, a songstress who had not previously been heard, Fraulein Bely, who sang Zerlina.

RACINE, Wis., Dec. 10.--It is stated this evening that Assignee Lee will make his report on the condition of the affairs of the J.I. Case Plow Company either next Saturday or Monday. LAWRENCE, Mass., Dec. 10.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Boston and Maine Railroad was held to-day.
LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 10.--In the Quarter Sessions Court this morning Lewis Parker and Charles Thomas, colored, charged with the murder of John Dixon, of Salisbury township, were called for trial.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10.--Mrs. Ida Froelich, of No. 404 North Ashland-avenue, to-day received the welcome news that her claim for a pension on behalf of her husband had been allowed and that she would receive $10,000 back pension and $72 a month hereafter.

The fact that a protective association of holders of American stocks and bonds was being formed in England was cabled from London a short time ago. The full plan of the proposed organization has just been received here, and has attracted much interest in Wall-street.

The agreement to restore and maintain passenger rates east bound from Chicago has fallen through. It only needed the signatures of the General Managers of the roads, the General Passenger Agents having agreed upon all points.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9.--When in Raleigh, N.C., about a fortnight ago, your correspondent had opportunity, although a very brief one, to notice some changes that had taken place since his last visit to the city, three years before.
POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 10.--The ruins of the fire at Trenton continue to attract large crowds of people, who come from the surrounding towns and discuss the terrible fate of the Barlow family.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 10.--An injunction to-day was served at Rochester upon William H. Gillette, granted by Supreme Court Judge Vann, of Syracuse, restraining him from giving further performances of "The Secretary."
Some of the friends of Mr. John McCullough, the tragedian, have been suggesting to his wife, who lives in Philadelphia, the advisa bility of placing him immediately in some retreat for the insane.

PARIS, Dec. 10.--The court yesterday waived the rule which would have required Mme. Clovis-Hugues to be brought into the presence of the corpse of her victim.

Congressman Richard Crowley, of Niagara County, who has been practicing law in Buffalo during the last two years, was in this city yesterday, arranging for the removal of his office to New-York. He intends to establish himself here permanently.
NYACK, Dec. 10.--The Missionary Board of the Rudson River Central Baptist Association met in the Baptist Church of this place yesterday afternoon.

Chief Drummond, of the United States Secret Service, aided by two of his men, four United States Marshals, and three police officers, late last night arrested five notorious counterfeiters and seized a lot of bogus coin and the necessary implements for manufacturing it.

The ladies who have charge of the arrangements for the matinee at Delmonico's on Saturday afternoon next, for the benefit of the New-York Orthopedic Dispensary and Hospital, anticipate a large attendance and promise an exceedingly enjoyable time.

SCHENEVUS, N.Y., Dec. 10.--The excitement over the failure of Peter H. Mitchell Co. is still great. Further facts developed to-day are that the management of the bank was intrusted to Timothy Parsons, one of the firm, and his son Addison, aged 20.
A noisy young man recently slammed the door in the business office of L.F. Robertson Son's leather store, No. 39 Spruce-street, and shouted out that he was looking for Mr. Robertson.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Dec. 10.--Twentythree years ago Ambrose Sterling, a Scotchman, occupied a position in one of the village mills. His family consistad of a wife and a daughter, 20 years of age, who was noted for her beauty.

BERLIN, Dec. 10.--The Congo Committee to-day discussed the question of free navigation of the Niger River. Mr. Kasson, American delegate, presented a neutrality project, which has a much wider scope than any other proposals that have yet been made.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 10.--A board of trade is to be organized at Gloversville for the protection of the glove manufacturers, who have met with heavy losses of late from the overbuying of customers.

LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 10.--The third cremation in the Lancaster Crematory took place this afternoon, the body of Washington E. Schmid, who died at the residence of his father, Peter Schmid, of No. 226 Clinton-avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y., being incinerated.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Dec. 10.--Last Summer Leander Ladd bored an artesian well on his farm, four miles from this village. At the depth of 66 feet the drill passed through a brittle black deposit 8 feet thick.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10.--Judge Allison to-day granted the motion for a new trial for the seaman, James Sullivan, recently convicted of the murder of John Tomney, a saloon keeper, who, Sullivan claimed, took about $600 from him for safe keeping, and refused to return it, and denied that he ever had it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10.--Monday afternoon A. W. Simpson, living in Jefferson, while walking on the track of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad near Fortieth-street, found a heavy iron rod used for bracing puposes on passenger coaches placed upright in a cattle guard.
CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 10, via Galveston. --The first acts of the Diaz administration are giving general satisfaction.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Dec. 10.--The Mandelbaum case was adjourned in the Police Court this morning because the lawyer from NewYork who was to aid in the prosecution had not arrived. The case came up again this afternoon.

At the fifty-eighth annual meeting of the City Mission and Tract Society yesterday Secretary Jackson reported that $46,325.15 had been received during the year for regular work, of which $43,692.62 had been paid out for the support of churches and missionaries.
The second of the matinees of orchestral music given at the Brooklyn Academy, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Society, took place yesterday afternoon.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 10.--A.B. Wilson, the inventor of the Wheeler Wilson sewing machine, was to-day taken to the Hartford Insane Retreat. A stroke of paralysis broke him down physically and mentally a year or two ago.

NEW-ALBANY, Ind., Dec. 6.--On Wednesday afternoon Mrs. Barney McManus, of this city, sent her little son Clarence, a bright lad of 10 years, out upon an errand, telling him to return home immediately after performing what he was sent to do.

The interview of the Mayor yesterday with the representatives of the County Democracy was a notable meeting. It was notable for the stolid frankness with which the Mayor avowed the theory, which he had before only put in practice, that public office is a personal perquisite.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 10.--The savage end of one of the Kentucky mountain feuds came at Farmer's Station, Rowan County, when a mob of armed men entered a railroad car in which John Martin was being conveyed to the county seat for examination on the charge of murder and riddled him with bullets.

UNION, S.C., Dec. 10.--While a negro and his wife were working in an adjoining field one day last week their house was burned, and their twin children lost their lives. They had been locked in the house by their careless parents. Soon afterward, in the neighboring county of Chester, a 6-year-old colored child was burned to death in a house where the mother locked it while she went to church.
HAVANA, Dec. 10.--It is reported that if the proposed Spanish-American commercial treaty becomes a law a line of steamers will be established between New-York and Sagua la Grande.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Dec. 10.--A fire was discovered in the hold of the steamship City of Augusta, which was to have sailed for New-York to-day, and was not extinguished until the steamer had been filled with water. About 1,000 bales of cotton are either partly burned or damaged by water. The loss to the cargo will be between $30,000 and $40,000. The vessel is only slightly damaged.
Mlle. Marie Aimee will make her first appearance in New-York in English comedy at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre next Monday evening, acting in Messrs. Jessop and Gill's "Mam'zelle."

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 10.--Dispatches received this evening from Missouia, Montana, state that news has just been received from Golden City, British Columbia, that a commercial traveler named Baird has been killed and robbed of $4,500 near that place. A large number of citizens are in close pursuit of the murderers. Eddy, Hammond Co., for whom Baird was traveling, offer a reward of $1,000 for the capture of the murderers.

NEWBERRY, S.C., Dec. 10.--Mr. W.T. Wright died at his home in this place the last of November. He had always enjoyed good health up to a few months ago, when he went to Atlanta, Ga., to have a throat affection examined.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Dec. 11.--The Commission appointed to inquire into the troubles between the Indians and Bishop Ridley, at Mellakahtla, British Columbia, have returned to Victoria in the warship Satellite, after taking evidence. The syndicate of capitalists which was organized to subscribe to the new Louisville and Nashville loan has been dissolved, inasmuch as the subscriptions by the stockholders of the company made the new scheme a success. WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 12.--Judge Jackson, of Parkersburg, has decided a somewhat famous case that has been in the courts for many years. In 1865 Ezekiel Harker, of Wellsburg, Brooke County, died, leaving an estate of $25,000 in landed property to his wife.

The woolen trade was taken by surprise yesterday by the announcement of the assignment of the great jobbing house of H.J. Goodwin Co. The firm has done a very large business ever since its formation three years ago, but has been pulled down by the continual shrinkage in the value of its stock.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 12.--Frank Detter, 19 years of age, was run over by a train of cars at the Forest-street crossing of the Nickel Plate Railroad and cut to pieces. It was at first thought to be an accident, but it is now believed that Detter deliberately threw himself under the wheels of the engine.

The Police Commissioners at their meeting yesterday resolved to abolish the steamboat squad in its present shape, and they established in its stead a new precinct, which has been designated as the Third Precinct.

DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 12.--David Myers, clothier, who failed this week, committed suicide on Wednesday night by shooting himself through the head. In falling the pistol went off again, sending a bullet through his abdomen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--On Friday evening of next week Mr. Lawrence Barrett will present at Albaugh's opera House, in this city, for the first time in America, Mr. Robert Browning's drama in blank verse entitled "The Blot on the 'Scutcheon."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12.--When the Swaim court-martial convened this morning Mr. Robert T. Lincoln, Secretary of War, appeared as a witness for the prosecution. His direct examination was confined simply to the inquiry whether he had received any report or communication from Gen. Swaim, prior to April 18, 1884, relative to the pay accounts of Col. Morrow.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Dec. 12.--A larger number of seizures were entered to-day against the insolvent firm of Tiffin Brothers. The total liabilities of the firm will exceed $200,000, the amount due the British Bank along being $198,000, of which $137,000 is on prime business paper.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12, 1884. Gen. Sheridan has accepted the position of Marshal of the Day for the celebration of the completion of the Washington Monument on Feb. 21 next. All religious, charitable, civic, or military organizations wishing to take part in the procession should report to Gen. Sheridan, who will give them such information as may be desired and assign them positions in line.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 12.--The Rev. J. W. Rosebro, one of the most prominent ministers in the Southern Presbyterian Church, has accepted a pastoral call to the Tabb-Street Presbyterian Church, of this city, to succeed the Rev. Robert P. Kerr, who some months ago accepted a call to the First Presbyterian Church at Richmond. Mr. Rosebro is now Pastor of the Presbyterian Church at Lewisburg, West Va.

Winch, tenor; E.A. Stoddard, baritone, and a chorus of 650 voices. "The Crusaders" and "Fair Ellen" were rendered in excellent style before a large audience.

Zinn, of New-York, who had pleaded guilty to receiving two one-hundred-dollar fees for the procuring of two pensions, whereas the law allowed but a ten-dollar fee in each case, was sentenced to-day by Judge Butler, in the United States District Court, to pay a line of $225 and the costs of prosecution.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 12.--Henry Walker, the mate of the schooner Julia Baker, on trial in the United States District Court here for stealing and selling the schooner's cargo, was to-day sentenced to six years' imprisonment in the Albany (N.Y.) Penitentiary.

LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 12.--Lizzie Balbach, of West Hempfield Township, while assisting her parents in hog butchering, stood too near a roaring fire, and her dress ignited. VIENNA, Dec. 12.--The National Bank will not press its claims against the Bohemian Mortgage Company, which suspended yesterday owing to the great depression in the sugar trade.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 12.--The case of Aubrey Bennett Co., of New-York City, against E.P. Covington, of Wilmington, N.C., has just been concluded in the United States Circuit Court after an eight days' trial.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 12.--Jones Laughlin, iron manufacturers, who have been drilling for gas at their works in Ormsby, tonight struck a vein equal to that of the great "Westinghouse Roarer."

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Dec. 12.--George Cook was hanged at Laramie City, Wyoming, to-day for the murder of his brother-in-law, Henry Blount, one year ago. He maintained to the last that he had been too drunk to know he was committing murder. His neck was broken by the fall.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 13.--A singular accident, which may prove fatal, happened near Goldsborough yesterday. Walter Sugg, 13 years old, was loading the cylinder of a five-shooter with cartridges. OTTAWA, Dec. 13.--From Jan. 1, to Nov. 30 the total number of immigrants arriving in Canada was 144,842, against 172,979 for the corresponding period last year. Of those who arrived this year 84,198 intended to settle in Canada, while the others were in transit for the United States. During the same period last year there arrived 103,767 immigrant settlers for Canada.

VICKSBURG, Miss., Dec. 14.--Deputy Sheriff Brown passed through this city to-day, from Morehouse Parish, La., on his way to Baton Rouge, having in charge Harry Fairchild, who will be placed in the Baton Rouge Penitentiary to serve a term of two years and a half for horse stealing. Fairchild is highly educated and is a native of New-York City, where his people are considered highly respectable.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 15.--Judge Henry Kent McKay was taken to Baltimore to-night for private treatment. He made a scene at the car shed by resisting an effort to put him on the car, accusing those present of wanting to spirit him away and kill him. He was carried in, however, and said as he was placed in the seat: "My blood be upon your heads."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15.--Henry J. Wilmot, the callow Fair Haven youth who has figured in the abduction of Delia Tucker, the 16-year-old schoolgirl, complained at Police Headquarters this morning that Delia's two brothers had assaulted him on North Quinnipiac-street.

BRANFORD, Conn., Dec. 15.--Dr. W.H. Zink, who was recently conspicuous as the victim of a mysterious assault, has so far recovered as to be able to ride out into the country daily. He has just escaped another serious accident. The kingbolt of his carriage broke and his horse ran off furiously. The carriage struck a post near the railroad bridge, breaking it off, and the doctor was thrown against a tree and severely bruised.

TORONTO, Ontario, Dec. 15.--The Board of Trade Examiners to-day waited on the Hon. John Co. tigan, Minister of Inland Revenue, in regard to the proposed amendments in the law relative to the grading of wheat.

CANTON, Miss., Dec. 15.--The annual field trials of the Southern Sportsmen's Association were begun here to-day. The Derby Stake was the first contended for, the winner of the first prize to get $200, of the second $100, and of the third $50. There were 11 entries.
American Institute Hall, in Third-avenue, was opened last evening as a skating rink, under the auspices of the Knickerbocker Roller Skating Club, and 3,000 young people were present for the occasion.
TRENTON, Dec. 15.--The State Board of Assessors met to-day to receive protests from their assessment of railroad values throughout the State, and they were overwhelmed by the multitude of them.
In the Kings County Count of Sessions yesterday two men, indicated last Summer for selling pools at Coney Island, were placed on trial before Judge Moore and a jury.

In France there are anomalies which am unable to understand. For instance, no store is set upon "la vertu de la femme." If we have Mosaic ideas on this subject, the French, and indeed, all Catholic countries save Ireland, have pagan notions. Yet there is no people who make so much ado about it as the French.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15, 1884. Senator Logan presented a large number of petitions from tobacco and cigar manufacturers and labor organizations of Illinois New-York and other State, protesting against the ratification of the Spanish treaty.

CLINTON, Iowa, Dec. 15.--For several days past testimony has been taken here before Commissioner W.B. Estabrook, by the contestants in the celebrated McGraw-Fiske will contest, in which the husband and heirs-at-law of Jennie McGraw-Fiske, late of Ithaca, N.Y., contest a legacy of about $2,000,000 to Cornell University.

Unless the Senate objects to the action of the House of Representatives to-day, Mr. Cleveland will have eight Cabinet places to fill instead of seven, the addition being in the shape of a Secretary of Agriculture.

The streets bounding Washington Market are being cleared of the unsightly booths that have disfigured them, and the dealers are getting into their places in the new market as fast as they can.

Means or getting more aid for the hospitals were discussed and planned at St. Luke's Hospital, Fifth-avenue and Fifty-fourth-street, where the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association hold a stated meeting last evening. Appeals will be made, as usual, to all the churches and synagogues, but especially to those which gave no aid last year.
UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Melvin Taylor, aged 17, son of a well-to-do farmer of Lenox Furnace, Madison County, accidentally shot and killed himself this morning.

Representatives from various Roman Catholic organizations met at the Hotel Brunswick last night to arrange for the removal of the remains of the late Rev. Dr. D.W. Cabill from Holywood Cemetery, Boston, ...
"No, Sir," emphatically remarked Secretary McCulloch, of the Board of Aqueduct Commissioners, to a TIMES reporter, yesterday, who had asked for the estimates of the engineer on the contracts awarded.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 15.--At Stacyville Plantation last evening, Michael Welch followed Charles H. Nealey to the latter's home, when an altercation ensued, and Nealey to protect himself and family shot Welch and instantly killed him. Nealey has given himself up.
Mrs. Ellen Peck, the well-known confidence woman, was up for examination in the Tombs Police Court yesterday, on the charge of obtaining money under false pretenses.

The Coney Island Jockey Club has just issued its entry book for the racing season of 1885 at Sheepshead Bay. The June meeting will include 10 days of racing, the opening being on Thursday, June 11, and the closing events on Wednesday, July 1.

Last evening's representation of "Faust" at the Academy of Music does not call for extended comment, but its promise was sufficiently flattering to bring together an audience that filler the house to overflowing, and its merits were so marked as to keep the spectators in their seats until the late hour at which the performance terminated.
LANCASTER, Penn., Dec. 15.--Joseph Herzog, a grocer of this city, failed to-day in consequence of an execution for $14,000 issued by Dana Graham. The liabilities are $30,000; assets, $15,000.

Civil Justice McCarthy was in this city to-day and engaged rooms at Willard's Hotel for the Thomas Jefferson Association of New-York, which will come to the inauguration of Cleveland with Gilmore's Band, and expects to fill 100 rooms to overflowing.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15.--Jay Gould's steam yacht Atalanta, which has been undergoing repairs at Cramp's ship yard, has been ordered to New-York this week. A seven thousand-dollar steam launch has been added to the Atalanta's outfit. In February her owner and a number of his friends will sail from New-York for New-Orleans.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 15.--A report that Alexander Mitchell and Dr. Davies, of the University of Wisconsin, had recently been in consultation respecting the rebuilding of Science Hall, at Madison, was verified by Mr. Mitchell this morning.

Mr. Curtin to-day introduced a joint resolution providing for an official representative of the United States in the American Exhibition in London in 1886, authorizing the President to direct that the Government exhibit at New-Orleans be forwarded to London in public vessels.
ALBANY, Dec. 15.--The Board of Public Instruction, after being in a deadlock since June last, organized to-night. The board is non-partisan, and the differences arose over the selection of officers.

The value of the cocoanut as food is as yet but little understood. An instance of its use is found in the experience of two shipwrecked sailors. They were seven years on an island where their only food was cocoanuts and an occasional flying fish. They retained good health and gained in weight.

Among the passengers who arrived at Castle Garden on the last Italian steamship were two Arabs from Beyrout. Their trunks were seized by the Custom House officers, as in one of them were jewels invoiced at $1,500, but which were thought to be worth a good deal more.
Mary McGee, the insane girl who threw vitriol into the face of William H. Clark, of the Clark Thread Works, was arraigned in Judge McCarter's court at Newark yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 15.--The Mark Lane Express, in its review of the Grain trade during the past week, says: "Continued rains favor the Autumn-sown crops, especially wheat.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 15.--The rivalry between the "Mossback" and "Kid" factions in the Ohio Democratic Party has increased to such an extent as to cause alarm among the more far-seeing and judicious statesmen of that party. The Jackson Club, under whose banner the young Democracy have ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 15.--This city was visited this morning by one of the most severe storms of wind and rain that has over been known in this section, the wind at times attaining a velocity of 64 miles an hour.

More people than have ever been in the Chamber of the Common Council crowded into the room yesterday afternoon when the Council met. The wit who remarked that "an honor may be without profit as well as a prophet without honor" touched, unconsciously, upon one of the deepest political truths of modern history.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15.--A legislative inquiry, which may develop into a sensation, begins here to-morrow. The affairs of the Townsend Savings Bank, an institution which in its day mulcted many of the industrious people of this quiet city, are on the verge of being settled, and some 13,000 depositors are anxiously ...

BOSTON, Dec. 15.--The Committee of One Hundred, representing the independents and the anti-Blaine Republicans in the last campaign, met to-day and adopted a report, the Executive Committee recommending that the organization be made permanent.

Charles Parker, who had been in the employ of Frank S. Gray, a real estate agent, of No. 1,295 Broadway, is now a prisoner in the Ludlow-Street Jail, having been arrested on a civil order of arrest granted on the complaint of his employer, who charges him with embezzlement.

The threatened fight of the coal-producing companies among themselves receiver a fresh impulse yesterday. A gentleman largely interested in the coal trade said last evening that all hopes of a restoration of the coal combination...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 15.--At a late hour Saturday night 20 horsemen rode into the yard of P.J. Slocum, a school teacher, at the village of Horse Cave, Ky. A fusilade of shots quickly followed the entry of the horsemen, and one of them, ...
