WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--When the question of appropriating $250,000 to enable Secretary Frelinghuysen to buy the Menocal canal concession was before the Senate at the last session it was stated that the United States did not intend to construct the canal under that concession, but intended to obtain further rights and ...

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 15.--The opponents of Father McGee, Pastor of the French Catholic Parish of Notre Dame de Lourdes, have possession of the church building. Yesterday morning they locked the doors and refused admittance to Father McGee, and prevented the celebration of mass.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 15.--The Capitol Building, Governor's Mansion, and the Capitol grounds are in total darkness to-night, owing to the city authorities having turned off the gas.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Litigation has just been instituted by Joseph Haworth against Dion Boucicault. Mr. Haworth has been for the past two years leading support to John McCullough, and continued as such until the tragedian's retirement from the stage.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 15.--Isaac Lyon, aged 90 years, the father of Associate Justice William P. Lyon, of the Supreme Court, was found dead in bed at 9 o'clock this morning by his granddaughter, who, knowing that he was not in his customary good health, had gone up to see him.

Assistant District Attorney James T. Fitzgerald, Mr. Anthony Comstock and 10 assisants, and Property Clerk John F. Harriot were engaged at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon in carrying out the order of District Attorney Olney to destroy 20,000 copies of the Brookside Library.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15.--Jack Dempsey met his match at Arthur Chamber's "Champions' Rest" to-night, where, in the presence of a large crowd of sporting men, gamblers, politicians, and detectives he endeavored to fulfill his engagement to knock out George Wilson in four rounds under the Marquis of Queensberry rules.

A large lot of securities was sold by Adrian H. Muller Son in the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broadway, yesterday noon, by order of E.K. Willard Co., of this city, for the account of the stock brokerage firm of Westcott Co., of Syracuse, which failed a few days ago.

A good deal of comment has been heard to-day regarding the report that Senator Mitchell, of Pennsylvania, is soon to go on the Federal Bench, thus creating a second vacancy in the Senate for the Pennsylvania Legislature to fill.

ALBANY, Dec. 15.--John Quirk, a young man, was fatally stabbed through the back with a pitchfork by his father this afternoon. Nicholas Quirk, the assailant, is a peddler, about 50 years of age, who was in the stable with his son unhitching his horse after the day's tour.

READING, Penn., Dec. 15.--While an engine was taking a lot of cars in the Leesport Iron Company's stone quarry at Leesport to-day it was derailed and fell upon the rocks below. The engine and a number of cars were smashed. The train hands narrowly escaped by jumping.

A musical scandal, the like of which has never been witnessed here before, was enacted on Monday evening at a concert given in the large hall of the Conservatoire by Dr. Hans von Buelow, who but a few months ago was the here of a similar scene at the brand Opera House in Berlin. The concert hall was crowded, ...
The New-York Alumni of Madison University gave themselves a dinner at the FifthAvenue Hotel at their eleventh annual meeting last evening. About 60 members of the association were in attendance.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 15.--In the breach of promise suit for $10,000 damages, brought by Maria L. Raddin, of Saugus, against Orrin S. Currier, of this city, a verdict was rendered this afternoon at Lynn of $4,000 for the plaintiff.

Several more overdue steamships reached this port yesterday and reported having met with very severe weather. Among these vessels were the Pennland, of the Red Star Line, from Antwerp, and the Thingvalla, from Copenhagen, both of which made unusually long voyages. Several steamships which with favorable weather would have been in on Sunday had not been reported at sundown yesterday. No anxiety under the circumstances is felt about any of these vessels.

The fat and rosy cherubs that sport among the wreaths in deshabille clear around the frieze of the great ballroom in the Hotel Brunswick looked down last night upon a gorgeous and glittering carnival of mimic commerce. It was the Charity Fair in aid of the Louis Downtown Sabbath School, which is carried on by the ladies of Temple Emanu-El.

At the annual meeting of the New-England Society last evening, at Delmonico's, the Secretary reported that during the year 16 annual members had joined the society and 38 life members. There were 29 deaths and 6 withdrawals, leaving a total membership on Dec. 1 of 1,365, the highest number ever reached.

A loud explosion like the report of a heavy gun was distinctly heard by many persons in the lower part of the city about 11:30 o'clock last night. The noise sounded loudest to those who happened to be in the vicinity of the Battery or along the North River front.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--Senator Manderson, of Nebraska, to-day introduced a bill to increase the efficiency of the army by providing that each infantry regiment shall consist of 12 companies instead of 10 and of 3 Majors instead of 1 as present. It also provides that all appointments to regular vacancies above the grads of Second Lieutenant shall be filled according to seniority in the infantry arm of the service.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 15.--William Harrington, who created quite a sensation in the city last week by purchasing large bills of goods with forged checks, and ostensibly for the Lake Superior Iron Company, the total forgeries ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 15.--Day and night hammers are ringing in the various buildings at Exposition Park. Carpenters, painters, and decorators are at work--an army of artisans at least 2,000 strong. To-day a body of police, organized by the Farrell Detective Agency, 300 strong,

ALBANY, Dec. 15.--The case of the people against the Gold and Stock Telegraph Company to recover the amount due for taxes upon the company's corporate franchise or business came up to-day before the Court of Appeals. Gen. Wager Swayne appeared for the defendant,

WINSTED, Conn., Dec. 15.--Litchfield County's little town of Harwinton is in a fever of excitement over an attempt at wholesale poisoning. The suspicion that some person had been poisoning wells and running streams was first aroused about a year ago by the mysterious death of several cattle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--J.J. Barker, in his testimony before the subcommittee investigating the alleged irregularities in the First Controller's office last Friday, said accounts were passed through the Department of Justice pro forma and not upon their merits.
ROME, Dec. 15.--Quarantine will be abolished at all the Italian ports next Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15.--Two carpet factories surrendered to the strikers to-day, and work was resumed at those places at the old rates, but the relative position of the carpet manufacturers and employes in the movement inaugurated three weeks ago has not changed,

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15.--At a meeting of cigar manufacturers here this evening resolutions were adopted protesting against the new Spanish treaty, and requesting the Senators from Pennsylvania to do all in their power to prevent its ratification.

Lena Mesner, a young Swedish woman is employed as a servant at No. 419 McDonoughstreet, Brooklyn, and while she was in the kitchen yesterday morning a young negro entered, and, seizing her round the waist, tried to choke her.
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 15.--At a meeting of the Portland Fish Exchange this afternoon a letter was read from Congressman Thomas B. Reed, in which he said:
Edward Leonard, who says that he is from Des Moines, Iowa, was taken to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday to answer two complaints of swindling Servant girls in search of employment.

Giuseppe Marone, a liquor dealer, of No. 62 Mulberry-street, who furnishes railroad contractors with Italian laborers, and his brother Michaele, who keeps a saloon at No. 66 Muclberrystreet, were arrested last night by DetectiveSergeant Owen Haley and Detective Benjamin...

The committee on the erection of a monument to the late Commissioner Nichois by members of the Police Department met yesterday at the Central Office to open bids for the work. Inspector Murray was in the chair, and the other members of the committee who were present...
TROY, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Willie E. Griffin and Flora A. McIntyre, the two children who ran away from Worcester, Mass., and were married here, reached Troy on Saturday morning at 3 o'clock.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 15.--Official notice was to-day given the operators of the Western Union Telegraph Company that from and after date no pay would, be allowed for extra work. The wages of employes in the clerical department were reduced considerably and the compensation of messengers was also cut down.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 15.--The Methodist Centenary Conference resumed its session at Mount Vernon Church this morning, Bishop Hood, of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, presiding.

BOSTON, Dec. 15.--Dr. Dudley A. Sargeant, Director of the Harvard College Gymnasium, delivered a lecture in this city to-night on the "Evils of Modern Athletics," which proved to be a discussion of "Professionalism in Modern Athletics."

Yesterday our esteemed contemporary the Sun remarked in italics: "There is one man in the United States who is fitter than all others to be Secretary of the Interior. His name is WILLIAM STEELS HOLMAN." Now, a joke is frequently a good thing; but is not the Sun carrying its renowned Holman joke a little too far?

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 15.--John Drake, an old farmer living in what is known as the "Purchase district," a tract of rough broken country on the east bank of the Housatonic River, 30 miles above its mouth, is at present searching for his missing daughter, Mildred, 19 years of age.

LONDON, Dec. 15.--A dispatch from Korti says that a messenger who has arrived there from Khartoum, which place he left 11 days ago, reports that Gen. Gordon was well and that he recently severely defeated the rebels, killing a large number of them and blowing up the forts at Omderman.

LYONS, N.Y., Dec. 15.--Rumors of a possible murder in the town of Sodus, adjoining this place, have caused great excitement here. The supposed victim is Miss Pamelia Marquet. By her father's will she was bequeathed a large tract of valuable farming land in Sodus, besides several thousand dollars.

Mrs. A.J. Vanderpoel, No. 1 West Sixteenth-street, gave a reception yesterday afternoon from 3 to 6 P.M. She was assisted in receiving by Miss Granger, of Baltimore; Miss Billings, Miss Sloan, Miss Green, of Elizabeth;
The Treasury Department at Washington has had under consideration for several weeks charges against James R. Davies, Tea Inspector for the port of New-York.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 15.--Commander F.W. Dickene, of the United States Navy, has presented the city of Danbury with a large collection of rare Peruvian curiosities, which are to form a feature in the public library.

THE TIMES was eagerly sought down town and at the hotels and news stands very early yesterday morning for the news it published exclusively in regard to the proposed Nicaraguan treaty, and discussion of the merits of the instrument interlarded current business quite generally among merchants and lawyers during the day.

BERLIN, Dec. 15.--A motion was carried in the Reichstag to-day increasing the salaries of two officials in the Chancellery. A motion was also made to create a second Directorship in tho Ministry for Foreign Affairs, which met with considerable opposition.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 15.--The wheat market was weak at the opening to-day, and the January option fell to 68 5/8 cents, the lowest point reached yet. As the morning advanced, however, a reaction set in and the option worked...

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Dec. 15.--A report has been received here from Shoal Harbor, Trinity Bay, of the loss on Saturday of the British schooner Turtle, which was upset by a violent squall in Smith's Sound. A portion of the crew who were below in the cabin sank with the schooner, but the remainder were saved.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 15.--The Times gives to the public for the first time a review of the opera "Culprit Fay," written by Judge Gedney, of New-York, which is to be produced here in January.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 15.--The river coal miners met in convention at Monogahela City, Penn., to-day, to consider the advisability of demanding an advance in the mining rate. There was a good attendance, nearly every mine in the district being represented.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 15.--An ice yachtsman of this city has displayed a new model for an ice yacht called the Lateen, and claims for it great advantages over other ice yachts. He claims that the present ice yacht, when it moves against the wind, while beating to the windward ...

Henry Levy and Sampson H. Levy, composing the firm of H. Levy Son, importers and manufacturers of fancy goods at No. 477 Broadway and No. 50 Mercer-street, made an assignment yesterday to William H. Gelshenen, ...

The first regular meeting for the season of the New-York Association for the Protection of Game was held at Pinard's last evening. Among those present were the President, R.B. Roosevelt, Mr. B.L. Ludington, ...

Prof. WOOD'S very interesting article concerning the extensive use of arsenic by manufacturers of wall paper, children's toys, textile fabrics, , to which we have already referred, contains a summary of the laws by which in several European nations such a use of this poison is forbidden.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--Capt. bedford Pim, of the royal navy, and lately a member of Parliament for Gravesend, is at the Leland Hotel, having returned from looking over the cattle ranches of the West. He has on foot a plan for building a railroad from Cheyenne to Hudson's...

Secretary MeCulloch is determined to use every precaution in his power to prevent the introduction of cholera into the United States, and with that view issued the circular prescribing four processes to be observed for disinfecting imported rags to be used in the manufacture of paper.

The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher delivered his lecture on "The Reign of the Common People" last evening in Steinway Hall. Mr. Beecher was in excellent spirits, and his sallies of wit were received with applause, as well as his telling periods. Mr. Beecher traced the effects of education upon the common classes of society.

At a meeting last night of the New-York Cremation Society, at No. 109 West Fiftyfourth-street, the Rev. Dr. Howard Henderson, of the Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church, of Jersey City, read a paper on "Cremation."
In Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, ex-Judge Arnoux made a motion in the case of Mile. Ida Riccetti against Col. J.H. Mapleson to vacate the attachment obtained by Mile.

A Connecticut manufacturer of hardware stated at a meeting in this city last week that with the duty removed from the materials he used he could compete with foreign manufacturers in all the best markets of the world. This gentleman employs some 3,000 hands.

ST. HYACINTHE, Quebec, Dec. 15.--The first span of the new bridge being erected across the Yamaska River was blown down to-day. A man named Allard was killed, and a man named St. Germain and another whose name is unknown are dying. Fifteen other persons were seriously, although not fatally, injured.

The Kings County Democratic General Committee met last evening at Fulton Hall, Flatbush and Fulton avenues, Brooklyn. The credentials of the delegates elected at the recent primaries were received and approved, except in the cases of the delegates from the Twelfth and Nineteenth Wards.

Robert Henderson, a retired revenue officer, was arrested yesterday, charged with having made a savage and apparently unprovoked assault upon James W. Weed, a young clerk, cutting him in the face and head with a ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--When the Swaim court-martial convened this morning the defense called Francis Trowbridge, of New-York, who testified that he is a broker and a member of the New-York Stock Exchange, and that he was at one time associated in business with Mr. A.E. Bateman.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15.--Gen. Sherman says that Senator Vance, of North Carolina, is not the man to whom Jeff Davis wrote saying that if a certain State withdrew from the Confederacy he would turn his batteries loose upon it, but the General still alleges that Davis wrote such a letter, and that it is in his possession.

Thomas J. McCann, of No. 392 Tenthavenue, earns his living by collecting fares in a surface car. Thomas is a, well-built, muscular young man, and he has often expressed a desire to be appointed a minion of the law.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 15.--A dispatch from Newark, Ohio, says the origin of the fire at Johnstown on Saturday, by which seven buildings were destroyed and William Tront, a saloon keeper, was burned to death, is believed to have been incendiary.
New disclosures concerning the peculiar business transactions of Ewen Brothers, cotton Brokers at Nos. 31 and 33 Broad-street, are made from day to day.

Nearly 200 Chinamen noiselessly entered Calvary Chapel last night and held the first public service given by the recently formed schools to which they belonged. A long and interesting programme, comprising various hymns in the Chinese and English languages, were listened to, and several of the pupils read aloud in English, showing careful training.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--The publication in THE TIMES to-day of a synopsis of the provisions of the convention with Nicaragua has at once surprised Senators and Representatives in Congress, and excited among them new admiration for the newspaper enterprise that has laid before the public so interesting and important a matter.

Gen. Hazen, Chief Signal Officer, has preferred charges against First Lieut. Ernest Garlington, Seventh Cavalry, for disobedience of orders and gross neglect of duty in connection with his command of the Proteus expedition of 1883 for the relief of the Greely colony at Lady Franklin Bay.

We might derive more satisfaction from the vote in the Board of Aldermen yesterday on the Mayor's nominations if we could interpret it as an evidence that a majority of the Aldermen honestly resented Mr. EDSON'S disreputable, attempt to tie the hands of his successor.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 15.--The will of the late Reuben Runyon springer was probated to-day. The largest public bequest is 750 shares of special guaranteed stock of the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad, of the par value of $75,000, to the music Hall Association.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 15.--At 11:30 o'clock this morning men walked into the City Bank here and made deposits as usual. An hour later passers by saw a rough white pasteboard fastened to the door with the simple inscription "Suspended" written in irregular black characters.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15.--Michael Doherty, father of Registrar J.J.P. Doherty, was in the City Court to-day as witness against Warren Hotchkiss, accused of assault with intent to kill.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15.--The committee of members of the Transcontinental Association, which has been in session in New-York for some days, arrived here yesterday and reported at a meeting of the association at the Grand Pacific Hotel this afternoon.

Dr. H.D. Coggswell, of San Francisco, whose ambition it is to give to every city in the United States a drinking fountain, has offered one to the city of New-York. It will cost, Alderman Miller told the Common Council yesterday, ...

The Trustees of the American Yacht Club will meet to-day for the purpose of arranging a definite plan to carry out two ideas which have recently been suggested by some of the members. One is to have regular classes instructed in the club rooms during the Winter in navigation and marine engineering.

The city of Montreal was somewhat extensively represented yesterday in the lobby of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. Aldermen William Farrell, H. Jeannotte, M. Laurent, and Archibald, Treasurer J.F.G. Black, Auditor Robb, and City Clerk Charles Glackmeyer composed the representation.

PRINCETON, Dec. 15.--Since Saturday the college has been agitated lest it should lose the valuable services of George Goldie, the instructor of gymnastics. Mr. Goldie has been here ever since the present gymnasium was built, in 1869, and much of its efficient apparatus is due to his ingenuity and painstaking skill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15.--Major Powell, Director of the Geological Survey, in his statement to the joint commission of Congress which is considering the organization of the scientific bureaus of the Government, while sympathizing fully with the general tenor of the recommendations of the Academy of Sciences, objected to the constitution of the Board of Commissioners recommended.
The Richmond County Board of Supervisors were surprised yesterday, when engaged in auditing bills, to find a remarkable array of warrants presented as claims from Constable ...

At the meeting of the Jersey City Board of Finance last evening Mr. Hardenbergh reported that, as Chairman of the Finance Committee, he had negotiated the sale on Monday of $300,000 of city bonds and $100,000 yesterday at par. He said that the appreciation of city bonds was due to the enforcement by the present board of the payment of water rents.

The bill for the admission of Dakota as a State was passed by the Senate to-day, substantially as it came from the Committee on Territories, by a vote of 34 to 28, the Republicans voting in the affirmative, and the Democrats...

The Atlantic express of the West Shore Road is due at Jersey City at 7 o'clock in the morning. Albert Hawkins, who has been coachman for all the Presidents since Gen. Grant's time, was to-day re-engaged for the same service under Grover Cleveland. Albert is extremely proud of the fact. This is the first assurance of the sincerity of Mr. Cleveland's statement, made some time ago, that efficient public servants should not be alarmed, but should simply attend to their business without alarm about what would become of them.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Dec. 17.--Two farmers in this county have failed within a week. Clifford L. Benham, of Byron, assigned a week ago, with liabilities of over $20,000, and now David C. Jones, of Pembroke, makes an assignment to John H. Ward. Jones owned ...

Indications accumulate that the NewJersey railroad tax law, formulated with so much care and pressed so vigorously last Winter by Gov. Abbett, is goint to have a hard time in passing the gantlet of opposition of the numerous companies affected by its provisions.

Thomas C. Platt, Richard A. Elmer, and Chauncey H. Crosby, of this city; John N. Knapp, of Auburn, N.Y., and Almeria H. Lighthall, of San Francisco, Cal., have formed a corporation known as the New-York, New-Jersey and Pennsylvania Railway Cable Company.

Shortly before midnight on Tuesday John F. Fisher, a machinist, living at No. 352 Fourth-avenue, while passing through Sixthavenue noticed John Benson, a negro, standing with his back toward one of the large windows of Simpson, Crawford Simpson's store, No. 307 Sixth-avenue.

Col. Dexter A. Hawkins, of the Union League Club Committee on Politcal Reform, invited a large number of gentlemen who favor national aid to education to meet at his residence, No. 5 west Thirty-fourth-street, last evening.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--The Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade have ordered the suspension of Peter McGeoch from the board for 30 days, owing to his plea in suits brought against him in Milwaukee that the contracts upon which the suits were based were not legal. George L. Dunlap, another prominent member of the board, was suspended for one day for a somewhat similar plea in another suit.

We often receive complaints from ladies who have applied to other retailers for the genuine "nonpareil velveteen" and have been supplied with other and much inferior qualities. It is to protect purchasers that the trade mark is stamped on the back of each yard.

At the annual meeting of the Constitution Club, of Brooklyn, held last evening at No. 371 Fulton-street, the following officers were elected: President--J.H. Hill; Vice-Presidents --Henry Hentry, John H. Clayton, and R.V. Leech; Secretary--Charles D. Dunnell; Treasurer--George B. Douglass. Prof. I.L. Rice, of Columbia Law School read a paper on "Theories of Politics."
Some Choice securities were sold at auction in the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broad, way, by Adrian H. Muller Son yesterday noon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Coon was callad to-day by J.J. Barker as a witness before the sub-committee investigating the alleged irregularities in the office of the First Controller of the Treasury.

SCHENECTADY, Dec. 17.--Yesterday afternoon a boy asked for 10 tickets to Amsterdam at the Central Railroad office. The ticket agent refused to furnish them. Shortly afterward the local ticket agent of the West Shore Railroad entered the waiting room and throwing down a bill called for 10 tickets to Amsterdam.
BOSTON, Dec. 17.--The latest report from the Hon. Robert C. Winthrop is that he is not suffering and that his mind is clear.

Mr. W.W. Ker, ex-Government counsel in the star route cases, said to a reporter tonight that it was not true that he had stated in a letter to Mr. Randall that the juries in the Kilbourn-Thompson suit were "fixed."

Sanitary Inspector Tracy was before Messrs. Morris, Adler, Fairchild, Reichardt, Esterbrook, Wingate, Vanderpoel, and Shaler, of the Tenement House Commission, yesterday afternoon, and answered 99 printed questions and many oral ones relating to his district. Dr. Tracy's district is that part of the city below Chambers-street, and in it are 437 tenements.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 17.--A mutual council of delegates from 20 of the North New-Jersey Baptist churches was held here to-day on a call signed by the Willis-Street Baptist Church and the Rev. George Guirey, its late Pastor, who ...

ALBANY, Dec. 17.--Gov. Cleveland has pardoned Joseph P. Wall, who was convicted in New-York of the crime of manslaughter in the first degree in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, and sentenced Feb. 18, 1878, to 15 years' imprisonment in Sing Sing Prison.

The Young Men's Republican Club held a meeting last evening at No. 21 West Twenty-seventh-street, James W. Hawes in the chair. The Executive Committee reported a resolution recommending the club to take measures to urge the nomination and election of the Hon. William M. Evarts for United States Senator.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--The wholesale leasing of Indian reservation lands was again briefly discussed in the Senate to-day, when Mr. Dawes presented a protest of many Montana citizens against the leasing of a large part of the Crow Reservation.
The Reagan Inter-State Commerce bill has been loaded with amendments to-day, and the prospect of its becoming a law has lessened with the adoption of each new amendment.

The market for quinine has recovered very materially from the depressing effect of the recent sharp competition between foreign and domestic manufacturers, and the result is that there is now a greater demand for the article in this country than was ever before known at this season of the year.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 17.--A local paper this afternoon publishes an interview with a telegraph operator, who is represented as saying that there is every reason to believe a telegraphic strike is imminent; that the operators here are ready to give the signal; that the plans ...

NEW--HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17.--George Hewes, of Thompsonville, who was employed at the metallic cap works in that place, was instantly killed by an explosion at the works. He had always been an unlucky man, but had escaped with his life on previous occasions.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17.--Inspector-General Goddard and Cols. Hassinger and Greene went to Washington this evening to arrange for the accommodation of the Pennsylvania National Guard at the inauguration of Presidentelect Cleveland.

There was a general decline in prices in the Stock Exchange yesterday, and particularly in the securities commonly known as the coal stocks. The course of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad stock was the chief feature of the market.

LACONIA, N.H., Dec. 17.--The heaviest earthquake shock ever experienced here occurred at about 2 o'clock this morning. It was felt in all the adjoining towns, but the heaviest jar was at Centre Harbor, lasting half a minute. The vibration seemed to come from a northerly direction and to pass toward the south. Doors and dishes were shaken in many residences of this town.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--At the meeting of the Transcontinental Railway Association to-day most of the session was devoted to a resolution by the Central Pacific that the members define their positions in regard to the action of the seaboard...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--The proposed treaty with Nicaragua is forcing itself more and more upon the attention of members of Congress, and it appears rather to gain than lose in popularity as the opportunity to grasp a great claim becomes understood. The disposition at first manifested to class it with the ...

Robert Fleming, Dilwyn Parish, and C. Sligo De Pathonier, three of the four gentlemen who have been investigating the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad Company, in the interest of the English, Scotch, and other foreign bondholders, sailed for home on the Oregon yesterday.
Senator Riddleberger's persistent opposition to the confirmation of Mr. McCulloch as Secretary of the Treasury is likely soon to result in the failure which has been anticipated from the beginning.

Speculators in cotton have been somewhat anxious during the last two or three days over rumors that a syndicate had been formed to get up a "corner" in January cotton. Men who have been operating on the "short" side of the market have been busy for more than a week covering their contracts.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 17.--Notice has been given the boilers, muck rollers, and helpers of the Jefferson Iron Works that their departments will close next Saturday. The remainder of the works will shut down in three or four weeks. The competition in the manufacture of steel nails and the large stock on hand in excess of orders are the reasons given.

The Inman steamship City of Montreal and the National steamship Strain both arrived from Liverpool yesterday, and reported having encountered remarkably severe weather. Capt. Redford, of the City of Montreal, reports that he left Queenstown on Dec. 3, and has since met with nothing but a series of strong westerly gales.

The unmusical spirits who pay large sums for seats in the opera in order that they may gaze upon the personal charms of worldrenowned songstresses had a magnificent opportunity yesterday in the Superior Court of feasting their eyes upon two popular prima donnas, a contralto and a soprano, who were present not to lift up their voices in song, but in testimony.
TAUNTON, Mass., Dec. 17.--The eighth annual exhibition of poultry and pet stock and the third annual bench show of dogs of the Southern Massachusetts Poultry Association opened here to-day.
PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 17.--Sheriff Johnson sold to-day at public auction $19,500 of the Southern Telegraph Company bonds, of the denominations of $1,000, $500, and $250, at the rate of $17 per $100.

The death of LOUIS KOSSUTH will revive in the minds of all Americans who a full generation ago were of an age to note passing events memories of the greeting which he received on these shores in 1851. So warm and generous and general an impulse the Nation has felt but rarely since.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 17.--This has been a day of nerveless reaction after the great strain of opening day. Besides the rain has fallen briskly all day, greatly hindering travel of all kinds, and divesting Exposition Park of all its outside beauties.

Mr. Ad. Neuendorf, after a quite extended period of absence from theatrical life in New-York, is about to return in his old managerial capacity. The gentleman named has secured, upon exceedingly favorable terms, a lease of the Third-Avenue Theatre, the name ...
PARIS, Dec. 17.--M. de Lesseps appears to be in no wise daunted by the American Nicaragua scheme. His health is good, and he never felt better disposed to carry out his great tasks.

ALBANY, Dec. 17.--Gov. Cleveland's visitors to-day included several gentlemen of a severely Southerntype. Virginia and South Carolina are believed to be their States. The rumor has reached Albany that several Washingtonians are missing from their boarding houses, leaving behind them unpaid bills, and the impression is that they have been called to Albany on business relating to the new Administration. The orderlies about the Executive Chamber are anxiously awaiting their appearance.

ALBANY, Dec. 17.--William M. Evarts will probably publish to-morrow or within a day or two a letter defining in unequivocal language his position on the tariff question. The idea has been suggested to him as one of the necessary preliminaries of the Senatorial canvass, upon which he is now fairly launched.
MINNEAPOLIS, Kan., Dec. 17.--The Bank of Minneapolis, J.P. Cummin Co., proprietors, made an assignment to-day to Charles Fairfield. They state that all depositors and creditors will be paid in full.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 17.--The Cigarmakers' Union at Canton addressed a communication to Gov. Hoadly earnestly urging the withdrawal of troops from the Hocking Valley.

According to the report that Superintendent Jasper handed in at the Board of Education meeting yesterday 553 children were refused admission into the public schools because of insufficient accommodations last month, principally in the Twelfth. Nineteenth, and Twenty-second Districts.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 17.--The National Sugar Growers' Association met this morning. Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Wisconsin, New-York, and Kansas were represented. President Norman J. Coleman, of Missouri, in his annual address denounced the Spanish treaty as the destroyer of American sugars for the benefit of the foreign sugar trade.

In its original estimate of the amount of money required for the legislative department of the city during the coming year, the Common Council asked for $25,000 for clerks and officers of the board, that being the full amount allowed by law.
The Hungarian Orchestra make their first appearance at Chickering Hall to-night.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 17.--In a remote part of Hall County at midnight last night a desperate fight occurred between Deputy Marshals and two moonshiners, Anderson Grant and a man named Prater, both of the moonshiners being killed.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17.--Offcers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, in view of the alarm that has been caused by the frequent announcements that that company would not enter into an agreement to regulate the mining of coal next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--The proceedings of the United States Supreme Court to-day were as follows: No. 75--Samuel Head, plaintiff in error, vs. The Amoskeag Manufacturing Company.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 17.--At 6 o'clock this morning as the miners living at the surface over No. 11 colliery, operated by the Philadelphia and Reading Coal Company, were eating their breakfast a loud rumbling noise resembling the report of an earthquake was heard, and at the same time the houses shook on their foundations.

AUBURN, N.Y., Dec. 17.--The local ministerial association celebrated the centennial anniversary of the birthday of one of its members, the Rev. Dr. Oliver S. Taylor, in the First Presbyterian Church, this evening. Dr. Taylor was born in New-Ipswich, Dec. 17, 1784.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 17.--There was received at the Baton Rouge Penitentiary, yesterday, from Morehouse Parish a young man, 24 years old, named Harry Fairchild, who is to serve a term of two years and a half for horse stealing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 17.--Encke's comet was found last night by Prof. Young, of Princeton College. He observed it at the Halstead Observatory, very near to the predicted place. It is extremely faint and somewhat irregular in form.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--Reports from all points throughout the West and Northwest indicate the severest weather yet experienced during the present Winter.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17.--The necessity of some action to prevent the prices of soft coal "going all to pieces" next year, as the dealers express it, has resulted in several conferences between the railroad companies, with the view of pooling that portion of the production which is to be sent to tidewater.
Miss Belle Weil, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Weil, was last evening married to Mr. David Hochstadter in Delmonico's.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17.--Rain, which was so badly wanted, commenced falling last evening. Reports from the interior show that it has been general throughout the State.

Messrs. Sullivan and Greenfield, charged with the heinous offense of "engaging in a fight or contention without weapons" in MadisonSquare Garden, on the evening of Tuesday, Nov. 18, were triumphantly acquitted yesterday by the 12 intelligent gentlemen who were impaneled to sit in judgment upon them the day before.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17.--A special dispatch to the Times says: "Equinunk, in Wayne County, on the Delaware, the home of State Senator Nelson, is greatly agitated over the discovery of gold. For many months a farmer by the name of Daney, whom the neighbors have ...

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 17.--A fire broke out this morning between decks on the British steamship Barrowmore, which was taking in cargo at Locust Point preparatory to sailing tomorrow. She had on board about 3,000 bales of cotton, and in the lower holds 50,000 bushels of wheat and corn. The entire damage is estimated at about $40,000, though the cargo will have to be taken out before the actual damage can be known.

The needs of the National Guard in this city in the way of new armories engaged the attention of the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund for nearly an hour yesterday, and drew to the Mayor's office Gen. Shaler and the principal officers of the Eighth, Ninth, Twelfth, and Twenty-second Regiments.

LEIPSIC, Dec. 17.--The trial of the anarchists for attempting to kill the Emperor and others at Niederwald was resumed to-day. Kuechlen testified that Reinsdorf said the Emperor should be spared. Any accident to Crown Prince Frederick William would have the desired effect. Rupsch denied this testimony.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 17.--The Governor has commuted the sentences of Herman Brown and Samuel Casper, who were sentenced on April 1,1877. Brown was sentenced for 18 years and Casper for the term of 15 years in the State prison at Auburn for robbery. They will be released on Dec 20.
A new circular was issued by the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Directors yesterday asking the stockholders to subscribe $2.50 a share for the purpose of paying the floating debt.

BOSTON, Dec. 17.--The report of the President of the Union Pacific Railway for the quarter ending Sept. 30--the first complete quarter following the change of administration brought about by the resignation of President Dillon-- was issued to-day.

About 200 real estate owners of Long Island City met in Alber's Hall, Astoria, last night for the purpose of taking measures to compel delinqueut taxpayers to pay up. The financial condition of the city treasury and the fact that four of the largest property owners owe ...
A long session of the Sub committee of the Brooklyn Independent Republicans was held in the rooms of the Art Association last night.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 17.--Jeremiah Wonders and Joseph Harter, two old miners residing in the village of Luzerne, after prospecting on Kingston Mountain for over two weeks, have returned with some fine specimens of silver ore.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 17.--The will of Miss Carrie J. Welton, who bequeathed most of her property to Mr. Bergh's society, is attracting much attention in this city. It is stated that Mrs. Joseph Welton, mother of the late Miss Currie J. Welton, is opposed to the recent effort made by the relatives of the young lady to contest her will.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 17.--H.B. Guion, while repairing electric lights in Mascot Rink this evening, a professional skater ran against the ladder, throwing Guion to the floor and injuring him so badly that he died in a few hours.

At the meeting of the Dock Commissioners yesterday the resolution offered last week by Commissioner Voorhis, requesting that the Corporation Counsel apply to the Supreme Court for a writ of mandamus requiring the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund to issue the full amount ...

PARIS, Dec. 17.--Admiral Peyron, Minister of Marine, has received a dispatch from Gen. Briere de I'Isle, which says: "Two or three thousand Chinese left the mountains, intending to attack a village eight kilometers northeast of Chu. A portion of the Chu garrison, assisted by some friendly natives, dispersed the Chinese, inflicting heavy loss on them. The French lost 24 in killed and wounded.

The Board of Education of Jersey City sat till after midnight Tuesday. There was a large lobby present, who had been attracted to the meeting mainly to protest against the proposed shifting of Principals Ridenour, Sweeney, and Day.
A funny turn was given yesterday to the question of who should succeed Commissioner Thompson and Corporation Counsel Lacombe by a story which was circulated around the City Hall in the afternoon.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17.--A list has been prepared of the members of the last graduating class at Yale, and of their future occupations. Of these 46 are reading law, 27 are teaching, 19 are in business, 13 are continuing their studies, 12 are reported without occupation, 5 are studying theology, 2 are studying medicine, 2 are engaged in newspaper work, 1 is "ranching," and several are traveling.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 17.--Benjamin F. Estes was held in $1,000 to-day in the District Court on a charge of bigamy. The complaint states that in Washington, D.C., in 1862, he married Henrietta Thompson, and that in Providence in 1882 he married a Mrs. Miller, with whom he now lives.

BERLIN, Dec. 17.--There was no sitting of the Congo Conference to-day, owing to the continued indisposition of Count von Hatzfeldt, the German Foreign Secretary. It is reported that the conference will adjourn before Christmas until some time in January.

Among the passengers of the Cunard steamship Oregon, which sailed yesterday for Liverpool, were the Hon. Walter Maxwell, Robert Appleton, Jr., Henry Bell, E. Berry Wall, Col. Gowen, and Capt. James H. Hogg.

The representation of "Le Prophete" given at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening is to be accounted the most complete and impressive that has been witnessed in this city during the last 15 years.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 17.--As the Mexican steamer Esteban Antunano was about leaving port this evening Mr. J.F. De Zamacona, the Mexican Consul, accompanied by his wife, had gone on board to bid the officers good-bye.
The Masonic fraternity of the State thronged the Grand Lodge Room of the Masonic Temple last night to take part in the crowning of the Poet-Laureate of Freemasonry, Robert Morris, LL.D., of Kentucky.

Superintendent George W. Cummings, of Casebolt's laundry, at Belleville, N.J., has reached the conclusion that Chinese labor is not all his fancy painted it, for on Tuesday evening the Chinamen in the laundry struck work and introduced a reign of terror into Mr. Cummings's bosom.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 17.--The Rev. E.R. Hendrix, of Missouri, presided over the deliberations of the Centenary Conference this morning, and the Rev. W.P. Stowe, of Chicago, opened the session with prayer.

The counsel to the Board of Health has under consideration a communication from the Rev. J.M. Pullman, of the Church of Our Saviour, in West Fifty-seventh-street, in regard to circulars sent out by Grayton Johnston, a lawyer, of No. 82 Nassau-street, of which the following is a copy:

The Aqueduct Commission had so little business of importance before it yesterday that the meeting was an open one. Considerable discussion was had as to whether bondsmen of the contractors should be required to appear before the commission to qualify, as specified in the rules, or whether they might qualify before a proper official wherever they live.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 17.--Willis A. Kane, formerly an employe of the Naugatuck Railroad Company, has just died under peculiar circumstances. Some weeks ago a passenger train on the Naugatuck Road was derailed by an open switch at Seymour, and travel was interrupted for three hours.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--In the Swaim court martial to-day the cross-examination of Mr. Humphrey was continued without eliciting anything material. After proceeding for some time it was suspended to permit the witness to examine his books.

An octoroon named Annie Green died early yesterday morning at No. 68 Sullivanstreet, and John David, a native of South Carolina, was arrested by Capt. McDonnell because there is proof that he ill-used her.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 17.--Capt. Forbes, of the bark Albemarle, which arrived at this port yesterday from Rio Janeiro, says that when he left Rio Janeiro, Nov. 12, there were rumors of war between Brazil and the Argentine Republic. The Brazilian authorities were conscripting for the army when he left.

LONDON, Dec. 17.--The Times this morning devotes a leader to the proposed treaty between the United States and Nicaragua, based on a cabled summary of the synopsis of the treaty printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--William J. Gallagher, a brother-in-law of "Mike" McDonald, the Mayor's "boss" gambler, was arrested last night on the charge of aiding and abetting persons in the County Clerk's office in perpetrating the Eighteenth Ward election frauds.
SHANGHAI, Dec. 17.--It is rumored that the Chinese cruisers which left here yesterday have gone to Corea. After the Corean riots the Japanese withdrew to Chumul-Po.

On an order of arrest granted by Judge Lawrence in the Supreme Court William W. Parrish was arrested yesterday and subsequently released on $2,500 bail. The order of arrest was obtained in an action brought by Robert J. Dean against William W. Parrish, Treasurer; ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--Leave of absence for 10 days has been granted Capt. George E. Pond, Assistant Quartermaster. The leave of absence on Surgeon's certificate of disability granted First Lieut. Palmer Tilton, Twentieth Infantry, has been extended two months on account of sickness.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. l884. The Senate to-day passed the Naval Appro priation bill which falled at the last session, modified in form, as a substitute for the House bill making a lump appropriation for the remainder of the fiscal year. This action sends the whole subject back to the House for its consideration.
Those who went early to the Metropolitan Opera House last evening to hear Meyerbeer's "The Prophet" were unaware of a little scene that was going on behind the curtain.

The Japanese Minister of War, Gen. Oyama-Qua-O, spent yesterday on the water under escort of Albert Bierstadt, the artist. As yesterday was the last day that the Minister will spend in this vicinity, Mr. Bierstadt thought he might like to see the fine fortifications in the harbor.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 17.--In the United States court to-day the solicitors for the complainants in the chancery suit of John C. Shoemaker and the Indianapolis Sentinel Company against James G. Blaine filed the following:

The Directors of the Pascific Mail Steamship Company decided yesterday to pay the company's obligation to the Panama Railroad Company, which amounts to about $800,000 and bears 7 per cent. interest. It is stated, however, that the Panama Company will insist upon maintaining the present contract, which calls for payments by the Pacific Mail Company of $20,000 a month.

The exposition at New-Orleans cannot fail to be of great service to the Nation as a whole, and especially to the inhabitants of the Southern States and to their neighbors in Mexico and Central America.

Senator BECK, of Kentucky, is an able man. No one doubts it, and he as little as any one else. He is also a bold, bluff man, and when he has taken it into his head to advocate a principle or a policy he does it with directness and courage.

The annual reunion and dinner of the Alumni of Dartmouth College residing in NewYork and vicinity will be held at Delmonico's on the evening of Friday, Jan. 30, 1885. Judge Horace Russell is President of the association.

Little Annie Frey, who claims to have been assaulted by her school companions Lottie Nesfield, Mamie Moran, and Maggie Rogers, while on her way home from school on tho 5th inst., lay helpless on a sofa at her home in Fourth-street, Hunter's Point, last evening.

LONDON, Dec. 17.--Gen. Wolseley, in a telegram from Korti to the Marquis of Hartington, Secretary of State for War, says that the English boats have fulfilled his best expectations; that the work is hard, but the men are in good health and fit for any work.

A delegation of marketmen from Gansevoort Market appeared before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday morning and urged that a larger sum than $150,000 be included in the final estimates for the erection of a new market building.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 17.--The Record will to-morrow publish an account of the discovery of a series of subterranean caverns in a mountain two miles from Wilkesbarre. The caverns are of human construction, antedating the earliest settlement by whites during the last century. They ware discovered by a farmer who was prospecting for silver. Specimens of galena have been found.

ALBANY, Dec. 17.--The test case to determine the constitutionality of the law prohibiting the manufacture of cigars in tenement houses, which has been vigorously pushed by exJudge A.J. Dittenhoefer in the interest of the manufacturers, was argued before the Court of Appeals to-day.

BOSTON, Dec. 17.--The Boston Baseball Association to-day elected the following officers: President--A.H. Soden; Treasurer--J.B. Billings; General Manager--W.H. Conant; Directors--A.H. Soden, J.B. Billings, and W.H. Conant. It was voted that the Directors be authorized to purchase land in Boston for a baseball ground, which is now used by the corporation, at a price not exceeding $100,000.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 17.--The annual report of the Fitchburg Railroad Company for the year ended Sept. 30 was issued to-day. It shows the total earnings to have been $2,856,657; expenditures, $2,131,404; net earnings, $725,253.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17.--The special committee consisting of Messrs. Springer, of Illinois; Van Alstyne, of New-York, and Stewart, of Vermont, appointed to investigate the alleged misconduct of Marshal Wright in the Ohio election last October, held its first public meeting this morning. Dr. R.B. Bradford, a resident of Cincinnati, but temporarily residing in Washington, ...

CHICAGO, Dec. 17.--Henry Boxhorn, of Paris, France, arrived in this country a few weeks ago with $10,000 worth of diamonds. These he offered for sale, and disposed of many of them in the metropolis and other cities.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., Dec. 18.--Assistant Postmaster-General Marr has written to parties in this city stating that the Post Office Inspector has made a supplementary report favoring the introduction of a free delivery system in Lockport, and as soon as the streets are properly numbered and named it is expected that free delivery will be adopted here.
The Excelsior Boat Club gave an athletic entertainment in Clarendon Hall last evening.
Senator Riddleberger's protracted argument against the confirmation of Secretary McCulloch was concluded to-day in an executive ...
NYACK, Dec. 18.--A permanent Republican organization has been formed at Haverstraw, to by known as the Ira M. Hedges Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec.18.--Gen. Swaim took the stand to-day to testify in his own behalf. After narrating his military experience he said that the paper presented to him by Bateman Co. in the Fall of 1883, as the Antrim claim, purchased by him, did not represent the claim which he had authorized them to purchase for him.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 18.--Lieut. Abercrombie, of Gen. Miles's staff, has just returned from Alaska, where he has been engaged in Government explorations. MANCHESTER, Dec. 19.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "The market is extremely dull. Great difficulty to sell goods is experienced. VIENNA, Dec. 19.--Orders have been telegraped throughout Europe for the arrest of Lucas Jauner, the defaulting and absconding Director of the securities department of the Lower Austrian Discount Bank. Liberal rewards are offered for the apprehension of the culprit.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 19.--Intense cold prevails at all points in the Hudson River Valley, and the river north is freezing up. There are masses of ice between Staatsburg and Hudson, and from the latter place north to Albany the ice is fast from shore to shore.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Dec. 19.--There is at Milford, Pike County, Penn., seven miles from this village, the oldest Court House but one in that State. It was built in 1814 of cobble stones, and remained unchanged in any particular until this Fall.

Engineer A.G. Menocal will start for Nicaragua to-day to perfect surveys of the proposed interoceanic canal route. Civil Engineer Peary and Ensign W.I. Chambers, both of the navy, will sail with him on the Colon, and assist in the work to be done, which will occupy them four or five months.

LONDON, Dec. 19.--The Pall Mall Gazette publishes under reserve a statement from a "well-informed American correspondent," to the effect that the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher will be the successor of Mr. James Russell Lowell as American Minister at the Court of St. James.

Judge Rapallo, re-elected to the Court of Appeals Bench, filed his oath of office with the Secretary of State yesterday. Judge Rapallo states his age to be 61, and he can, therefore, serve nine years of his term before prevented by age disability.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 19.--The steamboat Fred A. Blanks, which played a conspicuous part in the ceremonies of opening the Exposition, being the boat on which the distinguished visitors went to the park, came to a sudden termination of her career last night.

A small muscular young man entered the jewelry store of Ferdinand Kraft, at No. 427 Grand-street, yesterday afternoon, and asked to be shown some wedding rings. The proprietor readily consented and placed a tray on the counter in which were 70 rings, valued at $500.

Michael Gavin has secured from Judge Van Hoesen an injunction restraining the Common Council from passing over the Mayor's veto the resolution granting consent to the ChambersStreet and Grand-Street Ferry Railroad Company to construct a railroad through Chambers and Duane streets from river to river.

For some time past a two-story shanty on the Hoboken meadows, at Sixteenth-street, has been occupied by a family named Kennedy. Kennedy's family increased, and he persuaded his landlord, J. O'Hara, to elevate it a story, and John Gleason, a Wehawken house mover, was employed for the purpose.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Dec. 19.--Farmers at various points along the line of the Delaware and Hudson Canal in Ulster County report the loss of many hogs owing to a disease they term "sore throat." In the town of Rochester a great many swine have died suddenly. The disease resembles diphtheria.

MARSHALL, Texas, Dec. 19.--Anthony Walker, colored, was to-day sentenced to hang Jan. 23 next for the murder of William Henry, a white man. Walker appealed for charity for his wife and six children, and passed a hat around the court room himself. He collected $6.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19.--The plates on which the counterfeit ten-dollar silver certificates were printed, were dug up seven miles west of Waukesha, Wis., to-day by Operative Hall of the United States Secret Service of this city, and Deputy Sheriff Tom Nelson.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES is conceded to be one of the leading newspapers of the country. Independent and fearless for what it believes in, THE TIMES maintains by its outspoken career the respect of all thinking men and has great influence with the reading public.
LONDON, Dec. 19.--At the sale of the Syston Library to-day a "Psalmorum Codex" of 1459, printed by Faust and Schoiffer, brought 4,950.

ALBANY, Dec. 19.--The Governor has pardoned George Lewis and Harvey J. Totten. Lewis was convicted of larceny in the county of Queens, and was sentenced, Dec. 6, 1883, to two years' imprisonment in the Kings County Penitentiary.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., Dec. 19.--The number of men who patrol the line of the West Shore Railroad, day and night, has been increased since the accident happened to the Atlantic express at Herring Point, near Highland, last Tuesday morning. Naval Academy, has been authorized to make certain quantitative analyses of such specimens of steel for the shafts of the new cruisers as may be supplied him by the Advisory Board.

Cleve Stuart was the only son of John Stuart, a cotton planter of Mississippi. In his seventeenth year, Cleve embarked for St. Louis, with his parents, on the ill-fated steamer Lucy Lee, which perished by an explosion within sight of her landing.

An ice condora, or cairn, is about to be erected under the auspices of the East End Winter Carnival Committee, on the Champ de Mars. The structure is round, tapering to a point, its base diameter measuring 50 feet.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21.--The application of 1,000 destitute people to the Infirmary authorities for aid during the past week has prompted an investigation, and it is now stated that at least 8,000 workmen are idle in the city. It is thought that the authorities will have a to provide 15,000 people with the necessities of life during the rest of the Winter. There is more destitution in the city now than during the panic depression.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--The much-taking-of billiard match between William H. Catton, of St. Louis, ana Edward McLaughlin, of Philadelphia, for $2,000, straight rail game, 3,000 points, was concluded at Central Music Hall at a very late hour last night.

DELHI, N.Y., Dec. 21.--Charles Tyler, in the employ of a farmer named Gould, at Fish's Eddy, Delaware County, was drowned while trying to ford the Delaware River near that place. He was driving a team, and instead of crossing at the usual place attempted to ford the river one-eighth of a mile lower down. Before startnig out he said in a joking way: "I guess I will be drowned to-day." The team swam ashore.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 21.--At the French Catholic Church to-day there was considerable disturbance for the evident purpose of annoying Father McGee, who is obnoxious to a large number of the congregation, but no acts of violence were committed. A meeting was held to-night to take further steps toward raising a fund to send a deputation to Rome to lay their grievances before tha Pope.
BERLIN, Dec. 21.--England, Germany, Holland, and Italy are now in accord upon the proposition to neutralize the territory of the African International Society.

Chief-Justice Waite, who has been seriously ill for a week past and whose condition yesterday and on Friday was such as to cause his family and friends much uneasiness, is much better to-night.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 21.--Another silver mine has bean discovered in North Georgia. Two young men of this city brought here a piece of ore weighing several pounds, about 80 per cent. of which is silver. It was taken out of Cohutta Mountain, a few miles from the famous Legal Tender mine, and 50 miles from this city.

BOSTON, Dec. 21.--The Herald will publish to-morrow an interview with Simeon Levy, proprietor of the Mexican Financier, who visited Gov. Cleveland last week and had a talk with him upon Mexican affairs.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 21.--From 5,000 to 10,000 people visited the Exposition to-day, and from 3,000 to 5,000 occupied seats in Music Hall during the playing of sacred music by the Mexican band and the brief sermon by the Rev. Charles A. Allen, of the Unitarian Church.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES is one of the very best, ablest, purest, and most honest and reliable papers published in the United States. In politics it is Republican; its line is one of conservatism. For a family newspaper we know of none better in the United States than THE WEEKLY TIMES.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES still retains its place in the front rank of newspapers, and is distinguished for its elevated tone, its able and honorable character, and its independent, discriminating, and fair course. THE TIMES was one of those public journals which took honest and high ground against the election of Mr. Blaine,. though adhering to Republicanism as a political party, and will undoubtedly wield important influence in the immediate future of its party.

LONDON, Dec. 22.--A fire broke out in the parcel office at the Windsor Railway Station on Saturday and burned quite rapidly for a while, but was soon extinguished. Among the debris were found a number of brass wheels and a bottle supposed to contain an explosive substance.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--A large meeting of the insurance men of the city was held yesterday afternoon at the rooms of the Board of Underwriters. All the regular agencies, with the exception of two, were represented.
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 21.--The Directors of the Holyoke and Westfield Railroad held their annual meeting at Holyoke yesterday and declared a dividend of 4 per cent., or $10,400.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21.--William J. Gallagher, brother-in-law of Mike MoDonald, who was recently arrested for alleged complicity in the Eighteenth Ward ballotbox fraud, was taken from his bed very early yesterday morning by Constable Brokoski, and brought before Juestice Lyon.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 21.--Sister Theresa, one of the inmates of the orphan asylum attached to St. Mary's Church in this city, is dangerously ill and her recovery is doubtful. Sister Theresa is a niece of James G. Blaine and returned from Washington last Monday, where she was called upon by the ex-Secretary of State.

The steamship Canada, of the National Line, arrived yesterday from London after a long and stormy passage of 21 days. Capt. Pearce reports that soon after entering the Channel it began to blow heavily from the westward.

BOSTON, Dec. 21.--The 8 o'clock train on the Boston and Albany Railroad came in collision with a train of empty passenger cars at Newton Lower Falls last night.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Dec. 21.--Burglars broke open the Post Office safe last night and stole $300 and a quantity of registered letters. They left all their tools behind, having drilled open the safe. The same office was robbed in the same manner two years ago. No clue has been found.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Dec. 21.--The schooner St. Peter, of this port, owned and commanded by Capt. Edward Cautillion, went ashore this morning at Portsmouth, N.H., and lies in four fathoms of water. She is valued at $1,000 and insured for $600 in the Boston Marine. The crew were saved.

GALVESTON, Texas, Dec. 21.--The dry goods house of William Epstein, of Luling, was closed Saturday by New-York creditors. Attach ments amounting to $8,000 were placed on the Stock. The failure was caused by short cotton crops.

A memento of the days of Louis Kossuth was shown Thursday morning by ex-Mayor Cowan, of Lewiston. It was a Hungarian bond, bought in Lowell, Mass., in May, 1852, when Kossuth was in America.

MORICHES, L.I., Dec. 21.--The steamer Oliveto, 1,400 tons, Capt. Trotter, in ballast, from Shields, England, to Austin Baldwin Co., New-York, went ashore on the beach off here at 5:30 this morning. She is well upon the beach and will probably be a total wreck. Capt. Smith and the Forge River Life Saving Corps rescued the crew. The vessel went ashore during a heavy snowstorm and fog.

PARIS, Dec. 21.--In the elections to-day, the complete autonomist list of Senatorial Delegates was elected in Paris. The opportunists were successful at Dijon and Grenoble, and the irreconcilables at Lyons.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 21.--About 8 o'clock this evening William Rice, a bricklayer, was shot and instantly killed by policeman Snyder, of the Allegheny City force. Snyder had arrested a companion or Rice's for disorderly conduct, and the latter with a friend attempted to rescue with the above fetal result.

CHATTANOOGA, Dec. 21.--A special dispatch from Knoxville says that about 4 o'clock this afternoon Joseph Mann, of North Carolina, but who is in the employ of the Dayton (Ohio) Hedge Company, was stabbed and killed by George Hines, of Knox County. Hines escaped.

An informal meeting of the Democratic members of Congress and citizens of indiana was held at the capital last night. The sentiment was generally expressed that Indiana was entitled to recognition in the Cabinet of the President-elect, and the opinion was unanimous that in that event the honor should be conferred upon ex-Senator McDonald. Senator Voorhees and all the Democratic members of tue House were present and concurred in the views expressed.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 21.--The residence of Henry Workenour, No. 1,401 Wetzelstreet, this city, was the scene, at 3 o'clock this morning, of a desperate and villainous robbery.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 21.--Boats from windward report that the British steamship Azalea, from Cardiff to Havana, struck Tennessee Reef day before yesterday and laid there several hours, but jettisoned her coal, and having relieved herself without the assistance of wreckers, proceeded to Havana.

WHEELING, West Va., Dec. 21.--James A. Bee, Superintendent of the Mannington flouring and saw mill, near this city, has been missing since last Saturday. His accounts, which are large and valuable, are undergoing examination. Miss Rosa Brookhover, a wealthy young lady of Mannington, is also missing, and yesterday afternoon it was found that they had gone away together.
The steamship Schiedam, of the Netherlands Steamship Company, arrived at her wharf in Jersey City yesterday. She had been nine days making the voyage from the Newfoundland Banks to this port.
BOSTON, Dec. 21.--A collision occured on the Boeton and Lowell Railroad last night at Cambridge. One passenger, a gentleman, was slightly injured, and about $5,000 damage was done to rolling stock.

NEW-ORLEANS, Dec. 21.--The South American Trade Commission, composed of Gov. Thomas C. Reynolds, of Missouri; the Hon. Solon O. Thacher, of Kansas, and Mr. W.E. Curtis, Secretary, of Illinois, arrived yesterday morning direct from the city of Mexico, via the "Sunset Route."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21.--Albert Latroussi died to-day from the effects of injuries received at the hands of J.S.Jobbs on Wednesday last. Mr. and Mrs. Latroussi were having an animated discussion in the German tongue. Jobbs was passing the room, and remarked that they had better stop talking about him in that manner. A quarrel ensued, during which Jobbs fractured his antagonist's skull with a hammer. Jobs fled, and has not yet been arrested.

NEW-HAVEN, Dec. 21.--According to the report of the Yale College Corporation, the new athletic grounds still need a further expenditure to put them in good condition. Up to date $53,184 25 has been spent and $10,000 more is needed.

The Chamber of Commerce yesterday gave a verdict against the Spanish commercial treaty which will, beyond any reasonable doubt, be indorsed by Congress, and which unquestionably expresses the judgment of the great body of business men in the country.

WINCHESTER, Va., Dec. 22.--The negro Banks, who was indicted as accessory to the killing of Joseph McFall during a Democratic procession here on the evening of Nov. 14 and convicted of murder, was to-day sentenced to be hanged on Friday, March 20, next. The case will go to the Court of Appeals on a writ of error.

OTTAWA, Dec. 22.--John Lowder, the father of George Lowder, who was hanged last June for the murder of Peter Lozier, died at Pictou on Saturday, and before his death, it is said, he confessed to having committed the ...

TRENTON, Dec. 22.--The State Board of Assessors held an important meeting here today. It was a field day for the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. Edward T. Green and Senator William J. Sewell appeared before the commission to argue against the imposition of the franchise tax.

The police on Sunday arrested a number of saloon keepers for violation of the excise law. They were taken before Justice White, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday, and placed under $100 bail to answer.
LONDON, Dec. 22.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "The week's rainfall has materially improved the already promising Autumn crops.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Dec. 22.--The schooner run down by the steamer Bristol in the Race Sunday morning, and subsequently towed into this port, proved to be the Zamora, of St. John, New-Brunswick, Capt. W.A. Finlay, from Alma for New-York, with laths.

For some time the city authorities have been desirous of getting possession of the dock property now covered by the West Washington Market, and used by the lessees in larger part as a wholesale market, the majority of the stands being for the sale of beef.

The Westchester County Grand Jury have found an indictment against Theodore Degraw, a small boy only 10 years of age, for deliberately loading a shot gun and shooting another boy named Michael Keoghan on Thanksgiving Day at Verplanck's Point.

A valued correspondent in Remsen send the details of a remarkable combat witnessed near Bordwelitown last week. The report says William Williams, who is employed in the tannery at Bordwelltown, while on his way to work ...

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 22.--John Quinn, a trackman, was clearing snow from the track of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad this morning, when an engine approached. Though warned, he remained on the track till the engine was near, when, in stepping out of the way, his foot caught between the rails. His legs were cut off and he was disemboweled. He cannot live.
Our esteemed contemporary the Tribune yesterday remarked that "the climate of New-York has a good reputation and deserves it generally."
T.M.R. Talcott, formerly Vice-President of the Richmond and Danville Railroad, has been made Vice-President and General Manager of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad.
Mr. W.E. Curtis, correspondent at the capital for the Chicago Inter Ocean, was named by the President several months ago as Secretary for the South American Commission.
BERLIN, Dec. 22.--Dr. Busch, Under Foreign Secretary, presided at the meeting of the Congo conference to-day. The American neutrality scheme was brought up, but a for mal debate was postponed.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 22.--Gov. Pattison wrote a letter to-day to Judge Krebes, of Clearfield County, ordering the release of Michael Norton, who was kidnaped from NewYork State and brought to Pennsylvania without a requisition. A letter was also sent to Gov. Cleveland announcing the decision arrived at by Gov. Pattison.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 22.--Robert W. Rose, a prominent young musician of this city, was adjudged insane by a board of magistrates today. He has been married about a month. He is a brother of Dr. George W. Rose and a nephew of Dr. H.M. Nash, of this city.
There was much talk last night at the Windsor over the action of the Board of Directors of the Lake Shore Road at the meeting this week, at which the question of a dividend will be discussed.

Detective Mullin was called into Macy Co.'s store yesterday afternoon to arrest Mary Emily Springs, a very handsome young woman, the request being made by her mother, Catherine Hinde, wife of a farmer of Highland Falls.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22.--The Reading Bondholders' Committee was formed to-day, and will hold the first formal meeting to-morrow.
Alexander Ashe, aged 24, a veterinary surgeon, has been missing from his home on South Ninth-street, between Second and Third streets, Brooklyn, since Thursday last.

The Elizabeth of Paolo Giacometti is very like the Elizabeth of history, but the play can scarcely be considered an inspiriting production. Done into English almost literally, it is just a little more oppressive than in the original Italian.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 22.--Judge E. F. Colo, who was committed to jail several months since for contempt in refusing to give information, as a witness, which he claimed was confided to him as counsel, has sued the responsible persons for $10,000.

The mausoleum in course of erection by the Empress Eugenie approaches completion. It is a stately building within the grounds of her estate at Farnborough, but not in the park itself, being on the other side of the main line of the Southwestern Railway, over which the Empress has constructed a bridge.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22.--President Porter announced in chapel this morning the names of the following men as winners of the Sophomore composition prizes:
CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--The facts in regard to an accident on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, near Bremen, Ind., are made known here tonight.
MORICHES,, Long Island, Dec. 22.--The steamer Oliveto, which went ashore here yesterday morning, remains high on the beach. She is still in fair condition and making no water.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22.--When the Chaplain made the opening prayer in the Senate today very few Senators were present, and it looked as if the fear that no quorum would appear would be realized, but more came in, and in a few minutes more than 40 Senators were in their seats.
Some of the stockholders of the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad are decidedly opposed to the latest scheme of reorganization proposed by the committee of second mortgage bondholders.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--T.L. Brooks, claiming to be a theatrical manager, has been arrested by the Central Station detectives.

LONDON, Dec. 22.--The parcel room at the Windsor Railway Station, in which the fire occurred last Saturday, adjoined the covered way over which the Queen passed on Wednesday when she started for Osborne.
In announcing his readiness and desire to be considered a candidate for the Senate Mr. EVARTS has had the good sense to be guided by the advice of THE TIMES.
CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 22, via Galveston --The national bank loan of $4,000,000 to the Government made last May has been renewed for another six months.

The two hundred and sixty-fourth anniversary of the landing of the Pilgrim Fathers was celebrated last night by the members of the Pilgrim Church of New-York, at Madisonavenue and One Hundred and Twenty-firststreet.
PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 22.--A party of white emigrants from Canada arrived here this morning, bound to North Carolina, being the third party passing here within a week. Others are to follow.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Dec. 22.--While a party of miners were at work improving the ventilation in the Barnum mine, near Pittston, this morning a miner rushed through one of the chambers with a naked lamp, igniting the gas, which caused a terrific explosion. Patrick Egan was instantly killed, and Andrew McMillan and Jefferson Yandel seriously burned and injured internally.

A remarkably interesting performance of "Aida" was given at the Academy of Music yesterday evening. Its attractiveness arose chiefly from the first appearance this season of Mme. Fursch-Madi, but the representation as a whole was spirited and effective, even Signor ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 22.--Justice C.A. Colley heard motions to-day in the Carrie Welton will case, in which Henry Bergh, representing the New-York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, is bequeathed a large sum.

BOSTON, Dec. 22.--The annual report of the Saving Bank Commissioners of the State shows the number of banks to be 168, the same as in 1883. all but one are in good condition, the exception being a bank that was temporarily enjoined and is now being wound up. The total deposits amount to $262,720,146; surplus, $5,247,371; aggregate amount of outstanding loans, $4,365,675; interest or profits received or earned, $13,575,047.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22.--In the Probate Court, this morning, a motion was made to probate the will of the late Wilbur F. Storey, editor and proprieter of the Times, which was dated Aug. 16, 1879. Clinton A. Snowden, of Washington, and E. Chamberlin, of Boston, two of the witnesses to the will, were in court.

The demand for seats at the annual dinner of the New-England Society was so great that the large banquet hall of Delmonico's was unable to accommodate those who had purchased tickets last night, and a small dining room had ...
The managers of the Great Western Railway have naturally been trying to make the British public believe that it has been shaken by a false alarm about the Windsor station fire.
Controller Loew yesterday opened the proposals received for the new issue of $1,650,000 8 per cent. bonds of the city of New-York.
A detective arraigned in the Tombs Police Court yesterday Louis Joekale, age 18; Edward Russell, age 25; Joseph Mincell, age 23, and George Kaerper, age 24.
ALBANY, Dec. 22.--Some things must be accepted as facts because they cannot be denied, among them the following with reference to the incoming Administration:

PETERSBURG, Dec. 22.--The Novoe Vremya, in an article discussing Russia's interests in Corea, urges the Government to seize the opportunity now offered by the rebellion in that land to raise the Russian flag and so supplant England or any other power competing for influence in that quarter, and at the same time obtain the ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 22.--The officials of the Window Glass Workers' Union report that, as far as can be learned, no glass works will be shut down on Jan. 1, as was talked of a month ago. Ihmsen Co., who decided to suspend, have reconsidered their determination, and will allow the condition of trade to decide the question.
